Content: PATNA: The coronavirus pandemic has forced many private and government schools in the city to promote the students of nursery to class VII without writing any examination.The final exams of nursery to class IX, which were being conducted by several schools, had to be suspended after the state government issued a directive for closure of all educational institutes till March 31.According to the officials at the regional office ( Bihar and Jharkhand ) of the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE), around two-third schools in the state have not completed the final exams. Hence, the students of nursery to class VII will be promoted.Officials of the Bihar Education Project Council claimed that promotions would be granted to the students based on their performance in the first and half-yearly exams as well as other classroom activities.Patliputra Sahodaya School Complex secretary C B Singh told this newspaper on Thursday that only those schools, which were selected as centres of classes X and XII boards, had already conducted the annual exams.“In Patna , there are 178 CBSE-affiliated schools, of which only 40 are made examination centres. The remaining schools generally conduct the annual exams, which have now been cancelled due to coronavirus, in the mid of March,” Singh said and added that the students of classes VIII, IX and XI would write the final exams after the schools reopen.Private Schools and Children Welfare Association president Shamael Ahmed urged the state government to allow schools to complete the ongoing final examinations. “The schools have been forced to promote even the weak students to the next class. This is not good for the deserving ones,” he rued.Meanwhile, some parents are worried and others have heaved a sigh of relief as their kids will be promoted without any exam.Sumit Priyadarshi, a resident of Phulwarisharif, whose son and daughter study in classes II and V, said, “My children will not get a report card, which could have helped us analyse their performance.”All schools affiliated to the Council for the Indian School Certificate Examinations (CISCE) have already completed their annual examinations. However, Board exams are going on in CBSE and CISCE schools amid precautionary measures.

Title: Nonagenarian offers to repay IFIN loan, seeks early release of mortgage
Content:
Chennai: Vallal RCK, a nonagenarian, has sought to repay his loans outstanding to IL&FS Financial Services and sought early release of the collateral. The beleaguered financial institution is yet to respond to his offer for settlement.

Vallal had availed of a Rs 175 crore loan from IFIN offering 17.5 acres of property at Koluthuvanchery in Alandur of Kancheepuram district as collateral. He drew only Rs 50 crore from this sanction.

In a letter to IL&FS Financial Services or IFIN, Vallal has offered a settlement along with interest. “In terms of my settlement and pending approval of my settlement proposal by IFIN to prove my bona-fide, I have remitted a sum of Rs 1.6 crore on August 21, 2019. Even after remittance, I have not received IFIN approval,” the 92 year old said in a second letter to IFIN’s authorised officer (a copy of the letter is with TOI).

He has also submitted a revised offer which envisages Rs 25 crore payment within 30 days of approval of settlement plan and the balance including interest at 14% within 90 days.

IFIN has clarified: “The assets of RCK Vallal are with Enforcement Directorate under investigation and attachment."

Title: Bihar: Unfazed Tejashwi Prasad Yadav says no need for coordination panel
Content:
Tejashwi Prasad Yadav

PATNA: RJD’s chief ministerial candidate Tejashwi Prasad Yadav on Wednesday denied that there was any lack of coordination among the grand alliance partners, hinting that there was no need for a coordination committee as demanded by the allies.

“They are talking about the need for a coordination committee, but there has always been coordination within the grand alliance. That’s why HAM (S) chief Jitan Ram Manjhi’s son was given a grand alliance MLC ticket,” Tejashwi said, adding, HAM(S) had also been given one assembly seat in the bye-election and three parliamentary seats last year.

Manjhi, RLSP chief Upendra Kushwaha and even Sharad Yadav had been stridently insisting on a coordination committee to sort out the differences within the grand alliance, which also includes Congress and VIP led by Mukesh Sahni.

Recently, the confusion among the opposition alliance partners got compounded on the eve of the filing of nomination papers for the five Rajya Sabha seats early this month. While the NDA was in a position to secure victory for its three candidates, the grand alliance could secure win only for two of its nominees.

Congress, Kushwaha and Sharad aspired to get the Rajya Sabha nomination from the grand alliance. However, RJD unilaterally fielded two nominees – Prem Chand Gupta and Amrendra Dhari Singh – for the two seats.

This blocked the other aspirants, which not only accentuated their internal differences, but has now also opened the way for their divergent paths that the smaller grand alliance partners like RLSP, HAM(S) and VIP, could easily take to, observers felt.

On Wednesday, Tejashwi, accompanied by RJD state president Jagdanand Singh, MLAs Bhola Yadav and Shakti Singh Yadav, among others, remained unmindful of the emerging fresh bout of differences among the grand alliance partners.

While Manjhi has shown that he could keep a window open to CM and JD(U) chief Nitish Kumar, Kushwaha has been trying to cement and strengthen ties with Congress high command and Sahni has been reportedly looking for a more stable nest outside the grand alliance to settle in. In between, having been denied the Rajya Sabha nomination, Sharad Yadav accused RJD of selling its ticket to a business tycoon (read A D Singh).

Suspending Yatra due to Covid-19 scare: Tejas

Leader of opposition Tejashwi Prasad Yadav said on Wednesday that his ‘Berojgari Hatao Yatra’ launched last month had been gaining large-scale support from the youth, but the ‘yatra’ has been postponed due to the Corona virus scare.

“In the four districts we have so far covered, we have received tremendous response from the youth,” he said, adding, his party has launched an information technology initiative to engage the state’s youths with the campaign.

Accordingly, he announced a mobile number — 9334302020 — where the youths can respond to an SMS message for registering their association with the party’s programme by furnishing their CV and other details. “Later, all this would be used to create a data base on the unemployed youths,” Tejashwi said.

He also put forward 18 questions to the CM on unemployment, jobs given by the government in the past 15 years, migration from the state among others.

“We think the state needs a domicile policy to secure jobs for the state’s youths,” Tejashwi said, adding, the issue was raised by the party’s MLA Bhola Yadav and others in the budget session of the assembly.

Title: Myanmar airline suspends Gaya operations
Content:
Representative image

GAYA: The Myanmar National Airlines on Wednesday suspended its operations on the Yangon- Gaya route. The airlines took the decision in view of the global outbreak of Covid-19 virus.

According to a letter issued by an airlines official, flights will remain cancelled from March 18 to April 20. Earlier on Tuesday, Thai Air Asia suspended operation of its flights on the Bangkok-Gaya route. Confirming the suspension of flights by Thai Air Asia and Mynamar National Airlines, Gaya airport director Dilip Kumar said, “Air India too will suspended operation of its flights on Yangon-Gaya route from March 23 onwards.”

The airport director made it clear that Air India will continue its operations in the domestic sector on the Gaya-Delhi route. “Indigo flights too, in the domestic sector will continue,” said Kumar.

Earlier, the Union health ministry on March 16 and 17 issued advisories to the airport authorities. As per the advisory issued on March 16, visitors from or transiting through UAE, Qatar, Oman and Kuwait have to be put under mandatory quarantine for a period of 14 days. This is applicable also to Indians working in these countries. A sizeable number of people from Bihar and Jharkhand disembark at the Gaya airport.

The advisory further stated that travel of passengers from Afghanistan, Philippines and Malaysia stands prohibited immediately. A couple of days back, two Bodh Gaya hotels have been notified for mandatory quarantine of people, who have recently been to seven countries including China, Italy, France, Germany and Spain.

According to Gaya district magistrate Abhishek Singh, Hotel Siddharth Vihar and Hotel Lumbini have been notified for the purpose of quarantining people, who have been to high risk countries. “Quarantine protocol would be maintained at these places. Besides the quarantine hotels, a properly equipped isolation ward too was in place,” the DM said.

Screening of domestic travellers too has been made mandatory at the airport. Proper tracking of people who may have come in contact with high risk passengers was being done with the help of the passenger data available with the railways too.

On Tuesday, Thai Smile Airways landed at Gaya airport with just two passengers. The airlines left with 128 passengers and all of them were foreign tourists or pilgrims.

Earlier on Monday, two international flights—Myanmar Airways International and Myanmar National Airlines—landed at the Gaya airport with no passenger. Air India Yangon-Gaya-Kolkatta had only one passenger. The Indigo Kolkata-Gaya-Kolkata flight had 17 passengers. Indigo Kolkata-Gaya-Varanasi flight landed with 29 passengers.

Title: Madurai: Cops warn auto drivers of action after complaints pour in against them
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: Ramanathapuram district police have warned autorickshaw drivers of stringent action after a series of complaints were received against them of causing inconveniences.

Thousands of tourists and devotees are visiting Rameswaram every day and there are more than a 1,000 auto rickshaws operating in that island. The complaints stated that very few of them are operating in Rameswaram with the required permits and the majority is registered in other parts of Ramanathapuram district but operating in the island without the required permissions.

According to the police, the auto rickshaw drivers at the Rameswaram railway station are not interested in picking up rides for local commuters and are keen on targeting tourists, who become soft targets as they are easily fleeced by the drivers. Police added that denial of rides to locals has often resulted in quarrels between locals and the auto rickshaw drivers.

Similarly, at the Rameswaram bus stand and in important pockets in the island, auto rickshaw drivers cause inconveniences to commuters waiting for buses, block their way and force them to get into auto rickshaws and fleece them. Overloading, speeding and rash and negligent driving that pose a threat to the safety of passengers are other allegations against the drivers of Rameswaram.

The police said that causing inconvenience to traffic by obstructing the ways and parking the vehicles in areas that are not earmarked as auto rickshaw stands are also allegations against the drivers, apart from not wearing uniforms and not carrying the required documents. Asking the drivers at the tourist destination to correct themselves, the police warned to impound the vehicles and handing it over to the court if they do not mend their ways.

Title: 23-year-old admitted to NCH isolation ward
Content: SURAT: A 23-year-old man was admitted to the isolation ward of New Civil Hospital (NCH) in the city on Wednesday after he complained of cough and fever.According to Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) officials, the man had a travel history to Nagpur in Maharashtra. He had gone to Nagpur on March 2 where he had come into close contact with a COVID-19 positive patient and later had returned to Surat on March 16. “He has been admitted to the isolation ward and his samples have been sent to Ahmedabad for COVID-19 test,” said an SMC official.“As of now, there are three patients admitted to the isolation ward at the NCH in Surat and their reports are being awaited. A total of 423 people have been home quarantined in the city,”' said SMC deputy municipal commissioner Dr Ashish Naik Meanwhile in Valsad district , home isolation of 28 individuals out of a total of 72 people ended on Wednesday as their 14 days observation period ended. At present, 50 people are home quarantined in Valsad district.In Navsari, 108 people remain home quarantined.Meanwhile, Western Railway has cancelled 32 trips of more than eight train services due to low occupancy arising out of COVID-19 scare.

Title: Police lock-up death: Kin refuse to accept body
Content:
Surat: Family members of Dipak Modi , 49 , refused to accept his body on Wednesday after post-mortem demanding police action against the cop who had arrested Modi.

The snack seller died in the lock-up of Varachha police station on Tuesday soon after he was arrested by police as part of preventive action. Police claimed that Modi suffered a fit and died.

Family and relatives of Modi gathered outside the post-mortem room at SMIMER hospital on Wednesday morning after the police got a penal PM done under video shooting on the body following the kin’s allegations of torture.

The deceased’s kin demanded strict legal actions against the cop who arrested him and also met the city police commissioner R B Brahmbhatt during the day to buttress their demands to book the cop.

Sources in the police informed that Modi was arrested twice in the past — in 2014 and 2018 — for attack and preventive actions for carrying stick. On Tuesday too, based on specific information that he was likely to get into criminal activity, Modi was detained from near his cart in which he sold khaman. However, police refused to give exact information on what type of information was available to them. Sources in police claimed that Modi was involved in gambling activity apart from selling khaman.

The inquiry into the incident has been handed over to C K Patel, assistant commissioner of police, A division. "During PM no injury marks were found on the body. As the kin did not accept the body, we have kept it in the morgue. Police will try to convince the family again on Thursday," said Patel.

On March 11, 30-year-old Vimal Yadav , a worker, died in lock-up of Pandesara police station in mysterious circumstances. Yadav's family alleged that police did not shift him to hospital despite multiple attempts to inform cops in police station about his breathing related illness. Inquiry in the death is continue by assistant commissioner of police F division.

Title: ID refers two to NRS as number of Covid-19 suspects exceeds beds
Content: KOLKATA: The Beliaghata ID Hospital was forced to transfer two cases to NRS Medical College and Hospital’s isolation ward on Wednesday after the patient count exceeded its accommodation limit of 24 beds.ID Hospital is the nodal hospital for Covid-19 tests in Bengal and all suspect cases screened at the airport. Till Tuesday, the patient count was 10. On Wednesday, 15 more were admitted. Later in the day, the patients were transferred to NRS. On Wednesday, seven patients who tested negative for Covid-19 were moved out of the hospital, freeing up space.Anticipating a surge in patient count, the Bengal government is opening another Covid-19 testing facility in Kolkata at the School of Tropical Medicine (STM). Other testing laboratories are being set up in north Bengal and Midnapore Medical College and Hospital. The state has also sought approval to set up testing facilities in Malda and Murshidabad medical colleges.Cops on Wednesday also put in place special security arrangements for Beliaghata ID Hospital, which includes a full-fledged police outpost. Sources said this was to ensure that no one left the isolation ward nor entered it without approval of the hospital administration. The cops are also mulling setting up an information counter with help from hospital authorities and health department officials. “We have stepped up security as required. An assessment has been carried out at the police headquarters,” said Subhankar Sinha Roy, Jt CP (headquarters).At present, two shifts have been introduced with an ACP and an inspector leading a 12-member team in each. The cops on duty have received instructions from the doctors on how to maintain their safety. “We are providing enough masks and hand sanitizers for these men. We have advised them to clean themselves after the end of duty,” said an officer. Sources claimed each police station has also been asked to prepare a team that can convince patients or those suspected of carrying the virus to stay in isolation at government facilities or at home.The health department, in a high-level meeting on Tuesday, advised all state hospitals to set up isolation wards and ICU facilities for Covid-19 patients far from the OPDs. “OPDs are congested places in a hospital and may enhance the disease spread when these hospitals admit Covid-19 patients,” a senior officer said.

Title: Patna: Malls shut, markets wear a deserted look
Content: PATNA: Markets wore a deserted look and malls in the city remained closed on Wednesday as per the government’s order under the new Bihar Epidemic Diseases, Covid-19 Regulation 2020 notified on Tuesday as a preventive measure against coronavirus in the state. Residents also avoided moving out as there has also been restriction on gatherings amid Covid-19 panic.Patna DM Kumar Ravi said notices had been sent to all the malls in the state capital to keep their shutters down till March 31. “It is little difficult to differentiate between malls and shopping complexes. But those places which have multiple shops along with entertainment facilities and a place to sit and hang out have been asked to remain closed,” said Ravi. He said those violating orders will be dealt with sternly.He further said only grocery stores inside malls were allowed to remain open with instruction for their staff to follow sanitizing protocol.A mall located in Pataliputra Colony was completely closed for its visitors on Wednesday, except its one section of a hypermarket inside it to sell groceries and other essential items.Security head of the mall, Asharam Singh, said, “More than 20,000 people used to come here daily and their numbers on weekends and during festive season used to be over 50,000. But we are not permitting anyone, except those who have to buy groceries and food items.” Visitors have to first get their temperature checked before they were allowed inside the mall after cleaning their hands with sanitizers, he said.Marketing head of a Fraser Road mall, Ankur Chopra, said its closure has even forced food court and other eateries on the premises to pull down their shutters. “Since mall is closed, no one will go and eat in the food court,” he said.Though Ankur said they will incur a heavy loss, he appreciated the preventive step taken by the state government. “It is better to shut down for two weeks than taking the risk of spreading this virus which will have even worst impact on the economy,” he said and complained that a few big stores were violating the order.Even those who had kept their shops opened rued bad business because of coronavirus fear. The owner of a bag and shoe shop on Boring Road, Mohamad Parwez, said, “If this continues, I will not be able to meet even the establishment cost.”Salim Hasan, who runs a beauty salon, said at least 50 people used to come for various services. “However, in the last two days, not more than ten people have come.” Kundan Kumar, who works at a food joint also shared a similar opinion. “We are famous for waffles and over 60 customers used to come to our place daily. Today, we did not have any customer till afternoon and only five of them had come yesterday,” said Kundan.

Title: ‘Bid process for Patna ring road likely in two months’
Content:
Nand Kishore Yadav

PATNA: The bidding process for selecting a firm for construction of Patna ring road is likely to be initiated in two months as the ministry of road, transport and highways (MoRTH) has approved the alignment finalized by the state government for the same.

State road construction minister Nand Kishore Yadav told TOI on Tuesday that a meeting to hold deliberations on the project was held in New Delhi in the last week. “The Centre has approved the alignment for Patna ring road and the detailed project report (DPR) for the same is getting finalized. We are expecting that the MoRTH will initiate the bidding process for the project following approval on the DPR in around two months,” he said.

The RCD minister said the project is a part of the special package for Bihar announced by PM Narendra Modi ahead of 2014 general elections. “Since the project is part of the PM package, it is being executed by the Centre. The state government was supposed to suggest the alignment, which we have done and it has been approved as well,” he said.

The minister said the Patna ring road alignment is Bihta-Naubatpur-Dumri-Beldari Chak-Kachhi Dargah- Bidupur bridge-Astipur- Dighwara-Sherpur-Bihta.

Several sections of the ring road are already part of other ongoing projects, including four-laning of Bihta-Sarmera road and the Kachchi Dargah-Bidupur bridge under construction.

The ring road will start near Bihta airbase and go to Naubatpur on NH-98. From Naubatpur, it will go to Dumri, passing through NH-83, which connects Patna to Gaya.

From Dumri, the ring road will go to Beldari Chak, from where it will connect to Kachhi Dargah-Bidupur bridge over the Ganga. From Kachchi Dargah-Bidupur bridge, the ring road will go to Sarai and then to Astipur in Saran district on SH-74.

From Astipur, the ring road will go to Naya Gaon and further to Dighwara and again cross the Ganga via proposed Dighwara-Sherpur bridge and back to Bihta.

“The 130km-long road is targeted to be constructed utilizing funds to the tune of Rs1500 crore,” Nand Kishore said.

Title: ‘Sanitize mosques after every prayer’
Content:
PATNA: Imarat-e-Shariah, the Muslims’ religious body in Bihar, Jharkhand and Odissa, has asked all the mosques to remove the prayer mats and sanitize the floor after every prayer service. The directive has been issued in view of the Covid-19 virus and to adhere to the social distancing advisory for containment of the virus, said Maulana Shibli Qasmi, the general secretary of Imarat-e-Shariah, on Wednesday.

Religious authorities are advising the devotees how to pray without taking the risk of virus infection. Instructions have been issued to all the imams (religious leaders) of masjids to remove the prayer mats and sanitize the floor after every prayer service, Qasmi said.

“People can also bring their own prayer mats. Disinfectant is being used in the washrooms where people do ‘wudu’ (ritual purification) before offering the prayer,” he said and added: “Besides, tissues are being provided to the faithful suffering from cold and flu. They are being separated from others as precaution against the virus.”

Maulana Anisur Rahman Qasmi, vice-president of All India Milli Council, another religious body, said devotees enter the mosques only after doing wudu, which purifies body because by cleansing its open parts.

“The advisory itself said that maintaining hygiene is the only way to combat the Covid-19. Almost in all the city masjids, the washrooms are before the main prayer halls. People first cleanse themselves and then enter the prayer hall,” he said.

Maulana Rizwan Ahmed Islahi, president of Jamat-e-Islami Hind, said if the devotees want to shorten the period of Friday prayer, they can directly offer prayer and can skip the ‘Khutbah’ (public preaching).

Meanwhile, Afzal Amanullah, chairman of RERA (Bihar), has appealed to the management and Imams of all mosques in the state to regulate the conduct of Friday prayers. “It is important that proper distance between people offering prayers be maintained and those suffering from cold and cough do not go to masjids,” he said.

Amanullah said there is a Hadees of Prophet (SAW) in which he had instructed the people during the time of heavy rain to offer prayers from home. “We should take a cue from Hadees and ensure that Friday prayers are duly regulated so that people are safe,” he said.

Title: Bihar: Two shot dead in Khagaria
Content:
Representative image

KHAGARIA: Two persons—Rajendra Yadav (65) alias Pagloo Yadav and his 35-year-old son Rinku Yadav were shot dead by some armed miscreants at Poorvi Thattha village under the Mansi police station area in Khagaria district on Tuesday night.

Keepng in view the tense situation, additional reinforcement was rushed to the village. Khagaria SP Meenu Kumari said raids are on to nab the criminals involved in the incident.

The spectre of gang war was looming large over the village after the killing of three people only last month.

The trouble started when a former mukhiya Brajnandan Yadav of Thattha village was reportedly shot dead by one Vinod Yadav and his accomplices on February 8 as Vinod was not happy with Brajnandan ever since the latter's daughter-in-law Bulbul Devi was elected mukhiya of Thattha panchayat.

Enraged over the killing of Brajnandan, his supporters attacked and killed Amod Yadav, elder brother of Vinod and one Satto Yadav, a close relative of Brajnandan, on the same night.

The village has virtually turned into a fortress following the killings. "We are apprehending more killings in the days to come,” said a local resident on the condition of anonymity, adding last night’s killing was a fallout of old rivalry. A large number of families have deserted the village in the wake of war of supremacy between two rival families of the same village.

Meanwhile, altogether 32 suspects have been arrested in this connection and remanded to custody, while Vinod is reportedly at large, police said.

Title: Trichy: Man, 20, brings wife, 16, for delivery, held
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: A case of child marriage and sexual assault of a minor girl surfaced after a 20-year-old man took a pregnant minor girl to government hospital for delivery here on Tuesday. The all-women police station team, Srirangam, arrested R Manivel, 20, of Thiruvanaikovil , on charges of forcing a minor girl into marriage and impregnating her.

Manivel landed in police net after he took the 16-year-old girl to Mahatma Gandhi memorial government hospital (MGMGH) for delivery.

On information, police rushed to the spot and enquired with Manivel and the girl. Preliminary enquiry revealed that Manivel and the girl were relationship before tying the knot in May 2019. Police booked him under sections of protection of children from sexual offences (Pocso) Act. tnn

Title: Squatters removed to ease elevated road construction
Content:
Jaipur: Jaipur Development Authority (JDA) on Wednesday shifted 209 houses from Fauji Basti, which was a major obstacle in construction of the Jhotwara elevated road . The owners were rehabilitated in Anand Lok Scheme, which is constructed under ‘Basic Services to Urban Poor’ on Sikar Road. A JDA official said, “There are total 291 houses in this slum out of which 209 were alloted houses after drawing a lottery. The remaning will be shifted soon. The houses were razed after issuing notices.”

The (JDA) recently also received a nod to relocate the affected house owners who have permenent structres to Niwaru Road. Of the 604 affected owners, nearly 300 will be rehabilitated to Niwaru Road. A senior JDA official said, “As the district administration has transferred the land to JDA for rehabilitatiion, the process will begin soon .” The construction on a 900-metre stretch of Jhotwara elevated road project has not been touched as the JDA has failed to initiate rehabilitation process till date. Sources said the work is moving at a snail’s pace as JDA is facing a challenge in distributing compensation among the affected house owners of the project proposed between Panchayat Bhawan and Ambabari crossroads.

The road with a length of 2.3km is proposed to ease traffic in one of the most congested areas of the city and provide relief to more than 6 lakh residents. However, the continuous delay is mounting the problem of the residents as they face long traffic jams daily.

An official source at JDA said, “The foundation stone to the project was laid on July 2 and deadline is set for December 2020. Looking at the progress of the project, it looks nearly impossible to meet the deadline. The project is expected to be delayed by a year.” Sources said delay in project is expected to escalate cost and more problems might crop up.

In the budget of 2016-2017, the BJP government had announced the construction of elevated road to give relief to commuters travelling in Phalna’s Jhotwara.

Title: Covid worries push people to telemedicine consulting
Content:
Chennai: Staying in a hostel in Delhi, 23-year-old Rishabh Singh caught a cold and fever.

“I was extremely worried. I then took an online consultation on DocsApp. The doctor checked with me about my symptoms, my whereabouts and later based on my symptoms assured me that I have common flu. He prescribed me some medicines and advised precautionary measures to stay safe,” Singh said.

With the increase in the number of COVID-19 infections in India, online doctor consultation apps such as DocsApp, mfine and iCliniq are seeing a doubling in the number of consultations. Anxious users, who are avoiding the risk of hospital infection, turn to telemedicine to ensure that they are free from the pandemic attack. Globally, platforms such as Amwell and Teladoc Health are seeing a spike since the last month and now, the early trends are seen in India as well.

“So far, we have witnessed over 10000 queries from all over the country. We have also witnessed twice the number of DocsApp Gold subscriptions as individuals reach out to consult for their near & dear ones too,” said Satish Kannan, co-founder, DocsApp. The company said it noticed a 178% increase in consultations for cough and cold indicating a sense of panic among people. Bengaluru-based mfine is seeing a 20%-25% increase in the consultations for coronavirus-related queries. Prasad Kompalli, CEO and co-founder, mfine said that the company has created a customised flow to assess corona infections and in the last week up to 2,500 have used it. “During the consultation, the tool collects basic information from users by guiding them through a set of questions to ascertain their state of health, the timeline of symptoms, age, and medical history, travel details and gauges severe cases through symptom mapping. It then lets a doctor consult with the patient over audio and video, instantly enabling doctors to see more patients without being exposed to the virus themselves,” he added. Same is the case with Coimbatore-based iCliniq which is also witnessing a 20% rise in consultations from Delhi, Mumbai, Bengaluru and Hyderabad. “It is a black swan moment for us; this situation is helping the telemedicine industry. While we are not promoting ourselves in any way, we are trying to help customers who are in panic,” said Dhruv Suyamprakash, founder, iCliniq. To increase their reach, the telemedicine companies are either putting out advisories for their customers or partnering with communities to spread the word. DocsApp has extended its medical assistance to MyGate, Zee Digital, Seniority & will be working with more partners to spread awareness. iCliniq has put out a booklet explaining symptoms of flu and corona in detail to help allay the fears. “Summer is also a time when we see a rise in the number of flu infections,” added Suyamprakash.

Title: This year, teachers can check ICSE, ISC scripts at home
Content:
Kolkata: The Covid-19 crisis has forced the Council for the Indian School Certificate Examinations to modify the process to evaluate ICSE and ISC answer scripts.

Till now, teachers were assigned to the specific evaluation centre for correction of individual subjects in both ICSE and ISC. All the examiners would sit together and correct answer scripts over a scheduled period of time. “At the end of the evaluation, scores for each student were uploaded through tabs provided by the Council. The entry would immediately be registered on the CISCE server,” said Ram Mohan Mission School principal Sujoy Biswas. But this year, the assessment system will be decentralized as the examiners have now been permitted to check answer scripts at their respective residence.

“The Council has decided to review the policy of centralized evaluation keeping in mind the health and safety of all our examiners, which is of utmost priority,” said CISCE chief executive and secretary Gerry Arathoon.

“On the first day, the chief examiner or co-chief examiner or examiner coordinator of an evaluation centre will meet all the examiners for a short time to discuss the finalized marking scheme, evaluate dummy scripts, give necessary instructions and hand over the answer scripts. It is the responsibility of each examiner concerned to transport the answer scripts safely to their residence,” instructed Arathoon to the evaluators.

“If any examiner is absent, the answer scripts should be reapportioned on the first day itself and a record should be kept,” the CISCE wrote to the schools on Wednesday. The examiners will have to upload the marks on the Live Ink Character Recognition tabs at the evaluation centre as per the schedule drawn up and on the last day, each examiner will have to hand over respective marked answer scripts to the chief examiner.

Similar instructions have been issued by the Council for ISC. However, the decision of a revised evaluation procedure are for chemistry (Paper 1), fashion designing (Paper 1), history, biotechnology (Paper 1), commerce, mathematics, mass media & communication, physical education (Paper 1), computer science (Paper 1), electricity & electronics, geometrical mechanical drawing, geometrical & building drawing, sociology, biology (Paper 1), geography (Paper 1), business studies, home science (Paper 1), elective English, psychology and art (papers 1 to 5).

Title: Illegal flying of drone: T HC grants bail to Revanth
Content:
Hyderabad: Justice K Lakshman of the Telangana high court on Wednesday granted bail to Congress MP A Revanth Reddy , who was held by Cyberabad police for illegally flying a drone.

The judge agreed with the contentions of Revanth’s counsel, who argued that all the sections slapped against the MP were bailable and the MP is under an obligation to attend the ongoing session of Parliament.

Public prosecutor C Pratap Reddy, while saying that he has no objection to the bail, found fault with the conduct of the MP in resorting to the unauthorised use of a drone over a private building, apparently belonging to the state’s IT minister KT Rama Rao.

He also said that since bail was now granted, Revanth’s plea for declaring his judicial remand as illegal would become infructuous. The judge agreed with the view. The MP had, in fact, filed another plea urging the court to quash the FIR too. The judge sought counters from the police in four weeks.

The case against Revanth and other accused is that on March 1, they were found at Miyakhangadda. The police noticed that they were using a drone over a building allegedly belonging to the state IT minister. Using drones without permission from a competent authority is an offence..

Revanth was arrested after he went to the police station and argued with the officials over the case booked against him.

The judge directed the trial court to grant bail to the MP on his furnishing of two sureties and a personal bond for Rs 10,000. Revanth was also directed to cooperate with the investigation and was asked not to interfere in the process of investigation.

Title: Asymptomatic patients, super-spreaders the biggest transmission threats, say experts
Content:
Kolkata: Confirming the worst fears of doctors and experts, the first Covid-19 patient in Kolkata arrived without symptoms and remained so for the next 48 hours, during which he is suspected to have come in contact with several people. Asymptomatic patients, along with ‘super-spreaders’, are perceived to be the biggest transmission threats of this outbreak, according to experts. Even though opinion is divided, symptomless carriers are believed to be more infectious than those whose symptoms are evident.

The nCoV is believed to have an incubation period of two days and 14 days. The mean period for showing symptoms has been found to be four-five days.

“This means that every infected person is likely to be symptomless for five days, during which s/he can spread the virus. More than half the transmission has been done by symptomless individuals,” said Belle Vue Clinic internal medicine consultant Rahul Jain.

Incubation period is an extremely dangerous phase so far as transmission of any virus is concerned, said Sekhar Chakraborty, former director, ICMR-NICED. “Since the viral load in the infected is very high during this period, some symptoms will show up. But if they are mild, the infected person might not even feel sick,” he said.

Others, like RN Tagore International Institute of Cardiac Sciences consultant Arindam Biswas, however, differed. “Viruses proliferate to millions inside the cell. In this case, it has been riding mucus droplets to spread. But the viral load is difficult to assess during incubation or even at a later stage,” he said.

Super-spreaders, or those who transmit the virus to a large number of people, were also a threat, said Jain. “Most of them are asymptomatic. But they need to be checked to prevent rampant transmission,” said Jain.

Paediatric intensivist Prabhash Prasun Giri said that severity of symptoms for Covid-19 will differ from person to person depending on factors like age, co-morbid conditions and immunity. “A young patient with no underlying problem might have very mild to no symptom. But the symptoms in an aged person with other co-morbid conditions could be severe. The virus is also unlikely to cause much health issues to the boy who tested positive,” said Giri, PICU in-charge at Institute of Child Health

“Anyone who has had any contact with an infected person or has travelled to an affected region can become silent carrier even if they have no symptoms. All of them might not need to get their swabs tested but they need to be quarantined,” said microbiologist Bhaskar Narayan Chaudhuri of Peerless Hospital.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Educational institutions in Patna switch to online classes
Content: PATNA: With the sudden closure of higher educational institutes because of the threat of coronavirus , colleges and universities in the state have decided to conduct online classes now.Development Management Institute (DMI), Amity University, Central University of South Bihar (CUSB), Birla Institute of Technology-Patna, St Xavier’s College (SXC), St Xavier’s College of Education (SXCE), and St Xavier’s College of Management and Technology (SXCMT) will hold online classes for their students so that the syllabi can be completed before the final examination. They will help students utilize their free time at home in a constructive way and engage them in academic activities.DMI dean and professor Niraj Kumar told this newspaper on Wednesday that online classes would be conducted for the students of postgraduate diploma in management. “The teachers will provide notes, podcasts and video links to the students to ensure continuity in the teaching-learning process. We have prepared a schedule, which is being sent to everyone.”Amity University (AU) has suspended all academic activities till March 31. Its pro-vice-chancellor (VC) Vivekanand Pandey said, “We have planned to start online classes to make sure that studies do not get interrupted. Amity’s Amizone software will be used for the purpose.”Talking about the interactive software, AU VC T R Venkatesh pointed out that it allowed the students to connect with their teachers, ask questions and clarify their doubts.SXCE faculty member Deep Kumar has downloaded the ‘Zoom’ app to conduct the classes of BEd and MEd students. “The syllabi of these courses will be completed in the next 15 days,” he claimed.CUSB registrar Col R K Singh said, “Virtual classes will be held so that the syllabi are completed before the exams of the current semester begin. The total number of working days should be 90.”Meanwhile, all the institutes are adopting strict measures like sanitization of their campuses. Visitors are being thoroughly checked through infrared thermal scanners every day.

Title: Complaint case filed against Harsh Vardhan in Bihar
Content: PATNA: A complaint case was filed against Union health minister Harsh Vardhan before the court of chief judicial magistrate in Muzaffarpur on Wednesday alleging that he had failed to stop black marketeering of masks and sanitizers to protect people from coronavirus in the country.Complainant Tamanna Hashmi has submitted that he came to know through TV channels on Tuesday about the scarcity of masks and sanitizers in the country. Hashmi alleged in his petition that government failed to make these things available to common people, who need these items to tackle the problem of coronavirus.Hashmi, who claims to be a social activist, told TOI over phone that the court has fixed March 30 as the next date of hearing on the petition. “Central government should have made these things available at the primary health centre level across the country,” he added.He also alleged that both the items were being sold on the black market at ten times more than the actual market prices. A copy of the petition is with TOI.The case has been filed under Sections 406 (punishment for criminal breach of trust), 506 (punishment for criminal intimidation), 420 (cheating) and 120B (criminal conspiracy) of IPC.This is the second coronavirus-related case filed before a court in Muzaffarpur.Earlier on Monday, advocate Sudhir Kumar Ojha had filed a complaint case against Chinese President Xi Jinping and India ambassador Sun Weidong alleging that coronavirus was spread as a conspiracy to become superpower in the world. This case would come up for hearing on March 24.

Title: Covid-19: Kochi authorities look to boost health infrastructure
Content: KOCHI: As the number of people arriving in Kochi from foreign countries increases, district authorities are looking at enhancing health infrastructure. As of now, there are isolation facilities at Government Medical College, Ernakulam and district hospital, Muvattupuzha. The combined bed strength at isolation wards at these hospitals is 80.Union health ministry has given instructions to arrange facilities near Cochin International Airport Ltd (Cial) for quarantining 3,000 persons. “Anticipating the need for quarantining or isolating more people, we have already identified 900 beds at various hospitals in the district. We are in search of more facilities,” said district collector S Suhas.Now, the authorities are planning to set up isolation facilities at Tripunithura taluk hospital, Karuvelippady taluk hospital, Government Ayurveda Medical College , Tripunithura and State Institute of Medical Education and Technology, Tripunithura. The authorities are also planning to start isolation facilities at all the taluk hospitals in the district. “We are searching for centres which can be used as isolation wards or quarantine facilities at Aluva and Kochi,” an official with health department said. Navy have arranged isolation facilities on their own.Number of ambulances required for transporting suspected cases or persons diagnosed with Covid-19 also will have to be increased. “As of now, we have provided 75 ambulances for shifting persons to the medical college and their homes. We will be arranging more ambulances if need arises,” Suhas said. “More volunteers will be required for taking up various tasks, including awareness campaigns. We have already identified some,” he said. More police personnel also will be required to support the medical team.The district administration has given instructions to private hospitals to arrange facilities for isolation in case any patient being treated there are tested positive for Covid-19.If a person who is under treatment in a private hospital is diagnosed with the disease and the private hospital doesn’t have the facilities to set up isolation wards, health department will take over the treatment of that person. In case any foreign national or persons returning after foreign trip seeks consultation at private hospitals with symptoms of fever, such cases should be informed to corona control room at Kakkanad . Such persons should be shifted to a government hospital suggested by the health department. The department will provide vehicles for transporting such patients to government hospitals.Representatives of 92 private hospitals in the district attended the videoconference conducted by assistant collector M S Madhavikkutty on Wednesday. WHO consultant Dr P S Ragesh, deputy DMO Dr K Savitha, NHM district manager Dr Mathews Nambeli and Dr Nikhilesh answered the queries by employees of different hospitals.

Title: Don’t panic and sell your MFs in a hurry
Content: MUMBAI: Long-term investors should not panic and redeem their investments in a hurry in the current market, as that would convert their notional losses into actual ones. That’s the message most financial advisers have for investors. They also point out that investors who had put their money through systematic investment plans (SIPs) over several years are better off compared to the ones who had invested lump sum amounts.According to Etica Wealth Management managing director & CEO Gajendra Kothari, investors should not panic and redeem their portfolio, fully or partially, just because the market is going down at an extremely fast clip. “If you are a long-term mutual fund investor , remember: Your money is in expert hands. Don’t redeem and convert your notional losses into real losses,” he said.It’s also important to be aware of one’s risk-taking ability and stick to the already set asset-allocation plan and not to tweak it just because a large number of good stocks are looking attractive, financial planners said. A conservative investor suddenly shouldn’t invest like one who has a higher risk appetite and vice versa, they further added.Investors should also remember that SIPs in MFs give better stability to one’s investments in the long run than putting money through the lump sum route. According to Mukund Seshadri, co-founder of the financial planning outfit MS Ventures, investing through the SIP route means “it’s taking the human behaviour relating to investing out of the whole process”. Often investors invest out of an impulse or based on tips, but SIPs ensure such factors are ignored, and hence they provide stability to the investing process.Outside of the SIP route, if one has some extra money to invest, then that should be done through a staggered route rather than putting it all in one go. “Suppose you have Rs 100 to invest. Put that in five or seven tranches,” said Kothari. “No one can catch the market’s bottom. Don’t be greedy trying to catch the market’s bottom. It’s better to space your investments over some time.”The last but vital advice is that long-term investors should not look at their returns on a regular basis, more so during times of extreme market volatility, like the current phase. Such behaviour could lead to anxiety or even panic among investors. If investments are for the long term and with some goals in mind, one should look at their returns as the timeline for achieving goals nears, financial planners said.

Title: Bihar: Third front possibility emerges
Content:
PATNA: HAM(S) president and former CM Jitan Ram Manjhi on Wednesday hinted at the formation of a third front in Bihar to contest the upcoming assembly election due in the state later this year.

Though his meeting with chief minister Nitish Kumar on Tuesday fuelled speculations about fresh political alignments, Manjhi denied going back to the JD(U) fold and said he would explore the possibility of forming a “brihad mahagathbandhan” with Upendra Kushwaha’s RLSP, VIP led by Mukesh Sahani, JAP(L) led by former RJD MP Pappu Yadav, Mayawati’s BSP, AIMIM and more importantly CPI’s Kanhaiya Kumar, whom he described as a leader who works in the interest of the downtrodden in Bihar.

Manjhi’s statement assumes significance in the backdrop of his meeting with poll strategist and former JD(U) national vice-president Prashant Kishor, along with Kushwaha and Sahani in Delhi recently. Prashant is searching for a new face and also exploring options to settle political scores with Nitish, who expelled him after his frontal attack on JD(U) for its stand on CAA, NPR and NRC.

There is a strong possibility of a ‘third front’ in Bihar in the backdrop of RJD’s approach to its allies, particularly Manjhi and Congress. Party insiders say RJD does not take any notice of Manjhi’s statements citing his party’s poor performance in the Lok Sabha and assembly elections, which proved little clout Manjhi has among Dalits and Mahadalits.

Though a section of Congress is unhappy over denial of a Rajya Sabha seat, sources said the party is too weak at the grassroots level to part ways with RJD, unless it is made to “suffer a bigger humiliation” in the days ahead. “But Kanhaiya’s face can force the central leadership to think over it,” a Congress senior said.

RJD sources said the party will not contest than 150 seats in the 243-member assembly. Tejashwi took a personal dig at Manjhi on Wednesday saying it was his party, which made his son Santosh an MLC.

Though Kushwaha told TOI on Wednesday that he was with the mahagahtbandhan and will remain there to defeat NDA, RLSP sources said the party was weighing options and may go with Manjhi if it does not get a respectable number of seats.

CPI state secretary Satya Narain Singh told TOI that his party favours the formation of a “democratic secular front” with CPI-M, Pappu, Dadan Pehelwan, RLSP, VIP and Congress, provided it makes its stand clear.

“We had talks with Manjhi, Kushwaha and Pappu but things are still to take shape. We will also discuss the poll possibility at our two-day executive and council meeting to be held March 24,” Singh said, adding, Kanhaiya also wanted a non-BJP, non-RJD front in the state. However, Singh is not sure about CPI(ML) joining them for their obvious inclination towards RJD, which had left the Ara seat for the party to contest in the last Lok Sabha polls.

“There is need for a big alternative given the present political situation as democracy is in danger. CPI is welcome as it talks about Bihari interest. We will discuss the political scenario in our national executive committee meeting on Thursday,” Pappu said.

Qamrul Hoda, who opened the AIMIM account in Bihar assembly by winning the byelection from Kishanganj recently, said his party was not averse to a bigger alliance. “Our party leadership will decide as we are preparing on all 243 assembly seats. In fact, we had invited Manjhi to our Kishanganj rally to which he agreed, but backed out later. We will focus on Seemanchal, but joining any alliance will depend upon the partners’ clear stand on certain issues,” he said over phone.

Title: Hand sanitizers back in shelves, but 3 times costlier
Content:
SURAT: For over ten days , they had flown off the shelves in stores across the city. Now, even as the handy portable sanitizers have returned to the market, they are being sold at almost three times their original price.

Hand sanitizers have become popular as they reportedly kill the 2019 novel coronavirus disease (COVID)-19. After initial rush when they had gone out of stock, the sanitizers have returned to the stores.

Earlier, 100 ml portable gel-based hand sanitizers of leading brands were available at Rs 60 in chemist stores. Now, they have been replaced by locally manufactured sanitizers which are being sold at over Rs 180!

Local manufacturers have recently received license to manufacture this instant liquid cleansing material. But the price at which they are sold have left many surprised.

Most of these sanitizers are being sold under different brand names, a majority of which were so far unheard of.

Chemists themselves have no explanation on why such nondescript sanitizers are being sold at such high prices.

“We are just collecting the price that has been printed on the bottle. We are receiving limited supply. If we get 20 bottles in the morning, none is left in the evening,” said an employee of a chemist store at Parle Point.

As many as 20 different nondescript brands of sanitizers that are manufactured in the city and peripheral areas have hit the stores.

"Many manufacturers were issued fresh licenses to deal with the current situation and they have already started selling their products in the local market. So far, we have not received any complaint related to quality of these products," said an official in Food and Drug Control Administration (FDCA) in the city.

"Those manufacturers who are supplying hand sanitizers to hospitals and medical professionals have not increased their price. There is minor price hike due to rise in cost of raw material. The hand sanitizers falling in cosmetic category are sold to retail buyers and they could be selling them at a higher price,” said Ravi Patel , manufacturer of hand sanitizers.

According to FDCA officials there is no price cap on hand sanitizers but there are restrictions about its hoarding or overcharging.

“There is no price cap on maximum price of hand sanitizers. Our priority is to ensure that the product is available easily in the market," said H G Koshia, commissioner, FDCA, Gujarat.

Title: Gold foil worth Rs 20 lakh seized at Surat airport
Content:
Ganesh Valodara tried to slip away with his check-in luggage

SURAT: An innovative mule was caught trying to smuggle in gold at the Surat international airport late on Tuesday night. Scanning revealed the passenger flying in with a suitcase, the cover of which was laced with thin foil strips of about 500 grams of the yellow metal which carried a market value of Rs20 lakh.

The customs people sniffed a rat when the passenger, identified as Ganesh Valodara, who disembarked from the Air India Express flight from Sharjah to Surat, attempted to slip away with his check-in luggage.

Sources with the Air Intelligence Unit (AIR) of Surat customs said its sleuths intercepted Valodara after finding his movements suspicious and scanned his luggage. During the scanning exercise, the bag revealed some unusual images, leading the officials to physically inspect the contents which exposed the gold foil strips hidden in the false compartment of the bag.

It was ascertained that the gold was beaten into foils, cut into small pieces and hidden in the bag.

Sources said that the accused was questioned on the source and destination of the gold foil, but he failed to give satisfactory answers. The accused revealed that he had taken the smuggling job after he was offered good amount of money by the person who had asked him to bring the illegal consignment to Surat.

It must be noted that the Union health ministry has issued orders for compulsory quarantine of the passengers arriving from UAE and other countries at the airports from March 18, this smuggler tried to get away with the smuggled gold at the Surat airport .

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Diamond workers’ body demands one month paid vacation in Surat
Content: SURAT: The Gujarat Diamond Workers’ Union (GDWU) has demanded one month paid vacation for the diamond workers employed in the diamond centres in Surat in particular and Gujarat in general following the coronavirus outbreak.In a memorandum submitted to the district collector, GDWU office-bearers stated that the diamond workers are vulnerable to the virus as the diamond units, especially the small and medium units, are not taking any sort of health and safety measures to protect the workers. Like the schools and colleges, the government should declare paid vacation for the workers in the diamond industry as well.President of GDWU, Ranmal Jilariya told TOI, “At least four diamond workers sit on the diamond emery wheel to cut and polish the diamonds at the distance of two feet. Majority of the small and medium units are yet to take health safety measures like keeping the sanitisers and providing them with masks.”Jilariya added, “The industry will have to face serious consequence if the coronavirus disease would enter the diamond markets. Already, the workers are underpaid as the diamond units have reduced work. However, it is in the benefit of the government and the industry to announce paid vacation for the workers in the industry.”

Title: Bihar: Build more bus stops, says transport secretary
Content:
PATNA: Transport secretary Sanjay Kumar Agarwal on Wednesday issued an order for construction of more bus stops between Gandhi Maidan and Saguna Mor by March 31. He also asked the officials concerned to remove encroachments from the existing bus stops.

At a meeting conducted to review the condition of bus stops in the city, Agarwal, who is also Patna’s divisional commissioner, said more bus stops were required in the city. “Bihar State Road Transport Corporation (BSRTC) has been asked to identify places for the construction of new bus stops,” Agarwal said.

The meeting was attended by senior officers, including Patna district magistrate Kumar Ravi, SSP Upendra Kumar Sharma and traffic SP among others.

He said sufficient lights and cleanliness will be ensured at the bus stops.

Agarwal said the bus queue shelters were constructed at many places in the past but many of them were removed due to road widening work. “Those bus queue shelters will be installed again and maintained by Bihar Urban Infrastructure Development Corporation (BUIDCo),” he said.

The divisional commissioner also issued instructions to traffic DSP to remove encroachments from the existing bus stops by March 31. “Many bus stops have been encroached by putting carts and kiosks of fruits and fast food items. All such encroachments will be removed to ensure that buses stop at the designated stands only,” Agarwal said.

Title: ‘Open to fight a direct election, if party wants’
Content:
PATNA: When RJD announced businessman Amarendra Dhari Singh ’s name for Rajya Rabha, it had caused a stir in political circles. In an interview to TOI’s Sheezan Nezami, Singh talks about his shift from business to politics and why he opted for RJD. An excerpt:

You are a businessman. All of a sudden your name cropped up for RJD’s Rajya Sabha candidate. People want to know about you, your family background and business?

I belong to Ainkhan village near Dulhin Bazar in Patna and completed schooling at St Michael’s, followed by graduation from Delhi University. I am a businessmen but ours is a political family. My maternal aunt Pratibha Singh was four-time Rajya Sabha member. Before 1997, there were at least four MPs from my family in the Lok Sabha.

From business to politics, what made you make the switch?

I have been associated with Lalu Yadav Ji for many years and he convinced me to accept the Rajya Sabha nomination. In fact, many politicians in Bihar , including CM Nitish Kumar, know me personally.

Are you also a primary member of RJD?

Of course I am a primary member of the party and joined it long back.

Why did you choose RJD?

Tejashwi Yadav Ji has a new vision for the development of Bihar and in my interactions with him, I got the impression that this young leader should be given a chance to lead Bihar. During my frequent discussions with him, I found that he wants to take along all sections, be it any caste, class or religion ahead. That’s the reason for my joining RJD.

Why did you choose to become a Rajya Sabha member? Why not fight a direct election?

If I am alive and my party wants then I will definitely fight a Lok Sabha election, even leaving my RS term mid-way.

When it comes to Bihar politics, we cannot wish away the caste factor. You are a Bhumiar. Do you think RJD picked you to woo Bhumiars, who otherwise are said to be BJP voters?

I do not agree that RJD picked me to woo any caste. Tejashwi Yadav’s vision is development of all castes and classes. When real development takes place and people are happy, caste will get sidelined. Since development has not taken place in Bihar, people are still thinking on caste and religious lines.

Will your presence in RJD have an impact on Bhumiar vote bank?

If JD (U) and BJP are unhappy with my nomination to Rajya Sabha, this means they are apprehensive that my caste (Bhumiar) people will not vote for NDA.

Now that you are in politics, what are your priorities?

My priority will be anything to do with development. I feel very unhappy with the plight of Biharis.

Since you have business background, have you planned anything for this sector?

Let me share my experience. Ten years ago, I wanted to do some major development work in Bihar. But there was no co-operation from the CM and the bureaucracy and we lost a lot of money. The laughable part is whenever I sought appointment with the CM, I was given a date two to three months later. I cannot elaborate as the matter is sub-judice. Everyone knows big industrialists do not want to invest here. Current leadership has to welcome them with folded hands, but they want businessmen to fall at their feet.

As far as our agenda for setting up industries is concerned, initially we would focus on agriculture. Bihar produces maize, but then its processed in Andhra Pradesh and Madhya Pradesh, same happens with other agro products. Sugar mills are lying defunct.

What are your future plans?

That will be as per my party’s decision.

Title: Covid-19 in Odisha: Evacuation of tourists starts from Puri, ban on hotel bookings
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

BHUBANESWAR: To keep Covid-19 outbreak at bay, the Puri district administration on Wednesday imposed a ban on bookings in hotels in the beach town and started evacuation of tourists.

“We have issued an advisory to hotels and other tourist accommodation centres asking them not to accept any booking till further orders (for indefinite period). Hoteliers have also been asked to cancel all bookings of rooms, conferences, banquets and wedding parties with immediate effect for an indefinite period,” Puri district collector Balwant Singh told TOI.

Singh said the administration on Tuesday appealed to tourists to vacate their hotels and leave Puri within two days. “I understand that the hoteliers have already started facilitating the evacuation of tourists. Hoteliers have been strictly asked not to harass any tourist. They should politely convince the guests about the crisis situation and state government’s precautionary measures against Covid-19,” Singh said.

The Hotel Association of Puri (HAP) said only around 8,000 tourists, including around 20 foreigners, are currently present in different hotels in Puri. On a normal day in March, the presence of tourists in Puri would be at least 30,000. “We now have only 10% or 12% occupancy in almost all hotels. Puri has over 400 small and big hotels. We have been requesting the tourists to leave Puri. In the next one or two days, all hotels will be vacant. We are facilitating purchase of train and flight tickets for those tourists, who find it difficult to return home,” HAP secretary Raj Kishore Patra said.

Tourists said they were extending support to the administration. “We had arrived in Puri 10 days back when there was no fear of corona outbreak. The Odisha government started restrictions three or four days ago. We were planning to extend our stay for one more week, but we cancelled it for our own safety,” said Chandrakant Sharma, a tourist from Bhopal.

A joint team of Puri district and police officials has been patrolling at Pipili toll gate on Bhubaneswar-Puri National Highway-316 to restrict the entry of tourists, who are coming in vehicles bearing registration numbers of other states, to Puri. Over 15,000 tourists were denied entry to Puri in the last three days, sources said.

On Monday, the district administration imposed prohibitory orders under Section 144 of CrPC on the beaches in Puri and Konark. Restrictions have already been imposed on movement of tourists at different destinations, including Jagannath temple, where devotees are being compulsorily asked to wear mask before entering the shrine. However, the Jagannath temple administration has withdrawn its earlier plan of securing self-declaration from devotees on their health conditions.

Title: Coronavirus casts shadow on Puri Rath Yatra
Content: BHUBANESWAR: The state government’s six-month plan of action to contain coronavirus is likely to take the sheen off the 10-day Puri Rath Yatra, which is scheduled to begin on June 23 .Amid global concerns about the novel coronavirus and restrictions on almost every sphere of activity, especially outdoor events and public gatherings, the temple servitors and travel professionals apprehend that the state’s famed festival may be a low-key affair this time.“We pray to Lord Jagannath to put an end to the corona crisis. Since the state government is tying to sensitise people to Covid-19 for at least six months, there is an uncertainty that the ensuing Rath Yatra would be as grand as it has been in the previous years,” temple’s senior servitor Ramakrushna Dasmohapatra said.More than six lakh devotees from the country and abroad visit Puri during Rath Yatra every year. Most of them plan their tours well in advance. The construction of chariots is scheduled to start on the occasion of Akshaya Tritiya on April 26. “It will be difficult to organise the crowded festival if the situation continues to remain grim. My guests in Kolkata have already started inquiring about the fate of Rath Yatra,” Shyama Mahapatra, another servitor, said.The temple and district officials are keeping their fingers crossed. “Every year, preparations for the grand festival usually start two months in advance. With Puri in a near lockdown state, officials are uncertain about the Rath Yatra’s massive preparations. We will act according to the situation. At present, our priority is to check the possible spread of the deadly virus,” Puri district collector and the temple’s deputy chief administrator Balwant Singh said.Hoteliers said they usually receive bookings from tourists at least two months before the Rath Yatra. “By this time, we would have started receiving queries about the availability of rooms in hotels. But we have been asked by the district administration to not entertain any bookings for an indefinite period,” Debasis Kumar, owner of Hotel Victoria Club, said.Last year, the district administration had pulled out all stops in the aftermath of Cyclone Fani that devastated Puri in May and successfully conducted the Rath Yatra on July 4.

Title: Covid-19 in Bihar: ‘Urgent cases’ to be heard in Nawada and Motihari courts
Content:
Representative image

NAWADA/ MOTIHARI: Adhering to the recent directives of the Patna high court to prevent spread of Covid-19 virus, several civil courts across the state, including those in Nawada and East Champaran districts have decided to hear only urgent matters and restrict entry of non-essential people on their premises.

Nawada civil court judges and judicial magistrates went around the court premises on Wednesday morning and interacted with the advocates on precautionary measures to be adopted for containment of the deadly virus.

The district judge, chief judicial magistrate, accompanied by a number of judicial magistrates as well as the District Legal Services Authority (DLSA) secretary-cum-ACJM, toured the court premises to take stock of the situation with the viewpoint of hygiene and social distancing.

Sources said it has been decided that only matters related to emergency cases, bail hearing, injunctions and HC bail orders would be taken up in the truncated court hours (7 to 11am). Common people, other than those involved in urgent cases, would be barred from entering the court premises. The advocates welcomed the move and lauded the preventive steps.

Similarly, East Champaran civil court has also changed its office hour from 6 am to 10 am from Wednesday and all shops on its premises have been closed.

District and sessions judge Krishna Shankar Singh Sengar called a meeting of lawyers and all judicial officers to discuss measures to prevent the spread of Covid-19 virus. Henceforth only urgent matters would be put up in the court for hearing.

Title: Bihar: Rs 8 lakh looted from bank in Vaishali
Content:
Representative Image

PATNA: Unidentified armed criminals looted more than Rs8 lakh from a Uttar Bihar Grameen Bank branch at Ghataro village under Kartaha police station in Vaishali district on Wednesday. Hardly 24 hours back, another bank was looted in neighbouring Muzaffarpur district on Tuesday.

Police said at least four criminals had reached the bank on two separate bikes and fled after looting the amount. Sadar SDPO Raghav Dayal said eyewitnesses told the police that two criminals with pistols in their hands had entered the branch. “They forced the bank employees to hand over the cash from counter. They also threatened them to open the iron chest inside for more cash,” he said.

Dayal said some people standing near the branch told the police that four criminals had reached there on two separate bikes. “One of them remained seated while another stood guard at the main entrance while the remaining two looted the cash,” he said.

The SDPO said neither they fired nor damaged the digital video recorder of the CCTV cameras installed inside the bank.

Kartaha police station SHO Santosh Kumar Pankaj said the criminals entered the branch around 2.50pm and left in 12 minutes. Pankaj said hardly few hours before the loot, Rs5 lakh was deposited by a nearby petrol pump employees in the branch.

“There were two women employees and a chowkidar inside the branch along with few women customers when the loot took place. Criminals collected cellphones of everyone present there and dumped them in a washbasin before fleeing towards Lalganj,” he said, adding their movements were captured in the CCTV cameras inside the branch.

Pankaj said one of the criminals was wearing a helmet while another had covered his face with a piece of cloth. One had his face open. “The gang might be the same which had looted Rs2.53 lakh from State Bank of India’s Lalu Chapra branch at Paru in Muzaffarpur on Tuesday,” he said.

Paro police station SHO Faisal Ahmed Ansari said six criminals on separate bikes had reached the bank around 1pm and fled after looting the money.

Title: Coronavirus in Bihar: Muzaffarpur jail inmates make khadi masks
Content:
Representative image

PATNA: Amid reports of scarcity in the open market, the inmates of Bihar jails have started manufacturing face masks of khadi on their premises only as a step to contain the spread of coronavirus.

With assistance and encouragement from the prisons department, the inmates, especially at Shaheed Khudiram Bose central jail at Muzaffarpur, are manufacturing more than 500 such masks a day.

When contacted, jail superintendent Rajeev Kumar Singh told TOI over phone that the masks being manufactured inside the jail were being supplied for use by others lodged in different jails in the state. “Presently, the inmates here are manufacturing double-layer masks. The average production cost is Rs6.5 only,” he said, adding even the khadi is woven by inmates themselves.

Singh said the masks produced in Muzaffarpur jail had been supplied to jails in four different districts. “Our inmates had supplied 200 masks to district jail in Sitamarhi, 500 to district jail in Begusarai, 150 to sub-divisional jail at Dalsinghsarai in Samastipur district and 500 more masks to district jail at Madhubani in the last few days,” he said.

In reply to a query, he also said as there is a garment industry functional inside the jail for the last several decades, inmates did not require any especial training to start production of masks.

“At any required time, we can start producing three-layer masks with tissue papers in between for more effectiveness,” he said.

Meanwhile, IG (prisons and correctional services) Mithilesh Mishra told TOI that the superintendent himself had come up with the idea. “At present, such production has started in jails at Gopalganj, Purnia and Gaya also. There are several other jails, including at Muzaffarpur, which produce phenyl and soaps. All these items are being supplied internally to maintain hygiene among prisoners and on jail premises,” Mishra said.

He said the present capacity of all jails in Bihar are around 43,000 inmates against which 40,000 inmates were lodged at present. “Orders had already been issued to maintain hygiene and procure necessary items wherever required. Most of the requirements are fulfilled from inmates,” he said.

Mishra said even before the present scenario, orders were issued for rationalizing overcrowding of inmates. “Few jails have inmates more than their capacity. They are being shifted regularly under the process,” the IG added.

Title: Mahatma Gandhi Setu work: Union ministry denies allegations of irregularities
Content:
PATNA: An independent agency appointed by the Union ministry of road, transport and highways for monitoring the Mahatma Gandhi Setu rehabilitation project, has rebutted the allegations made by Congress MLC Prem Chand Mishra regarding irregularities in the project.

In a statement issued on Wednesday, R K Mishra, the team leader of the monitoring agency, gave point-by-point clarifications for the allegations made by the Congress MLC.

On the allegation of inferior quality of steel being used in the project, Mishra stated that the usage of high performance (HPS) weathering steel for fabrication of super structures was initially suggested to the contractor- M/S Afcons – Sibmost (joint venture).

“Initially the contractor took up steel fabrication work with HPS 70W grade of steel, but it was realised that HPS grade is not widely available in the Indian market as per requirement of the project. Therefore, the contractor proposed to use steel E410 (high grade steel) with metalising…Accordingly, the proposal was examined and found suitable for this project and the same was proof-checked by IIT-Mumbai,” the statement reads.

The statement further stated that there is no change in the fatigue life of steel and hence there is no question of sub-standard quality being used in the project. “It has also been claimed that E410 grade of steel has been used in several ambitious road and rail projects, including Chenab bridge project in Jammu, rail-cum-road bridge at Ghazipur in Uttar Pradesh, Gazol Dooba bridge project in Siliguri and Mumbai-Mankhurd-Ghatkoper link flyover among others.”

Earlier, the Congress leader in a presser held at the Bihar Congress’s headquarters here on Tuesday had alleged that not only sub-standard quality of steel had been used in the repair of the bridge, but also the top damaged structure was not “broken in segments, as was warranted by the rules of the agreement with the company, but at one go”, which violated the clauses of the agreement.

On allegation of change of dismantling mythology of super-structure from cutting to crushing method, R K Mishra said in his statement that the contractors had to evolve their own design and methodology for dismantling.

“The cutting of segments was indicative and not mandatory. The contractor submitted the methodology of dismantling super structure in the land span (pillar 1 to 26) by crushing method and segments in water span (pillar 27 to 46) using jaw crushers, and accordingly it was approved by the authority engineer before implementation,” the statement reads.

Title: Banks seek RBI nod for relief to borrowers hit by Covid-19
Content: MUMBAI: Relief to coronavirus-hit borrowers from being classified as defaulters and additional funding to help businesses tackle a shutdown are measures that lenders want the regulator to allow to help tide over the pandemic-triggered economic shock. The Indian Banks Association ( IBA ) has also created a working group to study the economic fallout of the coronavirus pandemic.According to an IBA official, every business is impacted either by supply disruptions or evaporating demand. An impact assessment is being done by the banks, which will be submitted to RBI by the IBA. “If a borrower depending on the tourism industry has availed home loans, he may fail to meet his EMIs for the month of March, which would cause stress. Any immediate dispensation will help the small borrower,” said Union Bank managing director & CEO Rajkiran Rai.He added that while there was already a special dispensation for micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs), there was a restriction on the period when it was applicable and there was a requirement for being GST-registered. “This may have to be extended to other SME borrowers. In addition to dispensation, we may have to give more money to some borrowers,” he said.Large corporate accounts may not slip into default in March, but the impact would be felt in the next quarter. “The sectors that will be immediately impacted are aviation, hospitality and tourism,” said Central Bank of India managing director & CEO Pallav Mohapatra.“While everyone will be affected, right now there is a window available only for restructuring MSME loans. This is not available for retail, agriculture and corporates. As far as I know, no call for a special dispensation across all sectors has been given,” said Mahapatra. He added that the sooner a decision is taken, the better, else the damage would be done.According to a report by ICICI Securities , the real impact of the Covid-19 crisis would come from the demand side due to the cascading impact of the slowdown. This can eventually lead to suppressed prices and, thereby, slow the financial growth of most companies. Further, a cash flow crunch can impact the debt-repayment schedule.Given the drop in demand, the chorus for a rate cut has got stronger.The RBI on Wednesday announced an additional Rs 10,000-crore liquidity infusion through bond buybacks. “Covid-19 is likely to exacerbate the spectre of slower growth domestically as clampdowns are increasing both within and outside India, which would curtail consumer mobility and lead to deferral of spending,” said Confederation of Indian Industry director general Chandrajit Banerjee.He added that the RBI must act before its April policy to deliver growth-supportive measures. “We were buoyed by the bouquet of innovative measures introduced by the RBI in its last monetary policy. The need of the hour is to continue with more such innovative steps, apart from announcing a rate cut by at least 50 basis points (100bps = 1 percentage point),” he said.

Title: Yes Bank to reopen under new avatar after 13 days
Content:
(File photo)

MUMBAI: Yes Bank , under the new ownership of SBI and other lenders, has said that it will open its doors for customers an hour early on Thursday to make up for the 13-day shutdown following a moratorium imposed by the RBI .
