The All Odisha Auto-rickshaw Association has requested the Bhubaneswar Municipal Corporation to provide water facilities at auto stands so that drivers can wash their hands frequently.“All are concerned about their health. So we are all cooperating. But we need support from the government and passengers to maintain sanitation. We advised our drivers to keep their vehicles clean and wear masks and gloves. Some have also kept hand wash and water to wash their hands frequently,” said Padman Kumar Samal , secretary of the auto-rickshaw association. He said 30,000 registered auto-rickshaws are plying in the city.Despite all the precautionary and sanitation measures, the auto-rickshaw drivers are worried about the sudden fall in their earnings as large number of people are avoiding commuting. The association has also requested auto-rickshaw drivers to move to their villages instead of staying in big urban centres.People are not ready to sit close to each other in auto-rickshaws for fear of infection. “So we are taking only two passengers at a time instead of four or five we used to take earlier. It has affected our income. Besides, very few people are coming out of their homes,” said Manas Pradhan, a visibly worried driver.

Title: T gram panchayats to get Rs 1,847 crore for developmental projects
Content:
Hyderabad: The 15th Finance Commission will release Rs 1,847 crore grants for development of gram panchayats in Telangana in 2020-21.

In all, the 12,751 gram panchayats in Telangana would get Rs 3,694 crore in the ensuing fiscal, including matching grant to be given by the state government.

However, the central funds come with a rider that 10-15% should be given to mandal parishads and another 5-25% to zilla parishads.

A senior official in the panchayat raj department told TOI that even mandal and zilla parishads have to spend the funds for development works in villages, but as per their priority plans. Four committees, constituted by the government at village-level, would spend the money in tune with the yearly and five-year plans prepared by them.

Though there were complaints from sarpanches of small villages that the budget being released to them was not sufficient as a major chunk of it would go towards purchase of tractors and paying salaries to the staff, the officials said the purchase of tractors was a one-time investment and that gram panchayats would have sufficient money to spend on developmental activities once the purchase is concluded.

Title: As fences rise across globe, mango exports wilt in state
Content: Vijayawada: The outbreak of coronavirus has begun to have an impact on mango exports in Andhra Pradesh. Mango exports to the Gulf, European countries, South Asian countries and USA have been stalled following cancellation of flights due to COVID-19 scare.Speaking to TOI, commissioner of horticulture, Chiranjiv Choudhary, said “Andhra Pradesh exported over 1,500 metric tonnes of mangoes (Banginapalli, Rasalu and a few other varieties) in 2019. We had planned to export over 3,000 metric tonnes of mangoes this year. We are estimating that AP is likely to produce around 60 lakh metric tonnes of mangoes this season. But exports depends on various factors and the coronavirus scare has not helped the industry at all. We will be able to get a clear picture of the impact of coronavirus in a couple of weeks.”Andhra Pradesh has about 3.45 lakh hectares under cultivation of mango and produces around 40 to 60 lakh tonnes of mangoes per year. Nearly 10% of the produce is exported. Experts in the industry said mango growers and traders earn at least 30% to 40% more profit through exports over selling it in the domestic market.Sanjeev D, a mango exporter from Krishna district said, “The outbreak of coronavirus has had an impact on mango exports as air services to all major countries have been stalled. We have managed to export only three tonnes of mangoes so far this year. But now uncertainty looms over further export.”A tonne of mango is sold for Rs 50,000 and Rs 70,000. But mango growers said the prices have currently dipped to Rs 40,000 per tonne.The export of mangoes from Krishan district starts from March and reaches the peak in the second week of April. This year, however, contractors have stopped visiting the traders to sign agreements for mango exports due to coronavirus outbreak. If this situation were to continue till April last week, it will adversely affect the export business, said a farmer and exporter, Durga Rao from Krishna district.“We suggest that mango growers focus on the domestic market in view of the coronavirus outbreak, said assistant director of horticulture department, Nuzvid, Krishan district, Ch Srinivasulu.However, buyers seem upbeat. A few said that this would allow them to taste export-quality mangoes. “If coronavirus hits the domestic market, (Delhi, Maharashtra, Bengaluru and other areas), the prices of mangoes may dip,” a buyer said.

Title: Set up addl labs to test corona patients in Vid: HC
Content:
Nagpur: Concerned over growing number of coronavirus cases in the city, Nagpur bench of Bombay high court on Wednesday directed the government to set up additional laboratories in Vidarbha to test for the disease.

The HC also expressed concern over TOI reports of suspected patients fleeing from IGGMCH isolation wards due to lack of facilities and unhygienic conditions. “They apprehended that although they’re admitted as a precautionary measure, they shouldn’t get infected by other diseases due to insufficient facilities and lack of cleanliness,” the judges said.

“If no equipment is provided to the isolated patients to interact with society, at least through internet, social alienation may occur. It may not augur well for the government machinery in its effort to control the epidemic, as patients as well as suspected patients may not volunteer to approach medical authorities for necessary check ups and treatment,” they added.

On setting up new labs, a division bench comprising justices Sunil Shukre and Avinash Gharote said, “Considering the sharp rise in number of coronavirus afflictions, authorities should take measures to create additional Viral Research Diagnostics Laboratory (VRDL) at Government Medical College and Hospitals (GMCH) at Nagpur, Yavatmal, Akola and Chandrapur.”

Taking cognisance of TOI reports of Tuesday and Wednesday exposing lack of facilities like internet connectivity at the MLA Hostel, which is housing those in quarantine, and also conflict between various government functionaries, the bench called on authorities to resolve differences and improve facilities.

“The reports show that some sort of conflict appears to have arisen between various government functionaries, which must not have been there in the first place. It indicates that some attempt is being made by authorities to pass the buck on each other. The conflict appears to be between the city’s civil surgeon and the divisional commissioner’s office, that needs to be resolved,” the judges said.

The orders came while hearing a plea filed by CH Sharma and others, regarding lack of facilities in GMCHs across Vidarbha, where Anup Gilda was appointed as amicus curiae. Another PIL by businessman Subhash Zanwar through counsel Ram Heda was also clubbed with this case. Zanwar prayed for a slew of directives, including activation of disaster recovery task force for every district to respond to threats emerging due to the coronavirus.

Gilda pointed out that VRDL, which tests for Covid-19, is currently available only at Indira Gandhi Government Medical College and Hospital (IGGMCH). It not only caters to Vidarbha region but also neighbouring states like Telangana, Chhattisgarh and Madhya Pradesh, due to which it’s overburdened, he said.

Before adjourning the hearing till March 23, the judges quoted a TOI report that some of the suspected patients of coronavirus, who were admitted only as precautionary measure, weren’t provided internet facilities that led to their office work getting affected.

“These patients got themselves admitted into isolation ward with a view to continue their office work from a private place, but are experiencing problems. We don’t know whether these patients are willing to bear the expenses of internet facilities if provided. But, the fact remains that if those aren’t provided, their idleness should be a matter of concern for everybody,” they said.

Title: Concrete panels of new road stick out at Loutolim
Content:
Panaji: The missing link of the national highway passing through Verna towards Loutolim-Ponda junction along the overhead bridge had to be restored as a part of the concrete panels could not withstand the soil deposits compression and developed a bulge, necessitating urgent repairs .

A month ago, the village panchayat brought the anomaly to the notice of the public works department (PWD),which in turn directed the contractor to carry out repairs of this vulnerable section.

PWD chief engineer Uttam Parsekar said the repair work is being carried out by the contractor MVR Constructions at his own cost, with no additional burden on the exchequer.

“The concrete panels were bulging out and the contractor has been asked to repair it,” he said.

Though PWD officials said that it is only repair work, locals said that a considerable stretch of the road has to be reconstructed considering the bulge. Percolation of rainwater into the soil is believed to have exposed the construction defects.

The repairs were ordered following a joint inspection carried out based on complaints from the locals.

The work on the missing link is funded by the central government and was taken up as part of the ongoing highway expansion work.

PWD officials have said that after the ongoing repair work is completed, the road will be opened for use after a safety audit.

The four-lane missing link road NH-17B at Loutolim is to connect the NH17 at Verna, reducing the travel time for locals by almost 6km.

Due to this missing link, normal traffic and trucks coming to the industrial estate had to follow the long route from Loutolim, Rasaim and Cortalim.

On a larger scale, the new road, once complete, will connect Vasco to Ponda, via the Borim bridge.

Earlier, the road tapered off into a dead end on the cliff at the end of the Verna industrial estate.

Title: Coronavirus in Odisha: Tourist from France refused rides in Koraput
Content: KORAPUT: Rumours of being infected by the novel coronavirus put a 70-year-old tourist from France in some trouble on Wednesday, with auto drivers refusing to ferry him from the railway station to his hotel.The man arrived in Koraput from Bhubaneswar on the Hirakhand Express. After being refused by all the auto drivers he approached, he was offered a lift by the station superintendent of Koraput, Narendra Bhitaria. He took the tourist, not to his hotel, but straight to SLN Medical College and Hospital for a check-up.However, the foreigner, who is himself a gynaecologist, was given the all-clear and asked to remain in his hotel room for 24 hours.“The tourist was discharged from the hospital,” said Makarand Beuria, CDMO (Koraput). Beuria said the tourist had reached India on March 5 and was screened on his arrival in New Delhi. He was also kept under observation at Capital Hospital in Bhubaneswar for a day on March 16 and discharged on Tuesday.“As the incubation period of Covid-19 virus is 15 days, and the man has already spent 14 days since arriving in India, we asked him to remain in his hotel room for an extra day,” he said.

Title: Crorepati bootlegger of east Delhi nabbed
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: A 61-year-old bootlegger , who allegedly holds properties worth crores in east Delhi , was caught recently after being on Delhi Police’s radar for the past three months. In December, the man’s driver was arrested while transporting liquor in Trilokpuri area but the bootlegger had managed to flee. Police are also taking legal opinion to book him under MCOCA.

The accused, Kamal Kishore, has also allegedly engaged his 23-year old son, Akash in the business and owned properties worth Rs 3 crores in the area. Police said he had bought seven 2006 model Honda City cars and improvised the boot to ensure 50 cartons of liquor could be accommodated. The accused would provide home deliveries of illegal liquor too. With his arrest, police claim, 70% of bootlegging in east Delhi will see a downfall.

“Kishore is a school dropout and has four children from three weddings. For the last 23 years, he has been one of the biggest bootleggers in the area,” said Jasmeet Singh, DCP (East).

The driver, Rahul, was arrested in December and Akash was held on January 31. At Rahul’s instance, police also seized 51 cartons of illegal liquor. Finally, police laid and trap and nabbed kishore on March 14. Kishore told the cops that he received goods from a supplier identified as Amit who lives in Palam.

Title: Covid-19 in Rajasthan: ‘Quarantine anti-CAA protesters’
Content:
KOTA: BJP MLA from Ramganjmandi Madan Dilawar has urged CM Ashok Gehlot to quarantine anti-CAA demonstrators by erecting four high walls/ barricades around the places of protest if they do not agree to abide by the request of vacating places of protest. He has asked Gehlot to also shut down meat shops. He hailed state govt for taking measures to contain coronvirus.

Dilawar appreciated the state Congress government’s efforts and measures so far put in place to prevent the spread of COVID-19. The MLA has written to the chief minister in this regard.

Drawing chief minister’s attention to people who have been staging ‘dharna’ in protest against Citizen Amendment Act (CAA), National Register of Citizens (NRC) and National Population Register (NPR) for long time at various places in the state, the BJP MLA asked the chief minister to request the protesters to immediately vacate the places of protest and to move to their respective homes.

“If the protesters are not agreed to request of vacating the places of protest, allow them to sit for the protest in as many numbers as they want but all of them should be quarantined by electing high walls/ barricades around the places of protest and none of them from inside and people from outside be allowed to move to and fro into the places of protest,” the BJP MLA wrote to the CM.

Title: Ex-neighbours rob man of ornaments worth Rs 1L
Content:
Vadodara: A civil contractor living in Nizampura was robbed of his gold bracelet and necklace by two women who are his former neighbours at a mobile phone shop near his house.

Deeprajsinh Zala suspect that the two accused Dimple Patel and her mother-in-law Jaya Patel took away his jewellery worth Rs 1 lakh as he owed Dimple’s husband money which he had borrowed in the past.

Zala told the police that on March 9, he went to a mobile phone shop near his home to sell an old handset. While Zala was talking to the shop owner, the two women entered the shop and forcibly took away his bracelet and gold chain before departing from the shop. Zala followed them out to take his ornaments back, but the women kicked his bike down and threatened to file a false criminal complaint against him.

Zala stated that he was afraid that the women may take advantage of the situation and lodge a false police case and so deferred from taking any coercive action on them. The contractor waited for a week before approaching the police as the two women were his previous neighbours. However, when his ornaments were not returned, Zala went to Fatehgunj police station on Tuesday to lodge a complaint.

Title: Shortage of test kits at Mayo Hospital delaying results?
Content:
Nagpur: The viral research & diagnostic laboratory at Indira Gandhi Government Medical college (IGGMCH) Nagpur, the only facility conducting Covid-19 tests of suspects from most part of Central India experienced scarcity of test kits on Tuesday. Timely intervention by state government authorities resolved the issue on Wednesday and the lab is now functioning with optimum capacity.

The issue came to fore when the lab did not release results of 16 new suspects admitted on Tuesday as well as four samples pending since Monday. Health minister Rajesh Tope also accepted that there had been some miscommunication resulting in shortage.

Tope said that there was some issue with testing kits at the IGGMCH, which was sorted out later. “There is a need for these labs to convey their kits requirements to the Centre before 48 hours,” he said.

Presently, 51 Labs conducting Covid-19 tests in country get these kits on behalf of the ICMR through the NIV Pune. As per protocol, they must inform the NIV about requirement of test kits 48 hours in advance.

IGGMCH Dean Dr Ajay Keoliya accepted that there was shortage but also claimed that it was resolved after intervention by secretariat. “It was due to some miscommunication but the problem was solved quickly. Tests were not affected by the shortage. The number of samples has also gone down in last two days. All tests are being done in timely and meticulous manner,” said the dean.

Many suspects admitted in the government hospitals complained that they had to wait for long hours to get their results while some got their results in a short time. Many suspects had to wait for more than 30 hours in hospital isolation ward while some got results in 6 to 8 hours.

TOI talked to leading microbiologists in Nagpur about how this test is conducted and why it gets delayed in some cases.

“Diagnostic kits come in different capacities from 100 to 500. But this doesn’t mean that a kit with 100-capacity will test 100 samples,” said a senior microbiologist in Nagpur.

According to him, sometimes, one sample needs to be tested on different parameters as per the protocol. Sometimes, re-tests are done to re-confirm results. So, one kit of 100 capacity can test 20 to 30 samples at the most. Lab technicians generally wait for this number of samples to come before starting tests.

“Reagents and other components in kit are expensive. We can’t waste entire kit for one or two samples. So, we conduct these tests batch-wise. For example, if a batch of 20 samples is set as standard, we must wait for 20 samples to come. Once the batch count completes, the tests begin,” said the microbiologist. Due to this, some samples are get tested within 6 hours and others take time up to 24-30 hours.

Meanwhile state government, on Wednesday, announced that more labs will be opened in Pune, Mumbai, Dhule, Solapur, and Aurangabad to share the load of existing two labs in state. ICMR will be providing 10 lakh kits to these labs. This will ensure timely result in future.

Title: 3 yrs of U'khand govt: How has higher edu min fared?
Content:
Dehradun: In the past three years, how has been the performance of the higher education department which is handled by minister of state Dhan Singh Rawat? While some analysts feel the minister has tried hard to bring changes in the higher education sector, many are of the view that the situation on the ground remains unchanged.

Among the works done by Dhan Singh Rawat in last three years include announcements of more IT institutions in the hills and model colleges across the state. The minister has also said that those posted as temporary professors in universities will be made permanent through public service commission exams. He has also initiated a Common Umbrella Act for government and private universities as well as announced libraries to be built in each block of the 13 districts in Uttarakhand. Speaking to TOI, the minister claimed that much more is in the pipeline in next two years.

“We are opening IT colleges in hills and model colleges in the state. We are also ensuring 180 days of teaching in colleges. By 2021, Uttarakhand will have 105 degree colleges of government, 12 universities and 472 private colleges." But many educationalists say a lot more is yet to be done including enhancing the government’s focus on research, appointments of teachers in universities and colleges and upgradation of higher education so that it matches with global education standards. Ajay Saksena, principal of DAV College, Dehradun, who is also part of a body representing degree college teachers in Garhwal, says that there are 185 posts of degree college teachers in DAV, the biggest college of Dehradun, of which only 129 are filled yet and rest are lying vacant for long. He also expressed dissatisfaction at the higher education department's move of replacing the Choice Based Credit System (CBCS) with annual examination pattern. “The CBCS system helps a student to get education anywhere in the country as it follows the UGC guidelines which are same across the country. But with annual exam system, we lag behind in the pace of global education system,” he added. Ajay Singh Rawat, Nainital-based social activist who is former HOD of history department at Kumaun University, while evaluating the minister's performance said that he credited the higher education minister for trying to create job opportunities for guest faculties in the hill state, but added there has been a lot of political interference in education in Uttarakhand and the minister has failed to rectify this situation. “I feel nothing innovative has been done by the state government to improve research in the hill state. The government has also failed to introduce a single new subject in any of the colleges in three years which paves new opportunities to students who have been studying the old curriculum and subjects since decades,” he said adding that there have been many promises made by the higher education minister in the form of more colleges in the state but all of them have been confined to paper till now.

Major work done

Announcement of IT institutions in hills and model colleges across state

Appointments of temporary professors in universities to permanent posts through public service commission exams

Initiated Common Umbrella Act for government and private universities

Conducted student union elections across the state in one day

Still to be done

Filling up vacant posts of teachers in college

Introduction of CBCS system and getting all colleges accredited with NAC (UGC)

Practical training for students

Quality research in institutions of higher education

Title: CPCB reports lapses in flattening of landfills
Content: NEW DELHI: In a status report on the bioremediation and bio-mining process at all three landfills in the city, the Central Pollution Control Board ( CPCB ) has informed the National Green Tribunal (NGT) that despite trommel machines being used to screen legacy waste, the segregated waste is not being picked up, leachate is still seeping underground and the solid waste management guidelines are not being followed at Okhla, Bhalswa and Ghazipur sites.CPCB said waste stabilisation through bioremediation was currently only being practised at Okhla where bio-culture had been sprayed. But fumes were still being generated while moving the waste, indicating that the process was yet to be completed, it added.“At Bhalswa and Ghazipur, no waste stabilisation is being carried out and the legacy waste is just being excavated and spread two-three days prior to screening. No bio-culture is used at these sites,” stated the report, which was prepared after CPCB officials went on a field visit in January to all three landfills. The Bhalswa site was then processing 2,200 tonnes per day (TPD) of legacy waste, Okhla 250 TPD and Ghazipur 600. The report was submitted this week.The screening process to segregate waste is also not being done according to the CPCB guidelines, the report pointed out. Only a 6mm screen at Ghazipur was found to be compliant; otherwise only one screen of 30mm was being used instead of at least two screens of 30mm and 4-6mm, it added. The 30mm screen lets a lot of plastic and inerts pass, which restricts utilisation of the segregated waste for beneficial purposes, including as a soil enricher, CPCB said.It was also highlighted that barring refuse-derived fuel (RDF), the remaining screened waste was simply being dumped at the site. “It is a major issue at all sites, specifically at Ghazipur where it is precariously stored on the berm.”Another violation is non-maintenance of records for screened materials and leachate. According to CPCB, no corporation has a time-bound action plan, which may delay the process of flattening the landfills.The commissioner of North Delhi Municipal Corporation Varsha Joshi said inert materials from Bhalswa were now being used to fill up low-lying areas and at the NTPC eco park after getting a soil-test report from Sriram Institute. “Over 30,000MT has already been lifted. The processes will speed up soon,” she said. East Delhi Municipal Corporation has also said inert materials from Ghazipur are being used in filling-up activities. South Delhi Municipal Corporation couldn’t be reached despite several attempts.Civic officials have repeatedly claimed that they have no alternate site to dump the inert materials as a plea to do so in Asola has been turned down.The work started last October after NGT took cognisance of a TOI report, ‘Below Mountains of Trash Lie Poison Lakes’. CPCB submitted the report in compliance with an NGT order dated November 19, 2019, which followed another TOI report highlighting how leachate from the landfills had contaminated the groundwater and was also seeping into the Yamuna.

Title: UK man administered anti-HIV drugs for Covid-19 in Kerala
Content: KOCHI: A Covid-19 patient was administered a combination of two anti-HIV drugs for the first time in Kerala.The drugs, Ritonavir and Lopinavir , were given to a British national undergoing treatment at the Government Medical College, Ernakulam.Doctors decided to revise the treatment protocol since the patient was suffering from severe pneumonia.Authorities got the state medical board and the UK man ’s approval before administering the drugs prescribed to HIV-affected patients.The decision to revise the protocol was made at a meeting attended by Dr Thomas Mathew, medical college principal, Dr Fathahuddeen, nodal officer, Covid-19 treatment, Medical College, Dr Geetha Nair, deputy superintendent, and Dr Ganesh Mohan, RMO.The drugs were earlier used in Wuhan, China, and Jaipur, Rajasthan.

Title: KMC interns still stuck in Malaysia over technicality
Content: Mangaluru: The ordeal of fourth-year MBBS students from Kasturba Medical College , Mangaluru— Mahima Gupta and Naveen Mallya—continued at Kuala Lumpur on Wednesday. The duo who had gone to Malaysia on March 12 to pursue a one-month surgery elective were stranded after flights from Malaysia to India were cancelled, following a decision by the ministry of civil aviation to suspend flights in wake of growing concerns over the spread of Covid-19 Despite minister for external affairs S Jaishankar reaching out to them following tweets for help by these students, a technicality deprived them from taking a flight home on Wednesday. Air Asia operated two flights from Kuala Lumpur to Vishakhapatnam and New Delhi, respectively. However, only transit stranded passengers from the Philippines, and not other Indians who had gone to Malaysia ,either on study or tourist visas, came home on these flights.Mahima in a WhatsApp call from Kuala Lumpur, said that there were a lot of vacant seats on the two AirAsia flights that left for the respective destinations. “Our plea to the Indian Embassy officials and even to AirAsia officials here went unheeded, as they went with the directive of the ministry to bring back only the transit stranded passengers,” Mahima, who spent the entire day at Kuala Lumpur airport, added.Corroborating the developments in Malaysia, Rajeev Kumar Gupta, the worried father of Mahima, said a joint secretary in MEA had requested Indian Embassy and AirAsia officials in Kuala Lumpur to accommodate these students on flights to India. “However, the embassy and airline officials went with the letter and not the spirit of the exercise, and there are more than 150 Indians stranded in Kuala Lumpur hoping to return to India at the earliest,” he said.Noting that Malaysia is in total lockdown with essential items running out fast, Gupta said he is comforted by the fact that Dr Venkataraya Prabhu, dean, KMC, is going out of his way to ensure that the two students are being looked after well by the staff of their college there.“We are hoping that the Union government operates special flights to bring back other stranded Indians, including my daughter from Kuala Lumpur to India at the earliest,” he said.

Title: Hotels, tea shops, meat stalls down shutters in Piduguralla
Content:
Guntur: Close on the heels of Guntur Municipal Corporation (GMC) deciding to shut down Sunday market and night food bazar, municipal commissioner in Piduguralla has ordered closure of chicken and mutton stalls.

The commissioner directed sanitation wing to ensure the closure of all hotels, fast food centres, restaurants and other eateries with immediate effect. He said that no eatery should be allowed to open till March 31.

Municipal commissioner Annavarapu Venkateswarlu referred to the advisory issued by the food safety designated officer and assistant food controller, Guntur to impose the clamp down on hotels, chicken and mutton stalls in the town. He has also imposed a similar ban on roadside tea stalls.

“We have taken a decision to close all roadside eateries including small tea stalls keeping in view of public safety as these places are prone to attract big gathering. We can prevent such gatherings only with the closure of the shops ,” said the commissioner. He warned of taking legal action if anyone violated the instructions.

Meanwhile, district sessions and principal judge A Harinatha Sarma said no arrest warrant will be issued to the accused for the next two weeks for non-appearance in the court. He asked the petitioners too not to attend the court till March 31.

“All the cases including criminal cases will be adjourned till March 31 keeping in view of public safety,” said the judge. He said that exemption has been granted even for the accused in criminal cases in view of the advisory issued by the Centre.

Taking the support from the district police, all visitors including advocates and petitioners were being allowed to enter the court halls only after undergoing thermal scanner screening.

The authorities of the famous Sri Panakala Lakshminarasimha Swamy temple at Mangalagiri town have stopped all the Arjitha Sevas in the temple as a precautionary measure to prevent the spread of Covid-19. The temple officials deployed additional staff to keep the temple premises clean and spray the sanitisers. Temple authorities, however, decided to allow the Sarva Darshan to continue without any restrictions.

Title: Coronavirus in Vijayawada: Government reviews steps taken against coronavirus
Content: The endowments department has sought a report from all prominent temple trust boards across the state on what measures they have taken to prevent the outbreak of novel coronavirus After Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh has the highest number of prominent temples, which are thronged by tens of thousands of devotees every day.The Andhra Pradesh endowments seeking a report from prominent temple trust boards assumes significance as some of the prominent places of Hindu worship including Shri Shirdi Saibaba Sansthan in Shirdi, Siddhivinayak and Mumbadevi temples in Mumbai, Shri Mata Vaishno Devi yatra in Jammu and Kashmir, remain closed for pilgrim worship, after the respective state governments decided to prevent the outbreak of the novel virus.Clarifying to TOI on whether the Andhra Pradesh government would take such a step, endowments minister Vellampalli Srinivas said the state government has sought a report from all temple trust boards on what steps were taken by them.‘’It is too early to say anything. I’m expecting the department to table the report by tomorrow. The state government will review the situation and take a final call’’ the minister said.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Daily ridership in buses declines by 4 lakh in March
Content: NEW DELHI: After Delhi Metro, the novel coronavirus outbreak has affected the footfall of commuters taking public buses. According to the latest report, the average daily footfall in the past 15 days of February compared with the number of commuters in the first 15 days of March has gone down by four lakh.As per teh Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC) ridership figures, 4.86 crore passengers travelled in 3,781 buses between February 15 and February 29, with average daily footfall coming to 32.44 lakh. However, between March 1 and March 15, the total passengers who travelled by DTC buses was 4.47 crore with an average daily footfall of 29.84 lakh. The dip in DTC’s average daily ridership is of nearly 2.6 lakh in March compared with February.Though the exact ridership figures of the cluster buses, which has a fleet of 2,512, is not available, sources confirmed that compared with the average daily ridership in February, the daily average in the first 15 days of March has seen a dip of 1.4 lakh. As per the figures available till January 2020, cluster scheme buses approximately ferry over 12 lakh passengers daily.In the past 15 days of February, DTC witnessed ridership between 32 and 35 lakh on 10 days, the highest being on February 20 – 34.8 lakh. The highest ridership recorded in the first 15 days of March was 33.3 lakh on two days — March 3 and 4. The lowest ridership of 27.4 lakh was on February 16, a Sunday. In March, the lowest was on the day of Holi, March 10 — 16.1 lakh. On March 10, DTC had started its bus services after 2pm.“The footfall had started to fall in February itself due to riots in northeast Delhi. The Covid-19 outbreak has definitely affected the ridership further in March with many offices encouraging employees to work from home, among other reasons,” a DTC official said. He added that there was usually a dip in March every year due to many reasons, including vacations in schools and other educational institutions.Delhi Metro has also witnessed a dip of 18.5% in ridership in the same period. While February saw average passenger journey of 57.13 lakh per day, the average witnessed till March 15 has dipped to 46.53 lakh. Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC) said this was an annual trend, and every year and the footfall dipped in March. DMRC had said the number of passenger journey was dependent on various factors at any given point in normal course like vacation, examination, monsoon, festivals, strikes or closures etc, and utilisation followed a monthly pattern accordingly.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Mumbai prepares to quarantine 26,000 Indians coming from Gulf
Content: MUMBAI: As the total number of coronavirus cases in India went up to 171 and Maharashtra, with four more patients testing positive on Wednesday, continued to lead the list at 45 (by a wide margin), the Mumbai civic body prepared to receive around 26,000 Indians expected to land in the city between Thursday and March 31 from Covid-19-hit Gulf nations such as the UAE, Kuwait, Qatar and Oman.The BMC’s estimate of nearly 26,000 comes from arrivals at the city’s airport and information of travellers obtained from the Centre; 23 flights come to Mumbai from these countries every day. According to the Centre’s guidelines, all arrivals from the UAE, Kuwait, Qatar and Oman are to be quarantined for 14 days starting March 18 (Wednesday).Since 15 people from Maharashtra who earlier arrived from Dubai have tested positive, the BMC has converted one of its newly-constructed training centres for its engineers in Powai into a quarantine facility for the anticipated arrivals, apart from the isolation facility at SevenHills hospital in Marol. The Powai facility has several conference rooms where a few hundred beds are being installed, civic officials said.Most Indians expected to land by month-end are employed as blue-collared workers in the Middle East, officials said.They would be broken up into distinct categories. Those who are healthy and have their homes in Mumbai will be allowed go home, where they will have to self-isolate for 14 days. Those from places near Mumbai such as Pune or Nashik and are in the “lowest-risk category,” officials said, can proceed home as well but cannot take public transport; they would have to take private vehicles if they want to go home and not stay in the quarantine facility. All others who are from far-off places would be kept in Powai or SevenHills Hospital for 14 days. All the arrivals would be stamped and no one would be allowed to take connecting flights to other centres in India.Those who show any coronavirus symptoms would be sent for tests and those who are deemed vulnerable, such as senior citizens, would be placed in quarantine immediately.BMC commissioner Praveen Pardeshi said, “People coming in from the airport should be in home-quarantine for 14 days at their homes, at hotels in the vicinity of the airport or our facility at SevenHills or Powai. They cannot take public transport if they want to travel by road to their homes but can hire their own vehicles. Public participation is a priority, and all Mumbaikars have to fight the virus by taking precautions and maintaining hygiene to ensure that it does not spread to others.”

Title: KVs cancel home exams for students
Content:
Prayagraj: Kendriya Vidyalaya Sangathan has decided to postpone final year examinations for its students in classes I-IX and XI in the wake of the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak.

There are three Kendriva Vidyalaya regional offices in the state.

KVS has 39 schools in Varanasi region, 43 in Lucknow region and 37 of Agra region. In Prayagraj, there are nine Kendriya Vidyalayas.

According to the letter signed by deputy commissioner of KVS’ Lucknow region AK Dwivedi, all examinations for classes III to IX and XI have been postponed till April 2. The students would be notified about the the date of deceleration of results later.

“Although we were taking all kinds of precautions for the well being of our students and staff, we have still postponed all home exams. We have also initiated several steps based on the directives of the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) related to board exams of class X and XII,” said principal of KV’s Jhalwa branch in Prayagraj Vijeyesh Pandey.

Title: Int’l students at AU may be held back on campus
Content:
Vijayawada: International students at Andhra University are likely to be held back on campus for the summer vacation if the government does not allow them to fly back to their home nations.

Ongoing travel restrictions in place to tackle the spread of coronavirus may also prevent students from abroad returning to the varsity. Andhra University has nearly 500 international students from about 40 countries.

The Union government has, in a series of travel advsories, asked the airlines to discontinue operations from various countries to India to avoid the spread of infection.

Speaking to TOI, Andhra University vice-chancellor Prof PVGD Prasad Reddy said “The varsity will take appropriate decision if the international students are unable to travel home for the summer vacation due to the restrictions. The vice-chancellor also explained measures put in place on the campus,” said Prof Reddy.

Dean (international affairs) Prof EN Dhanamjaya Rao said the majority of the varsity’s foreign students are from Africa and SAARC (South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation) countries and Ethiopia, Afghanistan, Iraq and Palestine.

“All the international students of the varsity have medical insurance. We are taking the best care of the students and regularly monitoring the situation,” said Prof Dhanamjaya Rao.

About 100 to 150 international students take admission every year to pursue master’s degree, engineering and research and other programmes at Andhra University. The varsity releases a separate notification every year for international students. While the university has three international student hostels for boys, it runs a separate hostel for female students in MVP Colony in Vizag city.

Title: 3 yrs of U'khand govt: How has higher edu min fared?
Content:
Dehradun: In the past three years, how has been the performance of the higher education department which is handled by minister of state Dhan Singh Rawat? While some analysts feel the minister has tried hard to bring changes in the higher education sector, many are of the view that the situation on the ground remains unchanged.

Among the works done by Dhan Singh Rawat in last three years include announcements of more IT institutions in the hills and model colleges across the state. The minister has also said that those posted as temporary professors in universities will be made permanent through public service commission exams. He has also initiated a Common Umbrella Act for government and private universities as well as announced libraries to be built in each block of the 13 districts in Uttarakhand. Speaking to TOI, the minister claimed that much more is in the pipeline in next two years.

“We are opening IT colleges in hills and model colleges in the state. We are also ensuring 180 days of teaching in colleges. By 2021, Uttarakhand will have 105 degree colleges of government, 12 universities and 472 private colleges." But many educationalists say a lot more is yet to be done including enhancing the government’s focus on research, appointments of teachers in universities and colleges and upgradation of higher education so that it matches with global education standards. Ajay Saksena, principal of DAV College, Dehradun, who is also part of a body representing degree college teachers in Garhwal, says that there are 185 posts of degree college teachers in DAV, the biggest college of Dehradun, of which only 129 are filled yet and rest are lying vacant for long. He also expressed dissatisfaction at the higher education department's move of replacing the Choice Based Credit System (CBCS) with annual examination pattern. “The CBCS system helps a student to get education anywhere in the country as it follows the UGC guidelines which are same across the country. But with annual exam system, we lag behind in the pace of global education system,” he added. Ajay Singh Rawat, Nainital-based social activist who is former HOD of history department at Kumaun University, while evaluating the minister's performance said that he credited the higher education minister for trying to create job opportunities for guest faculties in the hill state, but added there has been a lot of political interference in education in Uttarakhand and the minister has failed to rectify this situation. “I feel nothing innovative has been done by the state government to improve research in the hill state. The government has also failed to introduce a single new subject in any of the colleges in three years which paves new opportunities to students who have been studying the old curriculum and subjects since decades,” he said adding that there have been many promises made by the higher education minister in the form of more colleges in the state but all of them have been confined to paper till now.

Major work done

Announcement of IT institutions in hills and model colleges across state

Appointments of temporary professors in universities to permanent posts through public service commission exams

Initiated Common Umbrella Act for government and private universities

Conducted student union elections across the state in one day

Still to be done

Filling up vacant posts of teachers in college

Introduction of CBCS system and getting all colleges accredited with NAC (UGC)

Practical training for students

Quality research in institutions of higher education

Title: Traffic cops get face masks amid scare
Content:
Traffic cops were provided the masks on Wednesday

Vadodara: Traffic cops, who man the city roads, can finally breathe in relief after the department on Wednesday provided them with face masks amid the Coronavirus scare.

For over a week, many citizens have begun wearing face masks apart from the government employees working in public sphere.

However, the traffic cops, who are exposed to thousands of citizens daily, were being forced to perform their duties without any precautionary measures.

“We have already begun supplying face mask to the traffic cops. Also, those posted in the police stations too would be given the protective gear,” said Anupam Singh Gahlaut, city police commissioner.

Face masks are also being provided to traffic brigade personnel. “We have also kept hand sanitizers in every police station and our other buildings and personnel are asked to take all safety measures,” Gahlaut added.

Though the city hasn’t registered any positive Coronavirus case, the city is taking maximum precaution to stop spread of the virus.

Title: Pune: PMC spends Rs 2 crore to curb Covid-19 spread in 2 weeks
Content: PUNE: The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) has spent Rs 2 crore on various measures to check coronavirus spread in a fortnight.Besides awareness drives and door-to-door survey, the funds were spent on procuring sanitizers, masks and medical equipment, among others, civic officials said. “The PMC’s efforts to mitigate the spread intensified after the first positive case was reported from the city on March 8. Thereafter, the infrastructure and other works to fight the contagion were completed on a war footing,” a senior civic official said.Anjali Sabane, assistant medical officer of health at PMC, said the funds would also be used for the development of health infrastructure, such as setting up intensive care unit at Naidu hospital. The procured material was being used for civic officials as well as common public.The health department had put forth four proposals worth Rs 1.27 crore, which were promptly approved by the standing committee as well as the general body of the PMC in a fortnight. Besides, solid waste management and anti-encroachment departments, among others, have also used funds for anti-coronavirus measures.“The standing committee has decided to take up and approve these proposals on priority,” Hemant Rasane , standing committee chairman, said.Mayor Murulidhar Mohol said the general body was displaying cohesiveness while considering these proposals for approval. “The situation caused due to coronavirus in the city is unprecedented. The corporators from all political parties have supported all the measures to deal with the problem. The projects and proposals were approved without any voice of dissent,” he said.“Senior civic officials, including additional commissioner and commissioner, have special powers to carry out procurement in larger public interest,” a senior official of municipal secretary department of PMC said.

Title: Avoid crowded areas: Rajasthan PHQ to cops
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Rajasthan police headquarters has issued an advisory owing to coronavirus according to which breathalyser will not be used till further notice.

Important meetings will be held through video conferencing. The top authority has directed that sanitizers be available at every police station and police personal should avoid going to crowded areas. Police personnel have also been directed to only interact with the complainant. In case the complainant is elderly or ailing, then one person can be allowed to be present with her/him. PHQ has also guided that meetings should be held only if necessary and video conferencing should be the option which has to be used at the maximum.

The advisory also suggests that international travel by police personnel should be avoided and emails to be used for sharing of information. All entry and exit points of the police stations should also have sanitisers. Also the additional facilities being run by the department including gyms, swimming pools etc to be closed immediately till further notice.

It has also been directed that traffic and railway police personnel who come in frequent contact with elderly persons need to take extra precautions to prevent from getting infected. All departmental examinations and the parades which are conducted on Monday as well as on Friday will be discontinued till further notice.

Police personnel have also been asked to avoid shaking hands and only salute as form of greeting. PHQ has also said that cops should avoid going to crowded areas and in case they have to then the police personnel should wear masks and carry hand sanitisers. All offices should also have hand washes and sanitisers. In case any police official has any symptoms like sneezing, coughing and others, they have been asked to take leave, according to the advisory.

Title: Most contacts of Mahe Covid-19 patient traced
Content: KOZHIKODE: As many as 60 persons who had come into contact with the woman hailing from Mahe and who had tested positive for Covid-19 on Tuesday have been identified and are kept under observation , district collector Sabasiva Rao said.Speaking to reporters at a press conference here on Wednesday, he said that the woman and her relatives who accompanied her to the Beach Hospital had worn masks and there was no need for panic. He added that efforts were underway to track all the contacts.The woman on her return from Saudi Arabia after Umrah pilgrimage had reached Beach Hospital with symptoms but had refused to stay in the isolation ward. She travelled to Kozhikode railway station in an autorickshaw from where she boarded the Mangala Express train back to her house in Mahe.Health authorities have identified the driver of the autorickshaw in which she had travelled and has kept him and family under observation. Also the Coffee House at Vadakara where the patient had visited has been closed down.The collector said that an investigation was underway to see if there has been any lapses from the part of Beach Hospital authorities in the incident.Meanwhile, the district authorities have strengthened the ward level rapid response teams (RRT) engaged in Covid-19 precautionary measures by including police personnel in the teams. There are 1,688 RRT squads in the district and of them, 202 teams have inducted police personnel.The famous Pattala Palli in Kozhikode has decided to indefinitely stop the customary daily prayers and the Friday congregations to prevent mass assembly of people in view of the Covid-19 situation.

Title: Hoax’ on Norwegian makes Goans jittery
Content: PANAJI: The state went into panic mode on Wednesday afternoon after a hoax caller informed a senior doctor at GMC’s medicine ward that the Norwegian national in its isolation facility had tested positive for Covid-19 Health minister Vishwajit Rane even made a statement in that regard, but retracted it within minutes after it turned out to be a hoax.Rane said a complaint has been lodged against the prankster.A GMC official said the call was traced to a woman in Taleigao and necessary inquiries are being made.Agasaim police, in whose jurisdiction the GMC complex comes, told TOI that they have not received any complaint in that regard.Till Wednesday evening, Goa had no Covid-19 positive cases, though five persons were in isolation facility and another 133 in home-quarantine.Nonetheless, rumour-mongers had a field day with at least two Whatsapp messages went viral. In one case, a fake name was circulated stating the person is Covid-19 positive.Rane said he had also received those messages, and there was no truth in it.

Title: Platform tickets to cost Rs 50 at selected stations from today due to coronavirus scare
Content:
JAIPUR/JODHPUR/AJMER: Visiting some railway stations for dropping and receiving your relatives or friends became costlier from Wednesday midnight. In a move to contain Coronavirus, North Western Railway (NWR) has increased platform ticket rates from the existing Rs 10 to Rs 50 per passenger.

Earlier, two of the important railway zones including Western Railway and Central Railway had hiked platform ticket rates in some of its stations.

To start with, the newly introduced platform ticket charges would be implemented to some of the selected stations.

“These stations include Jaipur, Alwar, Bandikui, Gandhi Nagar (Jaipur), Phulera, Kishangarh, Ajmer, Sikar and Durgapura (Jaipur). These fares would be applicable from Wednesday midnight. Necessary changes were also been made in the reservation system and its counters at these stations,” the officer added.

Title: Delhi: Tech helps cops nab gang that went on robbing spree
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: A gang of robbers that targeted several people in the same day in Dwarka was busted after police tracked down their motorcycle using the zipnet software . The men targeted at least three women within a span of 20 minutes and robbed them of their jewellery and valuables at gunpoint. A goldsmith has also been arrested for buying the robbed jewellery from the accused.

The gang members, identified as Mohammad Mukhtiyar, Mandeep and Pankaj, were caught from Uttam Nagar. One pistol and two live cartridges of 0.32 bore and gold chains were seized from Mandeep. Police said that the men committed several robberies in a single day near malls and crowded areas. The men would then flee on the motorcycle expertly, even while being chased.

DCP (Dwarka) Anto Alphonse said that the men were found to be involved in more than a dozen cases in a day.

The spree of incidents had happened on March 11, when the cops were bombarded with calls of robberies from different parts of Dwarka. In all the cases, the victims reported that the robbers were travelling on a Yamaha FZ bike.

Zipnet keeps a record of all the stolen vehicles, their location of theft and name of owner from which the place of theft was detected. It was found that the bike was stolen from Uttam Nagar.

“A team led by ACP Rajinder Singh was formed to track down the men,” said Alphonse. During the probe, the cops tracked the bike to Pankaj’s residence with CCTV footage of the area, using the number plate reading cameras.

After interrogating Pankaj, the cops also managed to nab the other two accused.

The accused told police that they had robbed many people in Dwarka using the Yamaha FZ motorcycle since October 2019. They also disclosed the name of the jeweller, Anil, who allegedly bought the gold off them. Anil was apprehended from his shop and four robbed gold chains were also seized from him.

Title: Govt mulls providing option of free or paid quarantine
Content:
Ahmedabad: Health department officials in Gujarat on Wednesday hinted that those returning from abroad can get a choice of quarantine, the AMC-designated quarantine facilities for free, or checking into a hotel for 14 days.

According to directives of the central government, all persons returning from abroad, especially those from countries with a COVID-19 outbreak and those showing symptoms such as cough/cold, fever or respiratory illness, will be quarantined. This will also apply to those older than 60 years and having other health conditions such as asthma, blood pressure or diabetes.

“We are creating quarantine facilities in Ahmedabad in association with Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC). The quarantine there will be free including meals and basic amenities. However, for those wanting to pay for better facilities, we are in talks with a few hotels to provide an entire floor for the purpose. These persons will get a discounted tariff. We are still working out the finer details,” said a senior state health department official.

AMC officials said that the two quarantine facilities in question are the new Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana housing units in Nikol and Gujarat Sports Club near Sardar Patel Stadium. AMC teams were seen shifting medical equipment and beds to both locations.

While the transition for the club house was smooth, with the identification of various zones and utilities, the 100-bed facility did not go down well with Nikol residents, who protested citing the health hazards.

“We are yet to get a satisfactory answer from the AMC on what measures they taken to ensure the safety of residents and what type of patients will be kept here,” says Jitendra Vyas, a resident of Jivanashray Society in Nikol. The AMC will add three more such centres, including the sports complex in eastern Ahmedabad, if needed, senior AMC officials said.

Title: Indian broadcast crew sent back to Pakistan from Wagah border
Content: Panaji: An Indian broadcast crew of 29 members working at the Pakistan Super League ( PSL ) have been stopped from returning home at the Wagah-Attari border.The Pakistan Super League was cancelled hours before the semifinals on Tuesday after one of the foreign players developed symptoms of Coronavirus . With the league cancelled, the crew wanted to return home but discovered that airspace was closed. Their return tickets via Doha at first and then Colombo had to be cancelled because these countries had stopped international arrivals.“Coming home through the Wagah border was our best option. The Pakistan Cricket Board (PCB) requested officials on the Pakistan side to allow us through. We crossed the Pakistan side of the (Wagah) border at 10am (on Wednesday) but when we came to the Indian side, they just wouldn’t allow us to cross. We were stuck for five hours and then sent back (to Pakistan),” a member of the crew told TOI on Wednesday.Immigration officials on the Indian side of the Wagah border told the crew that they had to mandatorily take a flight back home since their Pakistan visas were stamped through the Pakistan embassy in Dubai.“Since we reached Pakistan via Dubai, we were advised to follow the same route on our way back home. We all know this is an emergency situation and the country is calling everyone home. This is a crazy situation. Our own country is refusing to accept us,” said the member, who has a 45-day business visa to Pakistan.The broadcast crew has an office in Delhi and officials were trying to get in touch with the ministry of external affairs (MEA) and the ministry of home affairs (MHA) but till late on Wednesday, the 29-member crew were uncertain when, and how, they would get home. Prime minister Narendra Modi was also tagged in a tweet by one of the member.“The Pakistan side was more considerate with our situation than our own people. Now we are waiting to see how we can get home,” he said.The Pakistan Super League was cancelled just before the semifinals after a foreign player developed symptoms of coronavirus. The PCB has not as yet revealed the identify of the cricketer, who, according to reports, has flown out of Pakistan. All players and broadcasters were later tested for the virus.

Title: Psychiatrist helps MLA Hostel travellers adjust to quarantine
Content:
Police personnel and medical staff at the MLA Hostel

Nagpur: The quarantined travellers at MLA Hostel had a psychiatrist visiting them on Wednesday, apart from the health check-ups from time to time. The objective was to judge their state of mind during the stay in quarantine, said sources.

No clinical signs of mental disturbance like depression or other problems were seen. Though they were feeling restless and wanted to go home, even the loneliness was not of the type that is seen in clinical depression, said sources. They may have more visits by the psychiatrist in coming day, said officials here.

These travellers have arrived from the seven designated countries, China, Spain, France, Germany, Italy, South Korea, and Iran.

On Wednesday, 14 more persons were taken to MLA Hostel said a government press release.

Also, five persons, including a French national who works at Dassault Reliance Aviation Limited (DRAL) at Mihan-SEZ, were released. One of them — Prajeet Gupte from Amravati — who was slated for release, opted to stay at MLA Hostel for the entire 14-day isolation period.

From Thursday morning onwards, all passengers will have to stay for the entire 14-day period and those coming from Gulf countries will also be covered.

By around 4pm on Wednesday, the persons released had begun coming out. Some of them had been inside since three days, including Robert Mate, the French national. They were made to sign an undertaking that they will remain confined to home and report if symptoms develop.

Mate, who complained about the facilities not being up to standards, was seen getting closer to others than the recommended distance of one metre at MLA Hostel, including some officials. He was driven home by a chauffeur. “I have no choice as I have been assigned to take him,” said the driver, his face covered with a handkerchief.

Earlier, there were directives that persons will be kept for 24 hours and released if no symptoms are seen. However, for some, it has also taken longer as the process took time, said an official in the district administration.

The tension could be felt among relatives too, especially parents. One of them — a career consultant, whose son has come from Germany — was seen arguing with the officials. “You should have carried out orientation sessions if the period was to be increased. We were told it’s just 24 hours and now it has been 36 hours,” said the man in his fifties.

“My son has travelled with all precautions, and don’t worry we will keep him in a separate room if he is allowed to go home and be quarantined,” insisted a college teacher, whose son has come from France.

Not long afterwards, as the son of one of them came out, the mother tried to get close to him and was immediately admonished by officials, though she refused to budge.

Title: NITK reschedules academic calendar
Content: Mangaluru: NITK Surathkal has rescheduled its academic calendar in the wake of the Covid-19 outbreak. As per the revised schedule, the even semester will resume on June 1.The decision was taken during the 51st special senate meeting held on Tuesday. It was chaired by Karanam Uma Maheshwar Rao, director, NITK, Surathkal.Earlier, the even semester examinations were scheduled on April 17 and would end by May 4. The result was supposed to be announced a week later. “As per the revised academic calendar, classes will resume on June 1, and the end semester examinations will commence from June 29, and results will be announced on July 13. The classes for odd semester classes will commence from July 27,” said a source. The odd semester examinations will end on November 28, and results will be announced on December 1.

Title: Covid-19 safeguards in place for Intermediate spot valuation
Content: Vijayawada: Amidst the growing fears around the spread of coronavirus, the Board of Intermediate Education (BIE) has suggested implementing precautionary measures for spot valuation camps across the state. The Intermediate examinations, which began on March 4, concluded on Wednesday. The evaluation camps will begin on Thursday. The suggestions were made in view of the fact that evaluators have to handle lakhs of answer sheets at the camps.The BIE instructed camp officers to maintain a distance of one metre between two examiners and to ensure that spot valuation halls are not congested. All examiners have been advised to wear masks. Other suggestions include maintaining proper ventilation at the valuation halls besides providing water and sufficient quantity of liquid soap to evaluators.All valuation halls will be cleaned and disinfected every day. First-aid boxes and medical personnel will also be available at the camps. Persons with fever, cough and cold will be replaced with a substitute immediately and referred to a nearby facility. Information, education and communication material such as posters regarding coronavirus will be on display at all camps.Around 10.65 lakh students appeared for the Intermediate examinations in Andhra Pradesh this year. The exams were held at 1,411 examination centres across the state.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Allahabad high court halts all recovery work till April 6
Content: ALLAHABAD: The Allahabad high court on Wednesday directed that all the recovery proceedings of the district administration, financial institutions and other administrative bodies/authorities/agencies and otherwise by the instrumentalities of the state shall be deferred for a period of two weeks till April 6. The direction has been issued in order to discourage people from approaching courts in view of coronavirus threat.The court further directed that all the auction proceedings, and if any pending or initiated in the meanwhile, shall remain deferred for a period of two weeks, i.e., till April 6.Hearing a writ petition filed by one Darpan Sahu, who had challenged the recovery proceedings against him, a division bench comprising Justice Ramesh Sinha and Justice Ajit Kumar observed, “There is an extraordinary situation in the country due to pandemic Corona Virus and therefore, it calls for an extraordinary measure to be taken to contain COVID-19. It is a situation where ‘self quarantine’ should be encouraged amongst people in the society in particular and the country in general. Accordingly, in our considered opinion all the concerned competent authorities, both administrative and non-administrative, under the state government be issued directions restraining them from taking any coercive measures against any person or body of persons in the society so as to force him/them to approach the court for the redressal of grievance.”The court further restrained the district magistrates and the administrative authorities across the state from issuing any directions for presence of any person or persons in connection with any pending or any other proceeding for a period of two weeks, i.e., till April 6.Further, the court directed that no demolition exercise shall be carried out at the instance of district administration or any authorities under the state government/local bodies for a period of two weeks, i.e., till April 6.Besides, no eviction or dispossession exercise against anyone be undertaken for a period of two weeks, i.e., till April 6, the court further directed.The court directed the registrar general to forward a copy of this order to the UP chief secretary immediately to ensure its compliance by issuing necessary directions/circulars to all the concerned authorities in the matter throughout the state within 48 hours. Besides, the court directed that a copy of this order shall also be sent to the advocate general of the state for necessary compliance.

Title: Covid-19 scare in Delhi: Vendors’ woes multiply by the day as losses mount
Content: NEW DELHI: The informal sector in Delhi is fighting a battle for survival in the wake of threat of the novel coronavirus. As the city seems to virtually shut down to contain the spread of Covid-19, daily vendors are left in a lurch, with businesses being severely impacted.These vendors, who mostly comprise migrant populations from neighbouring states, say their earnings have gone down by at least 50%, forcing them to reconsider their lives in the city. They sell a variety of things along road sides – books, earrings, pens and clothes – but most of them have reported similar losses. When TOI visited major markets on Wednesday afternoon, stalls bore a deserted look.“This is a death knell for our business. Even GST and demonetisation did not impact us to this degree. If we earned Rs 100 earlier, now it’s difficult to even make Rs 10,” said Ankit Sharma, who sells men’s t-shirts by the roadside in Connaught Place. He took over the business from his father recently, after the latter had run it for over 20 years. “We may have to let go of our two workers to sustain ourselves,” Sharma added.Even so, Sharma’s family is one of the lucky ones as his father had been able to build a house with his savings.Sharma, whose father built a house after years of saving, is among the lucky ones. For other migrant vendors who pay monthly rents for their accommodations, the possibility of going hungry is more imminent than the threat of the virus. Living on the margin with daily earnings, they are left with very few choices. And most of them are rationing food money to save for their next month’s rent.“We have decided to eat as little as possible otherwise we will be forced to go back to our village, and there are no jobs there,” said Surendra, a 30-year-old, who sells mobile covers in CP. The youth is the only earning member in his family, and lives in a rented house in Paharganj.The community says that slump in business has resulted in loss of income that will be impossible to compensate. Vinod, who sells earrings outside Lajpat Central Market, said that on most days last week, he did not sell anything. “Shoppers are not stopping at stalls,” he said.Another challenge, Vinod said, was to sell at profit. “We can’t bargain at all. Right now, our only concern is to get back the money we have already invested in our product,” he said.

Title: Platform tickets to cost Rs 50 at selected stations from today due to coronavirus scare
Content:
JAIPUR/JODHPUR/AJMER: Visiting some railway stations for dropping and receiving your relatives or friends became costlier from Wednesday midnight. In a move to contain Coronavirus, North Western Railway (NWR) has increased platform ticket rates from the existing Rs 10 to Rs 50 per passenger.

Earlier, two of the important railway zones including Western Railway and Central Railway had hiked platform ticket rates in some of its stations.

To start with, the newly introduced platform ticket charges would be implemented to some of the selected stations.

“These stations include Jaipur, Alwar, Bandikui, Gandhi Nagar (Jaipur), Phulera, Kishangarh, Ajmer, Sikar and Durgapura (Jaipur). These fares would be applicable from Wednesday midnight. Necessary changes were also been made in the reservation system and its counters at these stations,” the officer added.
