Title: Work from home for all Icertis staffers in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Contract management software firm Icertis on Wednesday told all its 800 employees in the city to work from home till further orders.

The startup has also issued a travel advisory for its workforce to safeguard and prevent any kind of health threat. “Given the evolving reach of the virus, we have implemented precautionary measures in compliance with World Health Organisation and government guidelines across our offices and have asked all our Pune-based employees to work from home indefinitely. This follows similar measures in the US and Europe,” the company said.

The startup’s move comes even as other companies dabble in with split shift, alternate week work-from-home, among others.

Title: Coronavirus in Jaipur: Mandis buzz with crowd, malls wear deserted look
Content:
Vegetable vendor Badam Devi

JAIPUR: With a mask on her face, 65-year Badam Devi is a picture in clear contrast to her community of vegetable sellers in Lal Kothi Sabji Mandi. Even on a working day afternoon, the market is reasonably bustling, and the fear of virus is conspicuous by its absence.

“Much has been made out of the virus, there is nothing to be so worried. After all, what is to happen will happen. We are not worried,” says Imtiaz, a vegetable seller. When asked whether government officials visiting the mandi and creating awareness about the deadly virus, he said not so far, and there is no need for it.

But the scene changes as you step into World Trade Park, the city's showcase landmark for modern retail. “90% of the visitors have disappeared. We are pleading with the management to close the store. We are afraid of getting infected . Since morning till 1 o'clock, we have sold goods worth only Rs 800 from all the three floors of our outlet,” said an employee of Shoppers Stop at WTP.

“We have closed down cinema halls and gyms as per government orders. Even the retail outlets are open, crowds have thinned out. Now it is only restricted to essential purchase,” said Gaurav Baradiya, promoter of an oldest mall in the city.

After initial dillydallying, IT companies fallen back on the last option – working from home. Big names in the industry have reoriented their operation and others are in the process of testing to ensure no disruption to the service delivery.

“Many have remodeled their operations to allow employees to work from home. Others have started trial runs to ensure that workflow remains seamless. Everybody has realized that working from home will remain a reality for some time to come,” said Puneet Mittal, founder of a software company.

In Sitapura industrial zone is home to many textile units, making garments for leading brands in the country and also for exporting. Gem and jewellery manufacturers also have a significant presence. Thousands of workers enter the factory gates every day. But thermal scanning, body temperature checking, and other precautions remain largely missing.

Gaurav Gupta, promoter of a manufacturing unit, said, “We do thermal scanning and also have alerted our employees to report any sign of illness immediately. But I cannot speak for others.”

Title: Rumour mongers beware, a spl team keeping watch
Content: Nagpur: The cyber cell of city police has appointed a special team to keep a watch on rumour mongers who are spreading fake news regarding coronavirus . The cops will keep tab on social media 24X7 to track down the miscreants.The step has been taken following an order from special inspector general of police, Maharashtra cyber, that any person or institution spreading misinformation regarding Covid-19 will be held responsible and necessary action will be taken against them under section 3 of The Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897. The section reads “Any person disobeying any regulation or order made under this Act shall be deemed to have committed an offence punishable under section 188 of IPC.”City police commissioner BK Upadhyay said that the cyber cell is on alert and they are keeping eye on rumour mongers. “We have already taken cognisance in one such case regarding after the fake news about collector Ravindra Thakre being tested positive of Covid-19. An offence in this regard was also registered at Sadar police station. I suggest all citizens to refrain from spreading any fake news or offences will be registered against them under relevant sections,” the city police chief said.Earlier, an offence was registered at Gobarwahi police station of Tumsar taluka in Bhandara against an unidentified person for allegedly spreading an edited version of a broadcast news stating that there was a covid-19 patient at Pathri village.Sources from the cyber cell claimed that it is very hard for them to track misinformation being spread through WhatsApp as it is impossible to find the origin of the message. However, if a person shares misinformation through a specific account, may it be Facebook or Twitter, he or she will be tracked down and booked under relevant section, they said.Since the coronavirus outbreak, loads of information is making rounds on social media but there is little scope to verify its authenticity. The notification from Maharashtra Cyber has claimed that any person or organization must avoid spreading any unauthenticated information regarding Covid-19.Maharashtra Cyber cell has also urged citizens to rely only on official sources for all the information regarding the Covid-19.Fake news dispelledA fake message was circulating on social media on Wednesday, claiming people should not come out of their houses between 10pm and 5am as “medicines will be sprayed to kill COVID-19”.Divisional commissioner Sanjeev Kumar said no such instructions have been given.“FIR will be filed against whoever those who spread rumours. We are not undertaking any such drive and haven’t asked citizens to stay indoors,” he said.

Title: Karnataka flyer’s 30 co-travellers traced, state looking for 8
Content: Panaji/Margao: Health authorities in the state managed to trace 30 co-passengers who travelled on a Dubai-Goa-Bengaluru flight last week with the Bengaluru woman who tested positive for Covid-19 on Tuesday. However, officials are yet to find eight persons who travelled on the same flight.A South Goa politician was also on the same flight and refused to get quarantined till Wednesday evening.“There was a prominent politician among the travellers in the same flight. Even he will be quarantined. Privacy doesn’t matter in this crisis,” health minister Vishwajit Rane told reporters on Wednesday.Stating that a prominent person refused to cooperate, Rane said that such irresponsible behaviour will not be tolerated from any one and “the police have been asked to take action”.Though the health minister did not reveal the identity of the person, sources said that it is a Salcete politician who travelled in business class on the flight from Dubai.The Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897, which was invoked last week, allows health authorities to forcefully, quarantine any person that may refuse to comply.Health services director Jose D’Sa said that seats of five travellers were located close to Covid-19 positive passenger and the process to trace other the travellers was on.The health department statement states that 48 passengers that de-boarded from the Dubai flight were tracked and quarantined. Samples of four persons taken and sent for lab testing. Reports of ten samples including those sent on Tuesday were awaited.One person was discharged from the hospital after he tested negative for Covid-19. Five persons were placed in isolation, number of persons under home quarantined jumped to 133, it stated further.Four persons were admitted in the isolation ward set up at the TB Hospital, Margao.Hospicio medical superintendent Dr Ira Almeida said that of the four persons isolated in the TB hospital, two are Indians while the other two are foreigners. These four were among the passengers who had travelled by the flight from Dubai to Bengaluru via Goa, Almeida said.Besides, two persons were admitted in the quarantine facility set up at the ESI hospital, Margao, on Wednesday. Almeida said that the two will be offered the option of getting home quarantined. The two suspects had flown into Goa and were brought to the quarantine facility at the ESI hospital directly from the Dabolim airport, sources said.A 69-bedded quarantine facility has been set up at the ESI hospital, Margao, while the capacity of the isolation ward has been enhanced to 12 beds, the statement stated.No Covid-19 positive case was reported in the State on WednesdayTh health minister said since there were complaints of passenger checking was not being done properly at the Dabolim airport, he would conduct an inspection along with director health services and GMC dean.

Title: Hotels seek waiver of SGST in wake of travel ban
Content:
JAIPUR: Leading global and national hospitality chains operating from various cities of Rajasthan have come together and written to the chief secretary seeking relief as the industry has come to a halt after travel ban following the coronavirus outbreak. Many of the properties have now told their staff to go on leave, allotted to them annually, in the absence of any operational requirement.

In the letter to CS D B Gupta, 16 hotels have sought waiver of SGST till the time the situation becomes normal. “In this crucial time, we draw attention of the state government to support tourism and hospitality industry. The state government should also try and convenience the Centre for a similar remedy,” a hotelier said referring to the letter.

Similarly, the industry has urged the government to make an arrangement with banks which will allow the deferment of bank loans. “We would like to highlight the fact that most of the hotel owners have taken loans from banks and in current situation it is difficult for us to pay interest and bank EMI. Banks should be advised by the state government to consider the situation and defer the EMI & interest,” reads the letter.

In the new excise policy, the state government has raised liquor licence fees. Recently, chief minister has announced to give 10% relief on the fees given the current situation. But the industry said, “Revised excise charges for liquor for 2020-21 should be rolled back and old charges should be implemented for the hospitality industry.”

Exemption of power bills is another demand they want the government to fulfil. “50% exemption will help us in this difficult time,” the letter stated.

Title: Corona scare: City roads, markets deserted, many events postponed
Content:
A mall wears a deserted look as people prefer to stay at home

Kanpur: Ever bustling with activities, the industrial city has slowed down due to scare of coronavirus, declared pandemic by the World Health Organisation.

With most of the establishments closed down following the government orders, the shopping stores and markets witnessed almost zero footfall. Denizens also refrained from moving outside as precautionary measure against coronavirus.

In compliance of the state government notification, district magistrate Dr Brahm Deo Ram Tiwari has postponed examinations of all universities, boards and schools and all competitive examinations till April 2. The offices have been asked to avoid biometric attendance and use attendance register.

The administration also had to postpone many events including Tehsil diwas, Samadhan diwas, Janta diwas and other important meetings under social distancing measures to counter the spread of Covid-19. DM and vice-chairman, Kanpur Development Authority Dr Brahma Deo Ram Tiwari has also postponed Pradhikaran Diwas, earlier scheduled to be held on March 19, till further orders.

Except health institutions all other establishments including educational institutes, gyms, museum, tourist places, cultural and social centres, zoo, swimming pools, multiplexes, religious places like temples and other public places in the district have been closed down till April 2.

As per the government notification, multiplexes and malls have been directed to avoid crowd at their premises and any violation of this order would be punishable under epidemic Covid-19 rules 2020 and section 88 of IPC.

Meanwhile, district magistrate and CMO, in a joint advisory for citizens, have asked them to contact district surveillance officer Dr Subodh Prakash on number 9838340355 and district epidemiologist Dr Dev Singh on 9473701284 if anybody, who has come from abroad, and is suffering from fever, cough and respiratory problems comes to their notice. Such people, even if they do not show corona like symptoms, will be isolated for 28 days. In another directive, people have been asked to maintain a safe distance during conversation, wash hands regularly and avoid crowded places. The DM, on Wednesday, distributed mask to officials and employees of Kanpur collectorate and asked them to maintain sanitation and hygiene.

Meanwhile, offices of Kanpur Municipal Corporation and Kanpur Development Authority were found almost vacant. Museum and other historical sites in Bithoor have also been closed for visitors.

Title: Limit online food orders: IIM-L
Content:
Lucknow: Amid growing concerns over the Covid-19 pandemic, IIM Lucknow has asked its students and staff to limit orders placed with doorstep food delivery services to reduce footfall on the campus, which now has a single entry and exit.

As yet another preventive measure, the institute has shut down two of its complexes.

In a circular (a copy of which is with TOI) issued to all students, deans, chairman, faculty members and non-teaching staff, IIM-L’s chief administrative officer Vinay Kumar Verma has asked them to also refrain from visiting crowded places unless absolutely necessary.

Among other measures, the institute is reserving four rooms in a hostel to isolate anyone who manifests symptoms on the campus. Outsourced staff are being screened at the main gate. Eateries have been issued an advisory on hygiene while food handlers are being routinely examined for symptoms.

The circular seeks sanitising of all door handles, especially of classrooms.

Title: Students returning from Europe raise stink at Sola Civil
Content:
Ahmedabad: For the 54 students who landed in Ahmedabad from two different flights early on Wednesday, the quarantine facility at GMERS Hospital at Sola was not what they expected, with unhygienic conditions and people huddled together. The students and their parents made representations to top government offices after which they were shifted to a hotel at GIFT City near Gandhinagar.

Health department officials said the state will pay for their 24-hour quarantine and will look into the complaints raised. Several parents and relatives took the issue to Twitter, marking central and state ministers. The students were mainly returning from the UK, France and Germany.

Tejal Shah, whose daughter returned from Frankfurt via Abu Dhabi, claimed that few passengers had any idea of why they were taken to the hospital. “When we raised the issues of being bunched together in a ward, which would increase chances of infection, and the unhygienic conditions and demanded an alternative, the officials threatened us with action under the Epidemic Diseases Act,” said Shah.

After parents and relatives took the issue to the Gandhinagar power corridors, the group was shifted to the hotel near Gandhinagar. “There too we had to fight. We were first told that for twin sharing, we would have to pay Rs 4,000,” said Shah.

In videos circulated on social media, the students were seen complaining about the toilets, passengers coughing and no one paying attention to it and lack of clarity over procedure.

Title: Maharashtra CM Uddhav Thackeray asks railways, BEST, metro to cut passengers by 50 per cent
Content:
No standees to be allowed in BEST buses from today

MUMBAI: CM Uddhav Thackeray on Wednesday directed transport agencies like BEST, Metro, the railways, the state transport corporation and even private buses to run their services at 50% passenger capacity in order to decongest public transport. The state government has also asked local bodies in urban areas to reschedule timings of shops in order to avoid crowds.Importantly, BMC officials, accompanied by cops, will start visiting private offices across the city from Thursday to check if they are implementing the state’s “50% staff only” directive in the wake of Covid-19 concerns.BMC chief Praveen Pardeshi on Wednesday issued a circular asking all ward officers to identify roads on which all shops and commercial activities would be kept shut on alternate days. In areas that see big crowds, shifts for stores may be decided so that all are not open at the same time. This rule would not apply to essential stores like chemists or grocery shops. Guidelines have been issued to BEST to not allow standees in buses.These steps were announced after the CM held a review meeting with stakeholders. But senior railway officials said crowds could not be reduced in this manner to 50% of capacity as those with valid tickets could not be stopped from boarding trains.AWR official said, “At the meeting with the CM, we were asked for suggestions to reduce crowding on trains. We said the number of services cannot be reduced as that will lead to overcrowding. We said there is already a drop in ridership by 25%, and if additional measures like implementing the work-from-home directive or closing non-essential shops are taken, ridership would automatically come down to 50%.” A CR official said, “Already steps like increasing rates of platform tickets and monitoring of crowds through CCTVs have been taken. No additional measures will be taken as we already have security personnel to streamline crowd movement at stations.”BEST general manager Surendrakumar Bagde said no standees will be allowed in BEST buses from Thursday. Announcements will also be made asking passengers to keep a distance from each other. “We will ensure passengers are seated and don’t brush past each other while boarding or alighting. The conductor will ensure everyone is seated,” he said. The state has said additional buses can be deployed if needed. In Panvel civic corporation limits, all shops except essential ones will be closed from Friday.Thackeray has already appealed to people to avoid non-essential travel, saying if they didn’t, the government would be forced to stop bus and railway services.According to data with the state, there has been a 27% drop in passengers on WR, a 51% drop in those using ST buses and a 40% drop in Metro users. All government offices are also to work at 50% capacity till March 31. But departments dealing with emergency services will work at 100% strength.

Title: Coronavirus in Kerala: 10 trains to Tamil Nadu, Telangana cancelled
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Southern Railway has cancelled services of ten trains, including eight special trains connecting Kerala, Tamil Nadu and Karnataka destinations. In a statement issued on Wednesday, railways said that in view of poor patronage of trains due to outbreak of coronavirus , the special trains stand cancelled.Train no. 22207 Chennai Central-Thiruvananthapuram Central AC Express from Chennai Central on March 20, 24, 27 and 31 and train no. 22208 Thiruvananthapuram Central-Chennai Central AC Express from Thiruvananthapuram Central on March 22, 25 and 29 and April 1 are fully cancelled.Special trains no. 06015 and 06016 between Ernakulam Junction and Velankanni on March 21 and 22, respectively, are fully cancelled.Weekly special trains no. 07117 and 07118 between Ernakulam Junction and Hyderabad on March 25 and 26, respectively, are cancelled.Weekly special trains no. 06048 and 06047 between Thiruvananthapuram and MGR Chennai Central on April 1 and 2, respectively, are cancelled.Weekly special trains no. 06045 and 06046 between Ernakulam Junction and Rameswaram on April 2 and 3, respectively, are also cancelled.

Title: Coronavirus in Ahmedabad: Gandhi Ashram closed to visitors for 1st time
Content: AHMEDABAD: For the first time in the history of Sabarmati Gandhi Ashram, trustees have unanimously decided to close the Ashram to visitors till March 29, or until the Covid-19 pandemic situation eases off, whichever is later. Each day, more than 3,000 people visit the Ashram including a number of international and domestic tourists. Over the past three days, footfalls had reduced to 800 to 1,000.“We took our decision based on the advisories of the government and the WHO and have unanimously decided to close Ashram premises till March 29,” said Sabarmati Ashram Preservation and Memorial Trust director, Atul Pandya.When Gandhiji established his base in Ahmedabad in 1915 following his return from South Africa, he chose a bungalow at Kochrab village on the outskirts of the city. However, two years later, in May 1917, a plague-like illness had broken out in the village and Bapu decided to set up his new base at Sabarmati Ashram. Since Bapu’s death the Ashram was never closed to visitors, even on public holidays.

Title: DC orders action against fake messages on Covid-19
Content:
632 people screened

MANGALURU: The district administration has decided to take action against those who spread fake messages regarding authorities carrying out a Covid-19 prevention drive Deputy commissioner Sindhu B Rupesh has directed officials to take action against those who created confusion among people by spreading a fake message. The fake message , which is being spread through social media and web portals, reads: “Kind Attention Mangaloreans, All are requested to stay indoors after 10pm tonight till tomorrow 5am… As there will be a disinfectant spraying procedure in order to contain Covid-19. Share this information to all your friends, relatives and family.”Khader Shah, senior assistant director, department of information and public relations, said,“As per the government order HFW/54/CGM2020 dated 11-03-2020 spreading rumours and wrong information about Covid-19 is a punishable offence. Hence, action will be taken against those who spread wrong information about Covid-19.”As many as 632 people were screened for Covid-19 in Dakshina Kannada on Wednesday. While 689 people are under home quarantine, eight have completed the quarantine period as on Wednesday.While samples of three people have been sent for tests, reports of 14 suspected cases were received. None of them tested positive for Covid-19. Two more people have been admitted for observation on Wednesday.In Udupi , five suspected cases of Covid-19 were reported, including three in the district hospital, and one each in KMC and Kundapur Taluk Hospital. Out of five suspects, two had travelled to Dubai, while others travelled to Qatar, Abu Dhabi and Bahrain. Samples of all the suspected cases have been sent for tests, and reports are yet to come, stated officials of the health department.Meanwhile, a patient from Puttur was admitted to Wenlock Hospital on Wednesday. ASHA workers have visited 55,241 houses as on Tuesday. Awareness has been created among 2,12,639 people so far on Covid-19.The health department has trained 1,331 ASHA workers to tackle Covid-19.

Title: Coronavirus in Uttarakhand: Residents, pilgrims asked not to take part in Ganga aarti at Har-ki-Pauri
Content: HARIDWAR: In an order issued on Wednesday night, the Haridwar district administration banned participation of local residents and pilgrims in the evening Ganga aarati at the Har-ki-Pauri in view of the fact that thousands of people were continuing to gather to take part in the ritual despite a ban imposed by the state government on assembly of more than 50 people at any place in view of the Covid-19 threat. The order will come into force on Thursday and will be in effect till March 31. District magistrate C Ravishankar told TOI that “with the beginning of navaratras on March 25, live streaming of the aarti will also commence so that devotees can take part in the ritual virtually.”Local residents had alleged that the steps taken by the Ganga Sabha, the body which administers the Har-ki-Pauri ghat, to sanitise the place, were "inadequate and not at all convincing."Ganga Sabha office bearers who participated in a meeting with the district administration on Wednesday had opposed the idea of restricting the pilgrim numbers and instead proposed that about 1000 masks can be distributed at the aarti every day and the ghat can be sanitised. But the idea was shot down by the district authorities as being “practically not feasible” and instead, the ban on assembly of people has been put in place.Ganga Sabha general secretary Tanmay Vashishth had told TOI earlier that "the aarti at the Har-ki-Pauri is an ancient tradition which cannot be stopped because of the virus threat and nor can Ganga Sabha advise people not to attend the aarti." "If the administration does not want pilgrims to gather in large numbers, it should ban their entry into the city," he further said.Rajesh Shivpuri, a member of the priest community as well as a senior Congress worker, said that "the bogey of coronavirus is being raised by the government in a bid to cover up its failures on most fronts and divert people's attention from key issues." "Coronavirus is no menace. Only the government is portraying it as such," he alleged. Akhil Bharatiya Sant Samiti spokesperson Baba Hathyogi meanwhile endorsed the government step saying that the number of pilgrims gathering for aarti should be restricted. "Faith is important, but no less important is science. We must take precautions as recommended by experts to check the spread of coronavirus," he said.

Title: Madhya Pradesh declares Covid-19 a ‘notifiable disease’
Content: BHOPAL: The Madhya Pradesh government on Wednesday declared novel coronavirus (Covid-19) as an infectious disease for the entire state. In the midst of political crises in the state, making a disease legally notifiable allows for intervention to control the spread of highly infectious diseases.A notifiable disease is any disease that is required by law to be reported to government authorities. The collation of information allows the authorities to monitor the disease and provides early warning of possible outbreaks. Any failure to report a notifiable disease is a criminal offence and the state government can take necessary action against defaulters.According to the notification issued by the Department of Public Health and Family Welfare , the action has been taken under Section 50 of the Madhya Pradesh Public Health Act 1949.On Wednesday, MP chief secretary M Gopal Reddy directed all district collectors to take measures prevent the spread of Covid-19. Two people were placed under quarantine in Ujjain. The couple have a travel history to Thailand. Five others, including those suspected for Covid-19 in Bhopal on Tuesday, were still under isolation. Test reports of all are still awaited, said a health department official.“With the mutual consent of the common people, make effective efforts to keep the crowd low at social and religious events,” said Reddy, according to a government press release. He was reviewing the ongoing activities to prevent the spread of novel coronavirus infection in the state through a video conference in the ministry.Principal secretary, MP health department, Pallavi Jain Govil, informed that continuous screening of passengers coming from the countries affected by the novel coronavirus is being conducted. In this context, Madhya Pradesh has strengthened the surveillance and control measures against the disease. MP has not reported any Covid-19 positive case so far.

Title: Coronavirus scare: 52 Indians stranded in Warsaw for three days
Content:
JAIPUR: 52 Indians including a few students, who have been stranded at the Poland’s capital Warsaw for the past three days after their flights got rescheduled thrice, have appealed to the Indian government to facilitate their return at the earliest. “If the government doesn’t help, where do we go?” asked one of the passengers.

So far, nearly 250 positive cases of coronavirus and five deaths have been recorded in Poland.

Pridhi Aggarwal (21), a student of Birla Institute of Management and Technology, Greater Noida, who is on a students’ exchange trip to the University of Warsaw along with three others, has through a video appealed to the government to help them.

The Indians were supposed to return on a Polish airlines flight at a rescheduled time (11.55 pm) on March 17, but that too was cancelled at the last moment.

“There are around 52 people stuck at Warsaw airport. Please help in a crisis situation,” Aggarwal tweeted on Tuesday. “Please help us out. We are stuck at Warsaw airport.”

“The flight scheduled for today (Tuesday) LO 8515 is said to be cancelled since it did not get permission from @DGCAIndia. We want help to get back to our home country,” she added.

Earlier she had tweeted, “20 people are at stranded at Warsaw airport . We would request @DGCAIndia to allow us to board the Lot Flight 8515. We request our country to help us out in this crisis situation. @DrSJaishankar @PMOIndia @PLL_RBLX.”

Her father Harsh Aggarwal, who is a resident of Model town in New Delhi, said he had tried to contact the Prime Minister's Office (PMO), external affairs minister S Jaishankar and Union health minister Harsh Vardhan, but didn’t get any positive response.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Lucknow: Bookings nixed, kalyan mandaps to be isolation units for patients
Content: LUCKNOW: Lucknow Municipal Corporation on Wednesday cancelled bookings in eight Kalyan Mandaps (community marriage centres) for next one month to turn them into isolation units, to be used for suspected and confirmed novel coronavirus infections if the number of cases rises dramatically.The decision was taken after mayor Sanyukta Bhatia met chief medical officer Dr Narendra Agarwal.Bhatia said city has 12 Kalyan Mandaps, of which bookings in eight have been cancelled for a month. As many as 200 isolation beds can be arranged in these centres, she added.At present, there are 188 isolation beds in the government and government-aided hospitals in the city and efforts are underway to create 500 more beds in other parts of the city, said CMO. After adding Kalyan Manaps, the number of isolations bed would be 888, said CMO.On masks being thrown in the open after use, Dr Agarwal said used masked are a medical waste and can be a source of infection.“To tackle this problem we have decided to make people aware and deploy a separate team for collecting used masks dumped in the open,” mayor said.

Title: Lawyers’ body asks lawyers to avoid court unless urgent
Content:
Vadodara: Two days after the district court exempted litigants from appearing in-person for their cases in court, Baroda Bar Association has now appealed to lawyers as well to not come to court till March 31 unless there is an urgent hearing needed.

President of Baroda Bar Association Hasmukh Bhatt appealed all lawyers in city through a letter on Wednesday to not come to the court in the wake of coronavirus pandemic.

Bhatt said that lawyers should come to court only if they have hearings for regular bails and anticipatory bails for their clients. “No bailable or non-bailable warrant will be issued by court even if lawyers do not remain present for hearing,” Bhatt said. The case will start at the same stage where it was adjourned in the previous hearings.

The new dates for the cases will reflect on the e-courts portal 12 hours in advance. On March 16, principal district judge M R Mengdey had issued a circular exempting litigants and even lawyers from appearing in court following guidelines issued by the Gujarat high court. Advocates too were requested to spend less time in bar library and advocates house.

Title: Four suspects admitted at SSG, Gotri hospitals
Content:
131 fresh individuals were screened at the centre in SSG hospital

Vadodara: Four persons including a husband-wife duo are currently under isolation at two government hospitals in the city after they showed symptoms similar to that of coronavirus (COVID-19).

At the state-run SSG Hospital, two individuals have been admitted in the isolation ward.

Of these, one middle-aged male, a resident of Makarpura, has travel history of Spain, while another is a female who has recently returned from United States. The 49-year-old Makarpura resident was admitted late on Tuesday night.

“We have sent samples of both these patients to Ahmedabad, results are awaited,” said Dr Rajeev Daveshwar, medical superintendent of SSG Hospital.

He added that by Wednesday late evening 131 fresh individuals were screened at the screening centre that has been set up at the hospital. “The screening centre is being run 24x7,” he said.

At GMERS Gotri Medical College, a husband-wife duo who had returned from Dubai on Sunday, were admitted in the isolation ward on Wednesday.

“We are treating them as suspected cases after they showed some symptoms similar to that of COVID-19. They are presently undergoing observation and we have sent their samples to Ahmedabad for test, results of which are awaited,” said Dr Vishala Pandya, medical superintendent of GMERS Gotri Hospital. “Wednesday was the first day when we started screening at the Gotri medical college. We have created a flu OPD where patients with fever, cough and cold are being screened,” said Dr Uday Tilawat, chief district health officer, adding that on the first day, nearly eight individuals were screened at the hospital where an isolation ward with ten beds capacity has been created.

Title: Secunderabad-Raxaul Exp derails near Butibori; passengers safe
Content:
The trolley of coach S-9 derailment took place when the train was moving at snail’s pace and hence, was halted... Read More

Nagpur: Passengers of Secunderabad-Raxual Express had a lucky escape after three wheels of a trolley of coach S-9 derailed near the Butibori yard around 7.30am on Wednesday.

Sources from Central Railways (CR) told TOI that the derailment took place when the train was moving at snail’s pace and hence, was halted soon. Passengers, who were asleep, experienced a slight jerk, but fortunately, none was injured.

Senior CR officials, including divisional railway manager, Somesh Kumar, rushed to the spot to take stock of the situation.

Railway spokesperson and assistant commercial manager (ACM) SG Rao said the reason behind the derailment is unclear. “We are investigating the cause of the accident. However, the rerailment of the train was done in a record 26 minutes. Nearly 1400-1500 passengers were on board and all were safe. Our doctors were also present at the accident site as well as the Nagpur railway station to provide medical assistance to passengers,” said Rao.

After coach S-9 was detached, passengers and their belongings were shifted to other coaches. Food and water were also provided to the passengers. The accident relief train also reached the site soon after the incident and rerailment was done. Initially, three front coaches were moved to Nagpur.

The remaining 16 coaches were later taken to Nagpur railway station at around 11.20am. Meanwhile, around 25 passengers were taken to Nagpur railway station by bus from Butibori. The train reached Nagpur station’s platform number 6 at around 11.50am.

Porters offered free service to the affected passengers. They quickly moved the luggage to the new bogie, a replacement for coach S-9.

The commercial staff, station staff and RPF personnel ensured that all the passengers got food. The entire restoration work was monitored by DRM Nagpur. The train left the station at around 12.20pm after a delay of over four hours.

Title: Three AP officials arrested by ACB
Content:
Vijayawada: Officials of the Anti-Corruption Bureau (ACB) on Wednesday arrested three officials in different locations in Andhra Pradesh for demanding and accepting bribes to carry out official favours.

The ACB unit of Nellore arrested Sayyed Jamsher Basha, a senior assistant at Kavali municipality for demanding and accepting a bribe of Rs 1 lakh from Ch Ramesh. In the second incident, C Krishnaiah was arrested for demanding and accepting a bribe of Rs 10,000 for processing the mutation and issuance of a pattadar passbook. ACB officials in East Godavari district arrested U Rajendra Prasad for accepting Rs 60,000 bribe for reassessment of central sales tax for 2016-17. TNN

Title: Coronavirus in Lucknow: Lucknow University devises digital tool for teachers
Content: LUCKNOW: As the city inches closer to a lockdown amid coronavirus outbreak, Lucknow University ’s education department has readied a special four-week online course to train teachers on use of digital tools, which will allow them to remotely hold classes.The massive open online course (MOOC) titled ‘Enhancing life skills through technology (EnList)’ has been developed after three years of research to help teachers integrate technology into education and give lectures or provide study materials virtually.The education department has started using EnList and the university is working on the modalities to make the course available on SWAYAM portal, developed by the HRD ministry.The research that gave birth to EnList was done by Shipra Srivastava, a scholar at LU’s education department, under the guidance of faculty member Kiran Lata Dangwal.Shipra conducted a survey of digital competence of around 450 teachers at six universities in UP, two central, two state-run and two private.Shipra said EnList was based on Web 2.0 tools, which are free interactive digital programmes for using blogs for interactive lectures, Android-based applications for PowerPoint presentations, and doing online evaluation, among other things.The four-week MOOC provides knowledge about blogging and can be used to effectively articulate and communicate views digitally through videos and content sharing.

Title: Metro installing solar panels atop stations at fast pace
Content:
Metro aims to install 14MW and so far 1MW has been installed

Nagpur: MahaMetro, which aims to meet 65% of its energy requirement from solar, is installing panels atop its stations at a fast pace. Its aim is to install total 14MW and so far 1MW has been installed and work is going on another 1.5MW.

A Metro spokesperson said that solar energy was a win-win situation for the agency. “A private operator installs the panels through Solar Energy Corporation of India (SECI), a central government undertaking. We don’t spend a penny on it. We just provide the space in our stations. The operator sells power to us when the panels are installed. We get electricity at less than half of MSEDCL’s power tariff,” he added.

“At present we are meeting 85% of our electricity requirement of our stations through solar. Panels have been installed atop six stations and Metro Bhavan. The average monthly generation is more than one lakh units. Till date we have exported over 2.5 lakh units of electricity to MSEDCL. More than 10.5 lakh units of solar energy has already been generated, which saved more than Rs82 lakh for Nagpur Metro Rail Project so far,” said the spokesperson.

He further said that work on installation at five Metro stations and two depots for 1.5MW capacity was in progress. “MahaMetro is in the process of signing agreements for development of another 3MW for upcoming 10 stations and depot buildings. More than 5MW will be installed by March 2021,” he added.

MahaMetro is one of the first Metro Rail agencies to go for solar energy right from inception. Many agencies started switching to solar when they were asked by central government and when their electricity bill ran into crores.

Going green helped MahaMetro secure loans worth around Rs4,500 crore from German agency KfW and French agency Agence Francaise de Developpment (AFD). According to the spokesperson, foreign lending agencies prefer projects that are green.

“We are using green energy wherever possible as our aim is to reduce pollution in Nagpur. Our feeder vehicles will run on electricity or LPG. Our stations have bio-digesters to recycle water. Our stations have got Indian Green Building Council (IGBC) ratings,” he added.

Title: Give paid leave to those quarantined: UP to firms
Content:
Noida: The Uttar Pradesh government has directed that all people kept in quarantine or isolation because of the novel coronavirus should be given mandatory paid leave by their organisations. It has also said that the state will bear the cost of treatment of all patients who test positive for Covid-19.

“All offices — government and private — will have to provide mandatory paid leave to employees in quarantine or isolation. The companies cannot avoid a state government order,” said B N Singh, district magistrate, Gautam Budh Nagar. Government spokesperson Shrikant Sharma said CM Yogi Adityanath had advised private firms to allow employees to work from home, “but in such a situation, they should be paid full salary”.

The order will have maximum impact in Noida, where most private and multinational companies that operate out of UP are located. So far, there are six confirmed cases of the novel coronavirus in Noida, Greater Noida and Ghaziabad and more than 10 people have been kept in isolation facilities. Around 500 people, including working professionals, have been put in home quarantine so far. Officials said all these residents will receive a certificate at the end of the 14-day quarantine.

Representatives from industry bodies said that while all government orders will be supported, it may be difficult to sustain companies if cases increase. “We are fully cooperating with all government directives and many companies have allowed leave as well as work-from-home option. However, entrepreneurs, especially MSMEs, are suffering economically already because of the virus scare. If it spreads to a point where we need to shut entire companies, it would be difficult to pay all staff with no output,” said Sudhir Srivastava, vice-president and spokesperson for Noida Entrepreneurs’ Association (NEA).

Sec 144 extended

The state government on Tuesday released an advisory for residents on social distancing and other steps needed to be taken by RWAs, offices, restaurants and government officials. The shutdown of all schools, colleges and universities has been extended till April 2. The imposition of Section 144 in the district, prohibiting all public gatherings, including political, cultural, religious, as well as sports programmes, was extended till April 5. In Gurgaon too, all restaurants at the popular Cyber Hub and One Horizon Center on Golf Course Road shut down on Wednesday.

One metre between tables

Meanwhile, restaurants have been advised keep outdoor seating if possible or with a distance of at least one metre between tables. They have also been asked to maintain hygiene, follow hand washing protocol and regularly clean things that are often touched, such as door handles and chairs.

Owners said that most restaurants are already following the guidelines. “It is not very difficult to maintain distance as restaurants are not seeing any crowd anymore. Many pubs, bars and cafes that had larger crowds have shut down since they did not have footfall or want large gatherings,” said Varun Khera, head of the National Restaurant Association of India in Noida.

Title: History-sheeter Aslam denied bail
Content:
Vadodara: Notorious history-sheeter Aslam Sheikh alias Aslam Bodiyo was denied bail on Tuesday by a sessions court in a case of extorting Rs 11 lakh from a general manager of a finance company.

Bodiyo had sought bail from the court claiming no involvement at all in the alleged extortion from the complainant Ashish Shinde. He told the court that he never met Shinde nor ever called him asking him to give the money. In his bail plea, Bodiyo said that the investigation in the case is over and other accused in the case have been granted bail by Gujarat high court. Thus, on the grounds of parity he also should allowed bail.

Opposing his bail application, additional public prosecutor Prakash Bhatt told the court that Bodiyo faces at least 59 cases of kidnapping, murder, assault, rioting and cheating in different police stations in Vadodara. If he will be allowed bail he will once again start his criminal activities, Bhatt argued.

Title: NZB: Kavitha files MLC nomination
Content:
Hyderabad: With chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao nominating K Keshava Rao and KR Suresh Reddy to fill two Rajya Sabha berths from Telangana, it was assumed his daughter, former Nizamabad MP Kalvakuntla Kavitha will have to wait for a longer time to become a lawmaker. But KCR sprang a surprise on Tuesday by announcing her candidature for the MLC seat under the Nizamabad local bodies.

Kavitha, who recently celebrated her birthday (March 13), could not have expected a better gift from the TRS president. Accordingly, she filed her nomination at Nizamabad collectorate on Wednesday. Polling for the local body MLC polls will be held on April 7 and counting will be taken up on April 9.

Kavitha suffered a defeat at the hands of BJP’s Dharmapuri Arvind in the Lok Sabha elections from Nizamabad, which was considered her pocketborough.

Speaking to the media, legislative affairs minister Vemula Prashanth Reddy said TRS would secure the seat with a huge majority. “Of the total 824 votes, both TRS and MIM have 532 votes. Congress has 140 and BJP has 85 votes. It is going to be a cakewalk for Kavitha,” he said. Apart from Prashanth, who accompanied her while filing the papers, party MPs and MLAs congratulated Kavitha.

Party sources see a silver lining as Kavitha could regain control of Nizamabad party affairs once she becomes the MLC.

Title: How Bikaner checked cholera spread in 1927
Content:
Jaipur: Similar to what the country is doing to contain coronavirus, the erstwhile Bikaner state had done to combat cholera in 1927.

It had sealed its border by framing an Act to fight the spread of the disease by restricting the entry of unwell persons and imposing a penalty on those who violated the law. The Act existed till Bikaner state still it merged with the Union of India and later in Rajasthan.

The Act named ‘Khatarnak Phelne wali Bimario ka Act (Infectious disease Act 1927) was passed by the Bikaner state assembly in view of the spread of two diseases—plague and cholera — under the reign of Maharaja Ganga Singh (1880-1943). The Act says it will be applicable once the state notified the outbreak or pre-empt the spread of any infectious disease in the state or the neighbouring state.

Documents at Rajasthan State Archives Bikaner suggest that how the Act helped the state preventing its people from the spread of any infectious disease till it was merged with India. “It shows the wit and commitment of the ruler who ruled the state close to 90 years ago by granting special powers to health workers and enforcement agencies to screen any suspected patient of any infectious disease,” said Mahendra Khadgawat, director of Rajasthan State Archives Bikaner.

At present, the country has banned the entry of foreigners and sealed its borders as an effective tool to stop the spread. The erstwhile rulers have also on occasions formed check-posts at borders screening the entry of outsiders, health workers at public places including the railway station, bus station, kutchery (Court) and other public places. “Great emphasis has been laid on creating awareness on the infectious disease by pasting posters, banners and verbal announcements. I don’t see any parallel of this visionary Act in India during the time the country was taking on Britishers,” said Khadgawat.

The country is yet to make the violators of stringent measures as a punishable offence, the former rulers have granted the special powers under the Act to run a legal case against them. Reportedly, Ganga Singh was among the first king to have introduced state assembly in then united India.

Title: Anti-CAA protests in Uttar Pradesh: Two more pay fine of over Rs 26,000
Content:
KANPUR: Two more people who were “identified for violence” during the anti-citizenship law protests in the city paid Rs 26,952 on Wednesday for the damage caused to the public and private property.

To recall, the district administration had issued notices to 21 people soon after the December 20 and 21 violence during the anti-CAA law protest after a damage of nearly Rs 2.83 lakh was assessed across the city by the police and the district administration.

“Two persons, identified as Mustafa of Anwarganj and Nadeem of Colonelganj, who were issued notices for the violence, paid Rs 26,952 on Wednesday,” said SP (East) Raj Kumar Agarwal .

Now, of the total 21 persons, 15 had paid dues amounting to Rs 2,02,140, he added.

Three persons had died of bullet injuries in the Babupurwa and Yateemkhana areas of the city on December 20 during the violent protests against the amended Citizenship Act. Several locals and policemen had suffered injuries.

Title: Gujarat: Three bundles of Class X answer sheets found on Virpur roadside
Content:
The education department has assured strict action

RAJKOT: Future of over 1,000 Class X students was at stake after three bundles of answer sheets of science exam conducted recently by the Gujarat education board were found on the road near Virpur on Gondal highway of Rajkot district on Wednesday.

What is more shocking is that at least 135 answer sheets were missing and more than a dozen sheets were soiled or damaged, said officials from the education department. Some answer sheets were damaged to such an extent that it was not possible to examine them, said the official.

The exam was held on March 7 and the answer sheets found by the roadside were yet to be evaluated, the official added.

The state education department has ordered a probe and assured strict action against staffers whose negligence resulted it the incident. Police are questioning one security guard and two employees of the Gujarat Secondary and Higher Secondary Education Board (GSHSEB), who were in-charge of transporting the answer sheets in a mini-bus from Mehsana to Keshod and other centres in Saurashtra region for checking.

The three bundles with 400 answer sheets each were found by staff members of a cement company who passing by in their staff bus. The company staffers took the bundles to their factory and informed the police.

GSHSEB chairman A J Shah said, “The bundles have been sent to a nearby school in Virpur. Those who were carrying acted irresponsibly and action will be taken against them. An inquiry committee headed by M A Pandya, commissioner of schools, will probe the incident. I have also ordered that an FIR be lodged against the two staffers and the security guard and a driver of the vehicles transporting the answer sheets.”

According to police, the answer sheet bundles is believed to have fallen from the open window of the running mini-bus. However, there are some witnesses claiming that the bundles were thrown out of the moving bus. Police are verifying the claims.

Education minister Bhupendrasinh Chudasama said, “A thorough investigation has been ordered to find out whether any more answer sheets were missing. Whether this happened accidentally or done deliberately will be found during the probe.”

Rana Bhojani, police sub-inspector of Virpur police station said, “We are verifying the details given by the district education officials. Based on which FIR will be filed.”

“After finding the missing answer sheets we will lodge a formal police complaint,” said Rajkot district education officer R S Upadhyay.

Title: Bhopal: Footfall at airport, stations drops by 50%; ticket cancellation up
Content: BHOPAL: The coronavirus scare has started affecting footfalls at the railway stations and airport in the state capital. In past one week, the footfall at Bhopal’s Raja Bhoj airport has come down to almost 50% while daily ticket cancellations have gone up by 50%. Notably, schools, colleges, gyms and other public places have been closed in Bhopal till March 31.After witnessing a daily footfall of around 4,000 passengers at Raja Bhoj airport for a couple of months last year, the corona scare has drastically reduced footfall in March this year.A senior airport official, not wishing to be named, said that the average daily footfall at the airport was recorded as around 2,000 passengers.“This has come down to just 1,000. All important measures are being taken to keep the passengers safe, but the coronavirus havoc is forcing them to sit at home,” he said.Footfall data suggested that on March 16, the footfall was 1,040. Just a day earlier, on March 15, the footfall was 1,555 while the March 13 footfall was 1,451. On March 14, the footfall was 1,674. The highest footfall at the airport in March was recorded at 1,868 on March 7.Airport officials said that the doctors’ unit is working at the airport for the screening of passengers.“Airport provides the list of passengers coming from abroad. A medical experts team then conducts the screening accordingly,” said an official of the department, on condition of anonymity.It is a similar situation at Bhopal and Habibganj stations. Due to the coronavirus scare, the graph of ticket cancellation in trains has also increased. In the last one week, additional tickets worth about Rs 5.5 lakh have been cancelled. This figure is only for Habibganj and Bhopal railway stations.From February 23 to 29, around 2,725 passengers from both stations cancelled tickets worth Rs 10.19 lakh.In comparison, the number of passengers cancelling tickets between March 9 and 15 was 4,207 who have cancelled tickets worth Rs 15.44 lakh, says dataRailway public relations officer, I A Siddiqui, said that tickets worth Rs 1.45 lakh are cancelled on both these stations during normal days, whereas the figure has reached Rs 2.20 lakh daily for the last one week.

Title: All six isolated at government hospital test negative for Covid-19
Content: COIMBATORE: The public health department on Wednesday confirmed that all the six people, who were admitted at the isolated ward at Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital (CMCH), tested negative for Covid-19 The swab samples of a 35-year-old man from Udumalpet with travel history to Singapore, a 67-year-old woman with travel history to Kottayam , two French nationals , a teenager from Mettupalayam and a resident of Cheranmanagar were sent to the King Institute in Chennai for tests.Public health department officials confirmed that all the six patients tested negative.The 35-year-old man from Udumalpet landed in the city from Singapore last week.Since he had fever and symptoms of flu, he was admitted to the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital on Monday.The 67-year-old woman from Valparai had visited Kottayam last week. She was suffering from a cold and fever since then and wanted to get tested.The 15-year-old boy from Mettupalayam had returned from the UAE and had low grade fever on and off for the past 10 days. He had high fever for the past two days. The two French nationals reached the district on Tuesday evening for Ayurveda treatment at a centre and were referred to the CMCH.When asked about news reports that at least three more people had approached CMCH with symptoms of Covid-19 and local travel history, dean of the hospital Dr B Ashokan said he did not know about any such cases.

Title: Cab drivers’ desperate plea: Suspend our EMIs
Content:
Covid-19 has dealt a body blow to drivers operating on the app-based platforms

NEW DELHI: Sanjay Kumar* (42) who drives a cab for a living is dreading the first week of April — that’s when the monthly instalment for his cab’s loan is due.

“I’m afraid that this virus is going to finish me, one way or the other,” said Kumar. “Initially I was afraid of getting infected by a passenger; now I’m afraid of not getting any passenger.”

Covid-19, the disease caused by novel coronavirus, has dealt a body blow to most drivers operating on the app-based platforms. They are definitely scared of infection. But now with educational institutions also shut in addition to cinema halls, malls and tourist places, and many private companies asking employees to work from home, it’s their livelihood that is at stake.

“Paying the EMI every month is a big burden. Even before this virus started affecting work, I had to work 12 hours or more to earn enough to run my house,” Kumar said. “There is hardly any work now even during morning and evening peak hours. There is just no passenger,” he rued. “If the situation remains this way, not only I won’t be able to pay my EMI but will also not be able to feed my family.”

The Sarvodaya Driver Association of Delhi has decided to request Delhi government to intervene.

“We are going to meet chief minister Arvind Kejriwal to request him to help us in getting EMIs postponed for a month or two. We don’t want the banks to waive it off but just to postpone it,” said Kamaljeet Gill, its president. “We are the backbone of NCR’s transport system and are requesting for some help in this tough time. We also want the app-based cab aggregators not to charge commissions now as the income is already down,” he added.

Both Ola and Uber, the cab aggregators, refused to comment about any dip in the demand or any step to help drivers.

Gill claimed the companies were not even providing masks or sanitisers. “The association is providing sanitisers to as many drivers as possible. They are bringing bottles and we are filling these with sanitisers at different points,” he said.

“I’m wearing a mask for my own safety and also to assure passengers that my cab is safe. I got the mask after great difficulties,” said Ajay Sharma, another driver. “I open doors for passengers so that they don’t have to touch the door handle. Many ask us to open the windows as they feel ventilation will help them avoid any infection," he said. "I’m willing to entertain all requests as long as I’m getting passengers.”

*Names of drivers have been changed on request

Title: MSU’s statistics dept sees record campus placements
Content:
Vadodara: Even before they clear their final year exams of masters in science (MSc) in May this year, students of department of statistics under faculty of science at MS University have started bagging job offers.

Out of 32 students in the current batch, 15 students have already got placed in reputed firms through campus placements as the department is heading towards a record number of placements this year.

Market research major, Nielsen, has selected four students offering them Rs six lakh per annum package and another ten students with Rs 3.15 lakh per annum packages. Another city-based firm, Numerator, has picked up a student with Rs four lakh per annum salary.

“Every year, students of statistics get placed through campus placement but this year the response is much better compared to previous years,” said professor Hari Kataria, dean of faculty of science.

“We are heading towards a record number of placements as statisticians are getting more opportunities these days. Earlier, a handful of students used to get placed through campus placement. The rest would gradually get jobs within a period of six months to a year of clearing their exams,” said placement coordinator Dr Rupal Shah.

Title: 20 buses for quarantine run
Content: On Wednesday evening, two senior deputy municipal commissioners Om Prakash and K B Thakkar were rushed to the city airport for setting up transportation facility and to spruce up fever screening facility at the airport . “We ask flyers to self-declare their travel history, any symptoms, and if they took paracetamol before leaving the aircraft,” said an AMC official. Twenty BRTS and AMTS buses have been deployed to take flyers with Covid-19 symptoms to a nearby quarantine.

Title: We too are at risk: Bhopal college & school teachers demand leaves
Content: BHOPAL: School and college teachers have demanded leaves after campuses were closed in the state capital in view of the Coronavirus scare. They feel that like students , they too are vulnerable and need to be given leaves.Teachers said it did not make sense to ask them to be on campus when classes were not being held. “We are also humans. Why are authorities forcing us to come to schools and colleges when students are not there due to the corona scare? Are we made up of steel? We have also family. What happens if a teacher gets exposed to coronavirus? Please give us leaves,” said a teacher, on condition of anonymity.Another teacher, not wishing to be named, said, “We are asked to attend the school full time. By asking us to attend schools, we are forced to be exposed to the coronavirus. Today, they have given leaves to students. What will happen tomorrow if teachers are exposed to the coronavirus? Who will teach students in the class?”It was a similar sitution with college teachers. “We are doing nothing in colleges. Is is strange that cinemas in Bhopal are closed, but teachers are asked to attend campus. What exactly do authorities want to achieve by doing this?” said a college teacher, not wanting to be named.When contacted, school education and higher education department authorities refused to comment on the issue.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Fertilizer company director shoots self
Content:
KANPUR: Sushil Kumar Joshi (45), director of Kanpur Fertilizers & Chemicals Limited , committed suicide at company’s guest house under the limits of Cantt police station on Wednesday.

Joshi, who was a resident of Swaroop Nagar , shot himself with his licenced revolver at the company’s guest house near Navsheel apartment in Cantt area of the city.

Joshi was rushed to a private Hospital in Sarvodaya Nagar , where he succumbed during treatment.

Police confirmed that Joshi committed suicide by shooting himself in the temple. The body was sent to mortuary for postmortem. The reason which prompted him to take the extreme step was yet to be ascertained.

“Sushil Kumar Joshi was a director of Kanpur Fertilizers & Chemicals Limited located in Panki. On Wednesday after arriving at company’s guest house near Navsheel apartment, he asked for a glass of water from a waiter. After having a glass of water, he went to the toilet, where he shot himself. Hearing the gunshot, his colleagues and other employees rushed to the toilet where Joshi was found lying unconscious in a pool of blood on the floor. His licenced revolver was was lying close to him. Forensic experts recovered an empty cartridge near the door of the toilet. The bullets entry and exit wounds could be seen in his head,” said CO Cantt RK Chaturvedi.

He was immediately taken to a private hospital in Sarvodaya Nagar where he died during the treatment.

Inspector Cantt Aadesh Kumar said Joshi’s body has been placed in the mortuary and the police were trying to speak to his family members, particularly his wife Menka, to ascertain the exact reason which prompted him to resort to extreme step.

Title: Kanpur:Minor’s rape-murder: 1,600 mobiles under surveillance
Content:
KANPUR: Following rape and strangulation of a nine-year-old girl on March 10, police have put nearly 1600 mobile numbers in Bihar police area of Unnao district under surveillance after they have found that the same count of mobile phones were functional in the village on the day the incident.

SP North (Unnao) Vinod Kumar Pandey told TOI that the police have procured the family profile of each and every mobile phone user across the village and are monitoring their activities to zero-in on the perpetrators of the crime.

“We are also scanning such mobile phones that were used to capture photos and the video footage of the ‘ Phaag ’ singing programme held in the vicinity which the girl had gone to witness on the occasion of Holi. Six police teams, comprising 12-13 personnel, have been formed for the task”, the SP added.

To recall, a 9-year-old girl succumbed to her injuries in a hospital in Kanpur after she was sexually assaulted and strangled on the day of Holi festival by an unidentified man in Bihar’s Bighapur area of Unnao on March 10.

The incident had occurred when the girl, a student of class V, had gone to witness ‘Phaag’, a singing event held in the vicinity on Holi.

Investigations had revealed that the accused, after luring the minor, took her to a nearby field where she was raped.

The locals informed the family members after they found the girl lying unconscious in a field. The police said that the girl was raped after which the rapist tried to kill her by strangulating her in order to conceal his identity. The police, on being informed, rushed the girl to the district hospital from where she was referred to a hospital in Kanpur where she died the same night.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Gujarat: Education department orders Kutch University’s suspension over 'strip test'
Content:
College conducted a strip test on 68 girl students to check if they were in their periods

RAJKOT: The Kutch university has issued a show cause notice to Sahjanand Girls Institute of Bhuj on Wednesday asking the college authorities to reply within 24 hours why its affiliation should not be suspended. The move follows the state education department’s order to suspend the college’s affiliation after the inglorious episode of its authorities forcing 68 girls to undergo a ‘strip test’ to check their menstrual status last month .

The four female staff members, including the principal of the college, Rita Raniga, who herself led the demeaning exercise, were arrested and later released on bail. The other three staffers were Anita Chohan, Ramila Hirani and Nayna Gorasia.

Vice-chancellor of Kutch university, Darshna Dholakia told TOI, “We have issued the show cause notice following the state education department’s order. We will take further decision after the college authorities reply on Thursday.” However, she had no answer when asked about the future of the existing students if the varsity suspends its affiliation.

The college is run by the rules of Swaminarayan sect and its trustees, after the shameful incident came on the back foot, promising not to enforce the rules on the girl students.

The issue that TOI highlighted made headlines for its torture on the female students started with the discovery of a “used sanitary pad” found in the garden outside the college’s hostel premises. This led to an inglorious chapter of ignominy when the girl students were forced by the four female teachers to undress and were checked if they were having periods.

The episode opened the Pandora’s box on how the college was also forcing the girls to remain in isolation during the menstrual period in a basement and forced to sleep in a dingy room alone. The girls came out in the open with the trauma they had to undergo every single month, which forced a few to hide facts in order to skip this rigourous ordeal. The four staff members are also facing suspension from the college and inquiry ordered by NCW.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Ahmedabad: Schools closed, teachers ask why they can’t stay home
Content: AHMEDABAD: “So what are teachers doing in school, when there are no students? The academic year is over and reports have been given. Are we waiting to get infected?” a city based educator asked the state chief secretary on Wednesday through an email.She has further asked whether more than 60 staff gathering in a school doesn’t amount to a public gathering given the government has appealed to citizens to avoid social gatherings, and going to malls among taking other precautionary steps.The mail was sent as the schools across the state have been closed since March 16 as a precautionary measure to check spread of Covid-19, but the teaching and other staff continue reporting to duty. Most of the schools have staff between 70 and 250 people. Even though the government has clearly instructed people to stay away from gatherings and quarantine themselves at home, it seems educators, and school administration are immune from Covid-19 infections.Speaking to TOI, Gujarat government’s education secretary (primary and Secondary education) Vinod Rao said, “Covid-19 has been declared a “notified disaster” and all essential service providers will continue to provide service as before. Teachers fall in essential service providers and cannot shun their responsibility just like the army, police and doctors cannot.”A teacher said, “We have a staff of 200 and everyone is coming to school. We are working in advance for the next academic session.” She adds, “We educators, are never on leave, whether its Covid-19 or anything else.” Pointing out that work for this academic session is almost over, another educator said, “Even if one of us is infected, we will be putting all others and their families at risk.”SGVP principal Padma Kumar said, “From Day 1, we made it clear that if any educator is unwell, they need not report to school, and we have five people working from home.” She added, “This is the time when we upload revision tests and worksheets for students and educators are doing that from school, besides taking online classes, taking online trainings and preparing schedules for next year.”

Title: 20 injured as bus falls on its side near Andhiyur
Content:
Representative image

A private bus carrying about 40 passengers fell on its side on the Andhiyur-Bhavani state highway in Erode district on Wednesday. Police said 20 passengers were injured in the incident, which happened when the driver lost control of the vehicle at a blind turn.

“V Sakthivel of Ramapuram was on the wheels of the bus that was heading to Erode from Andhiyur via Bhavani . When the bus neared Kuttaimedu on the Andhiyur-Bhavani state highway, the driver lost control of the vehicle. It hit an electric pillar and fell on its side,” a senior police officer attached to the Velli Tirupur police station said.

“As many as 20 passengers suffered injuries. They were taken to the government hospital at Bhavani. Some of them were referred to the Erode government hospital,” the officer said.

Title: Pune’s first Covid-19 patients off medicines, wait for quarantine to end
Content: PUNE: Ten days after a couple and their daughter were placed in quarantine at the Naidu hospital on March 9 after they tested positive for coronavirus , they have been put off medication amid signs that they are recovering well.All three are waiting for the mandatory quarantine period to get over so that they can get back to their normal lives. “We are feeling fit and have no health complaints,” the couple told TOI on Wednesday.A doctor from Naidu hospital who has been treating them said, "The couple and their daughter will be among the first to be discharged. As per the discharge policy, their throat swab samples will be tested twice within 24 hours. If they test negative in both the tests, they will be allowed to go home."The husband said his colleagues at work were waiting for him to resume office after his discharge. All three have been undergoing treatment under the watchful eyes of the doctors at the hospital.“Since Monday, the doctors have stopped giving us any medicines. We have completed our course which was extended for two days as a precautionary step. We were responding well and had no health complaints,” the husband said.The couple’s son tested negative but was also quarantined at Naidu Hospital in another building as precaution. He too will be discharged soon.“We have to follow the protocol so that others outside do not suffer. The doctors have been checking out blood pressure, pulse rate and other parameters which is more routine. They are happy with our progress so it is just the waiting period that we are undergoing,” the husband added.But the quarantine has weighed on them. They had run out of ideas for spending time at the hospital, he added.“How much are we going to read and watch shows on cellphones? It gets boring at times. But, there are a few other patients here who are progressing well and we often sit in the evenings and chat. That way we get to know each other and we share our thoughts,” he said.Many of the quarantined patients, he added, were disconnected with the outside world and had refused to read the news or forwards on social media to keep a healthy mind.“We speak to our friends over the phone and they tell us about what is happening but we prefer to stay disconnected,” he said.

Title: Assignments on website, lectures via videoconferencing
Content:
Campus life paused: Students were seen vacating the VNIT campus on Tuesday

Nagpur: As the coronavirus epidemic looms large over the city, almost all the educational institutions have stopped academic activities and asked their students to stay at home. Some premier colleges have come out with innovative concepts to keep their students busy in what they termed as “forced break”.

At Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology (VNIT), which is home to largest number of outstation students, the administration asked students to complete some assignments which would be uploaded on its website. “All over 3,500 students have now reached their respective homes after being told to evacuate hostels. We’ve told them that they can’t be sitting home ideally, as we would be providing them with assignments which would last for two weeks till the college is closed,” director Pramod Padole told TOI.

He added that the students would be told to read and prepare some part of the syllabus so that when the classes resumed it would be easy for the lecturers to explain the subject. “Moreover, assignments would also be posted on the website and the students have been told to monitor it regularly,” the director said.

The All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS), Nagpur, has asked students to stay at their hostels and not to venture out. “We are conducting classes with the help of PowerPoint presentation and video conferencing. Since our syllabus is vast, we are using technology to conduct theory lectures. Proper care is being taken to ensure students remain inside our secured campus. We as doctors can’t stop treating patients,” director Vibha Dutta told TOI.

In the wake on unprecedented situation after the Covid-19 outbreak, the students staying in various hostels were told to vacate the premises and stay at home at least till March 31.

Nagpur University has already stopped all classes and also told its affiliated colleges to follow the suit. The university has also directed students staying in its hostels at Law College Square and PG hostel near campus to vacate rooms.

“Directives have already been issued in this regard and majority of them have left for home. As per the government’s directives, summer examinations commencing from March 19, comprising over 180 papers are already deferred and the students should utilize this extra time to study for their papers,” registrar Neeraj Khaty and exam director Prafulla Sable told TOI.

At Symbiosis International University (SIU), about 417 students staying in hostels were sent back home. “Most of them are from the MBA programme. Some faced problems while getting tickets, but eventually, we ave closed all four schools,” said SIBM director Shrirang Altekar.

Even at National Law University (NLU), about 450 hostel students left on their own after classes were suspended. “We allowed them to go home. Even the administration is working for just four hours,” registrar Ramesh Kumar said.

Indian Institute of Information Technology (IIIT) director Omprakash Kakde said that over 200 students have vacated the hostels after academic activities were suspended. Similarly, at IIM, about 230 students left from the hostels for their respective homes after being told so, according to spokesperson Anagha Wankhede.

Title: VMC’s attempts to get thermal guns go blank
Content:
Vadodara: The Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) is hunting for infrared forehead thermometers or thermal guns at all its urban health centres (UHC). It has also received requests from other government offices to provide them with the device so that the temperatures of visitors and employees entering the premises can be measured.

However, the civic body is in a quandary as the supply of thermal guns has evaporated with the rise in the pandemic scare. Vendors have tried approaching sellers across the country, but have not been able to lay hands on a single device.

“We have reached out to distributors and even importers to get some such devices, but have not been successful,” said a supplier. The vendors have been working on procurement since Tuesday, but with little success.

The VMC, which has 34 UHCs, wants to allot two such thermal guns to each UHC to measure temperature of patients coming there. The decision is being taken to segregate those coming to the UHC with fever apart from other symptoms of an upper respiratory infection.

These patients would be segregated and kept away from the others to ensure that others do not get infected in case a COVID-19 patient approaches the UHC.

The civic body has already started making separate queues and making patients with a history of an upper respiratory infection with fever sit separately at UHCs.

This is, however, being done only on the basis of what the patients tell a staffer and not after measuring their temperature.

Title: Covid-19: Gujarat govt to telecast lectures for Class VII-XI
Content:
Representative image

GANDHINAGAR: To ensure that students don’t suffer for not attending school due to the Covid-19 pandemic, the state government will be telecasting lectures for Classes VII-XI from March 19 to 28 through regional television channels and Doordarshan . This will help students revise their syllabi at home.

According to officials in the state department of information this arrangement was made by CM Vijay Rupani . For Class VII, lectures will be telecast on Science, English and Maths from 12 to 4pm on various regional news channels, while for Class XI the telecast will be from 11am to 6pm.

The government said that for Classes VII to IX lectures will be telecast only for Mathematics, English and Science while for Class XI they will be on Chemistry, Physics and Biology. Regional channels telecasting lectures for Class XI will also telecast lectures on Maths on March 27 and on Accountancy on March 28. Lectures for Clas XI will also be telecast from Doordarshan, Ahmedabad, from 3pm to 4pm.

Title: Coronavirus News Delhi: Manjinder Singh Sirsa urges Arvind Kejriwal to help out daily wagers
Content:
Arvind Kejriwal (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Delhi Sikh Gurdwara Management Committee president Manjinder Singh Sirsa on Wednesday appealed to chief minister Arvind Kejriwal, asking him to deposit some money into the accounts of daily wage labourers who were now unemployed due to the novel coronavirus outbreak.

Sirsa claimed that footfall of these labourers seeking langar at gurdwaras had increased considerably over the past few weeks, putting them and others at the risk of contracting Covid-19.

The Shiromani Akali Dal functionary said most labourers had no money to buy food for their family, leaving them with no option but to approach gurdwaras.

“The number of people coming to gurdwaras has increased manifold. We have absolutely no problem in serving the community and our gates will remain open to as many people as possible. However, the greater challenge is to prevent large gatherings and putting more people at risk,” Sirsa said on Wednesday.
