Title: Fake sanitizer making unit raided in Nagpur
Content:
Representative image

NAGPUR: In a joint operation, Sitabuldi police and officials from Food and Drugs Administration (FDA) on Wednesday raided a factory allegedly manufacturing fake hand sanitizers in Pakodewala gully.

Police have seized around 1,000 bottles of fake sanitizers worth Rs10,400.

The cops have also seized some chemicals and sent the samples to FDA laboratory for analysis.

“We had received a tipoff about an illegal unit manufacturing hand sanitizers. The cops roped in FDA officials and a joint team raided the unit. We are now awaiting test result from FDA officials to register an offence against the accused,” said senior PI of Sitabuldi police station JN Rajput .

The police are now trying to find out from where the accused had brought the chemicals to be sold as hand sanitizer.

Since the outbreak of Covid-19, demand for hand sanitizers and face masks has skyrocketed. Many miscreants are trying to cash in on the soaring demand by selling spurious chemicals as hand sanitizers.

Earlier, Gittikhadan police had arrested two persons who were selling fake sanitizers to medical store owners.

Title: Uttarakhand: Some BJP legislators ‘disturbed’ over ‘government’s SC/ST move’
Content:
DEHRADUN: Some BJP legislators belonging to reserved seats are said to be “disturbed” by the impact of the government ’s move on SC/ST communities who were availing the benefit of reservation in promotion in the hill state.

The state has 15 reserved assembly constituencies and one parliamentary constituency, and reservation in promotion has always been a thorny subject. Party sources told TOI that senior BJP leaders have been always “divided over the matter”.

BJP legislator Khajan Das said, “I am a staunch supporter of the reservation in promotion which was in practise earlier in Uttarakhand . I will again take up the matter with CM and senior members of the core committee.”

Das did not comment on political impact the government’s decision would cause but hinted at the low political dividends. “The decision will antagonise the reserved category across the state and may send a negative signal,” Das said.

Another BJP legislator Deshraj Karnwal viewed the decision as a personal setback. “I am personally saddened by the development. In the state assembly, I had supported the reservation in promotion but today I do not know how to react on this development,” said Karnwal.

BJP spokesperson and MLA Munna Singh Chauhan said, “The state government will take care of the interest of all government employees in Uttarakhand.”

Meanwhile, some BJP MLAs had been putting pressure on the CM to accede to the protesting employees’ demands of scraping the reservation in promotion.

Title: Rajkot relieved as Narmada water flows into Aji-1 dam
Content:
Dam filled with Narmada water

Rajkot: Narmada water has started flowing into Aji-1 dam from Wednesday. Responding to the Rajkot Municipal Corporation ’s (RMC) request last week, the state government released the water under SAUNI ( Saurashtra Narmada Avtaran Irrigation) scheme to solve the city’s water shortage.

The RMC wanted the water to provide uninterrupted 20-minute water supply to the citizens every day.

According to a statement issued by the Rajkot Mayor Bina Acharya the state government will give 600 mcft water in Aji-1 dam in the coming days. The current level in Aji-1 is 287 mcft water which will last till March 31.

The irrigation department will pour 35-40 mcft water in Aji-1 dam every day and it is expected that in the next 20 days the dam will be full with 600 mcft water. The RMC takes 60 percent water of its daily requirement from the Aji-1 dam.

The irrigation department will pour 300 mcft water in Nyari-1 dam after Aji-1. The water in Nyari-1 dam will last till the end of the April. The city requires 280 MLD water per day and the demand is expected to increase in peak summer.

Title: Health department seeks action against healer Baskar in Coimbatore
Content: COIMBATORE: The district health department has written to collector K Rajamani to act against healer Baskar for reportedly spreading false information about Covid-19.He had reportedly released an audio clip stating that the Covid-19 outbreak was a depopulation measure ordered by the ‘Illuminati’ across the globe and claimed that all the people isolated would be eliminated later.Meanwhile, police said they were working on verifying the audio clip. Baskar is likely to be picked up for inquiries.Healer Baskar, a self-proclaimed medical practitioner, was arrested in 2018 for promoting delivery of babies at home, which is banned in the state.The health department says that Baskar is instilling fear and panic among the people over the virus.In the audio clip which went viral on social media, Baskar claimed Tamil Nadu would soon witness a situation like China, Italy, and Germany. While claiming that the coronavirus outbreak as a third World War, he warned that the health department would soon reach out to people door-to-door to isolate them.Deputy director of health services G Ramesh Kumar said, “We have requested the collector to take action against him for spreading false information and creating panic.” Ramesh said the representation is made based on the Tamil Nadu Public Health Act, 1939, and section 54 (punishment for false warning) of the Disaster Management Act, 2005.

Title: Covid-19: Salem region steps up preventive measures
Content: SALEM: All the district administrations in Salem region have stepped up measures to contain the spread of coronavirus (Covid-19).Salem collector S A Raman visited Kolathur on Salem-Mysuru national highway on Wednesday morning and monitored the disinfection drive. Talking to the media, he said health department officials were spraying disinfectant on vehicles that were coming from Karnataka. “They are also checking the passengers for fever and cold. If tested positive, they will be moved to special wards for further proceedings.” Salem Municipal Corporation commissioner R Sadheesh , meanwhile, opened a help desk at the Salem central new bus stand on Wednesday. He said sanitary workers were spraying disinfectant on all buses. “They will also apply sanitizers on passengers. I have appealed the passengers to approach the help desk for any medical assistance.”In Erode, collector C Kathiravan postponed the Sri Bannari Amman Temple festival that is usually celebrated from March 23 to April 13. “However, there will be puja on March 23. The festival will be held on some other occasion after containing Covid-19 spread.” He also appealed the public to alert police of any movement of foreigners or people from other states. He said the public could reach the district administration on toll free number 1077 for any medical assistance.On his part, Dharmapuri collector S Malarvizhi visited the town bus stand and monitored the disinfectant spraying activity. She also distributed handouts to passengers, detailing preventive measures to safeguard them from Covid-19.While Krishnagiri collector S Prabhakar visited Hosur and inspected the health department cell, Namakkal collector K Megraj inspected the entire district and monitored the disinfectant spraying activity.

Title: Maharashtra mantralaya lockdown due to Covid-19 hits egg export from Namakkal hard
Content:
Representative image

NAMAKKAL: Egg exporters in the district are staring at a huge loss as shipments to Oman, Qatar and UAE have been stuck at various stages of transit in the absence of clearance from the home ministry officials in Maharashtra.

Having gone into lockdown mode in the wake of Covid-19 outbreak, the Maharashtra mantralaya won’t be accessible to the exporters till March 31.

Pointing out that nearly one crore eggs worth Rs 5 crore have been at various stages of transit from the Mumbai port, the exporters said the cargoes can’t either be brought back or delivered at the end destinations in the present scenario. “They are likely to go waste,” an exporter said.

According to Dr P V Senthil, a leading egg exporter and general secretary of Livestock Agri Farmers’ Trade Association, they have to get export documents attested by both the chamber of commerce in Mumbai and Maharashtra home ministry officials before submitting them to the consulates of Oman, Qatar or UAE. “Only then they would accept the documents and issue papers to deliver the shipment in their countries.”

However, with access to the home ministry office restricted till March 31, the exporters have no other option to get the clearance papers for now.

“Without any prior intimation, officials simply closed the home ministry office. Sans its attestation, the documents and containers will not be accepted by the consulates of Oman, Qatar or UAE. The whole shipment is likely to go waste as eggs come with an expiry date,” Senthil said.

He said many containers had reached the destination, while the remaining were in transit. “The exporters are badly affected as most consulates are in Mumbai. If we won’t be able to deliver the cargoes in time, it will affect the country’s credibility also.”

The exporters have sought the intervention of both the state and central governments to find a solution to the issue. “On behalf of all exporters and in the national interest, we humbly pray the state and central governments to kindly make arrangements to accept the documents for attestation. This could be done at the entrance gate of mantralaya, where a staff member could collect the documents and return them the next day. Even token system is appreciated,” another exporter said.

Mohan Kumaramangalam , honorary president, Livestock Agri Farmers’ Trade Association, said the lockdown of Maharashtra mantralaya has hit the export of many agriculture, poultry, meat and food products worth several thousands of crores. “It will badly hit our economy and global trade. Appropriate steps should be taken at the earliest to ensure smooth export business,” he said.

Title: MSMEs see bleak year ahead as overseas clients turn cautious
Content:
COIMBATORE: Due to the travel ban in place to prevent the spread of Covid-19, industry representatives from abroad have stopped visiting the district, say micro , small and medium industrialists , who fear that there would be no orders in the coming months.

Industrialists here are now working on the orders they got in the beginning of the month, president of the Coimbatore Sidco Industrial Estate Manufacturer's Welfare Association (Cosiema) P Nallathambi says. “Buyers from the US, Italy and Brazil used to come here to give orders and to negotiate prices. As they don’t come now, we fear there would be a downfall in orders in the coming months.”

The disease outbreak has not only impacted new orders, industrialists say they face the risk of not being able to clear the orders they have received. “We have got orders from Australia and Italy. Now the clients have asked us to hold the orders. They say they would buy it after June,” says state vice-president of the Laghu Udyog Bharati S Surulivel.

Micro job work units have also seen a decline in the orders. District president of the Tamil Nadu Association of Cottage and Tiny Enterprises (TACT) J James says after the initial rise in orders in the first week of March, they have not received new orders.

The situation will impact payment collection, bank loans and GST payments, says Surulivel. “The state and Centre should suspend all loan and interest repayments until the end of the year and revoke all penalties and penal interest related to GST. GST payment for the next three months should be deferred.”

James says the sale of main items produced by the MSMEs here such as pumpsets, wet grinders and automobile spares procured by neighouring states such as Kerala, Karnataka and Andhra, has taken a blow. “Depending on the manufacturing capacity of the units, an interest-free loan of Rs 50,000 to Rs 5lakh should be given. Also, a moratorium of one year should be given to industry loans and interests. Penalties should be waived off.”

But the Covid-19 scare has not affected the workers, the industrialists said, adding that they have been taking safety precautions such as using masks and sanitisers.

Title: Covid-19 in Delhi: For restaurant owners & staff, a recipe for disaster
Content: NEW DELHI: A day after leading restaurant chains announced voluntary closure of their outlets till March 31 to check the spread of the novel coronavirus, it became starkly clear on Wednesday that returning to normalcy would not be easy for the hospitality industry. The sector is looking at massive job cuts, loss of revenues and permanent cessation of operations if things did not quickly come back on track.Already, February has proved one of the slowest months in recent history with the risk of infection deterring people from eating out. The pandemic couldn’t have come at a worse time since March is the month when annual taxes are paid and various licences come up for renewal.While restaurateurs are considering ways to stay afloat, the employees stare at an uncertain future. Many have already been sent on unpaid leave or asked to take a pay cut. The contracts of outsourced labour such as housekeeping, security and parking have also been terminated in many establishments.Restaurant body National Restaurants Association of India (NRAI) is reaching out to ministries and government departments for support. Anurag Katriar, president of NRAI, said the central and state governments had to step in. Else, the industry, which employs around eight million people, is looking at huge job losses.“We are meeting the authorities for restoration of input tax credit, deferment of licence renewals due in March, extension of licenses for a quarter without additional fees, GST relief and moratorium on repayment of interest on loans,” disclosed Katriar. He revealed that restaurateurs in their capacities are also reaching out to landlords for concession in rent dues. At his company, deGustibus Hospitality, which employs 700 people, Katriar is planning pay cuts to avoid job losses.Priyank Sukhija of First Fiddle Restaurants, which employs around 1,000 people across India, felt the government needs to consider itself a senior partner in the hospitality industry for its survival. While the decision was taken to close outlets to ‘flatten the curve’, if the situation persisted for a few months, most restaurants would not have funds to sustain themselves, said Sukhija.The hotel owner expects the government to offer a bailout package on the lines of the one given by governments abroad. Sukhija suggested that the government could utilise ESIC social security funds that various organisations contribute as a percentage of the salaries paid to staff salaries, given that this is an unprecedented emergency.Inderjeet Singh Banga of Biggie, which employs around 900 people, pointed out that to stay afloat a business needed to meet fixed costs such as rent, salaries and loan repayments. In the present scenario, the decision to cease operations is bad both in this context, he said. He was sure that if the government did not give clear directives to save the industry, numerous conflicts would arise between landlords and restaurant tenants, with the unfortunate possibility of closure of outlets and job losses. “After the airlines, we are worst hit by the virus,” Banga asserted. “That is why we need help from the authorities.”

Title: Man promises TTD jobs, collects money
Content:
Vijayawada: Police have registered a case against a man for collecting money from people by promising jobs at Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams ( TTD ).

The Two-Town police said the accused, Ramdev, used to introduce himself as a TTD employee and claimed he had good contacts with the temple administration’s top brass. He said there were vacancies in TTD laddu sale counter and collected between Rs 50,000 to Rs 3 lakh as processing fee from the job aspirants.

Ramdev has been accused of collecting money from over 60 persons, who belonged to Krishna, Prakasam, East Godavari and West Godavari districts. TNN

Title: Bhopal: Mystery fire at Imarti Devi’s bungalow
Content:
The reason for the fire is yet to be ascertained.

BHOPAL: Fire broke out at Congress MLA Imarti Devi ’s bungalow in Gwalior district under mysterious circumstances on Wednesday. The MLA from Dabra constituency Imarti is among rebel Congress MLAs holed up in a Bengaluru hotel.

Imarti and five other ministers were recently sacked from the Kamal Nath government after they along with 16 other legislators resigned in support of Jyotiraditya Scindia who left Congress to join BJP. She has already sworn her loyalty to Scindia saying that she would even jump in a well if Maharaj ordered her to do so. "I'll always stay with him even if I have to jump in a well," the Dabra MLA had said while slamming the chief minister.

The fire started in the afternoon and it took around an hour for the fire department to control it, said sources. “The guard room and some properties inside it were gutted. Details are being collected. The reason is still to be ascertained,” said a police officer, wishing anonymity. The bungalow is situated in Jhansi road area of Gwalior. Investigations are underway.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Man booked for making substandard masks
Content: BAREILLY: Amid huge demand for masks due to coronavirus pandemic, a man in Sambhal, on Wednesday, has been booked for allegedly manufacturing substandard masks.Sub-divisional magistrate (SDM) of Gunnaur Deependra Yadav said that an FIR was registered against one Vivek Kumar after they raided his shop in Babrala locality and recovered a huge quantity of substandard masks. These masks were being produced to supply in the market.SDM Yadav said that upon getting information they raided Kumar’s shop from where they found substandard masks sold at Rs 20-Rs 50. “It was a stationery shop where masks were produced using linen under highly unhygienic environment. We seized as many as 500 ready-to-sell masks, raw materials and three machines. We learnt that these masks were manufactured to supply in other districts. A report in the matter has been sent to district magistrate,” the SDM said.The administrative officer said that an FIR under relevant section of Essential Commodities Act has been registered against the shopkeeper.

Title: Coimbatore: Karumathampatti quarantine centre gets another 50 beds
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: The 50-bed Covid-19 quarantine centre set up at the hostel of the Tejaa Shakthi Institute of Technology for Women at Karumathampatti was fitted with 50 more beds on Wednesday.

Health department staff who cleaned the rooms and attached toilets also ensured that all cots had mattresses. The first inmates to the centre are likely to be the passengers of the Air Arabia flight from Sharjah, which will land here on Thursday morning.

A five-member medical team that will have at least a doctor will monitor the inmates, collector K Rajamani said. “The centre has a large hall, television, fans and medication for the comorbidities,” he told TOI.

While it was earlier decided to quarantine all asymptomatic people from the United Arab Emirates , Qatar, China, Oman, South Korea, Iran, Italy, Spain, Germany and France, authorities have now decided to quarantine only those above the age of 60 and those with comorbid conditions like diabetes and heart issues, the collector said. “The district administration has assuaged the fears of Karumathampatti residents regarding the quarantine centre. We explained who would be quarantining here.”

As many as 100 local residents had staged a protest in front of the facility and blocked the collector’s car on Tuesday evening.

Meanwhile, the testing centre for Covid-19 being set up on the Coimbatore Medical College premises is soon expected to get clearance from the National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune. “They have completed the preliminary procedures after the equipment and kits arrived as per the Indian Council of Medical Research’s protocols. The clearance from NIV is expected either Wednesday night or Thursday,” Rajamani added.

Title: Nirbhaya case: Last meeting done for all but 1 convict
Content:
NEW DELHI: The family members of three Nirbhaya convicts have already had their “last meeting”, when they were allowed to meet in a closed room and touch each other. However, Akshay Thakur’s family is yet to come and his wife and parents have been asked to meet him by Thursday, a Tihar Jail source said.

The four death-row convicts in the 2012 Nirbhaya gang-rape-and-murder case are scheduled to be hanged on Friday.

An official said the family members of Pawan Gupta and Vinay Sharma met them on February 29. Both of them broke down and jail officials had to console Sharma after he started crying inconsolably, he added.

The other convict, Mukesh Singh , mostly kept quiet during his meeting on March 2 while his family members had occasional emotional outbursts, a source said. Singh apparently kept assuring them that he still had legal options left to save himself from the gallows. A court on Tuesday rejected Singh’s plea claiming he was not in Delhi when Nirbhaya was gang-raped in a moving bus in south Delhi.

Even after the “last meeting”, the families are allowed their weekly interactions with the convicts, but no separate, one-to-one meeting is permitted.

Thakur, meanwhile, had told the Tihar authorities that his family members would meet him on Wednesday. An official said he seemed to have lost hope that his family members would meet him after his wife decided to seek a divorce.

“We facilitated a phone call between him and his wife after this. He then claimed that his wife would come and meet him on Wednesday,” said the official. His wife, Punita Devi (29), has filed a divorce case in a court in Bihar’s Aurangabad, saying she doesn’t want to live the rest of her life as a widow.

Meanwhile, the preparations for the hanging are in full swing and dummy executions have been carried out. Officials are also keeping a tab on the health of the four men and additional staff have been deployed outside their solitary cells to avoid any untoward incident.

Another accused, Ram Singh, committed suicide inside Tihar, while a juvenile has been freed after serving his term at a Home.

Title: Thermal screening of passengers begins at Nashik airport
Content: NASHIK: Hindustan Aeronautics Ltd (HAL) has started thermal screening of passengers arriving at the Ozar airport, located 20 km from the city, in view of rising number of Covid-19 cases in the state.“We have started thermal screening of the passengers arriving from Pune, Hyderabad and Ahmedabad from Tuesday evening as a part of precautionary measures,” said sources at HAL.Airline operators said that there has been a huge fall in the passenger traffic because of coronavirus , especially in the Nashik-Pune-Nashik sector. At present, Nashik is connected with Pune, Hyderabad and Ahmedabad.“We have sought the help of medical practitioners from the state primary health centres for thermal screening. We had meeting with the medical practitioners, who will also impart training to the staff of airlines and security personnel at the airport. The training workshop will be held on Thursday,” said the HAL sources.“Moreover, we have provided sanitisers for passengers arriving or departing from the airport,” said the sources.Sources in Alliance Air said there has been a huge drop in the number of passengers. “Earlier, 50-60 passengers would travel in a 72-seater flight in Pune and Hydrabad sectors, but only 15-20 passengers are flying now.”Airline sources said that the passenger load in the Nashik-Ahmedabad sector has reduced to 35% from 90% due to the outbreak of coronavirus.Alliance Air operates in the Pune, Hyderabad and Ahmadabad sectors from Nashik airport while private airline TruJet has daily flights in the Nashik-Ahmedabad sector.Airlines like SpiceJet and Indigo have also proposed to operate from Nashik to other cities like Goa, Bangalore, Hyderabad and Bhopal.

Title: Congress MLAs rush to Raj Bhawan after Digvijaya Singh’s detention
Content:
Congress MLAs with Governor Lalji Tandon after submitting a memorandum at Raj Bhawan in Bhopal on Wednesday.

BHOPAL: After senior party leader Digvijaya Singh was detained briefly on Wednesday by Bengaluru police, Congress workers swung into action in the state capital in protest.

Besides, Congress MLAs called on the governor at Raj Bhavan to enlist his support to “free” the 22 Congress MLAs who, according to them, are held captive by the BJP in Bengaluru. The memorandum handed over to governor Lalji Tandon referred to detention of Digvijaya Singh at Bengaluru and said that he was only trying to meet the Congress MLAs in the resort to enlist their support in the Rajya Sabha election.

They urged the governor to use his constitutional authority to secure release of the 22 Congress MLAs.

Meanwhile, a group of Congress workers tried to gherao a resort in Sehore district, where BJP MLAs are currently lodged. In an apparent act of “Gandhigiri”, they wanted to present roses to the BJP MLAs in protest of Digvijaya Singh’s detention and, as they described, against the BJP’s “sinister design” to topple the Kamal Nath government. However, they could not break into the resort due to heavy presence of police force and persuasion by administrative officers to disburse.

Title: Cops await detailed report on escape by 4 from Mayo
Content: NAGPUR: Tehsil police are awaiting a full report from Indira Gandhi Government Medical College and Hospital ( IGGMCH ) about the incident in which four persons had left the isolation ward of the hospital without permission on March 13.The four persons, who were initially suspected as covid-19 patients, were later traced and brought back to the hospital by police. They tested negative but IGGMCH dean Dr Ajay Keoliya filed a written complaint against them at Tehsil police station.A senior official from the police station claimed that they have asked the hospital to send a detailed report of the incident before taking further action. “After the report is received, we will verify whether the four can be booked under any sections. Law officers are also being consulted.”The four persons — two men and two women (one with a 4-year-old boy) — had voluntarily come to the hospital for test after showing coronavirus symptoms on afternoon of March 13.IGGMCH dean has confirmed that police have demanded a full report of the incident and claimed that they are working on providing it.

Title: Serial killer had taken ‘supari’ to kill Ahmedabad gun trader
Content:
Accused (three in the center) in police custody

Rajkot: Nilay Mehta , convicted of two murders and accused in four other murder cases, has confessed to have taken contract (supari) to kill Ahmedabad-based gun trader Udaisinh Bhadoria.

Based on Mehta’s confession, the Rajkot police on Wednesday arrested three key conspirators — Pradeepsinh Rajput, Kishor Koshti and Wasim Iqbal Kathiri— who had plotted to kill Bhadoria, said police.

Mehta was arrested on March 12, nearly a year after he had jumped parole, by the Rajkot crime branch.

“During interrogation, Mehta said that while he was in jaile under Prevention of Anti-Social Activities (PASA) Act, his co-prisoners — Rajput and Koshti — had given him supari (contract) to kill Bhadoria. The arms and ammunition for this purpose were supposed to be provided by Kathiri,” said H M Gadhvi, inspector with the Rajkot crime branch. While Rajput and Koshti were arrested from Ahmedabad, Kathiri was nabbed from Jasdan in Rajkot district by a team led by Rajkot rural crime branch inspector M N Rana. Mehta is accused in a total of 34 cases. Of these cases, six pertain to murder, while the rest of the cases pertain to robberies.

Rajput has been booked by Ahmedabad police in nine offences ranging from physical assault, molestation to faluting of the Prohibition Act.

Koshti faces six cases pertaining to burglary, robbery and criminal intimidation in Ahmedabad, while Kathiri is involved in 18 crimes ranging from attempt to murder and physical assault to arms trafficking registered against him in Ahmedabad, Bhavnagar , Amreli and Jasdan police stations.

Title: No Uttar Pradesh Board evaluation till April 2
Content:
Representative Image

LUCKNOW: UP secondary education board has cancelled evaluation of UP Board answersheets till April 2. New dates will be announced later. Postponement could delay the results which are announced by May second week.

The evaluations had started at 275 centres across the state on March 16 and were to end on March 26. About three crore copies have to be evaluated by 1.46 lakh examiners.

In an order issued on Wednesday, UP Secondary Education Board secretary Neena Srivastava asked all district inspector of schools and principals of colleges turned into evaluation centres to ensure there was no dampness in the store rooms where answer copies are kept. Directives have been issued to ensure uninterrupted power supply in these store rooms so that CCTVs remain functional round the clock. Inspection by centre superintendents and DIOS is a must.

Title: Covid-19: Thiru corporation to collect used gloves and masks
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The city corporation will tie up with IMAGE (Indian medical association goes eco-friendly) to collect used masks and gloves. Collection bins will be placed at hand wash kiosks which were set up in places like Thampanoor , Palayam, corporation main office, Kazhakkoottam, Pettah and East Fort.The collection process is being planned in the wake of unscientific disposal of used masks and gloves in large numbers on streets and drains. Separate bins will be used for the collection of masks and gloves.The civic body will also constitute a 10-member emergency response team comprising health inspectors in all health circles as part of co-ordinating fumigation and disinfection measures. The corporation will purchase thermal scanners, which will be used in public places in the city. The staff have been asked to conduct regular disinfection measures at various places.On Wednesday, Kerala government nurses association (KGNA) launched a campaign in Medical College Hospital to educate patients and bystanders on proper usage and disposal of masks. The association has been conducting campaigns in major hospitals. KGNA state committee member Priya Krishnan and district secretary Sushama led the classes.

Title: Rajasthan: Congress, BJP will get more time to select aspirants
Content: JAIPUR: Political parties heaved a shy of relief after the postponement of elections for six municipal corporations in Rajasthan Both major parties have welcomed the decision which will be helpful to prevent the spread of coronavirus and will give them enough time in ticket distribution. As per the decision, elections will be held after six weeks i.e. polls will be conducted in the end of May. Around two months will be utilized by the BJP and the Congress in selection of the candidates.One senior BJP person said that earlier only few days were left to file nomination which is why party was mostly dependent on the recommendations of MLA. “Now we will be able to scrutinize the candidates properly. Lotteries are completed so the situation is clear for everyone. We will now be focused in selecting the candidate from the community,” said a senior BJP member.Many people have been claiming tickets with the party are now been expected to become more active. One former Congress councillor said, “I have been asking for the ticket second time but the party was focused on making their decision for the elections on April 5. Not much thought was given while finalising the candidates list. Now, with the postponement I can approach more people and campaign better.”Many people have already made their social media pages claiming ticket from the party. People have started approaching higher officials as well and with more time, lobbying will start.The most important benefit with the postponement of elections is now public can be focused on the elections. As the threat of coronavirus is everywhere, people are worried about their security rather than civic issue.“There is no mood for elections in the city. Last time on every tea stall and local gathering elections were discussed. Now, people are not coming out of their houses and have less concerned about the elections. We expect that the spread of the disease will decrease with time and people can be back to normal live. This will affect the rise in the voting percentage as well which would have suffered if elections would have held on the decided date on April 5,” said a senior BJP leader anonymously.

Title: Prisoner hangs self in Badvel jail
Content:
Vijayawada: A 35-year-old remand prisoner killed self by hanging in Badvel sub-jail on Wednesday.

Talla China Bala Kondaiah was accused of killing his two daughters Bhavana (10) and Shobhana (8) by throwing them in a well at Jyothikshetram under Kalasapadu mandal in Kadapa district.

Kondaiah was a native of Srinivasapuram and was debt- ridden. A few years ago, Kondaiah’s wife had died by suicide and the responsibility of his two daughters fell on him.Kondaiah killed his daughters on March 2 as he was not able to afford taking care of them. TNN

Title: More beds for quarantine & isolation wards in Nashik
Content: NASHIK: The district administration and Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) on Wednesday jointly decided to substantially increase the number of beds in the isolation and quarantine wards.While the number of the beds for isolation has been increased from 16 to 76, a total of 78 beds have been kept ready for quarantine. Although no positive case of Covid-19 has been reported in the city, the district and civic administrations are taking every measure to monitor situation in case the number of suspects increases. Nashik district collector Suraj Mandhare , municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game and district civil surgeon Suresh Jagdale on Wednesday inspected some of the hospitals and municipal corporation buildings to review the arrangements of beds for isolation and quarantine.Mandhare and Game also took review of the arrangements of isolation and quarantine of Covid-19 with district civil surgeon and health officials during a meeting held after the visit.“Travellers coming from 10 most-affected countries like Dubai, UK, France, Germany, Dubai, Iran and Italy are to be quarantined in the hospitals, while those coming from other countries are to be quarantined in their homes,” Jagdale said, adding the positive patients are to be treated in the quarantine wards.Apart from the existing 16 beds for isolation in district civil hospital, arrangement of 60 more beds have been made at Dr Zakir Hussain hospital and other private hospitals. There will be 40 beds for quarantine at Dr Zakir Hussain hospital, while arrangements of remaining 38 beds have been done at six private hospitals.Meanwhile, the NMC has started spraying anti-biotic in public places across the city as part of preventive measures.The civic administration has started spraying of anti-biotic on experimental basis at Rajiv Gandhi Bhavan — headquarters of NMC, Central Bus Stand and district collectorate. The spraying was done on floor, railings, office tables and chairs.

Title: Salem: Construction worker killed in wall collapse
Content:
A 38-year-old man was killed after a 6 foot-tall sidewall of a newly-constructed car shed collapsed on him at ... Read More

SALEM: A 38-year-old man was killed after a 6 foot-tall sidewall of a newly-constructed car shed collapsed on him at Shevapet area here on Wednesday. The Shevapet police identified the deceased as P Chinnaswam,y of Pudhu Road near Suramangalam in the city. He was a construction worker.

According to a police officer, the incident took place when Chinnaswamy, along with 36-year-old Paramasivam and 35-year-old Sarathy, was constructing the car shed on Moongapadi Street. “Around 1 pm, Chinnaswamy was working on one side of the shed when the sidewall suddenly collapsed and fell on him. He was trapped under the debris. The remaining two were not affected as they were on the other side of the shed,” the officer said.

When alerted, fire and rescue services personnel cleared the debris and took Chinnaswamy out. They rushed him to the Salem government hospital, where doctors declared him brought dead. tnn

Title: Wholesale onion prices drop 30% in 3 days at Lasalgaon
Content: NASHIK: The average wholesale onion prices at the Lasalgaon APMC, the country’s largest wholesale onion market, have dropped by 30% in the past three days despite the Centre lifting ban on onion exports.The average wholesale onion price has dropped to Rs 1,200 per quintal now, against Rs 1,750 per quintal on Saturday.“The demand for onions in the domestic market as well as in international markets has drastically dropped due to the coronavirus outbreak. The demand for onion exports has also reduced due to the same reason. This has led to an overall drop in average wholesale onion prices,” said the APMC officials.Some traders have stopped buying of onions and have decided to wait and watch the scenario till April 1, said APMC sources.Around 16,000 quintals of onions were auctioned at Lasalgaon on Wednesday. The minimum and maximum wholesale onion prices were recorded at Rs 1,000 and Rs 1,400 per quintal, respectively.“On March 1, the Centre announced its decision to lift the ban on onion exports. The lifting of the ban came into effect after 15 days. Most onion farmers also preferred to wait for a fortnight with hopes to get a better price for their produce,” said onion trader Manoj Jain. “But the demand for onions have dropped. This is the major reason for the dip in wholesale onion prices despite the Centre lifting ban on exports,” said Jain.“Currently, onions arriving in the market are of late kharif onions. Fresh summer onions have also started arriving, but in very low quantities — just about 10%,” said Jain.APMC officials said the arrivals of summer onions will increase more by the first week of April. Late kharif onions have a shelf life of less than a month and the produce beings to tot thereafter. Hence, farmers can’t store summer onions and they have no choice but to sell the produce at the prevailing market rates. On the contrary, summer onions have a shelf life of six months and farmers prefer storing this stock with the hope of getting better prices.

Title: High drama in Bengaluru as Digvijaya Singh not allowed to meet MLAs, detained
Content:
File photo of Digvijaya Singh

Bengaluru: High drama prevailed outside a private resort near Devanahalli early on Wednesday, after local police stopped Congress Rajya Sabha member and AICC general secretary Digvijaya Singh from meeting the 19 rebel Madhya Pradesh MLAs holed up inside and took him into preventive custody. Karnataka Pradesh Congress Committee (KPCC) president DK Shivakumar and a few party legislators were also detained .

In a reminder of Shivakumar’s protest in Mumbai in 2019, when he tried to meet then Congress rebel MLAs to save the coalition government in Karnataka, Singh tried to drive home the point that state police and the ruling BJP government were not allowing him to meet the MLAs.

“I have repeatedly urged police to meet my voters, considering that I’m contesting the Rajya Sabha elections on March 26. However, I’ve been told my own estranged party colleagues don’t want to meet me. BJP has forcefully kept them in this resort and has even snatched their mobiles,” alleged Singh.

Title: ‘We cannot survive beyond a week’
Content:
Handcarts stand deserted at Vasantrao Naik basti on Wednesday

Nagpur: Jagannath Patel sells sugar cane juice at Civil Lines. His house had caught fire in May last year. “Property worth Rs2 lakh was destroyed, I haven’t earned enough to recover the losses yet,” he says. Taking out a few notes of hundreds from his pocket, he says, “This is the only money I have.”

Patel is an immigrant from Rewa in Madhya Pradesh where the house in which his family stays was burned.

The coronavirus scare had already reduced the earnings of many like Patel. Now, the closure order for eateries and roadside vendors till March 31 has pushed them to the brink. For many like Patel, subsistence depends on what they earn every day.

“I have to pay Rs4,000 as rent for the room at Vasantrao Naik Nagar shanties. So far, I have earned only Rs6,000. All the expenses can be met only if the earning are at least Rs10,000, but the daily sales have already halved,” he says.

Many of the vendors who are immigrants from neighbouring Madhya Pradesh or Uttar Pradesh say they will be forced to go back to their native villages and take up work as daily wagers there.

The Vasantrao Naik hutments near Bhole Petrol pump are home to around 100 street vendors . In the afternoon itself, handcarts could seen been parked outside their homes.

“We can pull on for a month and even more,” said one of them. Others pounced on him, literally. “How can you say that? don’t you have to eat every day,” asked a woman. “I have six mouths to feed and I am the only bread winner in the family. Do you think I can manage,” asked another in his late fifteen.

“It’s on for two or three days but we cannot survive beyond a week. I need at least Rs200 a day, ” said Bhagwandas Sahu, who runs a bhel stall.

“We don’t have children and my husband has diabetes as well as heart ailment. From where do we get money for the medicines now,” asked Nirmala Sahu in her sixties.

At Civil Lines, Shahzad Allam who sells goggles and watches whips out his smart phone and shows his three bank accounts. The maximum balance is Rs52 in the account at State Bank of India. “Now, tell me how can I manage if I am forced to sit at home,’ he says.

Title: Rs 5,000 crore blow to events and hospitality industry in Rajasthan
Content: JAIPUR: Estimated to be around Rs 5,000 crore, the events and hospitality industry in Rajasthan has come to a grinding halt threatening the livelihood of many of the 10 lakh people engaged in the sector directly and indirectly.With all conferences, festivals, sports activities, product launches, brand promotions, activations, exhibitions and trade shows remaining cancelled or postponed indefinitely, the events industry is grappling with a conundrum of complex issues marred by a potential uncertainty.“The coronavirus pandemic has collapsed our industry, forcing an unprecedented loss, impacting the livelihood of millions employed, making us unable to pay taxes, honour payment commitments to banks, while exposing our vendors and supply chain players to a very challenging times,” said Siddharth Chaturvedi, secretary of Events and Entertainment Management Association (EEMA), Rajasthan chapter.He said the brands are now resetting their plans, expectations, delivery systems, marketing focus and logistics. “This will force the experiential industry to lay off employees, reduce salaries, delay mandatory payouts and worse still, shut companies,” added Chaturvedi.Of late, Rajasthan has emerged as a top MICE (meetings, incentives, conferences, exhibitions) destination in the country, riding on the expanding hospitality infrastructure and its tourism appeal. Estimates suggest the state accounts for 20% of the large-sized cultural events and weddings.Compounding the problems, event management companies are now required to pay back the money received as advance for an event since the pandemic now falls under natural calamity. “The force majeure clause is being invoked. Which means we have to pay back the advance money received for an event. This is again a burden the industry has to face when it is battling to stay afloat,” said Mahavir Sharma, an EEMA member.The auxiliary segments supporting the events industry engage local artists, caterers, tent providers, security personnel, taxi services, and a range of suppliers who are now also sitting idle without any business and keeping their fingers crossed.The industry body has sought an appointment with the chief minister with a list of relief package for the sector to ride out the difficult times.It has appealed the government to pay the companies all dues for the work that has been completed so that they will be able to pay the staff their salaries on time. Similarly, a moratorium of 9-12 months on payments in the form of EMIs and interests to banks has also been proposed.“We also want the state government to convince the GST Council to waive taxes for a 12-month period so that the industry can recover. Besides, we want that the state should allow us its venues for use at very minimal rates whenever the situation improves. That would to some extent reduce the financial burden on us,” added Chaturvedi.According to industry sources, all the events up to the end of April have been cancelled. Leading hotel chains have announced to refund all the advance money deposited with them for events up to April-end which has been another factor for cancellations.

Title: Cleric: Offer namaz in smaller mosques
Content:
Lucknow: To help contain spread of Covid-19, Aishbagh Eidgah Imam and Qazi-e-Sheher Maulana Khalid Raheed Farangimahli on Wednesday issued an advisory for all mosques and namazis, asking them to avoid big mosques for Friday prayers and instead offers namaz in smaller mosques in their neighbourhood.

The advisory also asked children and elderly not to visit mosques and instead offer prayers in homes till coronavirus is contained. Devout suffering from flu, cough, cold and fever have also been asked to offer all namaz only in their homes until they recover fully.

“Imams have been requested to keep the khutba (speech) delivered before or after Friday prayers short so that namazis do not have to stay in mosques for too long. Special prayers will also be held in the mosques for eradication of the contagious disease and for the wellbeing of everyone” the cleric said.

Title: Three notorious truck robbers arrested
Content:
Rajkot: Three robbers who were experts in stealing goods from trucks by cutting the tarpaulin covers were arrested from Patadi taluka in Surendranagar district on Tuesday.

Police said they arrested Wasimkhan Malek , Jaswant Soya and Ali Ladak from the crossing between Upariyala and Navarangpura after they kept a watch following a tip-off about their whereabouts. “We have recovered 63 boxes of hair oil worth Rs 2.49 lakh and tobacco boxes worth Rs 50,000 from the accused. We also seized two SUVs involved in the crime. The accused trio confessed of their involvement in as many as 55 thefts from trucks in Surendranagar, Ahmedabad, Mehsana and Rajkot districts,” said D M Dhol, inspector with Surendranagar local crime branch.

Title: If needed, I too will go to Bengaluru: Kamal Nath
Content:
File photo of Kamal Nath

BHOPAL: With senior Congress leaders, including Digvijaya Singh and five ministers arrested in Bengaluru, CMKamal Nath on Wednesday said he may head for the southern city that has been one of the focal points of the Madhya Pradesh political crisis that started a fortnight ago.

“BJP is killing democracy in Madhya Pradesh. BJP is nervous about bringing our 16 MLAs to the state. What is the crisis in one person meeting the legislators? In 15 months, we have proved majority and faced floor-test several times. If need be, I will also go to Bengaluru,” Nath said around noon on Wednesday.

The chief minister also said that he tried to contact Karnataka chief minister BS Yeddiyurappa and Union home minister Amit Shah in the evening but both of them did not call him back .

“It is entirely dictatorial to stop, misbehave and forcefully arrest Digvijaya Singh, Congress ministers and MLAs who went to meet their party legislators held captive by BJP in Bengaluru,” said Nath.

“The entire country is seeing how BJP is murdering democratic values to destabilise an elected government. Why are we not being allowed to meet the MLAs? After all what is BJP afraid of? A dirty game is being played by BJP in the state,” was his next.

Democratic values, constitutional values and rights are being suppressed, the CM alleged, adding: “Our arrested leaders should be released soon and allowed to meet the hostage MLAs.”

Attacking BJP, CM Nath tweeted, “BJP does not have majority right now, neither has Shivraj Singh Chouhan been elected leader of the BJP Legislative Party . BJP government has not been formed, neither will it be formed. But Shivraj Singh Chouhan’s urgency and restlessness to become chief minister is seen by the entire state.”

The CM’s final tweet in this volley said: “How they are getting restless for power! They are sleepless, day-dreaming of becoming chief minister. They are threatening officials. I pity their condition.”

Title: Ticket cancellations at Nashik Road station
Content: Officials the Nashik Road railway station said that cancellations of confirmed tickets has swelled tremendously in the last few days owing to the coronavirus scare in the country.“The rate of cancellation of the tickets has gone up tremendously and it is entirely due to coronavirus,” a senior officer from the Nashik Road railway station said.A total of 184 tickets were cancelled on March 9; however, the number has gone up to 525 as of Tuesday.

Title: Rajasthan: Army chief reviews op preparations at Tanot
Content:
Army chief General Mukund Narwane at Tanot on Wednesday

Army chief General Mukund Narwane on Wednesday reviewed operational army preparations and readiness at Tanot forward area near the Indo-Pak border. In his two day visit, he addressed the Jawans and officers at Jaisalmer military station and told that modernisation work in the city was going with great pace and progress was on to induct many new equipment in army, air force and navy the tri-services together are efficient and ready to deal with any challenge. On this occasion southern command GoC Lt Gen CP Mohanti, Konark core commander Lt. general Anil Puri, battle axe division GoC Maj General Rakesh Kapoor and other senior officers were present.

In his motivational speech he said that army is ready to deal to any challenge and process of modernization is continuously going on and many new equipments and other resources are being included in the army. Emphasizing on imparting better training to army, he said good training is important for better activities and growth of army and everybody has to focus on this. In regard to future challenges he said army, air force and navy together are alert in security of the country and ready to deal with any challenge. He motivated all soldiers to maintain highest standards of professionalism and operational preparedness through realistic and focused training.

The army chief had come on three day visit to Gujarat Rajasthan border areas.

Title: Pandemic puts brakes on big fat destination weddings in Rajasthan
Content:
Event managers have to return advance to their clients due to cancellation of marriages in the state

JAIPUR: The outbreak of Covid-19 has made a dent on fat destination weddings which were scheduled to be held in coming months.

The event managers have to return the advance which they had taken from non-resident Indian clients for weddings slated for April. Besides, managers and their clients have crossed their fingers for upcoming marriages in May, June and July.

Rajasthan and its archaeological beauty appeals many non-resident Indians (NRIs), celebrities from Hollywood and Hindi film industry to organize weddings in the state.

TOI on Tuesday spoke to various wedding managers who deal with global clients from United Kingdom (UK), United States of America (USA), Italy and some parts of Europe.

“Every day, we are getting calls from them. Since Jaipur reported the Italian couple affected by coronavirus, I got calls from my clients in US and UK who urged me to cancel their upcoming weddings in April,” said Siddhartha Chaturvedi, a wedding manager based in Jaipur told TOI.

He added that in this particular case, where people are affected and are scared of travelling, the wedding managers and the hotels are giving the full refund of the booking amounts. “Usually if our client cancels without valid reason, we don’t repay the advance we take because of various operational costs. But in this case, we have to repay their advance. This year would be worst-ever for the state when we talk about marriage management and destination weddings,” Chaturvedi added.

He said many weddings were planned in Jaipur, Jodhpur and Jaisalmer which are either on the verge of cancellations or the clients are jittery.

“This year, the auspicious days for Hindu marriages which are usually more in winters are actually more in summers starting from April to August. We were thinking of getting good business while because of the corona scare, big losses underway,” said Mohit Sand, another Jaipur-based wedding planner.

Title: MSRTC cuts down buses to Pune
Content: NASHIK: The Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation (MSRTC) has cut down the number of buses from Nashik to Pune by 50%. “Given the current situation of coronavirus in Pune, the MSRTC administration was planning to cut down the frequency of buses towards Pune.We could not do it till Tuesday as number of passengers coming from Pune to Nashik was high. As the passenger count has reduced significantly now, we have reduced the frequency by 50%,” a state transport utility official said.

Title: NMC raids industry, seizes 1,786kg plastic
Content:
Nagpur: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation’s (NMC) Nuisance Detection Squad (NDS) on Friday conducted a raid and seized 1,786 kg of banned plastic. A fine of Rs 15,000 was also recovered.

In a press release, NMC said, “The NDS squad received information about storage of plastic used for kharra in huge quantity at an industry in the Small Factory Area, East Nagpur. The team of NDS led by block officer Sudhir Sudke and NMC Lakadganj Zone led by zonal officer Saket Kailkar conducted the search on industrial plot No. 257 of Jalaram Industries and found 1,786kg plastic. The total value of the plastic is Rs 2.14 lakh. Thus, a fine of Rs 15,000 was recovered from owner Jayant Manilal Dakshine.”

NDS of the NMC under the guidance of municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe, additional municipal commissioner Ram Joshi and deputy municipal commissioner Dr Pradeep Dasarwar had seized 364kg plastic in 109 cases between March 1 and 19. A fine of Rs 5.95 lakh was recovered in these cases.

So far, the latest case is the biggest action in March.

Title: Third batch of evacuees reach Jaisalmer, total count 484
Content:
A plane carrying Indians from Iran at Jaisalmer on Wednesday

JAISALMER: A fresh batch of 195 Indians stranded in coronavirus-hit Iran was brought back here by a special plane on Wednesday evening. They were shifted to the Army's wellness facility after screening.

With the arrival of this batch of evacuees, the total number of quarantined people at the wellness facility in the Jaisalmer Military Station increased to 484.

Civil airport authorities, army and district administration have made all preparations in this regard. Doctors from Jodhpur Medical College were deployed at the airport. Two flights — one carrying 105 (68 males and 37 females), and another 90 (41 males, 48 females and kid) — landed in the evening.

Airports Authority of India director B.S.Meena and other officers were present along with doctors at the airport.

Meena said 195 Indians came from Iran in two flights which landed at 4:30pm and 5 pm.

Meena said SOP was made in such a way that they need didn;t have to come to the main terminal and were screened at the apron and then sent to the military station.

District collector Mehta said the Indians were tested coronavirus negative.

Defence spokesman Col. Sambit Gosh said a batch of 195 Indians from Iran were brought to Jaisalmer by a special plane. “The passengers were screened at the airport and shifted to the Army’s wellness facility at Jaisalmer Military Station. With the arrival of this batch of evacuees, the total number of quarantined people housed at the facility rose to 484,” he said.

Title: Besides virus, Tamil Nadu government battles fake news
Content: CHENNAI: Rumours spread faster than coronavirus on Wednesday forcing ministers, public health and civic officials to issue warnings and lodge police complaints, besides making press announcements to clarify facts.An audio message circulated saying the Covid-19 outbreak was a conspiracy by the Illuminati to depopulate the country and that the health department was doing a door-to-door survey to isolate and eliminate people. Another message said government was planning to stop all public transport vehicles – trains and buses and closure of the vegetable and fruit markets in the city. None of these is true.“We knew fighting the virus was tough, today we found fighting these rumour mongers tougher,” said J Radhakrishnan, commissioner of revenue administration, disaster management and mitigation. Radhakrishnan and corporation commissioner G Prakash gave television interviews dismissing rumours. They warned of criminal action against those spreading false information.“We are closing down malls, theatres and large shopping complexes to discourage social gathering. Grocery stores, supermarkets and those selling essential items will remain open,” Prakash said. “Fish markets, meat, vegetable and fruit markets will remain open,” he said.Later in the evening, Chennai Metropolitan Development Authority member secretary D Karthikeyan the Koyambedu vegetables and fruits market and bus terminus have been disinfected and will remain open.The public health department filed complaint against ‘Healer’ Baskar, a self-proclaimed medical practitioner, for releasing an audio clip that said people tested positive will be isolated and eliminated later. “Such rumour mongering is a public health hazard. We filed a complaint against him with the collector and the police,” said director of public health Dr K Kolandaswamy The state has invoked the Epidemic Act and has declared the outbreak as a disaster. “Punishment will include up to seven year jail term for the guilty,” he said. Deputy director of health services G Ramesh Kumar said action will be taken under Tamil Nadu Public Health Act, 1939, and Section 54 (punishment for false warning) of the Disaster Management Act, 2005.In Madurai, M Selvam, 40, was arrested for spreading rumours that 47 Covid-19 infected people were isolated in an unoccupied apartment building near Othakadai in Madurai. The message triggered a protest by the residents. He has been booked under IT act and Disaster Management Act, 2005 and remanded in judicial custody.

Title: Golden city swings into action to prevent coronavirus
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

JAISALMER: The municipal council is using loudspeakers to inform people about the measures that need to be taken to prevent spread of coronavirus.

Apart from this, district administration and health department teams have started taking action against hoteliers for not providing information about tourists. The teams are also checking hotels to identify tourists who have not done screening. The administration is also spraying chemicals at government offices and houses.

On Wednesday, medical personnel screened 60 BSF jawans who came from north Bengal and permitted them to go to the border.

Municipal council commissioner Brajesh Rai said sodium hypochlorite will be sprayed at crowded places, gardens, public places, government offices and other places. The Darshan timings at Ramdeora temple has been reduced to six hours from 16 hours. Chemicals are also being sprayed in Ramdeora area and temple premises are being washed with chemicals where there is movement of large number of devotees. This is being done under the directions of Sankada block medical officer Long Mohammad.

The administration is also generating awareness on how to prevent the virus through hoardings, banners, pamphlets and door-to-door messaging on a warfooting. Loudspeakers have been fitted on taxis that are passing through various lanes and bylanes of the city.

People have also been advised not to shake hands and avoid crowded places.

Principal medical officer BL Bunkar said BSF’s 161st battalion deputy commandant informed that 60 personnel from north Bengal had been screened for the virus. District collector praised the medical team and department for taking necessary measures.

District collector informed that a guest house and a hotel had been seized with immediate effect, while action was taken on other hotels which were not following guidelines issued for preventing coronavirus.

Title: Nashik man robbed of cellphone worth Rs 10,000
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: A 21-year-old man was robbed of his cellphone worth Rs 10,000 by two unidentified people near Shani temple along the Peth road in the Panchavati area of the city at around 1 am on Tuesday.

The complainant, a resident of Hegdewar Nagar , Cidco, said that he was walking near the Shani temple along the Peth road in the Panchavati area when he approached a group of people for asking directions.

At the same time, two unidentified people approached him. They drew out a sharp weapon and threatened him, before forcibly snatching his mobile phone and fleeing from the spot.

Title: ‘Cold, fever due to weather change is not covid-19, but don’t ignore it’
Content: Nagpur: The sudden change in weather due to thundershowers on Tuesday night may develop symptoms like cough, cold and fever in many. In the present scenario, people may mistake it as covid-19 and panic. Doctors have advised citizens not to fear but also not to ignore these symptoms.“Every cough, cold and fever cannot be covid-19. Most of them are local infections due to weather change and can be treated by your family doctors,” said pulmonologist Dr Sameer Arbat.“But no one should ignore these symptoms in the present scenario. Consult your doctor, and get yourself treated immediately. Most importantly, follow the social distancing practices strictly until you have these symptoms,” Dr Arbat said and added that many citizens are still taking covid-19 casually.“Despite several guidelines and instructions, many are still not avoiding public gatherings . These restrictions are for our own safety. Sudden change in weather has increased risk of viral infections. We can’t afford any viral infection to spread,” he said.In Vidarbha, covid-19 has been detected in only those having travel history or those who came in close contact of positive patients. “Local transmission of coronavirus is not yet detected in Nagpur which is a good news,” said Dr Pritam Agrawal, infectious disease specialist.“Three of the four positive patients in Nagpur have travel history while the one is wife of a positive patient which means the person in close contact. Similarly, three positive patients in Yavatmal have direct travel history to Dubai. No one from their families is affected so far.“So, if you get cough or cold due to this sudden weather change, don’t think that you have covid-19. Most cough and cold due to weather change get cured with general medicines within four to five days,” she said.Similar weather conditions are going to prevail for the next 48 hours at least, states IMD. Orange alert has been issued for thundershowers in Gadchiroli, Gondia, Bhandara and Chandrapur on Thursday. There are chances of light rains in some places in Nagpur for next two days.“Protecting yourself from viral fever is the best remedy. Avoid going out in rains, follow hand hygiene, follow restrictions on movement, and those who develop symptoms should follow social distancing,” Dr Agrawal said.Don’t panic but take careIt is important not to panic due to symptoms like cough, cold and sore throatCommon cold and flu begins with a running nose, followed by cough and feverIf someone only has a sore throat, then it cannot be a symptom of coronavirusCurrently, only those who have travel history to suspected nations are at covid-19 riskSecondly, those in close contact with the positive patients are at riskThose having flu like symptoms should start practicing social distancing for sureConsult doctors immediately and stay away from others until your symptoms recede

Title: Driving licence tests rescheduled amid coronavirus scare
Content: NASHIK: The Nashik Regional Transport Office (RTO) has decided to reschedule all driving licence-related tests that were lined up till March 31. The tests will now take place next month. However, applicants whose learner’s licence validity expires before March 31 would be allowed to appear for the driving licence test.Various other works have also been stopped to do away the overcrowding of people at the RTO office.Sale of paan, tobacco products prohibitedThe district administration has announced a ban on the sale of all paan (beetle-leaves), tobacco and related products from Thursday. Orders issued by Suraj Mandhare, the Nashik District Disaster Management Authority (DDMA) president and collector, pointed out that spit can transmit the virus and since people who consume paan or tobacco products often spit in the open, the chances of others catching the virus become high. Therefore, the sale of these products has been completely banned till March 31, the DDMA order said.

Title: Contest on the cards for three Rajya Sabha seats from Rajasthan
Content:
JAIPUR: A fight for the three Rajya Sabha seats from Rajasthan is on the cards as none of the four candidates for the March 26 polls withdrew their nominations on Wednesday.

Returning officer Pramil Kumar Mathur said none of the four candidates withdrew their name on the last date.

Congress has named K C Venugopal and Neeraj Dangi as its candidates while the BJP has named Rajendra Gehlot. The BJP, however, sprang a surprise by fielding Omkar Singh Lakhawat, who filed his nomination at the last minute.

With Lakhawat staying in the fray, a keen contest is on the cards for the three seats.

According to the strength of the MLAs, the Congress could win two seats and BJP one. By fielding a second candidate, the saffron party is trying to test the pollical waters and keep the Congress, which is now fighting the flight of MLAs in Madhya Pradesh and Gujarat, on tenterhooks.

The BJP has 75 MLAs including its alley RLP while ruling Congress enjoys the support of 123 MLAs including independents and supporting parties in the 200-strong assembly. BJP requires the support of at least 27 MLAs to win the second seat. It seems an impossible task.

Rajasthan has a total of 10 Rajya Sabha seats and nine of them, including the three which are going to polls on March 26, are held by the BJP.

Congress’s only Rajya Sabha member from Rajasthan is former Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, who was elected unopposed in the RS bypolls held last year after the seat fell vacant following the death of BJP's Rajya Sabha member Madan Lal Saini.

Title: When every day in Chennai feels like a Sunday
Content:
Employees being asked to work from home, and schools and colleges closed.

CHENNAI: Ruchi Mohunta lives with her husband, 14-year-old daughter and in-laws on Taylor’s Road. Every day, the experiential educator and her husband head to work, and their daughter goes to school while her in-laws stay at home. Meals are hurried affairs as everybody follows their hectic schedules. But, dinner on Tuesday night was vastly different, with the entire family sitting down to share a meal, and an exotic one at that – nasi goreng whipped up by Ruchi and her daughter Parthivi.

“For the last one year I have been travelling 20 days a month, so I am super excited about this time I now have at home with my child,” says Ruchi. Since the Covid-19 scare, her husband Apurva spends just a couple of hours at work while she has opted to stay at home. And with schools closed, the entire family is now spending more time together than that they have in the last few years.

The fear of contracting Covid-19 has brought about a change of lifestyle for many. With employees being asked to work from home, and schools and colleges closed, families are now spending more time under one roof. And many are using this time to strengthen bonds, catch up on old hobbies, learn new skills, be more mindful and start new exercise regimes.

“With more time on my hands I wanted to try something new. My daughter wanted to have the Indonesian dish nasi goreng, so I googled the recipe and we made it together. She also googled fun facts about Indonesia, put it on post-its and stuck it around the dining table,” says Ruchi. “The whole family sat down to dinner, discussed the trivia and not once did we mention anything to do with coronavirus.”

In the next few days, the family also plans to do some craft and watch old classics. “We have a projector and we wanted our daughter to watch movies we had grown up on, like ‘The Sound of Music’,” says Ruchi.

Apurva, her husband, says that, “Now every day feels like Sunday. There’s not much traffic on the road, we did our grocery shopping at 3:45pm on a weekday, and whatever work is happening is happening on our laptops. It’s like you have to do whatever you were doing with your families in the 1980s, except now you have the Internet and Netflix .”

Sangeetha Arul, a homemaker in Thiruvanmiyur, says she wants to teach her 11-year-old son Alan how to play cards. “My uncle and aunt taught me and I want him to learn too. He loves to bake with me so we will bake butter cookies and sponge cake provided he spends one day cleaning up his room on his own. Since we don’t want to order food, it will address that issue too,” says Sangeetha, whose husband is out of the country.

Mridula Swamy, 38, a teacher and single parent, says she will just “chill out” with her sons, Aadhav, 11, and nine-year-old Vihaan. “We plan to try out some science experiment kits we bought but never used, do some spring cleaning, and also play badminton and run or cycle so that all of us get some exercise,” she says.

Author and textile specialist Sabita Radhakrishna , who is in her 70s, is catching up on old hobbies. “I have started painting and doing crochet again. I also plan to take out my sewing machine, and mend some of my old clothes,” says Sabita.

Title: Chennai: How to embrace learning outside of school
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: It isn’t surprising that for the last couple of weeks, as schools in more than a dozen countries have closed down as a precautionary measure against Covid-19, ‘how to homeschool ’ has been trending on Google. On Monday, parents in Chennai joined that search.

But as moms and dads in the city grapple with the idea of how to teach their children, homeschooling parents -- who have embraced this way of life for years now -- offer tips and resources on how to school away from school.

“Remember, school is out, so there is no rigid timetable to follow. Begin the day with what your child wants to do,” says Deepa Dixon, city-based homeschooling mom of a 13-year-old. “Look at homeschooling as a time to understand your child’s strengths and weaknesses in subjects or lessons,” says Dixon. “You don’t have to study a subject for 45 minutes and then jump to the next. This is an opportunity to explore the lesson or subject without a time constraint.”

Also, says Dixon, her experience has taught her that allowing a child to decide the schedule of study can give parents clues into what their child is thinking. “If for instance, every single day your child says they want to do math, clearly they love the subject. But if you find that if you suggest a certain subject and they keep saying they don’t want to do it, perhaps it is time to explore why. Is it a lack of comprehension, some difficulty they are facing at school?”

Homeschooling is not just about learning subject lessons, says Ijeoma Akomolafe , homeschooling mom from Egmore. “It’s also about learning life lessons.” Akomolafe has two children – six and two – and ensures the elder sibling reads to or teaches the younger one. “It gives them a sense of responsibility,” she says.

Akomolafe says that what works for her is using everyday activities and chores as tools for learning. “Younger children love helping out in the kitchen and around the house. And that offers avenues for practical learning,” she says. For instance, writing letters of the alphabet with rice, baking to learn science, card games for maths.

Meenakshi Umesh, who homeschooled her now grown-up children on a farm in Dharmapuri , says doing household chores is something parents must inculcate in their children during these weeks. “Teach them to do everyday tasks properly. Washing clothes, a little cooking, housecleaning. In homeschooling, housework is homework. It boosts self-confidence.”

Title: NMC teams detect over 25 in Nashik with travel history
Content: NASHIK: The Nashik Municipal Corporation ’s (NMC) squads have tracked down 29 city-based residents with foreign travel history in the last one week.The names of these residents were apparently missing from the lists that the local administration gets from different international airports across the country on a regular basis.As a precautionary measure, health check-ups of the said travellers was carried out by the NMC teams.“There were 29 city-based residents whose names were missing from the lists that we had received. But, our teams used their local networks and found out these residents and carried out the health check-ups. Fortunately, none of them showed Covid-19 symptoms. We have kept them and their family members in home quarantine for 14 days and are keeping a tab on their health,” NMC sources told TOI.Recently, the municipal corporation had formed 37 teams to scan each part of the city to zero in on residents with foreign travel history, especially from the severely-affected countries. The main task of these squads was to locate such overseas travellers whose names were not in the lists.District collector Suraj Mandhare, district civil surgeon Suresh Jagdale and civic chief Radhakrishna Game are in touch with each other on a daily basis to ensure that no one with travel history goes unchecked after reaching Nashik city.So far, the local administration has data of 150 Nashikites with travel history which was furnished by the state government and some had self-reported to the local authorities after reaching the city.“Our teams comprising medical officer and few other para-medical personnel are extremely vigilant in the city to identity such overseas travellers whose names are not in the list,” added NMC sources.According to a senior district administration functionary, the airports cannot be blamed for a few names that go missing from the list. “The workload of the airports at present is huge. And the ratio of people missing from the lists is negligible as compared to names appearing in the list,” said the top official.

Title: In fresh videos, rebel MLAs say they don’t want to meet Digvijaya Singh
Content:
File photo of Digvijaya Singh

BHOPAL: In fresh videos that surfaced on Wednesday, the rebel Congress MLAs supporting Jyotiraditya Scindia holed up in Bengaluru, have refused to speak to senior Congress leader Digvijaya Singh. The videos surfaced soon after Digvijaya Singh who went to meet the rebel MLAs in Bengaluru was arrested.

Former ministers in Digvijaya Singh cabinet during 1998 -2003, Aidal Singh Kansana and Bisahulal Singh who are among the rebel MLAs refused to speak to him.

Six-time-MLA, Bisahulal Singh said in a video clip, “For a year, I kept pleading to include me as a minister in the government. For 40 years, I accepted Digvijaya Singh as my leader, but he made a fool of me. Nepotism and blind love for his son made the Congress to drop my name from the list of ministers before the swearing-in. I will not speak to him, let him go back honorably.”

Another video showed Aidal Singh Kansana saying, “We came to know that Digvijaya Singh and other MLAs are in Bengaluru. For a year, we did a lot of talking and they did not listen to us. What will he do after talking to us for one day?”

Expelled minister Govind Singh Rajput said, “We have come here out of free will. All of us came here willingly. In the morning, we came to know that Digvijaya Singh has come and is unnecessarily creating trouble telling the staff and guards at the gates that he wants to meet us. We do not want to meet him. All the MLAs here have sent their resignations.”

Another expelled minister Imarti Devi said in a fresh video that she has come to know of Digvijaya Singh’s visit to Bengaluru. “I have just come to know that Digvijaya Singh has come here to meet us. We have fled from Madhya Pradesh because of Digvijaya Singh. He has destroyed the party. We do not want to be in a party which has Digvijaya Singh. I appeal to the Bengaluru police to protect us from Digvijaya Singh, we absolutely don’t want to meet him,” she said.

Title: Govt withdraws cases related to Tuni arson during 2016 Kapu stir
Content:
Vijayawada: The state government on Wednesday withdrew prosecutions related to Tuni arson in 2016 during Kapu reservation agitations and in the cases related to attacks on Reliance properties in Anantapur, Guntur and other places across the state in 2010 when then chief minister Y S Rajashekhar Reddy passed away.

Based on the report submitted by director general of police, the government decided to withdraw prosecution in 51 cases registered in connection with the Kapu Reservation agitation at Tuni in East Godavari district, said the GO 312 issued by the home department.

Similarly, the government issued GO 314 withdrawing the prosecution against the accused in the cases registered in connection with the attacks took place on Reliance properties at Anantapur, Guntur and other places across the state.

Various Reliance properties were attacked after reports about a conspiracy theory on the demise of Y S Rajasekhar Reddy. The GO said that the incidents took place out of emotional outburst and the cases were being withdrawn.

The government had ordered inquiries by Crime Investigation Department (CID) after agitators torched Ratnachal Express in Tuni. Several YSRC leaders were grilled by the CID as suspects for alleged conspiracy in the issue.

Title: Covid-19 scare: Bars, restaurants to remain closed until March 31
Content: PUDUCHERRY: All bars and restaurants will remain closed from Thursday to March 31 as a precautionary measure to prevent the spread of coronavirus in the Union territory of Puducherry , said chief minister V Narayanasamy.Speaking to reporters on Wednesday Narayanasamy said the retail and wholesale liquor outlets will remain open. He said a 68-year-old woman from Palloor in Mahe, Puducherry’s enclave in Kerala tested positive for coronavirus on Wednesday. He said the woman reached her hometown eight days ago after undertaking Haj pilgrimage.She had symptoms of fever, cough and breathlessness. She tested positive for coronavirus on Wednesday afternoon. She has been undergoing treatment at an isolation ward in Mahe government general hospital. Her condition is stable, he said.Narayanasamy said the health officials have begun the process of tracing and screening the people who came in contact with her after her return.
