He said he along with health minister Malladi Krishna Rao will visit Mahe on Friday to review the preparedness of the government machinery in the prevention and spread of the coronavirus in the region.Meanwhile, foreigners and Indians, who travelled abroad and reached Puducherry after January 1 have been directed to voluntarily come forward and contact the special cell at the district collector office for health screening. Puducherry district collector cum magistrate T Arun said special clinics have been set up at the government general hospital, Jawaharlal institute of postgraduate medical education and research (Jipmer), all medical colleges and chest clinic at Gorimedu to screen them as per the protocol prescribed by the Union health and family welfare ministry. The field-level officials of the primary health centres concerned will monitor their health condition periodically.Arun imposed various restrictions under the Epidemic diseases act to prevent the spread of Covid-19 virus. The Centre had declared the Covid-19 incidence as a disaster under the provision of disaster management act, 2005. Arun directed the closure of anganwadi centres, schools and other educational institutions and training centres, malls, Sunday market (on March 22 and March 29), cinema theatres, beauty parlours, spa, clubs, discotheque, gyms, swimming pools, sports training classes, sports academy and centres, stadiums and betel shops with different kinds of pan/ghutka masala until March 31.Similarly, Sri Aurobindo Ashram , botanical garden, Bharathi Park, Chunnambar Boat House and government museum will remain closed for the visitors and tourists.Arun said medical and dental colleges and paramedical institutions will function and the services of the faculty members, paramedical staff members and students will be used to strengthen the healthcare system in the territory.

Title: Coronavirus: 1 person’s prevention will help save many, says Uttar Pradesh CM in video appeal
Content: LUCKNOW: Chief minister Yogi Adityanath on Wednesday appealed to the people to take preventive steps against coronavirus to contain its spread.In a video appeal to the people of the state, the CM spoke about the state’s preparedness to counter the virus and emphasised how its prevention was easy.In the two-and-a-half-minute video, Yogi said: “The entire world is battling with coronavirus. The governments at the Centre and in the state are taking all possible efforts to provide best quality treatment to patients suffering from coronavirus. As many as 1,268 beds have been reserved across Uttar Pradesh to set up isolation wards in all the 75 districts.” The chief minister added that even as arrangements were being made, prevention was easier and more important.“Prevention will not only save the ones who adopt it, but also contribute towards saving one’s family, neighbourhood and community at large. Any suspected person, living anywhere, must get in touch with health officials in their district and follow isolation protocols. Washing hands with soap several times a day is the most effective step to keep the virus away,” he said.The video message is a joint effort of UP government, state health and panchayati raj departments, National health Mission, Unicef and WHO.The health team has produced 10 such videos with messages from health minister Jai Pratap Singh, technical experts, religious leaders among others.

Title: Extend 25% quota for Puducherry students in PU, Vaithilingam urges Centre
Content:
Representative image

PUDUCHERRY: Puducherry Lok Sabha MP V Vaithilingam has urged the Centre to extend 25% reservation for Puducherry students in all courses offered by Pondicherry University .

Vaithilingam made the plea during the zero-hour in the Lok Sabha on Tuesday. He said the university presently extends 25% reservation for Puducherry students only in 21 courses whereas the university offers 158 postgraduate and research programs. He said Pondicherry University established in 1985 is the only university in the Union territory.

“There is no state or private university in Puducherry. All the government and private colleges are affiliated to Pondicherry University. Initially, 25% of the seats were reserved for the students of Puducherry in eight courses. Subsequently, it was extended to 21 courses only whereas the university presently has 15 schools and 51 departments offering 158 postgraduate and research programs,” he said.

Vaithilingam pointed out that the university did not extend the reservation for Puducherry students for the courses launched after 2013 as it did not get the nod from the Union human resource development ministry.

“Due to this, the students of Puducherry are forced to compete through all India quota and our students are affected very much. I request the government to extend the reservation of 25% to the students of Puducherry for all the courses offered by the Pondicherry University,” said Vaithilingam.

Title: Covid-19 fails to subdue hostility between Kiran Bedi & V Narayanasamy
Content: PUDUCHERRY: The Covid-19 scare has not subdued the hostility between chief minister V Narayanasamy and lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi as they continue to engage in establishing their authority.Narayanasamy on Wednesday told reporters that he had directed the chief secretary and all secretaries to honour the Madras high court bench's order, which according to him, declared that the lieutenant governor can only act as per the aid and advice of the council of ministers and cannot outrightly reject any proposal or direct the authorities to act otherwise.He said he told them that the LG can call for clarifications on the proposals from them and they can submit information to her only through him. Bedi reacted sharply to Narayanasamy's move stating that the high court dismissed the single judge order, which the chief minister used to threaten the officials with contempt of court proceedings. She said the appeal filed against the single judge order by her and the Centre was allowed by the high court bench. The bench's order reiterated that Puducherry was governed by the Union Territory Act, the Business Rules and the Financial Rules."The same laws and rules have been tested in two preceding judgments of Honble Madras High Court which came a few weeks back, such as in the selection of the election commissioner and the decision of direct transfer money for free rice for BPL and APL being upheld. Hon CM has actually lost in all last three Court cases decided by Honble Madras High, which he did not share with the public. I am compelled to put the record straight. After securing all three judgments in favour of government of India and the Lt Governor I thought the HCM would have accepted that the Puducherry is not a State. And that it is governed by the Union Territory Act and the Business and financial rules which existed from the very beginning, much before I came," she said.

Title: Students stuck in Rome getting no help: Parents
Content: Hyderabad: A week after their flight back to India from Rome was cancelled, 129 Indian students are struggling to find food, water and accommodation, worried parents said on Wednesday.Thirty-four of those stranded are Telugus. “Just bring my daughter back,” said Srilatha, breaking down in tears, during a press meet. Her frustration resonated among the other parents in the room. Srilatha’s daughter Sabari Sirisha has been stuck in Rome since her flight was cancelled on March 11.“Our children don’t have food to eat. They are depending on others’ alms. My daughter is having one meal a day and sleeps at night after drinking water,” said Vijaylakshmi, whose daughter Sushma Narela, is also stuck in Rome. Parents said a local gurudwara was trying to help with some meals.Most students were on the same Air India flight and were asked to bring fitness certificates a few days before they were scheduled to travel. While the students went from pillar to post, local health authorities refused to give them certificates citing an overburdened healthcare system.“Italian authorities are saying they can’t treat their own citizens leave alone Indians,” said Upendera Gandla. He said that for 36 hours his daughter and others were told their flight would take-off, but was eventually cancelled. “I appeal to ministers KT Rama Rao and Eatala Rajendra to get our children back and isolate them here if need be,” he said.Gandla said after a lot of pressure, the Embassy finally got medical tests done and sent them to Pune for testing. “It has been days after the test, but they continue to keep us in the dark,” he said. Some parents said their children who left their university hostels had no option to go back. While the Embassy put them up at local hotels, they were now being told to vacate.D Rajender said he has not heard from his son Deepak for the past 24 hours. “I am worried about his safety. Recently, students from Milan were allowed to travel back without fitness certificates, so why are those in Rome stuck.” He said that with banks shut in the Italian capital, their children were left penniless in a foreign country.“We have been given two helpline numbers none of which are being picked up,”said Ramakrishna, whose sister Soumya is in Rome. His father Ravinder Reddy said it was ironic that despite his daughter not being able to travel back, flights could still be booked. “This shows a lack of coordination between authorities. On one hand, their flight is cancelled, on the other we can book another on their name. There are no disclaimers for fitness certificates,” he said.Ramakrishna also mentioned that he had heard of 14 students travelling by an airlines that did not ask for a fitness certificate. “We have to see if they will be successful in reaching India as they have to make a stop at Addis Ababa,” he said.Meanwhile the Indian Embassy in a three-part tweet said: “Indian Embassy Rome is doing all that is possible within its limited resources and despite the current lockdown, to support and assist more than 300 Indian students in Rome and nearby areas...Swab tests have been taken over the weekend and reports are awaited. We have explained to them what the next step would be. We assure the students that the Embassy is committed to ensuring their safe return.”

Title: Sarada peetam and TTD to conduct anti-Covid-19 yagams
Content: Hyderabad: Several religious organisations are taking up homams and yagams to fight Covid-19 . Sarada Peetham and TTD have decided to conduct ‘Visha jwara peeda hara yagam (anti-viral fever yagam) and health homam.Swathamanandendra Saraswathi, the utharadhikari of Visakha Sri Sarada Peetham, said, “Coronavirus has affected not only the country but the world. We are conducting Visha Jwara Peeda Hara Yagam. Currently, the planetary situation of the country is going through a bad phase. Three grahas and two bad grahas have come together and, as per astrology, it is not good. From March 23, the situation will become worse. The country will face Kala Sarpa Dosha between April 2 and May 10,” Swathamananendra Saraswati said, adding the yagam would help to keep people hale and healthy.“The yagam, which began on Wednesday, will continue for 11 days without break. We are using medicinal herbs, scents and cow dung . The homam’s residue will help everyone be healthy,” he added.Meanwhile, TTD has started performing Veda Parayanam and Yagam for the health of all citizens. The 10-day Sri Srinivasa Veda Mantra Arogya Japa Yagnam , which started on March 16, will conclude on March 25. Vedic exponents from all four southern states were participating in it. TTD is also organising Sri Srinivasa Shantyotsava Sahita Dhanvantari Maha Yagam between March 26 and 28 for the universal well being.

Title: Students coming home from Manila stranded in S’pore
Content: Hyderabad: As many as 100 students returning from Philippines were left stranded at Singapore ’s Changi Airport on Wednesday after local airport authorities barred them from boarding their flights at the eleventh hour.Students said that their boarding passes were either cancelled or withheld, citing official orders from the Indian government. Most of these students are from Hyderabad, Mumbai, Chennai and Bengaluru with many flying back via Malaysia.An advisory issued by the Union ministry of health and family welfare on March 17 prohibits the entry of passengers from Afghanistan, Philippines, Malaysia to India and states that no flight from these destinations can take off for India after 3pm IST.“We were in transit in Malaysia when we were informed about the advisory. While Malaysian Airlines, subsequently, rerouted us through Singapore, we were denied boarding passes by Air India when we landed here. We were told we couldn’t go to India as we had come from Malaysia, which has been blacklisted,” Abhishek Gurnani told TOI over telephone from Singapore. He was booked on an AI flight to Mumbai at 7.45pm (Singapore local time). “We are helpless and stuck here for over seven hours now. We appeal to the government to help. We want to be with our families,” he says.While the batch of Telugu students from Hyderabad, who landed in Singapore directly from Manila, were issued boarding passes, they were barred from taking the flight at the last minute. “We were not given any clear reason. Some said it was an immigration issue, while others claimed that it was because there wasn’t enough space to quarantine us in Hyderabad,” said Angel Suhanthika, a student of medicine. When TOI last spoke with her, she was still running from pillar to post trying to get help.“It’s a catch-22 situation. Now we can’t even go back to Philippines because the government there has withdrawn the 72-hour deadline it had extended to foreign nationals to leave the country. Returning home also seems impossible. If we step out of the airport (by applying for Singapore visa) we will be quarantined for 14 days,” said Manasa from Bengaluru.Students said they were trying to reach the Indian embassy. “Airline operators say they can’t do anything. Only Indian authorities here can rescue us now,” said Pari Gowtham, travelling to Mumbai.

Title: ‘Covid-19 has spread, hasn’t become deadlier’
Content: Q. COVID-19 has been described as a pandemic by the World Health Organization. What does that mean? What is UNICEF doing?A: Characterising COVID-19 as a pandemic is not an indication that the virus has become deadlier. Rather, it’s an acknowledgement of the disease’s geographical spread. UNICEF has been preparing and responding to the epidemic of COVID-19 around the world, and is working with governments and partners to stop transmission of the virus and keep children and their families safe.Q. Does COVID-19 affect children?A: As this is a new virus, we are still learning about how it affects children. We know it is possible for people of any age to be infected with the virus, but so far there are relatively few cases of COVID-19 reported among children. But the protection of children and educational facilities is particularly important.Q. Can pregnant women pass coronavirus to unborn children?A: At this time, there is not enough evidence to determine whether the virus is transmitted from a mother to her baby during pregnancy, or the potential impact this may have on the baby. This is currently being investigated. Pregnant women should continue to follow appropriate precautions to protect themselves from exposure to the virus, and seek medical care early, if experiencing symptoms.Q. Is it safe for a mother to breastfeed if she is infected with coronavirus?A: Considering the benefits of breastfeeding and the insignificant role of breastmilk in the transmission of other respiratory viruses, the mother can continue breastfeeding, while applying all the necessary precautions. For symptomatic mothers well enough to breastfeed, this includes wearing a mask when near a child (including during feeding), washing hands before and after contact with the child (including feeding), and cleaning/disinfecting contaminated surfaces – as should be done in all cases where anyone with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 interacts with others, including children. If a mother is too ill, she should be encouraged to express milk and give it to the child via a clean cup and/or spoon – all while following the same infection prevention methods.Q. How to protect school kids from COVID-19?A: One of the best ways is to simply encourage regular handwashing with soap, for at least 20 seconds. Focus on communicating good health behaviours, such as covering coughs and sneezes with the elbow and washing hands. If schools are closed, it is important for students to follow a timetable for study, play and leisure activities so they keep themselves occupied, safe and healthy.Rusdia’s Dos And Don’tsDOTalk about the coronavirus diseaseTalk about people “acquiring” or “contracting” COVID-19Speak accurately about the risk from COVID-19, based on scientific data and latest official health adviceTalk positively and emphasise the importance of effective prevention measures, including following our tips on hand washingDON’TTalk about people ‘transmitting COVID-19,’ ‘infecting others’ or ‘spreading the virus’ as it implies intentional transmission and assigns blameAttach locations or ethnicity to the disease. Remember: Viruses can’t target people from specific populations, ethnicities, or racial backgrounds.Repeat or share unconfirmed rumoursUse hyperbolic language designed to generate fear like ‘plague’, ‘apocalypse’ etc.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Uttarakhand government asks employees to ‘work from home’
Content: DEHRADUN: In view of the coronavirus threat, Uttarakhand government on Wednesday issued an order stating that state government employees — except those involved in essential services — will be allowed to ‘work from home’. The order will be effective from March 19 to March 25.The order, issued by state chief secretary Utpal Kumar Singh, said, “Only employees who are deemed to be necessary for carrying out work in office are required to be present.” The order does not apply to those employees who handle essential services like health, sanitation, police, transport, civil supplies, power, and drinking water, said a government official.The order further adds that all the employees availing ‘work from home’ facility should be available on phone and must be ready to come to office, if called, to carry out work when required.“World Health Organisation (WHO) has declared the coronavirus outbreak as a pandemic and experts from across the world are urging to practice social distancing to combat coronavirus outbreak. Thus, the government is taking all necessary steps to contain the virus from spreading in the state,” said the government order.Meanwhile, state health secretary Pankaj Pandey also issued an advisory on Wednesday for private companies and offices in Uttarakhand directing them to offer ‘work from home’ options to their employees and implement ‘work in shifts' systems so that only limited number of staff remains at office at a time. Besides, employees suffering from cough, cold or fever should be given leaves on priority by their employers, according to the advisory issued by the health secretary.

Title: BBMP’s plea for suggestions on budget unheard
Content:
The ideas can be submitted on the BBMP website or dropped in suggestion boxes placed at the Palike headquarter... Read More

BENGALURU: Two days after BBMP sought suggestions from citizens , Resident Welfare Associations (RWAs) and institutions for its 2020-2021 budget, not a single communication has reached the civic agency.

While residents and citizen-activists claimed they didn’t know such a notice was issued and saw a plot in it being tucked away in some corners, BBMP officials said the poor response should be viewed in the light of complaints that they never indulge in public consultations.

The ideas can be submitted on the BBMP website or dropped in suggestion boxes placed at the Palike headquarters. March 20 is the last date to respond.

“Last year, we hadn’t issued the advertisement properly but this time we did it well in advance and gave people five days to respond. It’s the third day today and we haven’t got any suggestion,” a senior BBMP official said on Wednesday afternoon.

However, citizen-activists faulted BBMP for sticking to a single mode of publicity, which fails to grab eyeballs. Wondering why the notice never made it to any of the Palike’s social media handles, they pointed out that the BBMP commissioner and mayor have 42,000 and 58,000 followers on Twitter, respectively.

Unni Krishnan, a resident of Jalahalli, said he didn’t know about the notice until somebody informed him. “BBMP puts out a small ad in a newspaper but most people’s focus is on the news,” he said, adding: “The agency should display these notifications in public spaces frequented by people. Also, public consultations about budget preparation should be held in every ward.”

Vishnu Prasad, member of Bellandur Development Forum, said: “The civic body doesn’t want to give better publicity to such things as it’s afraid of our suggestions.”

“The agency should focus on bringing about a transparent process, wherein everyone knows what’s happening in the corporation,” said Kavitha Reddy, a resident of HSR Layout.

However, BBMP commissioner BH Anil Kumar said: “We have done our best to publicise the issue. People need to be more interested in it instead of complaining.”

Title: Bill seeks to halve tenure of panchayat heads in Karnataka
Content:
KS Eshwarappa

BENGALURU: The government on Wednesday tabled a controversial bill which reduces the tenure of gram, taluk and zilla panchayat presidents and vice-presidents to half — from five to two-and-a-half years.

The Karnataka Gram Swaraj and Panchayat Raj (amendment) bill 2020 was tabled by RDPR minister KS Eshwarappa amid the din over the Madhya Pradesh political crisis.

While the debate on the bill is yet to begin, the proposed amendments suggest a drastic change in the original act. According to government sources, the decision to curb the tenure has primarily been taken due to “political considerations”.

“It is basically to share power among more people. Panchayat presidents and vice-presidents function under political patronage. They (parties) don’t like one person to be president for the entire five-year duration,” said a government official, adding that even now, political parties force panchayat presidents and vice-presidents to step down after 30 months.

Yet another reason for the amendment is to reverse the changes brought about by the 2014 Congress regime. A committee led by former Speaker KR Ramesh Kumar had presented a comprehensive report giving complete power to panchayat presidents and vice-presidents for a full term of five years from 30 months.

Another amendment has been proposed to safeguard the tenure of presidents and vice-presidents for at least 15 months, with the government suggesting no motion for no confidence will be moved against them till the expiry of half their tenure.

In other amendments, the government has said any no-confidence motion has to be moved in the presence of the district’s deputy commissioner. The government has also proposed an amendment to allow liquor shops to be open till 48 hours before polling.

Title: Bengaluru: Cops stop Digvijaya from meeting Madhya Pradesh MLAs, detain him
Content:
AICC general secretary Digvijaya Singh with KPCC president DK Shivakumar in Bengaluru on Wednesday

BENGALURU: High drama prevailed outside a private resort near Devanahalli early on Wednesday, after local police stopped Congress Rajya Sabha member and AICC general secretary Digvijaya Singh from meeting the 19 rebel Madhya Pradesh MLAs holed up inside and took him into preventive custody. Karnataka Pradesh Congress Committee (KPCC) president DK Shivakumar and a few party legislators were also detained .

In a reminder of Shivakumar’s protest in Mumbai in 2019, when he tried to meet then Congress rebel MLAs to save the coalition government in Karnataka, Singh tried to drive home the point that state police and the ruling BJP government were not allowing him to meet the MLAs.

“I have repeatedly urged police to meet my voters, considering that I’m contesting the Rajya Sabha elections on March 26. However, I’ve been told my own estranged party colleagues don’t want to meet me. BJP has forcefully kept them in this resort and has even snatched their mobiles,” alleged Singh, while sitting on a dharna along with other party members. He alleged BJP had tried to lure the Congress legislators with sums up to Rs 30 crore each.

However, extending an olive branch to the rebels, Singh said the Congress high command was ready to hold talks directly if they had any concerns. “If we have erred or irked you (rebels), then we are ready to talk to you. Soniaji, Rahul Gandhiji, Priyankaji or Kamal Nathji will directly talk to you,” said Singh.

Rebels in videos: Don’t want to meet him

The 19 rebel MLAs released videos claiming they had nothing to do with Singh and didn’t want to meet him. They said he was only indulging in drama after having ignored them in the past.

Early on Wednesday morning, Singh was welcomed at Kempegowda International Airport (KIA) by newly appointed KPCC chief Shivakumar and Karnataka Congress legislators, including Krishna Byregowda and NA Haris.

Police decided to initiate action against Singh and the others for protesting in a public space without authorisation. They were detained, taken to Amruthalli police station and released after two hours. Later, Singh addressed the media and said he will sit on a fast until he’s allowed to meet the legislators.

According to Congress functionaries, he’s staying at a star hotel in Ganganagar and hadn’t broken his fast till late evening. Meanwhile, Singh and Shivakumar met DG and IGP Praveen Sood to question police’s decision to detain them, asking him to intervene and assist them in meeting the rebel MLAs.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Low tax collection to stunt development projects
Content: AMARAVATI: In addition to the loss of the finance commission grant due to delay in conduct of elections to local bodies, poor tax collections are likely to stall development projects in the state.The revenue wings in the civic bodies could collect only 33% of the total demand during the current fiscal leaving many towns and cities in tatters.With 12 days left to complete the financial year, the authorities in the civic bodies are on their toes to mop up dues from property owners.Special teams have been constituted to collect balance taxes in many towns. The municipal commissioners have been directed to review the situation on a daily basis as the situation is slipping from bad to worse.With shops, malls and hotels are facing closure or restricted operations due to fears about the spread of coronavirus in the next few days, the officials are trying to recover the taxes to the maximum extent possible.Pulivendula, the home town of chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy, however, has logged nearly 70% of the property tax demand. Although Pulivendula is a small town with total property tax demand of Rs 3.88 crore, the authorities have collected nearly Rs 2.77 crore by Wednesday.Property tax collections in many cities including Greater Visakhapatnam, Vijayawada and Guntur are below 40% which could derail development plans. The tax collections in Visakhapatnam are the lowest among the big cities—25% of the total demand by Wednesday.“Although it is a normal practice that majority of the taxes are collected in the last one week of the fiscal, we are worried that the economic slowdown might impact the final stretch of collections too,” said a senior official in the municipal administration department.

Title: Fliers from Gulf moved to quarantine
Content: Passengers who arrived from Kuwait, the UAE, Oman and Qatar at RGI Airport on Wednesday were shifted to different quarantine centres in the city.Since Wednesday morning, nearly 1,300 passengers who arrived in 10 different flights were shifted from the airport and they were quarantined. The effort to shift them from airport and accommodating them in different quarantine centers was being done by health, revenue and police officials in coordination.On Sunday, the government initially decided to quarantine passengers who have been coming from seven countries -- China, Iran, South Korea, Italy , Spain, Germany, and France. But on Wednesday, officials decided to quarantine passengers coming from Kuwait, the UAE, Oman and Qatar also. Passengers have been screened and they are being either quarantined at the government-declared centres or asked them to self-quarantine in their homes.Health, revenue officials along with police are coordinating the process of transporting passengers from the airport to quarantine centres.

Title: Amid political crisis, Kamal Nath cabinet creates three new districts
Content:
File photo of Kamal Nath

BHOPAL: The Kamal Nath government’s big decisions continue in the thick of political crisis. On Wednesday, the cabinet approved creation of three districts — Maihar, Chachoda and Nagda.

Maihar was the claim of rebel BJP MLA Narayan Tripathi and Chachoda that of Laxman Singh, Digvijaya’s brother, who had removed ‘Congress’ from his Twitter bio yesterday. The number of districts in MP has now gone up to 55.

The government explained that creating new districts will speed up development work in these places, but in the middle of the political turmoil it is being seen as a move to placate MLAs.

Tripathi, who has repeatedly defied the party line and said that the Nath government is safe, has long been demanding that Maihar — so long in Satna district — be made a district. Laxman Singh has been campaigning for the same for his constituency, Chachoda, in Guna, and even sat on dharna at the residence of his brother, Digvijaya, in October last year to place this demand.

Similarly, there was long-pending demand from local leaders to carve Nagda as a district from Ujjain. On Wednesday, Dilip Singh Gurjar , the local MLA, was with law minister P C Sharma when he met the Press to announce the cabinet decisions.

Other Decisions in Cabinet

CCTV cameras in courts: The cabinet as granted administrative and financial approval of Rs 125.89 crore for installation of CCTV cameras in all subordinate courts of Madhya Pradesh high court. This project will be carried out in three parts — Rs 40 crore for the first year (2020-21), Rs 50 crore for the second and Rs 35.89 crore for the third. It will be implemented first in the courts of Jabalpur district.

Free govt guarantee of Rs 26,000 crore to Civil Supplies Corporation: The cabinet approved free government guarantee of Rs 26,000 crore for 2020-21 fiscal to Madhya Pradesh State Civil Supplies Corporation for procurement of foodgrains under decentralized procurement scheme, operation of PDS and other government schemes. It was also decided that RBI’s food credit limit, which has a higher rate of interest, would be obtained if a higher amount is required for procurement.

Extension of Tenures: The cabinet, in keeping with a Supreme Court order in connection with the Sardar Sarovar Project, decided to extend the contractual appointment of retired high court judge Shambhu Singh, Syed Ali Naqvi, IS Shrivastava, SL Jain and SS Dwivedi from April 1, 2020, to March 31, 2021. The contractual period of retired IAS officer Vinod Semwal and Arun Kochar as member (administrative) and retired district and sessions judge Abdul Jabbar Khan for the post of member (judicial) from April 1, 2020, to March 31, 2021, or till the disposal of cases (whichever is earlier) in the Grievance Redressal Authority for Narmada Package Projects.

Similarly, it was decided to extend the contractual appointment period of retired IAS officer Chaturbhuj Singh till December 31, 2020. Cabinet granted contractual appointment to retired district and sessions judge Tarkeshwar Singh for the post of member (judicial) for a year from the date of joining in Grievance Redressal Authority (Narmada Package Projects).

Title: ‘Puducherry lethargic in preventing Covid-19’
Content: PUDUCHERRY: The opposition AIADMK party has accused the Congress government of acting in a lethargic manner in preventing the incidence and spread of coronavirus in Puducherry . AIADMK legislature party leader A Anbalagan told reporters on Wednesday that he will write to the Union health and family welfare ministry on Friday listing out the shortcomings of the government in taking effective measures to prevent the outbreak of the virus.He regretted that the cabinet was divided in closing all bars and restaurants from Wednesday. He claimed that the chief minister's decision to close the bars and restaurants from Wednesday was stalled by two ministers. He was of the opinion that the Puducherry government has been acting belatedly in tackling the issue. He urged the Puducherry district collector to impose Section 144 of the CrPc banning assembly of people to prevent the incidence of the virus. tnn

Title: VSEZ tops countrywide growth rate
Content:
Visakhapatnam: The Visakhapatnam Special Economic Zone (VSEZ) has topped the list of SEZs in the country by registering a growth rate of 35.05%, in comparison with last year’s growth rate. “The consolidated export figures touched Rs 94,126 crore,” A Rama Mohan Reddy, development commissioner of VSEZ , added while making the announcement.

Reddy said that this was achieved despite globally unfavourable conditions and noted that the merchandise sector witnessed a growth rate 27.4% this financial year. Reddy announced that approvals for 95 new units have been issued, bringing in an investment of Rs 8,631 crore and projected exports to the tune of Rs 59,111 crore and employment to 69,077 people in the next five years.

Reddy added that the approval for one new IT unit and expansion of three existing units has been accorded during the Unit Approval Committee meeting held on March 18 at the VSEZ Hyderabad sub-office, keeping in view the sunset clause amidst fear surrounding the coronavirus outbreak. Reddy added, “VSEZ has already given permission for IT units to allow their employees to work from home.”

On the new proposed unit and expansion proposals, Reddy added that the new investments would be worth Rs 294 crore, providing employment to 4,955 employees.

Title: Hyderabad Coronavirus News: Wary Telangana set for quarantine;Target 10,000 beds
Content: HYDERABAD: Taking no chances, the state government has decided to have 10,000 beds ready to keep those coming from abroad under observation. Highly-placed sources told TOI that quarantine facilities would be ready in next three days.Allaying fears, senior officials said there was no need to panic and the situation was well under control. The revenue department was entrusted with the task to identify as many beds as possible in public institutitons and educational institutes.Revenue officials of erstwhile Rangareddy and Hyderabad districts have been scouting for suitable locations along with health employees. “We are taking these measures in view of the central government’s advisory that those returning from abroad have to be quarantined for 14 days,” a senior official explained.He clarified that those who test positive or those who are suspected to be having coronavirus symptoms would not be sent to these facilities. “Only those who are coming back from aboard will be sent to these faclities and keep them under observation,” the official said. Health minister Eatala Rajender had already announced in the state assembly a few days ago that virus-hit patients would be kept in Gandhi and chest hospitals.While underconstruction buildings of the government are being considered for such facilities, some private hospitals have also come forward to provide beds to keep those returning from foreign travel under observation. District officials are engaging some private agencies to provide food at these centres.Officials have also decided to counsel people who are objecting to quarantine facilities in their localities. “Most people do not differenciate between an isolation ward for patients and suspected cases and a simple quarantine facility,” an official pointed out.Residents in Vikarabad and Rajendra Nagar had earlier kicked up a furore over quarantine facilities coming up in their localities. “Official held a meeting with us. We are convinced with their response. We will cooperate with the government,” KR Reddy, a resident of Vikarabad, said.

Title: SC refuses to hear plea on deadline relief for BS-IV sale
Content:
NEW DELHI: In a setback to automobile dealers, the Supreme Court on Wednesday refused to hear their plea seeking permission to sell BS-IV vehicles beyond the March 31 deadline when BS-VI norms will kick in, to clear their inventory which they have not been able to sell due to economic slowdown and coronavirus scare.

A bench of Justices Arun Mishra and M R Shah refused to list the application filed by Federation of Automobile Dealers ’ Associations (FADA) and said it can’t be heard before March 31.

The apex court had way back in October 2018 ruled that not only manufacturing but sale of BS-IV vehicles will not be allowed after cleaner BS-VI fuel norm comes into force from April 1, 2020 to curb pollution.

FADA contended that inventory of BS-IV vehicles have piled up with dealers as they were not being purchased due to economic slowdown and pleaded they be allowed to sell till April end. The SC had in 2018 said health will have to be given precedence and asked the automobile industry to show the “will, responsibility and urgency” to adopt cleaner BS-VI fuel.

Title: Over 70k people under home-quarantine
Content:
People visit Gandhi Hospital for Covid-19 tests on Wednesday. Passengers, who have returned from abroad, will ... Read More

Hyderabad: With another case of Covid-19 reported in the city, the state government has gone into overdrive and placed 1,683 people, who arrived in the city on Wednesday, under quarantine. With this, the number of international travellers under home-quarantine has gone up to 70,545.

The health department has now decided to forms teams consisting of health, civic, police and revenue officials, who along with Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP) officials, will visit these suspected patients to review their conditions.

“Those showing symptoms of Covid-19 will be shifted to a hospital and tests will be conducted,” said a senior health official.

Meanwhile, the state government intends to put every international traveller returning to the city under isolation and rapid action teams will check on them at regular intervals. Passengers, who have returned to the city from abroad either directly or after landing at other cities, will have to compulsorily undergo thermal checking as well as fill up self-declaration forms.

The teams set up at the district level are checking on the people kept in home isolation by either calling them up or making video calls to check on them everyday.

So far, the rapid action teams have picked up atleast 10 suspected patients from their homes and rushed them to Gandhi hospital in the last two week. “In case a passenger reports of having symptoms of Covid-19, our team will take them to Gandhi hospital for check-up. Also people who do not respond to our follow-up calls are being physically checked upon apart from symptomatic patients in home quarantine,” said a senior official from the state health department.

Title: BJP says withdraw CAA resolution
Content:
Hyderabad: Telangana BJP on Wednesday appealed to governor Tamilisai Soundararajan to call for special assembly session to withdraw the resolution passed against CAA, NRC and NPR recently.

Party leaders — K Laxman, DK Aruna and N Ramchander Rao — submitted a memorandum to the governor to instruct chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao to hold a one-day session. They also urged her to instruct the state government to cooperate with the Centre in taking up NPR exercise, as envisaged from April 1 this year.

They wanted the chief minister to tender an unconditional apology for deliberately misleading the people of the state on CAA and NPR. TNN

Title: Uttarakhand: Platform tickets get costlier from today
Content:
DEHRADUN: A day after the Indian Railways hiked the price of platform tickets to Rs 50 to prevent unnecessary crowding in stations , the order came into effect in Moradabad division under Northern Railways . The divisional commercial manager of Moradabad division on Wednesday issued an order to revise the rate of platform tickets, in the wake of growing coronavirus scare.

In railway stations like Dehradun , Haridwar Roorkee, Najibabad, Moradabad and Bareilly, which fall under the Moradabad division, the price of platform tickets will increase from Rs 10 to Rs 50 from March 19 to April 15.

Speaking to TOI, Dehradun station director Ganesh Chand Thakur said, “We will follow this order from Thursday. As per directions, a single platform ticket will be charged at Rs 50 instead of Rs 10 now.”

“All passengers are requested to avoid unwanted gatherings at railway stations,” Thakur added.

Title: Alternate healing is in as people look to combat Covid-19
Content:
Hyderabad: Among those who are frantically turning up at private hospitals on the assumption that they may have Covid-19, only a few are being re-directed to Gandhi Hospital. This was largely seen at hospitals on Wednesday.

“My uncle was turned away from a top private hospital in the morning after he said he may have contracted the coronavirus. Although he had not visited any foreign country, he works in an IT company where some employees were suspected to have similar symptoms. He panicked and we had to make calls to various doctors, including homeopathic and Ayurvedic doctors, to assure him that all is well,” said B Rao, a resident of Mehdipatnam.

Some of the worried people are also approaching alternate healers and psychologists for help as overloaded hospitals turning them away.

Notwithstanding the WHO alert on the possibility of elderly people getting affected psychologically due to the virus scare, patients with psychological disorders were showing heightened symptoms, psychiatrists claimed. A 36-year-old woman patient, who has obsessive compulsive disorder, came back to the clinic this week complaining of repetitive thoughts getting infected with coronavirus. “She even started excessively washing hands specially because this infection spreads via contamination,” said a psychiatrist.

In another case, a 27-year-old software professional, working in Hyderabad and living away from family, sought help as he was constantly worried about the virus symptoms and having thoughts that his family members were getting infected. “He was worried that he is going to lose them. People with pre-existing anxiety have been the most affected psychologically with coronavirus,” said Dr Virinchi Sharma, consultant psychiatrist.

Title: Govt closes all edu institutions till March 31
Content: Vijayawada: The state government on Wednesday decided to close all educational institutions from March 19. Thousands of schools, colleges, universities and other educational institutions will remain closed till March 31 . The decision was taken at a review meeting chaired by chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy at his camp office here. The meeting, which was attended by health and education department officials, took stock of the situation in the state in view of the Covid-19 epidemic.PV Ramesh, additional chief secretary to the chief minister, took to Twitter to make the announcement: “The state government has decided to close all educational institutions to strengthen the ongoing measures to prevent and contain Covid-19. The closure of educational institutions applies to students, teachers, support and administrative staff of both private and public institutions, including nurseries, schools, colleges, universities, polytechnics, ITIs, coaching and training institutions, and professional colleges.”School education commissioner V Chinaveerabhadrudu, in a communique, instructed officials to close all schools with immediate effect. “However, all the notified board and entrance examinations shall be conducted as per schedule. All welfare hostels and residential schools under all managements shall continue to function for students appearing these examinations. Other students should vacate hostels with immediate effect,” said Chinaveerabhadrudu.In its recent advisory on social distancing measures in view of the Covid-19 scare, the Union government proposed the closure of all educational establishments, gyms, museums, cultural and social centres, swimming pools and theatres till March 31. The advisory asked the states to advise the students to stay at home and go for online education. It has also proposed exploring the possibility of postponing exams, but continuing the ongoing examinations by strictly ensuring a physical distance of one metre amongst the students.AP has so far registered one positive case of Covid-19. As per official statistics, the number of persons identified for observation is 879. While 254 persons have already completed the 28-day observation period, 605 persons were put under home isolation. The remaining 20 were admitted to isolation wards at various hospitals.

Title: Six staff members booked for keeping club activities open amid coronavirus scare
Content: KOLHAPUR: The Satara city police have registered an offence against six staff members of a recreational club for keeping the club activities open and violating the government orders.The six employees are identified as Sambhaji Anandrao Patil Mohan Ramchandra Chavan , Vishal Ramesh Chavan, Amit Ramchandra Jadhav, Vishal Pradip Solanki and Amit Narayan Kamble . They were booked under section 188 (disobedience of public order, duly promulgated by a public servant) and 505 of IPC (public mischief).Acting on a tip-off that the private club has continued its activities, a team of policemen reached the club and checked its premises, where they found few citizens exercising at the gymnasium. The citizens were warned and told not to use the club services until the government orders are evoked. Subsequently, the six employees were booked under different sections of IPC. For disobedience of public order, a court can sentence an individual for imprisonment for up to six years.Following the activity, the club immediately stopped all its services and put up a board announcing the same.Two-days back, the Satara district collector told all the shopping malls, movie halls, gardens, and other spots to be shut for the general public in view of the coronavirus outbreak.Meanwhile, the NIV report of a six-year-old girl, who was admitted to Satara civil hospital, has tested negative, said an official communication from the district administration. The girl had been to Abu Dhabi with her mother recently and as a precautionary measure was admitted to hospital on Monday. Earlier, a thirty-year-old youth also returned from Abu Dhabi tested negative. He too was kept under observation in the isolation ward of the civil hospital.Sangli district guardian minister Jayant Patil conducted a review meeting on administrative efforts to curb the coronavirus outbreak. Talking to media persons, Patil said that over 20 ventilators have been made available as demanded by the local administration.He added that reports of 11 people, who were kept in the isolation ward at Sangli hospital, are found negative. As many as 180 people in the district have been asked for home quarantine by the district health administration.

Title: Polish student can stay in India: Calcutta High Court
Content:
Calcutta High Court

KOLKATA: Polish student Kamil Siedcynski will not have to leave India, at least for the moment. The Calcutta High Court on Wednesday set aside the ‘leave-India’ notice issued to Siedcynski by the Foreign Residents’ Registration Office ( FRRO ) for being present in an anti-CAA rally with other students of Jadavpur University on December 19.

Siedcynski had moved the court against this order, stating that his version was not heard by the FRRO and that the Constitution grants him certain rights.

The Union of India had contended that the Constitution doesn’t grant rights to protest against the government to foreigners and submitted a confidential report stating how the Polish student had participated in other anti-government protests.

Justice Sabyasachi Bhattacharyya, after hearing both sides, dismissed the confidential report for not containing any valid ground for expulsion of the student from India. The court also held that some Articles of the Constitution do not discriminate between Indians and foreigners residing in the country legally. “In a democratic country like India, the rights of any authority cannot be totally arbitrary and unrestricted. The fundamental rights enshrined in the Constitution govern not only Indian citizens but foreigners as well, so long as they are on Indian soil,” the court observed.

According to Justice Bhattacharyya, all submissions made by the government regarding its sole right to decide on such issues pertain to illegal immigrants or foreigners whose visas have expired. He observed that this right cannot be used against somebody whom the government has not only issued a visa but also renewed it subsequently.

“The visa confers valuable rights on the petitioner, not merely to stay in India but also associated rights, which are assured by the Constitution to both citizens and foreigners…..For a brilliant student of the academic standard of the petitioner, it is but natural that he shall have free interactions in an atmosphere of freedom with Indians, at least while in India. Such liberties, as guaranteed by the Constitution….are basic rights inherent in human existence,” the court said.

The contention by the government that Siedcynski was heard at the FRRO was also shot down by Justice Bhattacharyya. The right of hearing was granted after issuance of the ‘Leave India’ notice, which makes it a mere ‘lip-service and eye-wash’, he observed.

Title: Over 3,000 Asha workers sensitised in Nashik
Content: NASHIK: Over 3,000 asha workers from across the district were sensitised about coronavirus under the guidance of district collector Suraj Mandhare , civil surgeon Suresh Jagdale , district health officer Dawal Salve and district Asha co-ordinator Sharad Nagare The asha workers operate at village-level and have been instructed to keep a close watch on villagers who are suffering with cold, fever and flu-like symptoms and report about the same to their respective primary health centre (PHC). The workers have also been asked to keep a vigil on people in villages with travel history from a foreign country.

Title: HC issues notices on Sanchaitha’s appt
Content:
Vijayawada: The high court on Wednesday issued notices to the state government and other respondents in the petitions challenging the GOs appointing P Sanchaitha Gajapathi Raju as the chairman and hereditary trustee of Sri Varaha Lakshmi Narasimha Swamy Vari Devasthanam, Simhachalam and also appointing her as chairman of Maharajah Alak Narayan Society of Arts and Science ( MANSAS ) Trust.

Former Union minister, P Ashok Gajapathi Raju, moved the high court challenging the GOs issued by the state government recognising Sanchaitha and her sister Urmila Gajapathi Raju as founder family members of the MANSAS Trust and Sanchaitha’s appointment as chairman of the Trust. On the other hand, Ashok Gajapathi Raju’s sister RV Sunitha Prasad challenged the GO issued appointing Sanchaitha as chairman of the Simhachalam temple trust board.

Arguing on behalf of Ashok Gajapathi Raju, senior counsel M Vidya Sagar argued that the three GOs issued by the state government are in violation of Deed of Trust executed in 1958. He argued that according to the Deed, only male successors are to be made the chairman of the MANSAS Trust. He said Anand Gajapathi Raju, the elder brother of Ashok Gajapathi Raju continued as chairman and after Ashok Gajapathi Raju continuing as the chairman after demise of his brother.

Sunitha Prasad also contended on the same grounds that according to the by-laws of the Temple Trust, only male children from the family are to be made as successors and appointment of Sanchaitha is illegal and in violation of Trust Deed executed by her father PVG Raju.

Taking the arguments into consideration, the high court issued notices to the principal secretary revenue (endowments) department and other respondents. Further hearing on the matter has been posted to March 24.

Title: Heavy rains lash city, region
Content:
Nagpur: The trend of surprise showers has become a regular phenomenon for the city as rains lashed the city on Tuesday night around 11pm and continued intermittently till Wednesday afternoon.

Many parts of the city saw heavy rainfall around 3am on the intervening night of Tuesday and Wednesday.

Till Wednesday evening, the city recorded nearly 6.2mm rains. According to met officials, a trough formed at the lower level led to rains. “On Wednesday, a cyclonic circulation was also formed over central Maharashtra,” an official said.

Rains brought down the mercury levels in most parts of the region . In Nagpur, the maximum temperature came down to 31.9 from 35.8 degrees Celsius. This was nearly four degrees below normal. The lowest maximum was recorded in Gondia at 28.6 degrees Celsius on Wednesday.

As per the forecast of Regional Meteorological Centre (RMC), Nagpur, light to moderate rains might occur in some places of the region on Thursday. In Nagpur, a few spells of thundershowers are expected for the next two days.

With 26.2mm, Bramhapuri recorded the highest rainfall in the region. Next in line were Amravati and Wardha receiving 25.9mm and 21.7mm rains respectively.

Since the beginning of the year, Vidarbha has been witnessing surprise showers due to discontinuity in winds. Last month too, a few spells of rains hit the region leading to fall in mercury levels. December 2019 and January this year too witnessed rainfall along with humidity and cold.

Title: Raisin auctions called off in Sangli & Tasgaon
Content: KOLHAPUR: The raisin trade in Sangli district, one of the largest raisin producer districts in India, has been stopped amidst the coronavirus scare.The production of raisins from the grapes grown in the region starts in January and last till April-end. The buyers, mostly traders, come from across the country to buy the raisins here. The auctions take place in two major markets — Sangli and Tasgaon. The raisin produced in south Maharashtra, mainly in Sangli and Solapur districts, are bought to the markets where every licenced shop holds auctions.Rajendra Kumbhar, the president of the Sangli district raisin association, said, “We have cancelled the auctions. The traders come from the big cities — some of which have had positive coronavirus cases. They may bring the virus with them. As of now, we have cancelled the auctioning in both the markets till March 31. If the condition improves, we will restart the auctions.”The grape farmers are facing the brunt of the auction cancellation. They can get money for their produce only after the auction. At present, only 50% of the raisins have been auctioned. The farmers are now in a dilemma about whether to go make more raisins or sell the grapes in the market. The farmers have to put their raisins in the cold storage facilities and they have to pay for the facility. Kumbhar said that the storages have adequate capacity to accommodate most of the raisins produced.Vilas Mane, a raisin producer from Nagaj in Kavathe Mahankal tehsil of Sangli district, has harvested the grapes and started processing them make raisins. “If the decision to cancel auctions was taken a few days ago, I would have sold the grapes. The table grapes are fetching good money as the production of grapes had fallen by around 30% due to untimely rainfall last year. Currently, the farmers like us have no other option but to wait till the auctions to restart.”The grapes grown for making raisins are of a different variety. They fetch less price in markets when compared to the table grapes. Therefore, even if the farmers decide to sell the grapes in the market, they will suffer losses.IN NUMBERS*Sangli area accounts for 60% of raisin production in India*Cultivation of raisin grapes is done across 60,000 acre*Annual raisin production is approximately 50,000 tonne

Title: Edu min urged to close down tech institutes
Content:
Hyderabad: Members of Telangana Engineering Colleges Faculty Association met education minister Sabitha Indra Reddy on Tuesday urging her to declare holidays for teachers in technical institutions as well.

In a representation submitted to the minister, the association said that teachers were equally susceptible to the spread of coronavirus (Covid-19). Although some colleges have asked teachers to come to college in batches, the association sought complete closure of higher educational institutions.

Teachers rued that many engineering colleges are conducting workshops in violation to orders. “We were asked to attend a seminar which was attended by around 200 teachers. This was complete lack of social responsibility towards teachers,” said a teacher of Chaitanya Bharathi Institute of Technology.

Title: Indian-Americans seek to play increased role in US politics
Content:
HYDERABAD: Ahead of his visit to India, Donald Trump retweeted a video from the film Baahubali with his head morphed instead of the actor Prabhas. He shared the video with the caption, “Look so forward to being with my great friends in INDIA!”.

While many saw the US president’s gesture as a curtain-raiser to his India trip, others felt this was his attempt to create a greater connection with Indian-Americans, especially Telugus, in an election year.

Analysts have been speaking about the potential of the Indian-American community in the US. In fact, student group North American Association of Indian Students (NAAIS) has recently started a #DesiVote campaign to get unregistered Indian-Americans to exercise their franchise.

NAAIS claims there are over two million unregistered Indian-American voters. Breaking down the number, Sudhanshu Kaushik, founder, NAAIS, said, “We found that there were about 4.5 million Indian-Americans in US in 2016, out of which 3.5 million people were above 18 years old. In 2018, 800,000 Indian-Americans came out to vote for the mid-term elections. Even if we round that figure to a million, it means there are definitely over two million voters who did not vote.”

The focus of the #DesiVote campaign are these eligible voters, said Kaushik, adding that while Indian-Americans play a huge role in the economic and social spheres in the US are, “Politically underepresented and at the same time are not going out to make our voices heard.”

Also speaking of the great demographic profile, Chinmayi Balusu, a NAAIS member, said, “I wanted to join the effort to mobilise Indian-Americans to register to vote. This would be the first step to exercising their political power.” As a first-time voter herself, she said the initiative would aim to help people find the resources to register.

Meanwhile, several India-Americans agreed they would like to see the community play a more proactive role. “We contribute majorly towards taxes and are educated, law abiding citizens. Better representation for us would mean better politics in the US,” said Suresh K, a resident of Dallas. Ramesh Reddy, from New Jersey, said he did not vote in the last presidential elections, but will this time. “I think every vote matters,” he said.

Title: Webinar for Sec V on nCoV measures
Content: Kolkata: The Nabadiganta Industrial Township Authority ( NDITA ) held a webinar with several top IT companies operating in Sector V on Wednesday to discuss the precautionary measures that are needed to prevent Covid- 19 from spreading in the IT hub.Around 90 company representatives attended the webinar, where two doctors from the state health department, along with senior officials of NDITA and Nasscom and Sector V stakeholders, laid down the general precautionary measures.The IT firms have been advised to allow employees to work from home as much as possible. The authorities are urging people not to spit on streets. The NDITA officials will keep a watch through CCTVs on this while the offenders will be slapped with highest fines. The IT representatives were asked to avoid meeting visitors at their workplaces. The respective facility managers of the IT buildings should ensure that the office premises are cleaned at least twice with utmost care.The gyms and other recreational centres in offices should be closed, the IT representatives were advised at the webinar.“We will circulate an advisory to all the IT companies operating in Sector V about the precautionary measures,” said an NDITA official. The link of the webinar video will also be circulated among the IT firms by Thursday.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: YSRC opposes poll observer for Chittoor
Content:
Representative Image

VIJAYAWADA: Panchayat Raj minister Peddireddy Ramachandra Reddy on Wednesday strongly opposed the appointment of IAS officer Siddharth Jain as election observer for Chittoor district.

“Election commissioner Ramesh Kumar has posted an officer, who worked as a shadow to former chief minister and TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu in the past, as observer for Chittoor district. Ramesh Kumar and Naidu have been friends since their college days, and have now joined hands. Naidu put the state in a debt trap. Now, the state is going to face a loss of Rs 5,000 crore,” he alleged.

The contention that elections were postponed in West Bengal and Maharashtra stands no ground as no notification was issued in those states, he said. “But in AP, election notification was issued, nominations have been filed and when the elections were due for completion in 10 days, they are postponed all of a sudden,” Peddireddy added.

Meanwhile, Naidu welcomed the SC’s decision on postponing of local body polls in AP. “Coronavirus has created panic across the country and the top court has rightly upheld the decision of the SEC in postponing local body polls in the state,” Naidu said.

Title: Pune standing committee nod to Rs 233 crore for Metro extension
Content:
PUNE: The standing committee of the Pune Municipal Corporation has given its go-ahead for allocating Rs 233.75 crore for the Swargate-Katraj extension of Metro, which is expected to cost Rs 4,283 crore.

The standing committee has also sought the general body’s nod to allocate the project work to Maharashtra Metro Rail Corporation (MahaMetro) and show the final alignment of the route in the development plan (DP). The standing committee has also made it clear that the civic administration would not take any responsibility of the loan the Union and state governments would seek for the execution of the project.

As per the plan, the Swargate-Katraj extension work will be taken up in the second phase of the Metro plan and is expected to get over by 2028. The section will be the extension of the PCMC-Swargate Metro corridor, of which Shivajinagar to Swargate stretch is underground.

The MahaMetro has already started the civil work of the first phase of Metro in Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad , two corridors of which are expected to cover 33km distance.

For the extension, three option were under consideration, including a complete elevated stretch, complete underground stretch and alignment via Market Yard. The DPR, which has given preference to underground stretch, has proposed three stations and acquisition of some private land for the project.

The Metro extension up to Katraj has been shown in the city’s 2017 DP. The standing committee has proposed to introduce the latest changes in DP maps.

Title: NMC’s two officials face action for apathy
Content:
Nagpur: On the one hand municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe suspended deputy engineer for not responding to calls of the executive engineer and on the other, mayor Sandip Joshi directed action against the superintending engineer for not attending his meeting.

Following Mundhe’s orders, deputy commissioner Nirbhay Jain issued the suspension order of deputy engineer of Ashinagar Zone Ajay Pazare for not responding to repeated calls of executive engineer Rajesh Bhutkar. Jain also directed Pazare not to leave the zone and also prohibited him from working in a private company till further orders.

Chairman of legal consultative committee Dharampal Meshram requested Joshi to hold a review meeting on the water supply works under way in his ward and also on construction of a compound wall around the Bhandewadi dumping yard. Accordingly, Joshi sent a letter on Tuesday to superintending engineer Shweta Banerjee to attend meeting organized on Wednesday. But Banerjee reportedly did not attend the meeting and also did not respond to calls.

Accordingly, Joshi directed the administration to issue show cause notice to Banerjee. Also, Joshi directed Banerjee to come up with all details in next two days.

Title: Money lender in cop net for man’s murder in Kondhwa apartment
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The Kondhwa police on Wednesday arrested a money lender, Suhas Sharad Dandekar , on the charges of abetting the murder of a 23-year-old man, who was thrown into an open duct area from the 11th floor flat of a society building by three engineering students on March 10.

Kondhwa police inspector Mahadeo Kumbhar told TOI, “Dandekar (30) from Kondhwa Budruk had given Rs15,000 to Abhinav Jadhav, one of the three arrested students, for giving the amount as loan to the victim, Sagar Chelwari, at 10 per cent interest per annum.”

He said, “Since Sagar failed to repay the loan, Dandekar instigated Jadhav to sternly deal with him. He also told his friend to collect the motorcycle used in the crime for concealing it at an undisclosed location.”

The police had earlier arrested the engineering students, Jadhav, Akshay Gorde and Tejas Gujar, on the charges of assaulting and murdering Sagar by flinging him into an open duct from the 11th floor of Kul Utsav society on Pisoli Road near Khadi Machine Chowk around 2.45am on March 10.

The trio had reported themselves to the Khadi Machine police chowkey and admitted to their involvement in the crime. Omkar Chandrakant Yenpure, a security guard of the Pune Municipal Corporation ’s godown adjacent to the society, had witnessed the suspects assaulting the victim and registered an FIR.

Dandekar’s role in the crime surfaced during Jadhav’s custodial interrogation, inspector Kumbhar said, “He will be in police custody remand till March 22. Investigations revealed that Dandekar was illegally running a money lending business. He had earlier given loans to engineering students by mortgaging their valuables,” the officer said.

The police have obtained Dandekar’s bank statement, collected technical evidence and recovered the motorcycle used in the crime. He has been arrested under sections 109 (abetment) and 201 (causing disappearance of evidence) of the Indian Penal Code .

“The Kondhwa police had arrested Dandekar in a body offence case in 2015. We are questioning him to find out to who else he has given loan to,” Kumbhar said.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Hyderabad: Confusion prevails over hostels’ closure, inmates fret and fume
Content: HYDERABAD: Confusion prevailed on Wednesday over the closure notice served on hostels and telling the inmates to vacate immediately in the wake of coronavirus scare. While GHMC insisted that all hostels must shut down immediately, the IT industry Covid committee said private hostels could function and that only hostels run by educational institutions should be closed.GHMC officials visited various hostels on Tuesday night and issued an ultimatum to the inmates to make alternative arrangements within 24 hours. Employees and students residing in these hostels are livid. Several of them said they do not have an alternative place to stay and they were not allowed to work from home.“I was informed that I need to vacate the hostel in 24 hours. I booked flight tickets for my brother and myself, but flights have been cancelled. Train tickets are running full. I request the authorities to give us some more time,” said Anuradha, a teacher in private school residing in a hostel at SR Nagar.V Dasharath, a software engineer and an inmate of a hostel in Kondapur, said they do not have the option to work from home. “Where will I go,” he wondered.The Covid panel held a video conference on Wednesday and said hostels run by educational institutions should be closed. “Private hostels can remain open,” said Bharani Kumar, a member of the committee. Cyberabad police chief VC Sajjanar is nodal officer of the panel.A verification done by TOI revealed that several hostel managements are yet to receive the Covid committee’s order.

Title: Traffic department to avoid breath analysers for drunk & drive cases
Content:
Representative image

KOLHAPUR: In the wake of the Covid-19 outbreak, the city traffic department has stopped the use of breath analysers to check on drunk and drive cases in the city.

The department, however, has stated that the action will continue against those found driving under the influence of alcohol and they will be directly sent to the Chhatrapati Pramila Raje (CPR) civil hospital for medical check-up.

Anil Gujar, a police inspector in-charge of the city traffic department said, “We regularly launch our drive to check on drunk and drive cases on city roads and mostly these are surprise drives at night time. However, following the outbreak of the coronavirus, we have decided to suspend the use of breath analyser apparatus which may act as an instrument to spread the virus.”

Gujar said that the move won’t deteriorate them from continuing routine drives of checking vehicle documents, driver documents etc. “During our night patrolling if we come across anyone who is found under the influence of alcohol, then we will take him to the Chhatrapati Pramila Raje (CPR) civil hospital, where we will conduct a blood test to check the alcohol content in his body,” he added.

PUNE

Sanjay Shinde, additional commissioner of police, the use of breath analyzers has been discontinued until further orders. "In our day to day action as well, we are trying to take all precautions. We are relying more on contactless enforcement through CCTV network, online complaints and photographs. All personnel have been provided masks and gloves for on-road enforcement. This will continue until the situation persists," he explained.

NASHIK

A traffic PI from the Nashik Traffic branch confirmed, "'we have got instructions from the Additional Director General of Police (Traffic) of Maharashtra Vinay Kargaonkar about not making use of the breath analyzers until further orders to prevent the spread of Covid 19. The Additional ADG Traffic has issued instructions to all the police commissionerates across the state, SPs, SP of the Highway Police and special Inspector Generals (IGs) of Aurangabad, Nashik and Nagpur range.

AURANGABAD

Traffic police have already stopped using breathe analysers for drunk and drive cases.

Title: KMC changes water supply schedule to morning hours in suburbs
Content:
Representative image

KOLHAPUR: The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation ( KMC ) has accepted the request of the people in suburban areas for changing the water supply timing back to the morning hours.

Earlier, as per request of the locals from areas like Salokhenagar, Raigad Colony, More Mane Nagar, Bhavani Society , Kalamba Jail area and Katyayani Complex area, the supply timing was changed to the afternoon slot.

The locals had claimed that the elevated storage tank located at Salokhenagar could not be filled even to half of its capacity in the morning owing to which both supply and pressure were inadequate. Hence, the civic body decided to change the supply timing.

A senior KMC official said, “From March 6, we started supplying water in the afternoon for four hours. The locals are now complaining that they are mostly out at work and could not store water. Thus, we have decided to start supplying water in the morning hours from Thursday.”

He added, “Most of the families in these areas are working class people. Thus, being at home during the later afternoon hours was difficult for most of them.”

Santosh Jadhav, a resident of Salokhenagar, said, “The water supply started in the afternoon and continued till 5pm. This was done to ensure the high rise tank is filled properly so that we get supply at adequate pressure. However, many families are not available during the supply hours to store water. Therefore, we requested the KMC to change the supply timing. Supply for just two hours with adequate pressure is enough for us.”

With the onset of summer, the demand for water is growing. The suburban areas depend on the Shingnapur supply scheme which is old and the pumping capacity has been inadequate for current demand.

Keeping this in mind, the civic body has undertaken the work to repair valves, leakages to the pipelines to improve the supply condition.

Title: Nabanna cleans up after office visit by Covid-19 boy’s bureaucrat mother
Content: KOLKATA: A day after the of a top-level bureaucrat tested Covid-19 positive, Nabanna went into a massive sanitisation drive on all the floors, chambers — including offices of CM Mamata Banerjee and other top bureaucrats — lifts and the entire common area. Some employees who came in direct contact with the bureaucrat were sent to home isolation and have been asked to get tests done.The process of sanitization started in the morning with the chief minister’s room on the 14th floor. Four PWD teams worked in tandem through the day. The fifth-floor office of the bureaucrat whose son has tested Covid-19 positive has been sanitized and sealed. Though Nabanna officials termed the sanitization process as a ‘routine work’, top-level sources said the administration didn’t want to take any chance.“On Monday, the patient’s bureaucrat mother came to the office and held several meetings. So there is every possibility that if she has developed any kind infection from his son, it might spread further. So we are not taking any chance,” a senior PWD official said. However, PWD officials feel the process of fumigation can be done only in an empty building but that is not possible now. “We have done this temporarily and we will fumigate the entire building on a holiday,” an official added.The bureaucrat’s son testing positive has had a ripple effect among the employees of the state secretariat. Even chief minister Mamata Banerjee spoke on the “irresponsible behaviour”. “I do not support this. Why would a person, who has come from London, not go for a test? I cannot ignore anything because I am influential. Those who are coming from outside should maintain the basic protocol laid down by the health department. They should not go to malls or visit any other crowded place,” the chief minister said in a programme on Wednesday.The incident, however, has raised concerns among the employees of the department. “I went to the library and touched many books. She had also gone the library. I have been asked to go for home isolation. I don’t know what is going to happen,” an employee who works in the same department said.

Title: SIT on land scam disposes 342 plaints
Content:
Visakhapatnam: The Special Investigation Team ( SIT ) appointed by the state government to inquire into the land scam in Vizag, especially the tampering of government land records, has disposed off 342 of the 1,380 complaints lodged with it.

Chief of SIT, retired IAS officer S Vijaya Kumar told the media here that the SIT had conducted a review meeting with 13 tehsildars and asked about pending reports.

Vijaya Kumar said the SIT has examined cases of No Objection Certificate (NOC) issues and of government-allotted sites issued to private institutions and individuals. “In two or three cases FIRs were also filed against the persons who violated the rules. In two cases, Section 145 of CrPC was imposed. A government land under the control of a housing corporation was encroached upon and an FIR was registered,” Vijaya Kumar said.

Vijaya Kumar added, “We have written to the government to take action for violation in issuing NOCs and allotting government lands to institutions and individuals.”

The SIT has disposed off 44 complaints of encroachment of government land, 38 cases of land grab by private persons and 69 cases of tampering of land records.

Title: MCOCA invoked against inter-state gutka smuggling gang
Content:
Representative image

KOLHAPUR: City police have invoked the stringent Maharashtra Control of Organised Crime Act ( MCOCA ) against an 11-member gang that was involved in smuggling gutka from the neighbouring Karnataka state to Maharashtra.

According to police, it is the first such action under MCOCA against a gang involved in smuggling gutka. The gang is led by Mahesh Dalvi and is called MD gang.

The gang members have been booked in more than 21 criminal cases with several police stations in Kolhapur, Sangli and Satara districts. Police have invoked MCOCA against the gang for kidnapping and murdering a man to recover gutka from him.

On January 18, three people were carrying 144 bags of gutka from Tumkur to Athani in Karnataka by a truck. When they reached Athani, 53 bags were missing from the vehicle.

The truck owner contacted the MD gang to recover the stolen gutka from the trio. Following this, the trio was abducted by the gang members and was tortured which led to the death of one of them.

A police team got information from sources about the gang trying to dispose a body. The team swung into action and in no time 11 members of the gang were arrested. They were booked under several sections of the IPC at Jaysingpur police station.

“Following the incident we gathered information about the gang members and prepared a proposal to invoke MCOCA against the gang. The gang members were found involved in smuggling gutka from Karnataka to Maharashtra along with series of other crimes like murder, attempt to murder and extortion. A proposal was sent to the IG office for approval. We recently received the information from the IG office that our proposal to invoke MCOCA against the gang was accepted,” a senior police officer attached with SP office said.

Title: Five arrested on charge of damaging vehicles in Pune
Content:
PUNE: Five men were arrested on Wednesday on the charge of damaging 16 vehicles, including 13 autorickshaws , with stones at the Janawadi area off Senapati Bapat Road late on Monday night.

The Chatushrungi police identified the arrested as Sameer Khan (25), Mohsin Shaikh (22), Rafiq Shaikh (19), Amin Mulla (22) and Shahrukh Tamboli (21) of Janawadi.

A team headed by senior inspector Anil Shewale , sub-inspectors Mohan Jadhav and Basavraj Mali arrested the suspects after conducting a search operation in all the slum pockets around Senapati Bapat Road.

An officer of the Chatushrungi police said the incident occurred when the suspects had gathered at an open plot between Pandavnagar and Janawadi on Monday night. “They started making loud noises, which woke up the residents in the area. The residents then asked the suspects to maintain silence. This appeal did no go down well with the suspects, who then started pelting stones on the parked vehicles,” the officer said.
