He added that 13 autorickshaws and three cars were damaged in the incident.

Title: Youth cuffed for stalking & abusing neighbour in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A youth was arrested on Tuesday on the charge of stalking a 19-year-old woman from his neighbourhood for the past one year.

The woman lodged a complaint with the Kothrud police on Tuesday evening after the suspect (22) arrived at her shop and abused her. “We have arrested him under section 354-D (stalking) of the Indian Penal Code. The youth was produced before the courtand has been sent to Yerawada prison,” senior inspector Pratibha Joshi of the Kothrud police said.

The officer said the woman stated in her complaint that the man was her neighbour. He had been harassing her for the past one year. “Around 6pm on Tuesday, when the woman was working at her shop, he reached there and told her to come with him,” Joshi said, adding, “When the woman refused, the suspect tried to drag her out. He also threatened to kill her before taking to heels.”

Joshi said the suspect had criminal background. He has three non-cognizable offences registered against him.

Title: Kolkata Coronavirus News: Condominium on sanitisation overdrive to check virus spread
Content: KOLKATA: The apartment owners’ association of the residential complex off EM Bypass from where the city’s first Covid-19 positive was reported is preparing a list of residents who got in physical contact with any of the family members of the infected patient in the last three days and will ask them to get themselves tested and remain in home isolation thereafter.The owners’ association has also requested each of the apartment owners to disclose if any of their family members will fly back to Kolkata or has returned from novel coronavirus-affected nations in the last two weeks. On the basis of the disclosure, it will make a separate list of residents at risk and will submit it to the state government.“We have come across a few residents who had visited the patient’s home after he had returned from the UK. We have informed the state health department about them and are also asking the residents to get themselves tested and stay in home isolation for the next few weeks,” said the association secretary.On the list of “residents at risk” based on their travel history, the secretary said: “We have learnt from the example that people are not following home isolation advisory and hence we have pleaded to all the apartment owners to disclose details of those who have returned from virus-affected nations in the last few weeks and if anyone is scheduled to come from abroad in the next few days. Once the list is ready, we will submit it to the state government,” said the secretary.A meeting of the board of managers of the residents’ association was held at the complex at 11pm on Tuesday to decide on “emergency measures” that need to be taken. It was decided that all residents will avoid moving out of home as far as possible. Most have chosen to stay and work from home, barring even kids to go out and play in the greens or the club.“None of us knew that we had lived with a corona-positive neighbour till that late. We were racking our brains to think who amongst us might have been in touch with the family. Soon, it looked like an impossibility because there are 565 flats and many of us share maids, nurses and caregivers,” said one of the residents.The owners’ association on Tuesday started a clean-up drive from midnight itself. “As part of the process, we have been disinfecting the entire common area of the building, including staircase handles, lifts, lobby and its furniture and all other places. “Apart from that, we are also taking some immediate preventive measures, like mandatory handwash of everyone entering the complex, procurement of infrared thermometers for temperature check, keeping all doors and windows of lobby open so that people need not touch the doors. All social gatherings have been cancelled,” said another official, adding that they have even closed down the complex’s club and gymnasium till March 31. Also, public address systems are being employed to spread awareness about the do’s and don’t’s that residents are expected to follow.Meanwhile, KMC has identified the domestic help who used to work at the infected patient’s home and got her admitted to Beliaghata ID Hospital for necessary tests. “The woman lives at a slum in the Panchasayar neighbourhood and we have sent her to the hospital for necessary tests. We have also started a clean-up and disinfection drive along with an awareness camp at the neighbourhood where the woman lived,” said Ananya Banerjee, the councillor of ward 109.

Title: Telangana: Mild tension as Cantonment officials demolish illegal structures
Content:
Illegal structures being razed down at Bowenpally on Wednesday

SECUNDERABAD: Mild tension prevailed at an old-grant bungalow (OGB), No: 187 situated at Plassey Lines, at Bowenpally in Secunderabad Cantonment, as it was razed down after being deemed as an unauthorised structure by Defence Estates Office (DEO), Telangana, on Wednesday.

The Defence Estates Officer, Telangana is the custodian of all the existing OGBs in Secunderabad Cantonment.

According to sources in DEO, a few unauthorised structures were identified in OGB No: 187 according to GLR survey No: 517. According to DEO, the property owner was using the premises for commercial purposes on a hire basis, which is illegal. A courier office, a dhaba, and automobile dealers are operating their businesses on the premises.

“Based on the DEO’s instructions, all the unauthorised structures at the OGB premises were demolished. The demolition was completed within three hours,” sources in DEO told TOI.

Meanwhile, the property owner of the premises has raised objections that the Defence Estates Office (DEO) did not gave prior intimation on the demolition and the act of demolition was illegal.

Title: Cow urine: Cop custody for BJP leader in Kolkata
Content: KOLKATA: The BJP leader, who was arrested for allegedly inducing a Kolkata Police homeguard to drink gaumutra ( cow urine ) as prasad and preventive medicine for novel coronavirus , was remanded in five-day police custody by a city court on Wednesday.The accused, Narayan Chatterjee was charged under IPC sections 269 (negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life), 278 (making atmosphere noxious to health) and 114 (abetment to an offence) of Indian Penal Code following a complaint by Jorabagan homeguard Pintu Pramanik. He claimed that he had to be hospitalised after being induced by Chatterjee to drink the cow urine.

Title: Parents’ attendance restricted at commissioning ceremony
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The annual commissioning ceremony of the Armed Forces Medical College ( AFMC ) will be held on Thursday but the parents of the graduating medical cadets won’t be invited in view of the Covid-19 situation.

An AFMC officer, under the condition of anonymity, told TOI on Wednesday, “Only senior armed forces officers, required staff and medical cadets will attend the function. We had to change the attendance plan for the ceremony in view of the virus threat and have conveyed the same to parents, who would have, otherwise, attended the event as per tradition.”

He said, “The ceremony will be held as per the tradition which has been followed by the college over decades. The cadets will march the parade before they are officially commissioned into the armed forces.”

A batch of around 100 medical cadets will be commissioned into the Armed Forces Medical Services (AFMS), which is a tri-service (Army, Navy and Air Force) organization and one of the largest organized medical services in India. The AFMS has state of the art tertiary care hospitals and speciality centres of excellence and provides medical support to the armed forces during war as well as comprehensive health care to all service personnel, ex-servicemen and their dependents during peace.

Title: Isolation care for Covid-19 patients in Lavale facility
Content: PUNE: The newly established Symbiosis University Hospital and Research Centre and Symbiosis Medical College for Women (SMCW) have volunteered to isolate and treat patients of Covid-19 infection on their premises.The office bearers have approached the authorities for approval. This is the only hospital in Mulshi taluka in rural parts of Pune covering 143 villages.The move is 'much-needed' because going by the mathematical projections of the epidemiologists, cases are likely to rise in the next few days if social distancing is not properly practised by the citizens.The 300-bed hospital in Lavale in Mulshi taluka began operations in June 2019 and its attached medical college will begin from August 1, 2020.“We have already approached the divisional commissioner to allow us to isolate and treat patients of Covid-19 infection. We have the infrastructure and expertise to handle all patients exhibiting minor or severe symptoms. We have offered to support the government health machinery in the larger public interest,” public health expert Rajiv Yeravdekar, dean (health sciences) Symbiosis International Deemed University ) told TOI.Cardiothoracic surgeon Vijay Natarajan, chief executive officer of the hospital, said, “Financial constraints will not be a handicap for a patient to get the isolation care and treatment. Even for the affordable class, we will be rendering isolation and medical care at charges at par or even less than Central Government Health Scheme.”Other medical institutions like D Y Patil Medical College , Bharati Hospital and Medical College, Navale Medical College have already been roped in to offer medical services if the need arises.“There are 11 medical colleges in Pune including ayurveda and homeopathy colleges. They have already been told by the authorities to reserve a few beds for isolating and treating patients of Covid-19 infection if the cases go up. But volunteering when not being asked to is a noble gesture and is much needed in the fight against Covid-19,” spine surgeon Ajay Chandanwale, dean of B J Medical College attached Sassoon General Hospital, said.Pubic health expert Jitendra Bhavalkar, dean of D Y Patil Medical College in Pimpri, said, “The government authorities have told us to keep a certain number of beds reserved for patients with Covid-19 infection. We are following their directives.”

Title: NDA cancels outdoor activities of cadets amid coronavirus scare
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The National Defence Academy (NDA) has suspended all outdoor activities, including educational tours of cadets, in view of the spurt in Covid-19 cases. It has also stopped cadets from visiting crowded places.

“All cadets and personnel in NDA are briefed and sensitised about the causes and symptoms of Covind-19 by the Commanding Officer of Military Hospital , Khadakwasla . They are also advised to ensure personal hygiene at individual level. All large public gatherings, celebrations, mass activities, visit to crowded places, guest lectures and movies have been suspended till further orders. All educational tours have been cancelled, " the NDA authorities told TOI on Saturday.

The cadets are being monitored daily for flu-like symptoms by their divisional officers (DOs) and seniors.

“Any person with symptoms of flu, cough and cold are advised to report immediately. They will be screened and treated separately. In case of doubt, they will be shifted to the Armed Forces Medical Services (AFMS) hospital. Not everybody is required to rush to the hospital for checks. Only those who have symptoms are being checked. This is the advisory of the government,” the authorities added.

“All non-essential mass gatherings have been suspended. All educational hikes, outdoor activities outside NDA have been stopped till further orders,” the authorities added.

Visitors, including parents and others, are also not being permitted inside the campus. “The general public and school students can visit the academy on Sunday, but this has been postponed till further notice. Besides, we have advised parents not to pay visit to the academy. If they want to connect with their wards, there is a proper mechanism which they can follow,” a senior NDA officer, who did not wish to be named, told TOI.

On Sunday, the academy allowed its final-term (sixth term) cadets to leave the campus for some hours. “Currently, the outside environment is not safe. So, we have suspended this activity for the time being. It will be resumed only after the situation becomes normal in the city,” the officer added.

As far as training activities are concerned, the academy authorities said, “There is no deviation or change in routine training activities”.

The academy has also sensitised its teaching and administrative staff about the virus.

Title: Actor booked in Rs 97 lakh duping case in Pune
Content:
Actor Vikram Gokhale

PUNE: The Paud police are investigating a case lodged by a Kothrud resident accusing actor Vikram Gokhale and two others of cheating 14 investors of Rs 96.99 lakh in a plot scheme spread across Dongargaon and Hotale villages in Mulshi taluka as a part of the “Girivan” private hill station project.

In his FIR lodged on Tuesday afternoon, complainant Jayant Bahirat (57), an artist, named Gokhale as the chairman, and social worker Jayant Rambhau Mhalgi and his wife Sujata Jayant Mhalgi as directors of the Sujata Farms Private Limited, which floated the hill station project in 1989. He alleged that the three office-bearers of the firm misrepresented the scheme as “government approved” and misused the goodwill as well as their relationship with late former MP Rambhau Mhalgi to lure investors.

The FIR stated that after collecting money, the firm failed to get the plots demarcated by the state land measurement officials. When the investors secured an order from the land measurement department in 2016, they were restrained from getting the land measurement done, it read.

Gokhale said, “I was the director and the face of the company. I tendered my resignation on January 9 and I am not related to the project as of now. Despite this, my name has been dragged in the FIR.”

Gokhale said, “The company has handed over 958 plots in the scheme without any trouble. People mentioned in the FIR have also got their plots, but there are some issues with their measurement. This issue can be sorted out once the government-appointed team measures the land. It is not the case that they have not received their plots. All the documents and agreements have been processed clearly.”

Jayant Mhalgi could not be contacted despite repeated calls on his cell phone number. A text message too was sent on his number seeking his reaction, but there was no response till going to the press.

Complainant Bahirat alleged in the FIR that Gokhale and others won confidence of people and encouraged them to invest in the project. Considering the involvement of Gokhale and the other two directors, people trusted them and invested money, he said.

Despite the bookings and execution of legal documents of the plots, the company committed discrepancies in the allotment of plots other than the survey number of plots assured to each of the affected investor and restrained the investors from getting the land measured, the FIR stated.

One of the affected investors said, “We were fighting the matter for the past five years.”

Paud police inspector Ashok Dhumal said, “The case is more about discrepancies in allotment of plots and technical issues involving measurement of land. We shall investigate all angles before taking a call on whether to arrest those named in the FIR or not.”

Title: Ripple effect of ‘irresponsibility’: Bengal home secretary in home isolation
Content: KOLKATA: State additional chief secretary (home) Alapan Bandyopadhyay went on a self-imposed home quarantine from Wednesday as the ripple effect of Bengal’s first Covid-19 case was felt since morning. Bandyopadhyay had briefly interacted with the teenage patient’s mother — a senior bureaucrat — at Nabanna on Monday.Along with Bandyopadhyay, his wife Sonali Chakravarti Banerjee — the Calcutta University vice-chancellor — too stayed back home on Wednesday, fuelling speculations that she may also be in home quarantine. State education minister Partha Chatterjee later indicated that he had spoken to the CU VC and she was perfectly fine. The VC told TOI that she didn’t go to office as she was told by CU staffers that her presence would be required on Thursday and not on Wednesday.A family member close to the Bandyopadhyay family indicated the decision to self-quarantine was “in accordance with medical protocol”. Bandyopadhyay’s joining the office would now entirely depend on the test results of his colleague.Sources, however, said he had no sign of infection or allied symptoms of discomfort, weakness, cold and cough. He read books attended phone calls and passed on instructions to his office from home. He also held a meeting through teleconferences.For KMC assessment department’s assistant manager Subir Roy, things were slightly different. Roy was asked by KMC commissioner Khalil Ahmed to go on a fortnight’s home quarantine after it was known that he had met the bureaucrat on Monday at her Nabbana office. The officers Roy had interacted with at KMC after his return have also been asked to stay at home.Meanwhile, a premier Kolkata club on Wednesday held a committee meeting after complaints poured in that the bureaucrat and her son were seen dining in the club restaurant on Sunday night. The family has denied the charge. A club member indicated that they may take a decision on Thursday. “Many have said they are now scared to go to the club,” a member added.

Title: Radhika Madan is making the most of 'Self-Quarantine' and this video is proof!
Content: Radhika Madan's 'Angrezi Medium' has been the talk of the town since the announcement. The film starring Irrfan Khan , the actress impressed everyone with her performance.However, the makers of the film revealed that they will re-release the film as theatres have been shut down due to Coronavirus outbreak.Also, due to COVID-19 pandemic, the government has asked everyone to stay at home and avoid all non-essential travel to stop the spread of the virus. And Radhika is making the most of this self-quarantine! She took to her Instagram to share a video of her playing the tunes of her favourite songs on a piano. Dressed in a black top and denim and a hat, she looked absolutely pretty in the video. The caption of the post read, "Making the most of self quarantine! #corona #stayhome #staysafe❤️#learnsomethingneweveryday"Check out the video here:Meanwhile, in the film, Radhika plays the role of Irrfan's daughter who wants to take her higher education in the UK. The film is helmed by Homi Adajania and also stars Deepak Dobriyal Dimple Kapadia and Ranveer Shorey. Backed by Dinesh Vijan , the film was released last Friday.

Title: Covid-19: Treatment for Hyderabad boy with Chapel syndrome hits roadblock
Content: HYDERABAD: An eight-year-old boy from the city, the only known case of the rare Chapel Syndrome in India, was to travel to US to participate in a clinical trial for a drug being tested by the National Institute of Health (NIH), but with travel restrictions owing to Covid-19, his treatment has hit a roadblock.Chapel syndrome which is a genetic disease in which the CD 55 gene is missing in patients, meanwhile causes an extreme shortage of protein in the body. Patients also continue to lose protein through stools and have life threatening complications.Condition of the boy, Ayan, has worsened in the last few weeks and doctors are waiting for his health to stabilise.The doctor treating him has written to the institute to allow treating him in Hyderabad by supplying the drug locally. “With restrictions imposed due to Covid-19, the process has run into delays. The US-based institute is now trying to arrange for a health insurance of the patient as well as his family members, as travelling during the ongoing pandemic can expose them to the virus and they might require hospitalisation. While these things are taking time, Ayan’s condition has deteriorated. We have sought permission from the institute to allow us to carry out research here by enrolling our centre in the trial group and we will share the results with them,” said Dr Prashanth Bachina, paediatric gastroenterologist.For that to happen, an approval from the Drugs Approval Committee of India and permission from Drug Controller General of India is needed.Meanwhile, Ayan is on a daily dose of injections for hypoalbuminia and it is being administered 2-3 times a week. “We are told that it will take at least three months before he is stable and can be sent for further treatment. Since his treatment is not available here, doctors at AIIMS had contacted many institutes. While researchers from Turkey and Bangkok had initially wanted to take him as a research subject, but they later refused. Now our only hope is the US institute. We have exhausted all our monetary reserves and the little which came from crowd-funding. Each day is a challenge for us now,” said Ayan’s father Md Tajuddin, who is a postman.While Rs 2 lakh raised through crowd-funding sustained his treatment for a few months, the family is banking on crowd-funding once again for his treatment in Hyderabad till he is stable enough to be sent to US or approved for clinical trial in India. The estimated expense is between Rs 1.2 crore to Rs 6 crore depending on the response to the drug.

Title: 40 Indian pilgrims stuck in Saudi Arabia after travel restrictions
Content:
Bareilly: On a pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia, at least 40 people from UP’s Bareilly , Pilibhit and Rampur districts are now stuck in the Gulf country after it cancelled all international flights to check spread of novel coronavirus. They were scheduled to board the flight on March 15.

Their family members told TOI that the pilgrims are facing tough time as they don’t have enough money left to buy food and other essentials. Of these 40 pilgrims, 13 are women.

Pammi Warsi, convenor of Bareilly Haj Sewa Samiti, said, “40 people went to Saudi Arabia on February 25 for Umrah. Their return flight was from Medina on March 15. But, after Saudi authorities cancelled all international flights, they were advised to board flight from Jeddah airport. However, they could not board any other flight.”

He added, “These 40 people had booked Umrah trip through a tour operator in Bareilly. We have now sent an email to ministry of external affairs to bring them back to India.”

Mohd Nubaid, a resident of Pilibhit’s Amaria, whose 65-year-old father Mohd Shoaib is stuck in Saudi Arabia, said, “We have no idea on when he will return. He is old and we are very worried. We request Indian government to extend immediate help to my father and others stuck in Saudi Arabia.”

Embroidery worker Firasat Ali said, “My brother, Sajjad Ahmad, is left with no money. He is struggling to arrange meal.”

Title: Trial run on delay-ridden Kanaka Durga flyover project from April 15
Content:
Vijayawada: The Kanaka Durga flyover project is likely to miss the deadline once again. Krishna district administration, which has been working hard to complete the project works by the end of March, has now proposed to extend the deadline to April 15.

Kanaka Durga flyover is one of the prestigious projects in the city. The project work, which started way back in November 2015 with a deadline of December 2016, failed to get shape even after four years.

Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy had a special focus on the project after he assumed charge as CM and directed officials to complete the project by December 31, 2019. Endowments minister Vellampalli Srinivas said that the state government would give the project as a new year gift to the citizens.

But the project got delayed with a series of interruptions caused by Dasara celebrations and Bhavani Deeksha Viramana.

District collector A Mohammed Imtiaz, who also had a special focus on the project, had conducted a series of reviews with the agency and NHAI authorities. Officials decided to conduct a trial run from the first week of April and postponed the proposal with a delay in the works.

“We are committed to the completion of works by March 31. Around 90 percent of project work has been completed till date. Out of the 2.5-kilometer-long blacktop road, 1.5 kilometers have been completed. We hope the remaining work will be completed soon so we can start the trial run,” Imtiaz said.

However contracting agency, SOMA said that they would complete the works by April 15.

Meanwhile, citizens are unhappy over the delay. “We have been waiting for this flyover for the past three years. Officials should complete the work to ease up traffic in the city,” said G Kartheek Kumar, a resident of Vidhyadharapura.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Cage with bait placed at rubber factory to trap tigress
Content:
BAREILLY: A day after the photo of a tigress was captured in the defunct rubber factory campus, 18 km from Bareilly city, forest department placed a cage with a bait to trap it.

The tigress is said to have made the factory its den for the last 10 days. While the presence of a tiger was confirmed on Monday, close examination of its pugmarks showed the big cat is a tigress.

A team of experts visited the site on Tuesday evening to plan the rescue operation.

Chief conservator of forests, Rohilkhand zone, Lalit Verma told TOI, “We conducted a recce of the rubber factory and could smell the tigress -- which means it has marked its territory. But we could not spot it. Though a cage with a bait has been placed on rubber factory campus, we will soon be placing four more cages to trap the animal. Besides, we will increase the number of camera traps from five to 25 to ascertain its location. Once located, we will tranquilize the tigress.”

However, forest officials said tranquilizing the tigress at the rubber factory is tough and the operation could stretch to months. “Due to the presence of old trenches, tunnels, tanks and other equipment in the abandoned rubber factory, it is risky to dart the animal. We will try to lure the tigress outside to tranquilize it,” said Verma.

Divisional forest officer Bharat Lal said, “We have arranged meat which was half consumed by a male tiger. This half-eaten meat will be placed around the camera traps to attract the tigress to get an idea about its location and movement.”

A team of veterinarian and experts from WWF-India have reached Bareilly to assist the forest department in the rescue operation. A team from WTI is expected to reach here on Wednesday.

Title: Restrict invitees to marriages: Pune rural police
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The Pune rural police have urged people to ensure wedding ceremonies are conducted with minimum gathering, in the wake of the novel coronavirus pandemic.

The marriage season in the district usually begins in the last week of February and goes on till June. The police have been conducting meetings with would-be brides and grooms, their parents and relatives, regarding the same.

“All police station in-charges have been told to follow this and have been told to not give permission for any mass gatherings,” superintendent of police Sandeep Patil said.

The police station in-charges have been told to get in touch with owners of wedding halls to create awareness and take the necessary precautions at the venue, if at all there is a wedding or any other event.

Title: Kolhapur: KMC puts off screening of passengers
Content:
Representative image

KOLHAPUR: The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) officials have postponed the process of screening the passengers entering Kolhapur via road due to a shortage of staff.

All the people entering the city via six entry points were scheduled to be checked by the KMC staff. But due to the unavailability of staff members due to individual house-to-house survey, the process had to be scrapped.

The KMC officials conducted a survey of around 6000 people residing in 1500 houses in Kolhapur city and found eight people returning from foreign countries after February 15. Out of the eight, one was found coughing and was sent to the Chhatrapati Pramila Raje (CPR) civil hospital for screening.

According to KMC officials, as many as 50 people had approached them to grant them permission to conduct marriage ceremonies and other programs scheduled on March 19.

Ranjit Chile, chief fire officer, KMC said, “Number of marriages and other rituals were planned on March 19 and all the marriage halls were booked. However, we asked the marriage halls to cancel all the bookings. Many approached us but we have not given permission to any of them.”

The KMC commissioner Mallinath Kalshetti had earlier issued orders that not more than 20 people will be allowed to gather for any kind of programme in the city. He had appealed to all the restaurants and roadside food stalls to shut their shops by 9 pm to help them curb the outbreak.

Title: Hyderabad: 5 held for rape of two sisters in Kamatipura
Content:
Representative Image

HYDERABAD: In a shocking ordeal which came to light in Kamatipura in Old City, two minor girls were being allegedly raped by five persons for the last one year. Kamatipura police on Wednesday said the accused, including three minor boys, were arrested and booked on the charges of rape and under sections of POCSO Act. The girls are siblings. The accused also belong to the same area.

“In the last one year, each one of the five accused took the elder girl (17) to various places and raped her. One of the two adults raped her younger sister (14) also,’’ Kamatipura inspector G Rambabu told TOI. Police said the sisters faced the ordeal multiple times. The accused took the sisters to either a burial ground or an underconstruction building site in Kamatipura where they forced themselves on the hapless sisters.

The elder girl is a class IX student. She was befriended by a minor boy, a class VIII student. Police said they went to the same tuition class. “He lured her and said he loved her. He later raped her at the burial ground. After some days, he introduced her to other accused, who are his friends,” police said.

Police said the accused boy even threatened the elder girl with dire consequences if she disclosed the matter to her family members. The sisters are under the care of their uncle, who grew suspicious when the elder girl came home late on Monday. “When she was questioned, she told her uncle about the ordeal she and her sister have been facing at the hands of the accused. All the offenders are known to the two girls,” police said.

Based on a complaint from the family, the accused were nabbed on Tuesday. The two adults were arrested and produced before a magistrate, while the three minors were produced before a juvenile court.

Police registered a case under Section-376 (rape) of IPC and under various sections of the POCSO Act.

Title: Coronavirus in Hyderabad: Colleges still open, conduct exams
Content: HYDERABAD: A few colleges in the city are yet to declare holiday for students and are conducting semester, internal and practical exams even after three days since the government’s closure order.Among them was Institute of Insurance and Risk Management (IIRM) that held its semester exams. “We have to appear for the semester exams from 9.30 am to 12.30 pm. Sometimes, the institute also holds lab sessions during the afternoon. When the government has declared complete shutdown of all institutions, the IIRM management could have postponed the exams,” said a student on condition of anonymity.Similar scenes prevailed at Hindi Mahavidyalaya in Vidya Nagar. “Despite government orders, the management informed us that there are no holidays and we will have to appear for the internal and practicals exams,” said a student.A few engineering colleges, especially in the districts, are also conducting classes and students take to social media to raise their complaints. “@KTRTRS We, the students of SR Engineering College, Warangal wants to appeal to you that our college didn’t declare holidays even after the strict orders from the government,” tweeted Nikitha T, a student.

Title: Expressway lanes stay deserted amid novel coronavirus scare
Content: PUNE: The traffic on Pune-Mumbai Expressway has declined by over 40% in the past three days in the wake of the Covid-19 spread.Highway Safety Patrol (HSP) superintendent of police Milind Mohite confirmed the decline in the number of vehicles on the expressway in last three days owing to the rise in Covid-19 cases.“People have opted to stay at home instead of travelling,” he said.Around 35,000 to 40,000 vehicles used the expressway daily to commute between Mumbai and Pune, Mohite said.“Now, only 20,000 to 25,000 vehicles are using the expressway,” he said.Mohite said a majority of the vehicles using the expressway were heading towards Mumbai. “I took stock of the situation and found that very few cars were travelling in between the two cities. The trucks were mainly from Pune, Satara, Kolhapur and other southern states,” he added.A senior Maharashtra State Road Development Corporation (MSRDC) official in Pune told TOI, “Yes, there has been a reduction in the number of vehicles on the expressway and we are collecting information about it from the maintenance agency manning the toll and expressway.” HSP officials have appealed to commuters to avoid speeding on the empty lanes of the expressway.

Title: Police arrest four men, detain minor for criminal’s murder in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The Dehu Road police on Tuesday arrested four suspects and detained their minor accomplice in connection with the murder of Avinash Jadhav, a criminal on record.

The murder was the fallout of an inebriated brawl among them, a police officer said. Police probe revealed that Jadhav and the suspects — Ashish Jagtap (23), Prasad Alhat (25), Vikas Tandale (21), Sagar Dhanwate (18) and the minor, all from Nigdi Pradhikaran — were friends.

During questioning, the suspects admitted to being involved in the murder. “We have handed them over to the Nigdi police as they were drinking near a garage at Nigdi Pradhikaran on Tuesday when the incident occurred,” senior inspector Manish Kalyankar of the Dehu Road police said.

“Suddenly, Jadhav started abusing them and the suspects assaulted him with equipment kept in the garage. He died on spot,” an officer from the Nigdi police said.

Constable Pritam Wagh of the Dehu Road police received a tip-off that the suspects were hiding in Kivale. “Assistant inspector P G Gajjewar and his team rushed to the spot and took them into custody,” Kalyankar told TOI.

Title: West Bengal: Missing student traced to UP, say cops
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: Exactly a week after a 17-year-old student went missing from his hostel in Jorasanko under mysterious circumstances, the central division police officers said they had traced him near Varanasi in UP .

Sushanta Chowdhury, a student of Abhinav Bidyabharati School , who hailed from Bhagalpur in Bihar and was staying in a student hostel on Ratu Sarkar Lane in Jorasanko, had appeared for three of his CBSE Class-XII board papers before he went missing.

“A team has left for UP. We hope to bring him back at the earliest. So far, we have not found any foul play or any outside instigation behind his disappearance,” said a police officer.

Police said a missing case had been lodged with the Jorasanko police station earlier. However, cops were yet to get any lead to trace him. His family denied having received any ransom call so far.

According to police, Chowdhury had left the hostel on March 11 in the evening. The CCTV footage showed that he was wearing informal clothes and walking towards Kolutolla. Cops said the teenager carried some money with him but left his two mobile phones behind.

The teenager told his family that his exams were good and that he would return his Bihar home on March. He also claimed to have already booked a train ticket.

The hostel administration approached the police on March 12, after which a missing complaint was registered.

Other students staying in the hostel told cops that he had played Holi on March 10 with them and was to write his economics paper just a couple of days later. “His father has informed us that he had been speaking normally with them and showed no anxiety about the exams. We started speaking to his friends and relatives to find his whereabouts,” said a police officer.

Title: Uttar Pradesh- Honey bee buzz keeps animals off Haridwar-Doon tracks
Content:
BAREILLY: A buzz of a honey bee played on loudspeakers has helped curb collision between trains and animals on the the Haridwar-Dehradun railway track that passes through Rajaji National Park for the past two years, say Moradabad Railway Division officials.

The sound system installed near the railway tracks amplifies the recorded sound of honey bees that drives animals away from the tracks when trains approach, thereby preventing them from being run over. The Northeast Frontier Railway (NFR) has the system in place across four of its divisions at select crossings where elephant zones exist.

At least four elephants were mowed down by trains in separate incidents in Uttarakhand in 2018 as they failed to move away quickly out of the way of an approaching train. The buzzing sound of bees is audible to an elephant 600 meters away and is played for a few minutes before the train arrives so any elephant nearby changes its route “sensing the presence of beesaround”.

Speaking with TOI, Moradabad divisional railway manager (DRM) Tarun Prakash said, “The system has proved to be a success as no incident of collision between train and animals has occurred in the last two years. The idea was worked upon jointly by the railways and forest department and implemented around two years ago to keep animal off the railway track. The loudspeakers that have been installed at select railway crossings where animal zones exist play the buzzing sound of honey bees. It distracts wild animals, especially elephants, making them move away from the railway tracks. This way, animals do not die while crossing the tracks.”

The DRM added, “Other measures such as electric fences, temporary speed restrictions are also used to keep the animals at bay. Besides, real time updates are also shared by forest officials who alert the loco pilot in real time basis in case elephants are spotted. This further ensures that animals are not run over by trains.”

Title: Bareilly: Man dies after police raid on his house in search for loot accused
Content:
BAREILLY: A man in Imratpur village under Kundarki police station limits allegedly died of heart-attack after police barged into his house midnight on Tuesday in search of a youth suspected to be involved in a case of loot.

The family of the deceased alleged cops barged into their house at around 2am in search of the accused youth, initially asking questions but later proceeding to beat family members, one of whom died in the ensuing panic.

Iftekhar Hussain, elder brother of the deceased, Ateeq Ahmed , said, “Some cops arrived in two police vehicles late night on Tuesday and barged into our house. They said they were looking for a person accused in a case of loot, and began searching our house. Then they started beating us and dragged away my brother Aslam, seeing which, my younger brother suffered a heart attack and died. The panic created by the police led to his death .”

Police, though, denied the allegations and said Ateeq died of existing illness. Speaking to TOI, SHO Kundarki Prem Pal Singh said, “We got an input that a youth, Babu, accused of loot, was hiding in the area. Acting on a tip-off, we raided the house. The person who died was already unwell and his death has nothing to do with our raid. He died hours after we left.”

The SHO added, “Babu, resident of Imratpur village, had stolen a motorcycle from the area on March 11, and is still at large. The search operation is underway to nab the accused and his aides.”

Title: Grant loans to boost rural economy: Andhra Pradesh CM
Content:
YS Jaganmohan Reddy

VIJAYAWADA: Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy has asked bankers to be proactive in granting loans to farmers and tenant farmers and help in strengthening rural economy .

Speaking at the 210 State Level Bankers Committee (SLBC) meeting held here on Wednesday, Jagan said prioritising the farmers financially and strengthening the villages are a priority to the government and sought more cooperation between the state and bankers. To deliver hassle-free services to farmers, the chief minister said quality assured seeds, pesticides, and fertilizers will be delivered to farmers through internet kiosks which will be available in the (Rythu Bharosa Kendras) RBKs at village secretariats.

About 11 members are employed in every village secretariat to assist the villagers and strengthen the financial conditions in the villages. Moreover, details in e-panta will be integrated with banks so that the banks can issue loans to farmers based on the details entered.

Tenant farmers' details will be available in e-panta so that the landowner and tenant should sign the agreement under the revenue assistant to avail the loan .

He said that with the available details including the type of crop being cultivated in e-panta, banks should generously grant loans to farmers. RBKs will help farmers in suggesting the type of crop to be cultivated based on demand and supply as the main objective.

Rythu Bharosa amount will be issued through RBKs from May 15, he added.

The chief minister announced that a scheme will be implemented in June to support micro-enterprises and provides interest-free loans of Rs 10,000.

Title: Telangana: Eleven-day yagam against coronavirus
Content: Sarada Peetham began its 11-day amrutha pashupat yagam for visaha jwara peedhara on Wednesday. The peetham claimed the ritual would prevent the spread of coronavirus . The yagam is being conducted by ritual experts and rutviks under the supervision of Sarada Peetham Seer Swaroopanandendra at the Peetham in Chinnamushidiwada.According to Uttaradhikari of the peetham, Swamy Swatmanandendra, the country is passing through a bad phase as a result of kalasarpa dosha due to planetary positions. Uttaradhikari said the yaga would ensure the health and wellbeing of all citizens.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Police zonal football tournament to kickstart despite coronavirus scare
Content: BAREILLY: The Bareilly zone football tournament for police forces will kick-start as scheduled at Shaheed Jadunath Singh stadium in Shahjahanpur district from Wednesday, even though the government had similar programmes with mass gathering due to corona virus scare.ADG Bareilly Zone Avinash Chandra confirmed that nine police teams from each district of the zone will participate in the event. He said all efforts would be made to ensure that the tournament happens in hygienic environment.“We have been told by the headquarters that the inter-zonal tournament will happen on scheduled date, which is why we are going with the zonal tournament in Bareilly division . The winning will participate in inter-zonal competition. It is an internal tournament which doesn’t gather masses from outside,” Chandra told TOI.“We are also keeping an eye on the coronavirus updates in the country and the event may be called off if there is a state of emergency here, “he added.Teams from Bareilly, Moradabad, Pilibhit, Budaun, Sambhal, Rampur, Moradabad, Bijnor and Amroha districts would be participating in the tournament.Inspector Mukesh Singh, who is the looking after the preparations of the event, said, “Nearly 150 players, including the coaches, would be participating in the event. We are taking every precaution to ensure that safety of players is not compromised. Sanitisers and masks will be provided to everyone and a team of medical experts will be present on the ground. Shahjahanpur Municipal Corporation has been informed to ensure fogging at the ground and the reserve police lines. So far, no case of coronavirus has been reported from Bareilly zone, and we are hopeful that the event will be held without any hiccups.”

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Two fresh cases of swine flu detected in Bareilly
Content: BAREILLY: A resident of Kargaina in Bareilly and a Rampur native, both of them undergoing treatment at a private hospital here, have been tested positive for swine flu, officials said on Wednesday.This comes days after a resident of Uttarakhand, who was being treated here, and a local from Civil Lines, Bareilly, were tested positive for the disease.According to the officials, the first case was reported in February, whereas three others were detected this month.Since two patients were native of the neighbouring districts, (Rampur and Khatima in Uttarakhand), the health department in Bareilly has notified their counterparts about them.District epidemiologist Dr Meesam Abbas said, “No mortality due to swine flu has been reported this year in Bareilly and even disease of incidence is low in comparison to last year. Besides, with the rise in temperature in the next month, the cases of H1N1 will be minimised.”“As the symptoms of novel coronavirus (Covid-19) and swine flu are similar, doctors should check if the patient has acute respiratory distress syndrome or not. If the patient has acute respiratory distress syndrome, but has no travel history and did not come in contact with the infected person, then swine flu cannot be ruled out,” he added.In 2019, 65 people tested positive and three succumbed to the H1N1 virus in Bareilly division . Of these, 60, including the three deaths, were reported from Bareilly district , four from Shahjahanpur district and one from Budaun.In 2018, Bareilly district had reported only a single case of swine flu while 54 were tested positive in 2017.Experts said H1N1 virus is an air-borne contagious disease and spreads through the air droplets produced by sneezing, coughing, or by direct contact with saliva or mucus secretions.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: PTR to maintain data of stray tigers with help of mobile app
Content:
PILIBHIT: Pilibhit Tiger Reserve authorities have decided to maintain a data of tigers that stray into the eco-sensitive zone of the forest through a mobile app. This app will be the first of its kind in the state.

There are 276 villages in the eco-sensitive zone and of these, 176 have been declared as “sensitive”. From time to time, tigers stray into these villages. Now, if spotted, the information about the big cat will be relayed to the forest officials by “bagh mitras”, who have been selected for the purpose. Each of the bagh mitras will have the app on his mobile for the purpose.

The app will show the GPS coordinates, the photos and the brief description of the big cat spotted along with mobile phone numbers of forest personnel ranging from the forest guard up to the deputy director— all of which will be available on a single click. The information will then be compiled in PTR ’s data base online along with maps concerned.

Till now, PTR authorities had little or no information about tigers that stray out of the forest, said deputy director Naveen Khandelwal.

He said, “The app will be downloaded on the mobiles of some 12 bagh mitras in each of the 176 villages declared as sensitive in the eco sensitive zone of PTR. Each bagh mitra will transfer the information of any tiger straying into their area with specific details through the mobile app to the forest staff concerned.”

Once they get the information, the field forest personnel will immediately rush to the spot and verify the authenticity of the information. If they assess the situation as “alarming”, they will immediately inform higher officials to receive assistance of a rescue team.

The action taken on ground zero in response to bagh mitra’s information will regularly be examined by the SDOs and the deputy director, Khandelwal added.

“This information will be compiled and analyzed at PTR headquarters on a weekly basis and it will also help identifying the most affected areas in vicinity of forest and to study the reasons for the tiger to stray there,” the deputy director explained.

The bagh mitra and field forest force will be trained to use app, he added.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Two booked for extortion, death threats to Delhi-trader
Content:
Representative Image

PILIBHIT: The police on Tuesday morning booked two wholesalers of fruits for extorting over Rs 45 lakh from a trader based in Delhi’s Azadpur Mandi.

The accused owed the victim a large amount towards fruits supplied to them over the past five years. When the trader reached Pilibhit to demand his outstanding payment, the wholesalers abused him and threatened him with murder.

The victim, Ravi Kumar, who lives in Gur Mandi under Model Town police station in Delhi, filed a written complaint at Sungarhi police station late night on Monday, alleging that he had trade dealings with Anwar Hussain and company, of the agriculture produce marketing committee (APMC) campus in Pilibhit.

Partners Aftab Hussain and Guddu began taking supplies of fruits from him many years ago, but stopped paying since 2015. After every reminder, Kumar said they kept reassuring him they would clear all dues with the next consignment. Gradually, their arrears accumulated to the tune of Rs 45.6 lakh.

Unable to rely on their word any more, when Kumar reached Pilibhit and demanded payment of his dues, he was abused by the two accused and threatened with murder.

Sungarhi SHO Atar Singh said an FIR was lodged against both accused under sections 406 (criminal breach of trust) and 386 (extortion).

Title: Pune: Bail pleas of duo in extortion case rejected
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A magisterial court in Pune cantonment on Wednesday rejected the bail applications of Dheeraj Sabale (26) and Mandar Waykar (41), arrested recently in the Rs50-lakh extortion case, which also involves gangster Chhota Rajan ’s niece Priyadashini Nikalje , who is on the run.

Judicial magistrate first class (JMFC) Komal Singh Rajput said in an order, “It is not in the interest of justice to release the accused at this point of time on bail.”

The magistrate observed, “If we consider the record, it is noticed that accused persons were actively involved in the alleged act. One of them (Sabale) was caught red-handed while accepting money. One of the main accused (Nikalje) is still absconding and investigation is in progress. The nature of offence and from the involvement of the persons in it, the possibility of tampering and other adverse aspects cannot be ruled out.”

Earlier, the city crime branch officials produced Sabale and Waykar before JMFC Rajput at the end of the duo’s custodial remand and prosecutor Angela Navgire , assisted by complainant’s lawyer Milind Pawar , moved a plea for further extension of custodial remand. The magistrate, however, observed that sufficient remand had been given to the police and directed the two accused to be sent to the Yerawada jail under magisterial custody.

Soon after, the two accused moved their bail pleas, contending that investigation against them stood completed and, that, they had been falsely dragged in the matter. Both, the prosecutor and the investigating officer, objected to the grant of bail, arguing that the offence was serious, and the investigation was in progress. One of the accused is still absconding and, hence, the bail pleas be rejected.

Sabale, Waykar and Nikalje are facing charges of threatening a 48-year-old Katraj-based developer at gunpoint and demanding Rs50 lakh from him.

Title: Hyderabad: ATM firm driver who fled with Rs 92 lakh held
Content: HYDERABAD: A day after it came to light that a driver of an ATM cash replenishing service company escaped with Rs 92 lakh cash from Chilkalguda , police nabbed the culprit and recovered cash on Wednesday.Though the incident happened on Sunday, police, after a manhunt, managed to nab the offender on Wednesday. The offender provided fake details to his employer to hoodwink law-enforcement agencies, police sources said.On Sunday evening, P Harish, 45, manager incharge of CMS Infosystems, lodged a complaint with Chilkalguda police alleging that a driver of one of their vehicles used to transport cash from banks to ATM centres, had escaped with Rs 92 lakh cash on Sunday afternoon at Chilkalguda.According to the complainant, the accused driver, gunman Ravi Kumar and cash custodians T Ravi and Jogammeda went from their office in Lower Tank Bund to SBI’s branch at Koti around 10.30am on Sunday. Around 12 noon, CMS staff reached SBI’s Koti branch in an SUV. They took indent from a bank employee and withdrew Rs 1.6 crore to load in SBI’s ATM centres on the AS Rao Nagar route.The CMS team made their first stop at an SBI ATM near Shiva tea point in Chilkalguda at 1pm and took out Rs 68 lakh cash from the vehicle to load in the ATM.While gunman Ravi Kumar, cash custodians T Ravi and Jogammeda got down from the vehicle to load the cash in ATM, the accused drove the SUV ahead after informing his colleagues that he would take a U-turn and get ready to go towards their next stop.As the driver did not return with the vehicle for a long time, the CMS team alerted a colleague, who, in turn, alerted the manager. CMS staff tracked the GPS of the SUV and located it near Lalapet flyover.“At Lalapet flyover, CMS staff found the abandoned vehicle, but the remaining Rs 92 lakh cash and the accused was missing,” Chilkalguda police said. Police registered a case under Sections 408 and 420 of the IPC and launched a manhunt to nab the offenders. Both police and Task Force teams searched for the offender and nabbed him. According to sources, the accused joined CMS with an intention to commit the offence and provided fake details at the time of joining to avoid detection by law-enforcement agencies.

Title: Will boycott NPR in its current form, say prominent Sunni clerics
Content:
Bareilly: A group of Sunni Muslim clerics associated with an influential Islamic seminary on Tuesday said they will give a boycott call for the upcoming national population census if it is not on the lines of the one conducted in 2011. The Barelvi clerics, who had gathered at Dargah Aala Hazrat, said they will appeal to the Imams of mosques to give the boycott call if their concerns are not addressed by the government.

Amid apprehensions from a section of population that some of them will be declared “outsiders” if they are not able to furnish documents proving their nationality, Union home minister Amit Shah has told Parliament earlier this month that people will not have to submit citizenship documents under the NPR exercise.

Amid “confusion” over the National Population Register (NPR), BJP’s ally and Bihar chief minister Nitish Kumar has said that the 2020 format has several “controversial” clauses. The Bihar assembly also recently passed a resolution saying that the NPR will be implemented according to the 2011 format.

Parts of the country were recently embroiled in large-scale protests against Constitutional (Amendment) Act (CAA) and also the NPR. Most of the protesters were from the minority community.

On Tuesday, a meeting of the Barelvi clerics led by Mufti Asjad Raza Khan, also voiced their concerns about the proposed format of NPR.

National vice-president of Jamat Raza-e-Mustafa, an organisation affiliated to Dargah Aala Hazrat, Salman Hasan Khan said, “The population census should be carried out in the same way as was done in 2011. Muslims should not be afraid of NPR as dargah will stand by them. If anyone comes to your house for survey, talk to him in polite manner but there is no need to share any document with him. We will appeal to Imams of mosques to inform public about boycotting NPR during Friday prayers.”

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: KEM Hospital, Haffkine Institute to start tests today, up Mumbai’s capacity to 300 samples a day
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

MUMBAI: Testing capacity for Covid-19 will double from 150 to 300 in the city on Thursday, with authorities making arrangements for tests at KEM Hospital and Haffkine Institute, apart from Kasturba Hospital’s molecular laboratory at present.

The capacity will jump to 1,000 Covid-19 tests a day within a few days if the Indian Council for Medical Research (ICMR) gives permission to more government as well as private laboratories. The WHO has recommended scaling up testing facilities in India to confirm the extent of the virus’s spread. India is currently testing barely

BMC commissioner Praveen Pardeshi said Kasturba and KEM hospitals would jointly test around 300 samples a day. KEM on Wednesday tested samples which were reconfirmed by the National Institute of Virology, Pune, and the results were found to be definitive, the BMC said. Additional municipal commissioner Suresh Kakani said KEM will start testing swab samples from Thursday. “They will share Kasturba’s load that has been single-handedly testing samples from Mumbai and MMR,” he said. KEM may be able to handle 150-200 samples a day.

On Wednesday, Pardesi held discussions with private labs and hospitals, including Metropolis, SRL, Thyrocare and Hinduja Hospital laboratory, for testing facilities. The BMC has asked these laboratories to share their details with ICMR to get the mandatory permission to conduct tests. “Once they get the permission, they can also conduct around 1,000 tests a day,” said Pardeshi.

Meanwhile, earlier in the day, state health minister Rajesh Tope visited NIV in Pune and said eight new laboratories, including at Pune’s B J Medical College, would be allowed to conduct tests for Covid-19. The Centre will provide 10 lakh more kits for Covid-19 testing, he added.

Currently, the infrastructure at Kasturba allows for 150 samples to be tested daily.

The BMC is now ramping up the facility and will add new equipment that will allow 250 samples to be tested daily from Friday, said civic officials. “Kasturba laboratory currently has six trained personnel to conduct the tests. The BMC is now recruiting more professionals for the increased number of tests,” said BMC officials.

The state-run Sir J J Hospital, Byculla, which has a state of the art molecular laboratory to test for tuberculosis, will also provide Covid-19 testing facilities.

At Haffkine Institute, said Tope, two new laboratories will be added in the coming four days.

NIV will provide equipment in Dhule, Aurangabad and Solapur to set up Covid-19 testing laboratories. BMC officials said Aurangabad corporation has reached out to the BMC to train its personnel to conduct tests.

“The state is ready with 700 ventilators and 600 isolation beds. It is mandatory for all private hospitals to provide isolation beds,” said Tope.

He added NIV is networked with over 50-60 laboratories around the country. (Inputs by Sumitra Deb Roy)

Title: Bareilly: Two held for stealing 24 mobile tower batteries
Content:
Representative Image

BAREILLY: Hundreds of people residing in two villages in Sheeshgarh area of Bareilly district had to face poor mobile signal, as 24 mobile tower batteries were stolen by a gang of two thieves. However, their free run ended when the police caught them red-handed while selling the stolen batteries in a market.

Both the accused are nearly 22-year-old and have committed multiple robberies in the district.

Divulging details SHO Sheeshgarh Rajkumar Tiwari said, “Accused have been identified as Subhash Babu and Chaitanya Prasad . They both are residents of Deoraniya area of Bareilly. Subhash is a history-sheeter and has committed a robbery in Nainital district as well, while it was Chaitanya’s first robbery. Both of them stole nearly a dozen batteries from a mobile tower with the help of other gang members due to which the mobile connectivity of the entire area was affected. The accused were arrested while they were attempting to sell the 24 stolen batteries. We are trying to find the details of other persons involved in the robberies with them.”

Title: Pune: Undertrial sentenced via videocon proceeding
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A sessions court on Wednesday convicted and sentenced a 35-year-old man to life imprisonment for murdering his wife by setting her ablaze on May 1, 2014, in their fifth-floor flat at Utkarsha Society in Katraj.

Accused Vikas Kumar Suraj Bhan Kumar , lodged in the Yerawada jail, was produced before additional sessions judge GP Agrawal in a videoconference proceeding for the sentencing after he was convicted for murder.

“Due to Covid-19 virus, the Director General of Police has directed all district/central prisons to produce undertrial prisoners through videoconferencing . Accused is produced through videoconferencing. He is informed that charge under section 302 (murder) of IPC is proved against him and asked him what he wants to submit on point of sentence,” the judgment read.

Additional public prosecutor Sunil More told TOI, “Kumar was working with a builder who had given him a fifth-floor room in a building adjacent to his office for living. The accused would often suspect the character of his wife and beat her under the influence of liquor.”

“Around 8am on May 1, 2014, the accused set his wife ablaze following a quarrel. The burning victim ran out of the house and to the fourth-floor flat of a couple before collapsing there, shouting for help. She was shifted to a private hospital in Katraj and subsequently to the Sassoon hospital ,” More said.

Around 2pm, the same day, Anita recorded her dying declaration before investigating officer API SH Shaikh in the presence of Prasanna Nair , member of a Mahila Dakshata Samiti. The same was converted into an FIR. More examined total eight witnesses in support of the prosecution’s case.

The judge relied on evidence recorded by the couple as well as the conduct of the accused, who egged them on to let her die instead of saving her. The court cited Section 8 of the Indian Evidence Act referring to the previous and subsequent conduct of the accused to establish his criminal intent that was corroborated by the couple’s evidence.

Title: Pune: Koregaon Bhima panel summons Sharad Pawar for deposition on April 4
Content:
PUNE: The Koregaon Bhima inquiry commission has summoned NCP chief Sharad Pawar for deposition on April 4 in Mumbai related to the ongoing inquiry into the January 1, 2018, caste riots.

The commission has released a schedule of hearings from March 30 to April 4 to be held in Mumbai. Apart from Pawar, who is to depose on the last day, the commission has summoned then Pune district collector Saurabh Rao, then additional commissioner of police Ravindra Sengaonkar , then superintendent of Pune rural police Mohammad Suvez Haq and then Baramati division’s additional superintendent of police Sandip Pakhale for deposition.

On February 20, rightist think-tank member Sagar Shinde had filed an affidavit urging the commission to summon Pawar for providing additional information the latter might have regarding the caste riots. Both, Shinde and Pawar, filed affidavits in the past as witness before the commission comprising Justice (retd) Jainarayan Patel and former top bureaucrat Sumit Mullick .

On February 11, the newly formed Maha Vikas Aghadi government gave a “final” two-month extension to the commission — set up in February 2018 by the previous Devendra Fadnavis-led government to look into the sequence of events leading to the riots — to complete the proceeding and submit a final report by April 8.

It is Shinde’s case that the statements made by Pawar on February 18 at a press conference in Mumbai on the Pune police’s probe into the Elgar Parishad case indicated a contradictory position vis-à-vis what the NCP chief mentioned in his affidavit filed on October 8, 2018, before the commission. As such, Pawar may have some additional information to provide to the commission.

The NCP’s spokesperson and state minority development minister Nawab Malik said in a release on Wednesday, “Pawar will depose before the commission on April 4 as per the date of availability he had conveyed to the panel. Our party has always maintained that the caste riots at Koregaon Bhima were pre-planned and that is the reason why Pawar stated his stance through an affidavit filed earlier.”

Title: Covid-19: Ganga aarti at Haridwar, Kashi closed to public
Content: VARANASI/ HARIDWAR: The famous Ganga aarti of Varanasi, which is a prime attraction for domestic and foreign tourists, will now be conducted by just one priest, and without any public participation, with the Varanasi district administration banning gatherings on the ghats during the ritual as a precautionary measure against the coronavirus pandemic.In Haridwar, the district administration capped the number of devotees at 50 during the ritual at the Har-ki-Pauri area where on a normal day thousands of people witness Ganga aarti.Varanasi district magistrate Kaushal Raj Sharma said that the traditional aarti will not be stopped, but will be performed in a ‘curtailed form’. “Public participation has been banned and now only aarti organisers will participate in the ritual,” he said. Ganga Seva Nidhi member Dr V K Singh said, “It has been decided to continue the tradition of the daily aarti, but the number of archaks (priests) has been reduced to one.” Haridwar district magistrate C Ravishankar said the restrictions will be imposed at Har-ko-Pauri from Thursday and will be in effect till March 31. “With the beginning of navaratras on March 25, live streaming of the aarti will commence so that devotees can take part in the ritual virtually,” he told TOI.Office bearers of Ganga Sabha , a religious organization, who participated in a meeting with the district administration on Wednesday had opposed the idea of restricting the pilgrims and instead proposed that about 1000 masks can be distributed at the aarti every day and the ghat can be sanitised. But the idea was shot down by the district authorities as being “practically not feasible”. Instead, the ban on assembly of people has been put in place.Earlier, Ganga Sabha general secretary Tanmay Vashishth told TOI that "the aarti at the Har-ki-Pauri is an ancient tradition which cannot be stopped because of the virus threat and nor can Ganga Sabha advise people not to attend the aarti." "If the administration does not want pilgrims to gather in large numbers, it should ban their entry into the city," he further said.

Title: Covid-19 in Gujarat: Govt cracks whip on profiteering by mask, sanitizer sellers, 53 cases filed
Content: AHMEDABAD: The office of the controller, legal metrology has launched a drive against medical stores and manufacturers and dealers of masks and sanitizers for charging consumers more than the maximum retail price (MRP).Between March 12 and 18, as many as 686 premises were checked by joint teams of the legal metrology and FDCA. An official statement said that 53 cases of charging money over the MRP have been filed, while 17 other cases have been filed.D L Parmar, controller, legal metrology department, said on Wednesday that masks and sanitizers have been brought under the Essential Commodities Act and steps are being taken to regularize supply of masks and sanitizers. “Every medical store, dealer or manufacturer has to publicly display the stock of masks and sanitizers that are available on a daily basis. We have asked all district collectors and our field officers to file daily reports on the action being taken against those who are tampering with MRP of sanitizers and masks,” Parmar said.The official added that compounding fee of more than Rs 1.50 lakh has been recovered as part of the drive. Despite the drive by the government, hand sanitizers are still not available at a majority of medical stores in the city.

Title: Telangana: Principal, 3 staffers writing Inter exams for students held
Content: HYDERABAD: A principal and three staffers of New Madina Junior College , Tolichowki, were caught red-handed writing intermediate exam on behalf of eight students on Wednesday by high-power committee formed to catch malpractice cases.Golconda police arrested principal Shoib Tanveer and staffers Shabha, Shahida Shareen and Syed Kaleemuddin. Police also booked eight students and arrested four of them. Two students, who are minors, have been handed over to their parents, while two others are absconding.“On reaching the centre with cops, it was discovered that the principal and management of the said college was writing answers on behalf of eight students. The principal had entered into a deal with students for a certain amount,” said B Jayaprada Bai, district intermediate education officer (DIEO) of Hyderabad.Speaking to TOI, the DIEO said they received a tip about organised malpractice about three days ago. “They were said to have written answers on behalf of these students for at least three exams. But we could only catch them red-handed today.”The principal and three staffers were also handed over to the police and a case was filed against them by TSBIE officers.Meanwhile, TSBIE commissioner, Syed Omer Jaleel, has issued a show-cause notice to New Madina College and asked why the board should not cancel the college’s affiliation. The college management has been told to respond within three days.“The taskforce team along with officials of TSBIE visited your college and found organised malpractice activities at the exam center. These illegal activities are not possible without the support of the college management and members of the college too accepted their involvement in the crime. So, the secretary/correspondent of the college is directed to show cause, why your affiliation should not be cancelled,” read the notice from the board.

Title: Smart infotainment systems stolen from 13 parked cars in Pune
Content: PUNE: Smart infotainment systems worth over Rs1 lakh were stolen in the early hours of Tuesday from 13 cars parked across Right and Left Bhusari Colony, off Paud Road, after breaking their window glass.Senior inspector Pratibha Joshi of the Kothrud police said the residents had parked their cars along the road — devoid of CCTV cameras and security guards — in Bhusari Colony because of the ongoing road concreting work. “The thieves took advantage of it and stole the music systems,” Joshi said.“The thieves mainly targeted the top variants of cars having inbuilt infotainment systems,” Rahul Zalte , a resident of Gaurish society in Right Bhusari Colony, told TOI.Prachi Ballal (40), a resident of Runwal Paradise society, lodged an FIR with the police. She had parked her car along the road near her society on Monday night. On Tuesday morning, a security guard of the society informed her about the theft of the infotainment system from the car.This was the second incident of smart infotainment gadgets’ theft from cars in Right Bhusari Colony in the past six months. On September 15 last year, music systems from five cars were stolen. Five more cases were reported from Pashan on the same day.Zalte, pursuing law degree, said he came down to take his bag from the boot of his sedan around 5.30am on Tuesday. “I noticed the left window glass was broken and someone had stolen the infotainment system,” he said.After he alerted the police control room, the Kothrud police reached the spot immediately. “While checking the other parked cars, we noticed few more cars with broken window glass,” he said.Zalte has a designated parking slot in the society. “We had to park our cars on other bylanes because of the ongoing road work. There is no proper security in the colony,” he said. Software engineer Rehan Khan ’s car was targeted in Left Bhusari Colony. “My car was parked outside the society. I checked the CCTV footage. Around 1am, a motorcycle rider came near my car and returned. He may be the member of the gang. The footage, however, is not clear,” he said.Khan said his office had told everyone to work from home because of the coronavirus outbreak. “We have to be online 24 hours. I shall have to take a leave because I have to visit the police station for completing the necessary formalities,” he said.
