Title: Aurangabad: Admin plans action against tourists
Content: AURANGABAD: The district administration is seriously considering filing cases against tourists and visitors to Aurangabad to prevent the coronavirus spread.As a part of the plan, special squads would be deployed at all the 22 entry points to the district. These squads will screen everyone entering, including those coming in for tourism purposes. The administration is considering taking action against such people under section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by a public servant) of the IPC.“We are considering the deployment of squads at all the entry points to the district. This will keep a check on all the unwanted tourists entering Aurangabad. We will register offences under section 188, if we find that people are coming to Aurangabad for tourism purposes,” district collector Uday Choudhari told TOI.Following the state health department’s notification, the district administration has invoked provisions of the Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897. Using the special power delegated under this Act, the administration has closed down all the historical monuments, including the world heritage sites of Ajanta and Ellora, that attract a large number of domestic and foreign tourists. The officials have also advised against social, political or other gatherings.The health department officials said that stage I of the pandemic comprises cases imported from affected countries, stage II is when there is local transmission from positive cases. In stage III, the infection spreads in large communities and areas, while in stage IV there is an all-out epidemic. The collector said Aurangabad is in the initial phase of stage II, as the close contacts of a woman, who had herself tested positive of coronavirus, have started showing symptoms. “As a precautionary measure, we will not hesitate from exploring all legal options available,” said Choudhary.All the squads, before being deployed at the entry points, would be trained by experts in screening visitors and would be provided with the necessary gear to shield themselves. They will opt for thermal screening of the commuters, and their primary focus would be on taxi vehicles, followed by private vehicles from outside.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: 200 Indian medical students stranded in Manila seek govt help
Content: AGRA: Nearly 200 medical students from India, who are stranded in Manila after the Indian government stopped flights from Philippines on Tuesday, have sought help from Prime Minister Narendra Modi to ensure their safe return.Talking to TOI, Udit Bhardwaj, a student from Aligarh who is pursuing MBBS in Manila, said that all the students had booked return tickets to India for either Tuesday or Wednesday after the Philippines government declared a “state of calamity” on Monday, giving them 72 hours to leave the country. He added that they were caught off-guard by the Indian government’s decision to ban incoming flights and have now been left in the lurch.Bhardwaj said, “I arrived last night at the airport to catch my 1.30 am Air Asia flight to Delhi and was given a boarding pass. However, we were later informed that the flight has been cancelled.” Noting that the local government has declared a “state of calamity” for six months, he said, “We don’t know what to do. We did not get any satisfactory response from the airlines. There was no Indian government representative at the airport either. Many students are still at the airport due to the curfew and they can’t even travel back to their universities.”Echoing similar sentiments, another stranded student Sudarshan Patidar from Rajasthan said, “We were not given any prior notice. Nobody is able to tell us when the situation will improve or when we will be able to get out.” He also urged the Indian government to either lift the flight ban or take them back home in a special aircraft.Another medical student Geet Shankar Mazumdar from Assam’s Guwahati told TOI that the suspension of flights by the Indian government came as a huge shock to them. “They could have done this after all the students had left,” he added.Sharing videos from the Manila airport, the students said that their flight was cancelled after boarding passes were issued to them. “When we asked them to show us the official order, they refused and were very rude to all of us. They even threatened of police action if we made videos of their conversations.”Meanwhile, the Indian embassy in Manila tweeted that they are co-ordinating with the ministry of external affairs to work out a solution. It said, “It is requested to all to kindly have patience.”The government had on Tuesday prohibited entry of passengers from Afghanistan, Philippines and Malaysia with immediate effect.

Title: 8 new labs in Maharashtra to test Covid-19 samples
Content: PUNE: Maharashtra health minister Rajesh Tope on Wednesday announced eight new testing laboratories for coronavirus across the state.He said among these facilities, the ones at BJ Medical College in Pune and KEM hospital and Kasturba hospital in Mumbai would start fuctioning from Thursday.The minister said the additional laboratories would test 180-250 samples each day to reduce the burden on Pune-based National Institute of Virology (NIV).Tope said the necessary technical support and training would be imparted by NIV, which would also issue accreditation to these laboratories for carrying out tests for confirming the novel coronavirus infection.With the contagion entering its second phase, Tope said, the administration needed to be careful and more facilities have to be provided for faster testing of the Covid-19 samples. “The testing facilities are to be cleared by the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR). The new testing laboratories, apart from the ones at BJ Medical College, KEM and Kasturba hospitals, would become functional in the next 10 days,” he said.One testing centre would be set up in Mumbai’s JJ Hospital and two at Haffkine Institute . There will be a facility each in Aurangabad, Dhule, Miraj and Solapur, the minister said.On the spread of coronavirus cases in the state, he said 33 of the total infected people were the ones, or “import persons”, who returned from abroad. “Only nine were cases were that of local transmission (local persons who came in contact with people who returned from foreign countries),” Tope said.Referring to some complaints of shortage of kits, the minister said the state has sought 10 lakh additional kits have been sought from the Union government. He said the state has 700 ventilator kits and 600 isolation beds. In Pune, which reported the highest cases in the state so far, as many as 100 isolation beds are being readied at Naidu hospital and 60 isolation beds at the YCM hospital in Pimpri-Chinchwad The health minister said the NIV in Pune was networked with over 50-60 laboratories around the country.“There is a protocol for carrying out Covid-19 testing. The suspect person’s travel history and symptoms for coronavirus are first ascertained before being recommended for a test,” he said.

Title: Amdavadis pay Rs 6 lakh a day in traffic fines
Content: In reply to Vadgam independent MLA Jignesh Mevani, the state government said Rs 42.89 crore was collected i... Read More GANDHINAGAR: Every day, Amdavadis pay an average of Rs 5.87 lakh in traffic fines and in Surat city, the figure is Rs 5.83 lakh, government data shows. In reply to Vadgam independent MLA Jignesh Mevani, the state government said Rs 42.89 crore was collected in traffic fines from Ahmedabad city in last two years, and in the same period, Rs 42.62 crore was collected from Surat city. The government also stated that in 2018 and 2019, Rs 5.66 crore in traffic fines was collected from Ahmedabad’s rural areas, and Rs 2.16 crore collected from Surat district. A government officer said that the dense network of CCTV cameras at traffic junctions in both Ahmedabad and Surat has led to higher detection and significant collection of fines in the two cities. The officer said that this year the figures may increase four or fivefold as traffic fine amounts have increased after the latest amendment of the Motor Vehicles Act and consequent rules passed by the state. The new fines were implemented from October 2019. Suspension of the helmet rule for over a month also reduced the amount of fines collected, the officer said. The highest amounts of traffic fines were paid by people not wearing helmets, followed by illegal parking. The third-highest amount of fines was collected from those jumping red lights, followed by those talking on phone.

Title: Couple quarantined, 22 screened for Covid-19, including foreigners
Content: Agra: The health department surveillance team on Wednesday admitted an Agra couple at the isolation facility of the district hospital, after they were found with suspicious health condition.Residents of Sikandra, the man (40) is a worker at a private shoe factory, whose owner and his son are currently quarantined in Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital for Covid-19 infection. Dr Satish Verma, superintendent in-charge of district hospital, said, “Two weeks back, the man had visited the hospital and was found normal, but our surveillance team, who were in constant touch with him, found his wife too has developed suspicious health condition.”“On Wednesday, the couple was brought to our isolation facility and put under observation. Our teams have also screened 22 people, including train passengers, foreign nationals and locals, who arrived from Covid-19 affected countries,” he added.Among those screened were an Australian, an Argentine and four local women who had arrived from Dubai and Switzerland. Three of them, who landed from Dubai, travelled in Kongu Express from Delhi to Agra. Their samples were collected by health department staff.The Agra DM has issued an advisory to local residents that they should avoid visiting Kaila Devi Temple in Rajasthan, which locals traditionally visit after Holi to offer prayers and make wishes.The same order has been communicated by Karauli DM Mohanlal Yadav too. Kaila Devi Trust has shut down the temple.

Title: Agra Municipal Corporation to table Rs 660 crore budget in next meet
Content:
Representative Image

AGRA: The Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) administration has prepared draft of a Rs 660 crore annual budget for the financial year 2020-21. It will be tabled in the municipal board meeting on March 21, where the Jal Sansthan budget of Rs 158.34 crore will also be tabled. AMC administration has decided not to levy any new tax. No changes have been made in tax rates for residential and commercial properties, water, sewer, advertisement etc.

AMC administration has planned to install a statue of Maharana Pratap at Etmadullah view point crossing on Tran-Yamuna road. The statue will be developed by Padma Sri Ram Vanji Sutar , and will cost Rs 28 lakh in total.

The AMC administration has increased funds to be provided for community marriages to social organisation. In this regard, Rs 50 lakh was allocated in 2019-20, which has been increased to Rs 75 lakh for 2020-21.

In order to better manage municipal solid waste (MSW), the civic body has decided to distribute three dustbins to each household. The green colour dustbin will be for biodegradable waste (kitchen waste, garden litter, solid paper, house dust), blue colour for non-biodegradable waste (glass, metal objects and wires, plastic, leather, furniture, packing material etc) and red colour for hazardous waste (paints, batteries, solvent, cleaning agents, pesticides etc).

Mayor Naveen Jain ordered AMC to provide free of cost the set of three dustbins to those household that don’t have any house tax dues.

Title: Kasba Peth woman, Pimpri Chinchwad man test positive
Content: PUNE: A 28-year-old woman from Kasba Peth and a man (21) from Pimpri Chinchwad tested positive for Covid-19 infection, officials confirmed on Wednesday.With this, the number of Covid-19 positive cases in Pune has gone up to 19.The woman recently returned from the Netherlands via Dubai, while the Pimpri Chinchwad man came back from the Philippines.The woman from Kasba Peth is an IT professional. “She had gone to the Netherlands with her 32-year-old husband. We have quarantined her husband, the cab driver who brought them from Mumbai to Pune and her two domestic helps to rule out the contagion. Their reports are awaited,” a state health official said.The couple landed at the Mumbai airport around 3pm on March 15. “They took a cab from Mumbai and reached Pune the same evening. She self-reported to Naidu Hospital the following day, as she developed bodyache and malaise. The woman was aware how quickly the virus can spread and did not mingle with anybody outside. The couple has no children. Their parents stay separately,” the health official said.“The cab driver who brought the couple from Mumbai to Pune has been traced and isolated at Yashwantrao Chavan Memorial (YCM) Hospital in Pimpri Chinchwad. Her husband and two domestic helps are quarantined at Naidu Hospital. Their throat swab samples have been sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) for tests,” he added.The Pimpri Chinchwad man testing positive for Covid-19 has been quarantined at YCM hospital in Pimpri Chinchwad. “He has minor flu-like symptoms,” an official said.“He returned to Pune after touring the Philippines. His co-travellers are being traced. Those already traced have been out under home quarantine,” the official said.The total number of coronavirus cases in India went up to 159 and Maharashtra , with four more patients testing positive on Wednesday, continued to lead the list at 45.A 68-year-old domestic help tested positive for coronavirus on Wednesday, making this the first case to come from a slum pocket in Mumbai. A day before, her 49-year-old US-based employer, who came to Mumbai around 10 days ago, had tested positive for the contagion.

Title: AMU professor suspended after woman medico levels sexual harassment allegations
Content:
AGRA: The Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) on Wednesday suspended one of its professors after considering findings of an internal panel probing sexual harassment charge leveled against him by a senior resident doctor. The woman medico had filed a complaint against the professor on December 9 last year, which was then referred to the Internal Complaints Committee (ICC) for investigation.

After a detailed investigation, the ICC had submitted its report to vice chancellor (VC) Tariq Mansoor on March 7. According to varsity officials, the inquiry report had suggested suspension of the professor, after which the action was taken.

AMU registrar Abdul Hamid confirmed that the professor has been suspended with immediate effect pending departmental inquiry.

“He (professor) should not leave Aligarh without obtaining prior permission from the VC,” the registrar said. However, he didn’t reveal details of the findings of the inquiry.

When contacted, the professor refused to comment on the matter.

Title: Hyderabad: Inter papers full of errors, say teachers
Content:
Representative Image

HYDERABAD: More than 30 mistakes were noticed in question papers for inter exams between March 4 and March 18. While majority of errors (6) were in English second year paper, there were several errors, especially in Telugu and Urdu medium papers. “For almost all the exam, errata were sent. During zoology exam, a message was sent saying there are no errors, but at 10:40am, some corrections were sent. By that time, majority of students had attempted that question,” said P Madhusudhan Reddy, president, government junior colleges lecturers’ association, adding that majority of errors are result of translating questions from English into Urdu or Telugu.

Lecturers and principals said most errors are typos and board cannot afford to make such silly mistakes. Board officials, meanwhile, said almost all errors were rectified before start of exam.

Title: Biometric attendance suspended in government offices
Content: Agra: Biometric attendance has been temporarily suspended in almost all the government offices. Staffers are marking their attendance on register. Majority of the offices are having very few visitors. Developmental works have also been affected.Operations of the biometric attendance system has been suspended in commissioner’s office, collectorate, sub-divisional offices, cantonment board, health department, Agra Municipal Corporation , Agra development authority, Jal Sansthan etc since past one week.Chief medical officer Mukesh Kumar Vats said, “In the biometric attendance system, people touch the machine successively which poses as a risk of spreading the infection. Suspension of biometric attendance should continue till the danger of coronavirus subsides.”Meanwhile, the district administration on Wednesday evening issued fresh instructions to put a tab on the spread of coronavirus.District magistrate Prabhu N Singh ordered the suspension of all private conferences and meetings till April 2. School and colleges have also been closed.DM has ordered restaurants, hotels and other business premises to ensure frequent sanitization of the premises. Besides, visitors are asked to sanitize their hands at the entrance. People are advised not to leave home without any necessary work.

Title: Covid-19 scare in Pune: Diocese of Poona suspends Holy Mass and worship
Content: PUNE: The Diocese of Poona has suspended worship and Holy Mass, including on Sundays, till further notice, because of the novel coronavirus spread.In an advisory to priests and the Catholic faithful, Father Malcolm Sequeira , vicar general of the diocese, communicated the suspension of services on behalf of Bishop Thomas Dabre The diocese had earlier issued comprehensive guidelines to all churches and chapels to conduct prayers and Mass while making provision for hand sanitizers at entrances and to avoid embraces, among other measures.The advisory stated, “In view of the rising cases of the coronavirus pandemic, Mass and worship in the Diocese of Poona in the presence of the faithful have been suspended till further notice. Let us manifest our solidarity with the authorities and also with all humanity because coranvirus is a threat to humanity.”The Diocese of Poona has 39 churches in its care, spread across Pune, Pimpri Chinchwad, Solapur, Kolhapur, Miraj and Sangli.Speaking to TOI, Fr Sequeira said even area-wise Masses, the Way of the Cross which depicts Christ’s journey to his crucifixion and a major Catholic Charismatic programme to be held on Sunday stand cancelled. Father Sequeira hopes the situation will ease before Holy Week begins on April 5. Good Friday is observed during the week.

Title: Coronavirus in Maharashtra: Travel history ‘lapses’ on government radar
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Health minister Rajesh Tope has directed officials to check for any lapses in the travel history records of the Covid-19 positive woman (28), who came from Mumbai to Pune aftervisiting Rotterdam in the Netherlands and France.

On why the woman was not quarantined in accordance with the protocol with France being among the “high-risk” countries, Tope said details available with him revealed that the traveller mentioned that she had gone to the Netherlands.

“The Netherlands is not included in the list of the Centre’s list of ‘high-risk’ countries,” he told TOI, adding that an inquiry would be done into “lapses” if the travel details revealed that she had gone to France.

The Centre had issued instructions for all incoming travellers, including Indians, arriving from China, Italy, Iran, Republic of Korea, France, Spain and Germany after February 15, should be quarantined for a minimum period of 14 days.

The woman returned to Pune by a car from the Mumbai airport after returning from her foreign travel. She came to Pune on March 14, was admitted to Naidu Hospital and tested positive for Covid-19 on Tuesday night.

Title: Covid-19: Iskcon temple in Vrindavan shut till March 31
Content:
Agra: Iskcon temple in Vrindavan has been closed for public for the next two weeks in a bid to contain the coronavirus pandemic. The temple has been shut down for the first time ever since its inception 45 years ago.

Confirming this on Wednesday, the temple’s public relations officer, Saurabh Das, said that all routine work related to deity prayers and ‘kirtan’ will continue inside the temple as 80 brahmacharis live inside the premises. He said the decision to close the temple for public was taken on Wednesday and as of now no visitors will be allowed till March 31.

Meanwhile, Mathura police has registered a case against two persons for allegedly providing accommodation to 20 foreigners from various countries without informing the local district office or police. According to police, two persons, Ram Prakash Tewari and Ramesh Chandra Agarwal, were booked under sections 7 and 14 of Foreigners Act 1946 for allegedly providing accommodation to the foreigners since March 15.

The foreigners were immediately screened by the health department and fortunately none of them was found to have symptoms of the disease so far, said circle officer Govardhan Jitendra Kumar. He added that they had been charged Rs 500 per day and there was no registration of the guest house.

Mathura SSP Dr Gaurav Grover appealed to hotels and ashrams operators in the city to immediately inform the police in such cases to prevent spread of coronavirus. He said strict action will be taken if anyone violates the move.

Title: After monuments, forts & forests out of bounds
Content: PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: The forest department has banned entry of visitors to popular tourist destinations such as Sinhagad Fort, Pachgaon Parvati, Hingne and Bhamburda Forest Park till March 31 to avoid the spread of Covid-19.Pune division assistant conservator of forests Sanjay Kadu said instructions have been issued to Bhamburda range forest officer Deepak Pawar to not allow people enter Sinhagad Fort and the (forest) parks in areas under his limits till March 31.“Nearly 4,000-5,000 visitors daily visit Sinhagad Fort. The footfall goes up to 7,000-8,000 on Saturdays and Sundays,” Pawar said.Pachgaon Parvati and Bhamburda Park receive 3,000-4,000 and 2,000-2,500 visitors daily in the morning and evening. Pawar said the department has put up notice boards at the entry and exit points at all these locations, informing the visitors that the destinations would be out of bounds March 31.A section of the regular visitors to the hills and forts in and around the city were flummoxed by the administration’s directive.Ninad Deshpande, a visitor to Vetal Tekdi near Ganeshkhind Road, said he would now have to exercise at home. “I visit Vetal Tekdi every Sunday with my friends. I do not know what we will do this Sunday. In fact, trekking is considered a good way of exercise that boosts immunity. We will, however, have to follow the government’s regulations.” Vikram Patil visits Sinhagad Fort every alternate Sunday for a trek and said he was disappointed with the closure of hills and the forts, but the government’s decision to keep such places out of people’s bounds might be a wise move because these destinations get crowded in weekends.He said, “Sinhagad Fort remains overcrowded on weekends and holidays. The government wants to avoid large gatherings in the time of Covid-19.”The district authorities recently issued orders to close museums and monuments with high footfalls in the city till March 31. Among such destinations are Aga Khan Palace and Shaniwarwada. An average of 600 people visit Aga Khan Palace every day, while Shaniwarwada registers a daily footfall of around 1,600 visitors.

Title: Gujarat: Coronavirus clouds castor oil exports to Europe
Content: AHMEDABAD: While disruptions of castor oil shipments to China have eased, its export to Europe is now threatened with the continent in the grip of the novel coronavirus (Covid-19). Europe is the second largest importer of castor oil from India after China.“European buyers want castor oil dispatches to be delayed due to the Covid-19 outbreak. Demand from Europe has also been affected,” said a member of the Solvent Extractors’ Association of India, a pan-India body of the vegetable oil industry.Europe accounts for 30-35% of castor oil exports from India, while China makes up 40%. India’s castor oil exports stood at 5.71 lakh metric tonnes in the last fiscal. Most of this goes from Gujarat , as the state is the largest producer and exporter of castor oil in India.“After offices, factories in Europe have started shutting down. As a result, demand for castor oil is expected to fall,” a castor oil exporter said.With uncertainty looming over exports, prices of castor seed are also under pressure. Spot prices hovered between Rs 740 and Rs 750 at the Deesa and Palanpur mandis.Demand from Europe is under cloud at a time when export to China are gradually coming back on track, with shipments getting through.“Consignments to China were disrupted as movement of inward containers was hampered due to the coronavirus outbreak. Dispatches now have re-started,” said an industry player.Some players have also started getting fresh orders from China. “The situation seems to be improving in China. I have received orders from China," said Dilip Padhya, CMD of Palanpur-based Amee Castor and Derivatives.Echoing similar concerns, sesame seed exporters from Gujarat said that demand from Europe has been affected.“Europe accounts for 15% of the 3 lakh tonnes of sesame seed exported from India every year. Fresh orders have come to a standstill. Importers from Europe are in wait-and-watch mode. They are asking us to extend deliveries as demand for oil seed has gone down due to the outbreak in Europe,” said an office bearer of the Federation of Indian Spice Stakeholders.“Meanwhile, shipments of cumin (jeera) to China have begun. Exporters have started getting fresh orders, although at slower pace. Cumin is not exported to European countries,” the office bearer added.

Title: 28 daily wage sanitary workers terminated
Content:
NMC has around 6,000 permanent and 2,113 daily wage sanitary workers

NAGPUR: Municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe on Tuesday terminated 28 daily wage sanitary workers and initiated departmental inquiry against 35 permanent sanitary workers after they were found absent from duty without intimating the health department (sanitation).

It is for the first time in the history of the NMC that such a huge number of sanitary workers have been sacked.

Confirming the news, a senior health department (sanitation) official said the terminated daily wage sanitary workers were absent from duty without informing NMC for months and escaped action.

At present, the NMC has around 6,000 permanent and 2,113 daily wage sanitary workers. Each sanitary worker is supposed to sweep 500m of road. But many of them were irregular.

TOI has reported that it is a practice at NMC, especially in health department, that employees go on leave and resume work as per their convenience citing medical reasons. But the administration took no action against such erring sanitary workers.

Since December 2017, the NMC has implemented the system to track sanitary workers through GPS-enabled wrist watches under Smart City project. The civic body pays Rs207 per month towards rental charges for each of 8,000 wrist watches for seven years. The exercise was to record their attendance . But due to opposition from sanitary workers, the ruling party halted the usage of GPS watch from August to October 2019. Though the GPS watch system was restarted from November last year, it was implemented fully after Mundhe took charge at the NMC on January 28.

Despite high-tech system in place, citizens and even corporators complain about workers’ irregular attendance and sweeping. The objective of GPS-enabled wrist watches include recording shift-wise attendance of sanitary workers, prevention and control of misuse of manual attendance system, maintenance of transparency, accountability in operations and weeding out of fake, duplicate, and false workers.

Angry over this, Mundhe ordered an inquiry at the zone level and subsequently cancelled duty cards of 28 daily wage sanitary workers. Besides, the civic chief also directed to interlink GPS-based attendance of sanitary workers with their salary slips.

Title: Madurai: Plea against opening Tasmac outlet
Content:
Representative image

Madras high court has directed the authorities to consider a plea which sought to restrain them from opening a new Tasmac shop at Anna Nagar in Madurai .

In the petition, S Karthik, a resident of Madurai, stated several hospitals are situated on the 80 feet road at Anna Nagar. Many people visit the hospitals every day.He stated that he learnt that the officials were planning to open a new Tasmac shop in the area. Though he submitted a representation to the authorities concerned urging them not to open the liquor shop, no steps were taken so far. Hence, the petitioner moved the high court Madurai bench. When the case was taken up for hearing on Wednesday, a division bench of justices P N Prakash and B Pugalendhi disposed of the petition by directing the authorities concerned to consider the petitioner’s representation and pass appropriate orders.tnn

Title: Rs 1.2 lakh cost on firm for not replying to notice
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: Madras high court on Tuesday imposed a cost of Rs 1.20 lakh on the managing partner of V V Minerals for not properly responding to the showcause notice issued by the state government as to why the lease granted to them should not be prematurely terminated in an attempt to regulate beach sand mineral resources.

In his petition, S Vaikundarajan, managing partner of V V Minerals at Tirunelveli district stated that his firm has been granted mining leases for the purpose of mining beach sand minerals under the Mines and Minerals (Development and Regulation) Act, 1957 and Mineral Concession Rules 1960. The state government issued showcause notice to the firm in 2019, after the central government decided to include beach sand minerals as atomic minerals. The petitioner moved the high court seeking to quash the showcause notice issued to the firm. He also sought to stay the proceedings. Dismissing the petition, justice C V Karthikeyan imposed the cost on the petitioner for not properly responding to the notice. The judge directed the petitioner to pay Rs 30,000 each to the government medical colleges at Madurai , Sivaganga, Tirunelveli and Tuticorin.

Title: Madras HC asks state, Centre to give Rs 10 crore to 11 with rare disorder
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: Coming to the aid of people with rare disorders, including Lysosomal Storage Disorders (LSD), the Madras high court on Wednesday said a welfare state should not lose faith and give up on such people.

In its interim order, the first bench of Chief Justice AP Sahi and Justice Senthil Kumar Ramamoorthy directed the Centre to allocate Rs 4.40 crore this year towards the treatment expenses of 11 people in the state affected by LSD as approximately each patient would require Rs 40 lakh a year for medical expenses. The court also directed the state government to allocate at least Rs 5 crore every year for treatment expenses of deserving patients suffering from such rare diseases.

LSD is a debilitating disorder that can be fatal. “In the hope that a person cannot be treated, one should not forget that hope itself, at times, brings about miracles and therefore, it is the duty of every responsible citizen, more so, that of a welfare state, not to lose faith or hope and continue to provide whatever assistance is possible within the means available,” the first bench said.

The court passed the order on a PIL moved by Lysosomal Storage Disorders Support Society (LSDSS) seeking financial aid from the government for such people.

Passing the orders, the bench said: “There is a perception in the state government that in view of the nature of these diseases which cannot be permanently cured, a financial aid would only help to prolong the longevity of a patient suffering from such disease. We may put on record that such a perception need not deter the government from proceeding further as we are of the firm opinion that it is difficult to exactly predict the expiry of anything from this world.”

According to petitioner, LSDs are a group of around 40 plus rare genetic disorders that’s prevalent among one in 8,000 live births. In such patients, a progressive accumulation of partially-degraded compounds in vital organs results in multiorgan malfunctioning, adversely affecting their quality of life and eventually leading to failure to thrive and death.

Title: Banks advise customers to stay away from branches
Content: Kolkata: All the leading banks are issuing advisory to their customers urging them to avoid branch banking as much as possible and encouraging digital and phone banking for the time being amid a corona scare. Some private sector banks like ICICI Bank have come out with a special mobile app through which customers can perform all the activities, including applying for loan.The former deputy chief secretary of SBI Staff Association, Ashok Mukherjee, has gone one step ahead and said that NRI customers should stop coming to banks or there should be some advisory that anyone coming back from abroad cannot come to any branches with 14 days. “It has happened in Kerala. In one bank branch where an NRI carrying Corona infection visited a branch and one employee got infected following which the entire branch had to be closed,” he added.State Bank of India, ICICI Bank, HDFC Bank have all advised customers to do transactions in digital mode and card. “We are telling customers to use our e-services as much as possible. SBI has an e-corner where a range of services are available,” an SBI official in customer care said.HDFC Bank officials also added that the bank has mobile apps along with all the other digital mode of transaction facilities. ICICI Bank has announced the launch of ‘ICICIStack’, a set of digital banking services and APIs (Application Programme Interface), to ensure uninterrupted banking experience to customers.“Retail and business, including retailers, merchants, fintechs, large e-commerce firms, corporates — at a time when they are advised to stay indoors in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak. Many of the services are first-in-the-industry and are available instantly on the Bank’s mobile phone or internet banking platform,” the bank has added.‘ICICIStack’ offers nearly 500 services covering almost all banking requirements of customers, in one place. The list includes digital account opening (instant savings and current account opening), loan solutions (instant personal loans, instant credit cards, instant home loan sanctions, instant car loans, instant overdraft facility, instant business loans), payment solutions (digital payment solutions like UPI, bill payments using Bharat Bill Payment System), investments (instant FD, PPF, NPS and AI-led robo-advisory for other investments), insurance (term and health insurances digitally) and care solutions (protection for life, health, car and home).

Title: Pune: Permit rooms, bars to stay shut till March 31
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The district collector on Wednesday asked 1,000 and odd permit rooms , beer bars and clubs in areas under Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) and Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC) limits to shut shop till March 31.

In a bid to ensure social distancing against the backdrop of Covid-19 cases, the district administration passed an order to close all “on premises” liquor-serving establishments like beer bars, permit rooms (except star hotels).

While sources representing Pune Restaurants and Hoteliers Association (PRAHA) said there were around 2,400 such bars and permit rooms in PMC and PCMC limits, the excise department said there were at least a 1,000 such establishments.

The order, issued by Pune district collector and chairman of the District Disaster Management Authority Naval Kishore Ram, directed closure of all FL3 licences (sale of imported and Indian Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL) in permit rooms and restaurants — excluding star hotels), FL-4 licenses (permanent), FL-4 licenses (Temporary i.e. sale of imported liquor and IMFL at clubs) as well as on premise licenses like E (sale of beer on premises of a restaurant, club, canteen) and E-2 (sale of on premise wine) in Pune Municipal Corporation and Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation areas.

“Travellers have reached all over the country by international and domestic flights. Such travellers have also been coming to Pune district from abroad and many are on their return journey. Taking into account the possibility of further spread of Covid-19, it is imperative to take immediate control to prevent further increase in cases of the infection. We cannot rule out the possibility that Covid-19 has been transmitted in Pune district from travellers. It is thus important to maintain social distancing. Hence, the decision to shut all permit rooms and bars until March 31,” Ram said.

The order was passed based on the District Disaster Management Act, 2005, and Maharashtra Prohibition Act, 1949. Ram said.

PRAHA sources said there was confusion among restaurants in PCMC area if they would also have to stop serving food with liquor.

An official from the state excise department said, “The food can be served at these establishments.”

Title: Covid-19 in Pune: Market Yard to be closed on Friday for disinfection drive
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The wholesalers and commission agents at the Gultekdi Market Yard have announced a daylong closure on Friday to conduct a disinfection drive in the facility, in the wake of the novel coronavirus spread.

The Agriculture Produce Market Committee (APMC) said it would provide necessary facilities at the market to unload vegetables and fruits sent by the farmers on Friday, though the commission agents would not work.

“We are planning adequate measures for unloading the farm produce and assisting the local vendors to purchase vegetables from the farmers. This will assure the local city market gets the supply of vegetables and fruits despite closure by traders,” BJ Deshmukh , the administrator at APMC Pune, said.

Vilas Bhujbal, head of the association of commission agents at APMC, said, “We had a meeting of members on Wednesday. It was observed that the entire area of the wholesale market would have to be disinfected. We have planned a shutdown on Friday. Saturday is weekly off for the market. So, the APMC administration will get two days to conduct the drive.” tnn

Title: Pamphlets containing ‘fatwa’ of Hafiz Saeed found in Aligarh, FIR registered
Content:
Agra: Aligarh police have registered an FIR against an unidentified person for circulating pamphlets of a ‘fatwa’ (opinion) issued by

Mumbai attack mastermind and Jamat-ud-Dawa (JuD) chief Hafiz Saeed.

According to the FIR, a large number of pamphlets were found scattered in a city’s communally sensitive area.

Superintendent of police (crime) Arvind Kumar said, “The matter is being probed. There was an attempt to vitiate the peaceful atmosphere of the city. The content of the four-page pamphlet was objectionable.” The FIR was registered under IPC section 505 (1) (b) (with intent to cause fear or alarm to the public) and 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) at Kotwali police station. “The content of the pamphlet was highly objectionable and could have created communal tension,” the SP said.

Title: Plea to cancel licence issued for quarrying near KKNPP dismissed
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: Madras high court has dismissed a plea which sought to cancel the licence issued to a company to quarry near the Kudankulam Nuclear Power Plant (KKNPP) in Tirunelveli district . A division bench passed the order while hearing a plea filed by N Chendurpandi.

The judges observed that the petitioner in his petition said the authorities concerned had given quarrying licence to a private company within 2.8km radius of the Kudankulam plant and sought the licence to be cancelled.

The authorities have placed materials before the court to show that the quarry licence was given to the company in respect of the area, which is 5.98km from the plant and 2.9km from the compound wall of the site. The counsel appearing for the petitioner submitted that a GO dated April 29, 1991 states that whenever any activity is to be permitted by the revenue authorities within 2 to 5km radius around the nuclear power station, permission of the project local committee should have to be obtained, whereas, in this case, such permission has not been obtained.

The judges observed that the necessity to obtain clearance from the Kudankulam Project Local Committee would arise only where the proposed activity falls within the radius of 2 to 5km and not beyond it. The judges noted that the project director of the plant sent a communication stating that there was no objection for the quarry. Citing that the petition is devoid of merits, the judges dismissed the petition.

Title: Congress to contest two Rajya Sabha seats in Gujarat
Content:
After a meeting with AICC general secretary K C Venugopal in New Delhi on Tuesday night, Gujarat Congress chie... Read More

AHMEDABAD: Despite losing five MLAs ahead of the Rajya Sabha election, the Congress on Wednesday decided that it will contest both Rajya Sabha seats from Gujarat for which it has filed nominations. The Congress named Shaktisinh Gohil and Bharatsinh Solanki as its candidates for the March 26 RS poll.

The primary consideration for not withdrawing any candidate (Wednesday was the last day for withdrawing nominations) is the fact that as of now even the BJP does not have the numbers to get three candidates elected outright to the Rajya Sabha.

Importantly, the Congress has still not officially spelt out which of its two candidates will get the first 36 first preference votes of its MLAs and hence get elected automatically to the upper house. Congress leaders said that this will be decided later.

After a meeting with AICC general secretary K C Venugopal in New Delhi on Tuesday night, Gujarat Congress chief Amit Chavda maintained that there was no crisis and the Congress was ready for the election.

“The BJP has resorted to unethical means to win three seats, but the Congress has worked out a game plan to win two RS seats in Gujarat,” Chavda said.

While the BJP claims that more Congress MLAs will either resign or cross-vote, the Congress said that some BJP MLAs have been in touch with the Congress and will vote for Congress candidates

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Former assistant manager of private bank held for cyber fraud
Content:
Representative Image

AGRA: Former assistant manager of a leading private bank was arrested by Firozabad police over allegations that he siphoned off money from a customer’s bank account.

The accused was identified as Ajit Yadav of sector A Aliganj, Lucknow district. Yadav used to work in a branch of a private bank in Firozabad.

According to police, Rasoolpur-based resident Imran Khan had lodged an FIR against unknown person under IPC section 420 (cheating), 467 (forgery of valuable security, will, etc.), 468 (forgery for purpose of cheating), 471 (using as genuine a forged document) and IT Act 66 after an amount of Rs 1,56,859 was siphoned off his account without his knowledge.

SP Firozabad Sachindra Patel said, “During his tenure as assistant manager of the private bank, Ajit Yadav changed the mobile number linked with Imran’s bank account. This helped him purchase goods worth of Rs 16,262. He wired rest of the amount into his bank with not a single transaction alert sent to victim’s phone.”

“Our team is working to find if there were more victims of cyber fraud whose money was siphoned off by Yadav,” he added.

Title: Zoo on alert, takes off chicken from animals’ diet
Content:
Mysuru: After claiming that the Mysuru zoo is not facing any threat due to bird flu, the authorities at the centre have decided to make certain changes in the diet chart of animals and birds.

On Wednesday, the authorities started collecting feces samples from birds. They have also taken off chicken from the diet of animals after confirmation of avian flu in Mysore.

Sources in the zoo told TOI that they supply different types of food to zoo animals, reptiles and birds depending on the diet chart prepared by experts.

The zoo, which is celebrating its 128th year, has over 1,450 different types of animals and birds.

The zoo buys mutton and chicken daily apart from grains and other food items to feed the animals and birds.

Tigers, lions, leopards and other carnivorous animals like hyena, wild dogs and wild cats are fed mutton and chicken.

The zoo procures nearly 310 to 400 kg of mutton and chicken every day through a contractor.

“The zoo has completely stopped feeding chicken to animals from Wednesday,” said executive director Ajit Kulkarni .

Meanwhile, unlike Mysuru Palace and Brindavan Gardens , which get funds for maintenance, the zoo is solely dependent on its gate collection to manage its affairs. The state government had completely stopped giving grants to Mysuru zoo in 2002. Hence the zoo is dependent on its gate collection of nearly 29 crore every year, plus another three crore from rent collection from food plazas, canteens etc. Besides, another Rs 60 lakh is collected from animal adoption scheme where the public and donors can adopt animals and birds for a year to feed the same.

The zoo, which has been closed, will be in trouble if the closure is extended for another week.

It will be difficult to maintain the zoo without support from the government in the present circumstances. The government had cancelled block grant, which forced it to look at other revenue sources like adoption of animals’ scheme.

“Initially, Mysore zoo was not suffering from any fund crunch as it has own sources of revenue from gate collection, rent collection and animal adoption scheme. The zoo, which is financially strong, is also taking care of other sister mini zoos in Chitradurga and Gadag by providing financial aid. The zoo will definitely suffer losses if closure is extended for another few days,” said Kulkarni.
