Title: Telangana murder: Cops yet to establish woman’s identity
Content:
Representaive Image

HYDERABAD: Cyberabad police are working on available leads to solve the murder of a woman whose naked body was found under a culvert on Tangedupally-Vikarabad Road in Chevella town on Tuesday.

Six special teams comprising law and order and Special Operations Team (SOT) sleuths were verifying the details of the vehicles that passed through Moinabad-Vikarabad route in Rangareddy district via Tangedupally village. “The cameras at Tangedupally were removed due to road extension works. But, we have cameras on the route at Kothapally, Karmetta and Enkepally villages and we are verifying the CCTV camera footages,” said a Chevella police official.

Police found several four-wheelers, autos and mini vans carrying vegetables to the city from Vikarabad and Rangareddy districts in the CCTV camera footages. “The registration numbers were not visible due to headlight beam. We are taking the help of locals to identify the vehicles. We are also analysing the cellphone details of the murder spot to zero in on the suspects,” said a police official.

The doctors who performed the postmortem at Chevella government hospital told police that the woman was not sexually assaulted. Doctors also confirmed that the woman, who was aged around 30, had undergone caesearian and she was killed between 12 am and 5 am on Tuesday.

“There was no sexual assault. There were no strangulation marks also. After killing the victim, her body was brought to the culvert and her face was smashed with a boulder to avoid identification. It could be a case of sexual jealousy,” said an investigation officer. Gold bangles, a gold ring and a gold chain found on her body at the site indicate that she could be from a well-to-do family, police said.

As there was no reported case of missing woman that fits the woman’s profile from city Hyderabad and nearby districts, police have also alerted their counterparts in Karnataka and Maharashtra with the details of the murdered woman. Police have also sent the details of her ornaments to several jewellers for a possible identification.

Title: Coronavirus scare cancellations cost KSRTC Rs 1.5 crore in March
Content:
File photo KSRTC buses

MYSURU: The Karnataka State Transport Corporation has racked up losses of at least Rs 1.5 crore in March so far due to hundreds of trips cancelled daily over the coronavirus scare in its divisions in Mysuru (rural and urban), Hassan, Chikkamagalur, Mandya, Shivamogga and Chamarajanagar.

Outlining the magnitude of the problem, KSRTC authorities said on Tuesday alone, Mysuru rural cancelled 137 trips, followed by urban at 56; Shivamogga at 43; Hassan at 34; Mandya at 31; and Chikkamagaluru at 22 due to poor occupancy.

The Mysuru rural division, they said, has lost 30% of revenue so far while the urban division has lost 20%.

While passenger volume was dipping due to fears of an outbreak since the beginning of March, the curbs imposed by the state government and local administration has led to a steep decline, KSRTC officials said. Mysuru urban services, for instance, began registering a loss over the past 2-3 days.

The division lost Rs 2.3 lakh on cancellation of premium bus services on March 15 and 16 while the non-premium cancellations cost it nearly Rs 10 lakh between March 14 and 16.

The others have been bearing the brunt for longer. The rural division lost nearly Rs 78 lakh on cancellation of its premium and non-premium services between March 1 and 16.

In the same period, Shivamogga sustained a revenue loss of Rs 16.8 lakh on its premium and non-premium services, followed by Hassan at Rs 14.2 lakh, Chikkamagaluru at Rs 13.9 lakh, Chamarajanagar at Rs 13.4 lakh and Mandya at Rs 2.8 lakh.

Title: Pune: Working remotely taxing task for many, corporates give tips
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Shambhavi Singh has been trying hard to work from home, as advised by her office, but she faces several teething issues. Right from logistical support at home, like a good WiFi connection, to getting used to the office routine in a different environment, Singh mentioned she was also concerned about low productivity, delays in meeting targets and deadlines, among other issues. As a result, corporates have started issuing a list of tips to improve efficiency at home.

Setting goals, creating to-do lists, freshening up for work, organising the home space to turn it into a workstation, and being in touch with colleagues online are some of the tips shared to make remote working easy.

Senior officer at a financial institution Aarti Shastry said, “There are logistical challenges, especially with connectivity and data security. When the office issues a notice for remote working, the first thing I thought of was network and connectivity since I work in the finance sector. If there is an immediate requirement from a customer, I often go into a panic mode due to slow internet connectivity, access to data, etc. Of course, we escalate important calls to those still working in office, but it is not easy being at home.”

Rashmi Patil, another employee at a software firm, shared, “I am finding it very difficult to meet my target and the deliverables are getting delayed. Also, children are at home so managing them while working is taking a toll.”

Corporates are advising employees to be prepared for the regime and ensure access to proper infrastructure like laptops, wi-fi, video/audio, etc, at home. Co-founder of nutrition brand Oziva Aarti Gill said, “The most effective way to focus on work is treat it like your everyday routine so dress for work. You can also organise your space and turn it into a workstation. Be in touch with your colleagues online.”

Other tips shared by employers include giving a defined start to the day, planning tasks with time sheets, taking short breaks, staying connected, set daily goals, among others. Founder of BridgeLabz Narayan Mahadevan said, “It’s important not to multitask to get the maximum output. Also, to map progress, one should create and update a to-do list.”

Sandip Chhettri, chief operating officer at TradeIndia, said the company has developed a software to ensure employees remain focused on their work. “We have also developed an app to monitor the activity of our salesforce, which helps them work remotely,” he added.

Title: Sports complex hostel in Pune to house quarantine facility for 500
Content: PUNE: The officials of Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation have begun the process of setting up a 500-bed quarantine facility at Shiv Chhatrapati sports complex hostel in the Balewadi area.The increased international arrivals and demand for quarantine has prompted the civic body to convert the hostel into a quarantine facility. It will be the biggest quarantine facility in Pune, where suspected individuals will be asked to stay put as a precautionary measure to avoid the spread of coronavirus into the community.“We aim to make the facility operational at the earliest possible. The work is going on in full swing,” said additional municipal commissioner of Pimpri Chinchwad Santosh Patil Currently, the Pimpri Chinchwad municipal Corporation (PCMC) has 60-bed isolation facility at its hospital in Bhosari and another 10-bed isolation facility at YCM Hospital in Pimpri.“Eight private hospitals in Pimpri Chinchwad have shown willingness to keep 48 isolation beds ready, which can also be used if the need arises,” Patil said.The administration at the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) converted its hostel on Sanas ground into a 200-bed quarantine facility two weeks ago.“The PMC has also zeroed in on 10 municipal facilities, including halls and residential flats, in the possession of the civic administration. The civic body will check the demand and increase the number of properties that can be converted into quarantine facilities,” said Rajendra Muthe , the head of PMC’s land and estate department.Muthe said the vacant properties were maintained and made useful for residence. Beds and other facilities would be provided at these places for suspected patients and international travellers.The PCMC officials have also appealed to those who have recently travelled abroad to come forward and get themselves examined. People can inform authorities in such cases on PCMC helpline 8888006666 or WhatsApp number on 9922501450.

Title: Covid-19 in Maharashtra: Class X exams held with sanitisers at hand
Content: MUMBAI: On Wednesday, amid Covid-19 worries, schools conducted SSC and CBSE Class X exams on campus. Authorities said utmost care was taken to ensure students and teachers were not at risk.While the state cancelled all school and college exams till March 31, they allowed schools to continue with Class X and XII board exams.Over 3.6 lakh SSC students appeared for Science II paper from Mumbai division, which includes Mumbai, Thane, Palghar and Raigad. “We had sent out instructions to all exam centres to allow the use of sanitizers and take as many precautions as necessary. In case students wanted to wear masks, they were allowed to do so. We also provided sanitizers during moderators’ meetings. For the next two exams, similar precautions would be taken,” said Sandeep Sangave, secretary of Maharashtra State Board of Secondary and Higher Secondary Education's Mumbai division. While HSC exams ended on Wednesday, SSC students have two more papers to appear for.Class X CBSE students took social science paper. Madhu Singh, principal, Billabong High International School at Malad, said, “We are educating our invigilators to keep a vigil on the health of kids and identify students showing symptoms. Teachers were oriented about symptoms by a certified doctor. We kept only 12 children in a room and the distance between each kid was a minimum of one metre. Sanitizers are available.” Similar steps were taken by Andheri’s Rajhans Vidyalaya.CISCE issued an advisory to teachers to evaluate board exam papers from home.

Title: Coronavirus in Tamil Nadu: Uttar Pradesh man who came by train is state’s second coronavirus case
Content: CHENNAI: Tamil Nadu on Wednesday reported its second positive case of Covid-19 — a youth from Rampur district in Uttar Pradesh who came to Chennai on March 12. The 20-year-old hairdresser is now in the first-floor isolation ward in tower 2 at Rajiv Gandhi Government General Hospital and his condition is stable, health minister C Vijayabaskar said.“He came to Chennai from New Delhi by train and was staying with friends at an apartment in Chennai. He reported to the hospital with symptoms on Tuesday. He was tested positive today [Wednesday],” the minister said.Health department officials refused to reveal the coach number and the name of the train he travelled in or the place where he stayed in Chennai for five days before he was isolated in the government hospital. “We are still gathering details,” the minister said. “We will not able to reveal further details as it relates to patient confidentiality.” States like Kerala release flow charts of the places a positive patient has visited along with the time and date to alert people about a possible infection, but public health authorities in Chennai say they will not be able to do this as it might cause needless panic. Officials say the man boarded the train to Chennai on March 10 but did not have any “explicit” symptoms.He developed symptoms on Monday night and came to the hospital on Tuesday morning. “He reported to the Covid-19 op ward where we see patients with shortness of breath, cough and fever. Doctors suspected he could be infected . He is kept in isolation, but his condition is stable,” said dean Dr R Jayanthi. After two tests, on Wednesday evening, the state-run King Institute for Preventive Medicine confirmed he was positive for novel coronavirus infection.As of now, officials suspect the patient might have travelled to Nepal. “We are still talking to him,” said health secretary Beela Rajesh. “He has been to Delhi, travelled on a train and has moved around in Chennai. We are told his symptoms started only when he was here.”Public health officials are tracking his contacts, including fellow travellers, relatives and friends. The state’s first Covid-19 patient, who tested negative after treatment at Rajiv Gandhi Government General Hospital, was discharged on Monday.

Title: Man, 40, lands in prison for spreading rumour amid coronavirus scare
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: Madurai district superintendent of police N Manivannan has warned against any attempt to create and spread rumours in the light of the Covid-19 scare. This follows the arrest of a 40-year-old man named M Selvam from Irungalur in Trichy for spreading rumours that 47 people infected by Covid-19 have been isolated in an unoccupied apartment at Rajakkur near Othakadai .

A team of officials had visited the building to explore the possibility of setting up an isolation ward when people from the locality staged a protest based on the rumours. Selvam has been booked under IT act and Disaster Management Act 2005 and remanded in prison under judicial custody. The SP said that social media will be monitored by the concerned cell and those who create rumours will be taken to task. Manivannan said that a round-the-clock control room has been set up in the rural police office located at Surveyor Colony to handle all issues related to Covid-19. Public can share any details regarding the disease and mischief mongers with the facility by calling 7708806111, he said. Similarly, a control room each in Melur, Thirumangalam, Kallikudi, Usilampattti, Vadipatti and Peraiyur taluks has been opened jointly with the help of revenue officials. People can visit the centres to pass information related to Covid-19. Information received through the centres will be brought to the notice of officials concerned, he said.

Kits containing masks, hand sanitizer and kerchief were distributed to police personnel and ministerial staff in the rural police office by South Zone IG K P Shanmuga Rajeswaran and Madurai range DIG Annie Vijaya on Wednesday in presence of Manivannan and additional superintendent of police S Vanitha. Manivannan said that police and ministerial staff have been sensitised on personnel hygiene and how to sneeze, cough without affecting others. All police personnel involved in traffic regulation and vehicular check have been told to wear masks without fail. At police stations, officials have been instructed to provide hand sanitizers to those coming to file complaints.

Title: 100-bed quarantine facility comes up at Kalagram
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: In its fight to contain the spread of coronavirus, the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) and the district administration have come up with a 100-bed quarantine facility at Kalagram, which is spread across seven acres and is located in the Cidco area of the city. These arrangements are in addition to the 30 isolation-bed arrangement made at the Chikalthana-based district general civil hospital.

Health authorities said the arrangement made at Kalagram is the largest in the region. If required, the authorities are ready to increase the beds at this centre, apart from setting up more such accessible quarantine facilities in Aurangabad.

Responding to a letter sent by AMC chief Astik Kumar Pandey on Wednesday, district collector Uday Choudhary sanctioned Rs 2.5 crore for immediate procurement of equipment and medicines required to tackle Covid-19. “Rs 1 cr from state disaster fund and Rs 1.5 cr from the district planning committee have been immediately sanctioned to the civic body for the purchase of required items to tackle the outbreak,” said Choudhary.

The items the civic body intends to purchase include 50,000 triple layer masks, 2,000 personal protection devices, 10,000 N-95 masks, about 100 infrared thermometers, thermal body scanners, digital as well as portable X-ray machines, about five adult-cum-paediatric ventilators, essential drugs and other articles.

Sources said municipal commissioner sent a detailed requisition letter to the district administration seeking funds for the purchase of equipment, which was immediately sanctioned.

“We got Rs 2.5 cr for prioritizing the items and going for emergency purchases as soon as possible. We are ready with a 100-quarantine bed facility at Kalagram,” the AMC commissioner told TOI.

The officer said the civic body is leaving no stone unturned in terms of preparations, precautions and preventive measures, which are being carried out on a war-footing, to contain the outbreak of disease.

The civic body’s health department is working in close coordination with the district health department as well as the Government Medical College and Hospital authorities for monitoring the developments.

Title: Work on alternate road across the Vaigai begins
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: The Madurai Corporation has begun work on an alternative road on the Vaigai river to connect Vaigai South Bank Road with Vaigai North Bank Road, as the Kuruvikkaran Bridge is to be demolished to make way for a high-level bridge.

Officials said the contractor is providing the alternative route as per agreement. While the work order has been issued to the contractor, he will pull down the existing bridge once the alternate road is completed and tested fit for vehicular movement. Traffic police will also be consulted before demolishing the existing bridge, which was constructed around 50 years ago, since it is an important link between the southern and northern parts of the city.

“Basic structure of the road has been created by mounting soil and levelling it. Giant pipes are used to provide culvert like structure to allow the water in the river to pass. Once the soil got settled, bitumen road will be laid over it. The work is expected to be completed in a week or two,” an official from the engineering wing of the corporation said.

Corporation commissioner S Visakan said that the existing bridge will be demolished as soon as the alternative route is ready and construction will start without any delay. There was no need to go for land acquisition for this project since there is adequate space available. There is an encroachment by a private bar on the northern part of the city, which will be cleared when the work starts, he said.

The new bridge is planned at a cost of Rs 27.5 crore. It will be 1.5m higher than the existing bridge. It will also have a total width of 17.5m, including a two-metre-wide pedestrian pathway on either side. The total length of the bridge will be 223.20m, an official said.

Title: AK-47 theft case in Telangana: 5 cops suspended
Content:
Representative Image

HYDERABAD: Five cops who worked in Husnabad police station when two fire arms including an AK-47 were stolen in 2017, were suspended for dereliction of duty on Monday. In March 2017, D Sadanandam, 38, a shepherd from Akkannapet, sneaked into Husnabad police stationand stole an AK-47 and a carbine gun.

Following the incident, a probe was ordered but a case was registered only in April 2018. The incident came to light when Sadanandam opened fire at his neighbour on February 7, and police arrested Sadanandam. After the arrest, Siddipet ACP Ch Rameshwar conducted an enquiry and submitted a report, based on which five cops including Husnabad SI M Sanjay who were on duty at the station during the theft were suspended.

Title: Many avoid travel, train cancellation at its peak in Mysuru
Content:
Mysuru: The reservation and booking offices of South Western Railway in Mysuru are seeing a large number of ticket cancellations these days, thanks to the scare over coronavirus.

According to the authorities, booking of tickets declined by 25% while refund increased by 200-300% as many who had reserved their tickets well in advance have started cancelling them.

Divisional railway manager (DRM) Aparna Garg confirmed that there is a decline in the number of passengers travelling in trains.

According to the authorities, between March 11 and 16, some 4,446 passengers have cancelled their tickets at the reservation office in Mysuru. The total refund amount was Rs 17,08,908. In the reservation office, booking declined by 25% compared to other normal days while refund increased by 200-300%.

The booking office also witnesses a similar trend. The booking declined by 2,000 to 2,500 tickets per day while the number of passengers declined by 2,000 to 3,000 per day.

With the state and central governments shutting down all tourist places, events and conferences in various institutions, the passenger occupancy rate has come down drastically.

This apart, even regular passengers have also stopped travelling in trains. “This trend is not limited to trains. Even the number of persons using own vehicles or KSRTC buses has also come down. With no work and all preferring to work from home, naturally, the passenger volume has come down,” said Satish Babu, a regular passenger between Mysuru and Bengaluru.

“In every train, we used to find businessmen, travellers in a huge number every day. They are all missing now. With most tourist destinations being shut, those who had done advance booking have also cancelled them,” he said.

Title: Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation may charge for water supply
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Now get ready to pay for your municipal water supply based on consumption. A crucial water metering and water charge policy will be taken up for discussions in the upcoming standing committee meeting of the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC). According to this policy, consumers of municipal water supply like bungalows, flats, commercial complexes, institutions and government offices will have to pay towards water production charges of the municipal corporation.

According to this 21-page executive summary of the policy, each residential unit will get a free water supply of up to 22,500 litres a month. any extra litre usage will invite a water usage charge. If a household consumes anywhere between 22,5001 and 30,000 litres, it will have to pay the AMC at the rate of Rs 10 per 1,000 litres of water consumed. The monthly charges will not exceed more than Rs 75.

Similarly, a Rs 10 hike for per 1,000 litres consumed is being proposed for every additional 10,000 litres consumed. For instance, consumption between Rs 30,001 litres and Rs 40,000 will invite a charge of Rs 20 per for every 1,000 litres consumed, but the monthly charge will not exceed Rs 275. The highest consumption charge is being proposed for consuming more than 1 lakh litres or more for which the consumer will have to pay Rs 50 for every 1,000 litres of water consumed, while the monthly charge will exceed Rs 975 per month.

“Societies will be provided metered bulk water supply to common sumps from which individual households will have to withdraw via, preferably a metred system, to avoid conflicts amongst members,” says a senior AMC official. The official added that for slum dwellers there will be provision for common community taps.

Title: 100 sanitation workers deployed in Madurai
Content: MADURAI: Madurai corporation has involved 100 workers to sanitise public places by spraying disinfectant as a precautionary measure to prevent the spread of Covid-19.Corporation officials said they are being used in places where public gather, including markets, marriage halls, places of worship, bus terminals, hospitals and police stations. Health officials have been entrusted with the work of monitoring them. From Wednesday onwards, employees and visitors to corporation are being provided with hand sanitizers to clean their hands before entering the main building. Similar arrangement is in place in other corporation offices too. Banners and hoardings have been installed at around 200 prominent places insisting people to wash their hands, to avoid crowded places, mobility and maintain personnel hygiene. More than 500 dengue prevention workers are being used to visit houses to sensitise people. tnn

Title: Corona scare: Many opt for pvt taxis, avoid buses & trains
Content: Mysuru: The fear of the spread of coronavirus has now forced city residents to switch from buses and trains to private taxis for travel. Many city residents said for travel purposes they are now using the private taxis with white registration board they offer the service at a very affordable rate.According to several city residents, who travelled from Mysuru to cities like Bengaluru, Udupi , etc, these taxi service providers offer service at Rs 9 to Rs10 per kilometre. “Even 3-4 people travel at a time, this service becomes very affordable compared to the high-end buses or the super-fast trains. The travel time between Mysuru and Bengaluru has come down by 30-40 minutes compared to normal days. These taxies offer safe service from any kind of infection,” said Sudhakar Adiga, a resident of Jodi Bevinamara in Kanakadasanagar.However, the demand for regular cab services continues to decline. According to Jayakumar CA, honorary president, Mysuru Travels Association , the demand for cabs has come down by 90%.“This is the peak season for the cab service providers and the drivers. But there is hardly any demand for the cabs. The Covid 19 is playing havoc,” he said.According to the executive of another service provider, the ban on the gatherings by the district administration is adding to their sufferings. “The MNCs, IT companies stopped hiring vehicles to ferry their employees for annual gatherings or outing due to the fear of Covid 19. In Mysuru, it is the tour and travel service providers and the hotel managements which are facing the worst crisis due to Covid 19,” he said.Meanwhile, the Mysore District Tourist Vehicle Drivers & Owners Welfare Association approached the district administration seeking help to come out of the ongoing crisis which hit them worst. “We met the DC and submitted an appeal in this regard. We are facing big crisis this time due to the coronavirus,” said its president M Nagaraj.

Title: Gujarat: Court orders woman to return to her husband
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A Gandhinagar court ordered a woman to join her husband and fulfil her matrimonial duties after she couldn’t furnish evidence that her husband suffers from mental illness.

The woman, a junior clerk in the secretariat, deserted her husband three years ago claiming that he was suffering from schizophrenia and his erratic behaviour caused her mental pressure. She also filed for divorce on the grounds of his mental illness besides citing cruelty by him and her in-laws.

The woman is from Giyod village and her husband lives at Dashela village near Gandhinagar. They married in 2014. She got a job in a Vadodara court in 2015. A year later she got another job at the Sachivalaya and shifted to her matrimonial home. She left her husband and in-laws and went to live at her maternal home in Giyod in 2017. She filed for divorce in March 2019, and her divorce application is pending in a Gandhinagar court.

Two months after the wife filed for divorce, the husband approached the court and demanded restitution of conjugal rights under Section 9 of the Hindu Marriage Act. The deserter has to establish justifiable ground for desertion.

The husband claimed that since he was a farmer, his wife looked on his profession as below her dignity. He refuted his wife’s claim that he was suffering from schizophrenia and asserted that she had deserted him only because she does not like this marriage.

In reply, the wife claimed that she came to know about her husband mental condition immediately after marriage. During a schizophrenic stroke, he got violent and would continuously laugh without any reason. As soon as she came to know about his illness, she got a government job for security.

The wife, however, told the court that during their interactions for two years before their marriage, she did not find any symptoms of schizophrenia in her husband.

The court, while ordering her on Monday to go and live with her husband to fulfil her matrimonial obligations, said that she could not furnish any evidence to establish husband’s mental illness. Without this evidence, there was no justifiable reason for desertion.

Title: Closure of halls topples wedding plans in Aurangabad
Content: AURANGABAD: Citizens are either being forced to cancel the wedding plans or have low-key affairs at homes with fewer guests amid the coronovirus scare, even as dates believed to be auspicious fall in the last week of this month.Vikas Deshmukh, a college teacher, had planned his wedding in a hall, inviting at least 2,000 guests on Thursday. He has, however, shifted the venue to his house, where a few close relatives will attend the function.“The wedding hall cancelled our booking and the temple trusts are not allowing their premises to be used for weddings. Hence, we have decided to hold the ceremony at our home,” he said.Deshmukh’s family said they considered postponing the wedding, but the halls have already been booked for all dates during the ongoing marriage season.Ashok Sanap, a hotel owner, had booked a private lawn for his niece’s wedding for Thursday. “We had paid around Rs 1.5 lakh in advance for a lawn and pandal. Now, the venue has been shifted to our hometown, that is in Tagadgaon of Shirur-kasar taluka, due to fresh restrictions,” he said.Hrishikesh Kulkarni, proprietor of Venkatesh Mangal Karyalaya , said the civic body has communicated in writing to all wedding halls to shut operations till March-end. “We have been getting requests from interested parties to postpone the bookings for this month and are trying to manage it, according to the availability of slots,” he said.A wedding hall owner, preferring anonymity, said coronavirus has adversely affected his business. “Cancellation of bookings during the second half of March has already led to losses of lakhs of rupees. Contractors and workers associated with us are bound to feel the pinch,” he said.

Title: Ahmedabad: Man allegedly rapes woman he found on matrimonial site
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A 30-year-old woman from Chandkheda on Tuesday filed a complaint with Chandkheda police alleging that a 29-year-old man who contacted her through a matrimonial site repeatedly raped her.

In her FIR, the woman stated that she had registered with a matrimonial site in February 2018 . That month, the accused, identified as Abhishek Jambhle, a resident of Chandkheda, contacted her on the site and they became friends on Facebook too.

After a few months, they exchanged their cellphone numbers and began chatting. On June 16, 2018, Jambhle proposed marriage, saying that he loved her. The complainant stated that she too had fallen in love with him and they began meeting each other.

On November 8, 2018, Jambhle allegedly took the woman to a flat in Chandkheda and raped her. Later, he allegedly took her to a hotel near Adalaj and raped her.

The woman stated that she had told her parents in December 2019 about her relationship with Jambhle. But when her family members asked him if he wanted to marry her, he said no.

Jambhle later told the complainant that his parents were against their marriage. The woman stated that she continued to ask Jambhle to marry her for about two months.

On February 20, 2020, her parents met Jambhle and requested him to marry her. But he allegedly abused and threatened them with dire consequences. The woman fell into depression and had to be hospitalized. She later filed a police complaint.

Chandkheda police arrested Jambhle on Wednesday and booked him for rape.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: No storage facility, but veggie markets won’t shut: Traders
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: Major vegetable markets at Paravai and Mattuthavani have decided that they will not shut down but continue to receive their supplies though they have no facility to store the perishable vegetables.

The Paravai vegetable market on the city’s outskirts sees about 50 to 60 lorries from Andhra Pradesh , Karnataka , Maharashtra and Delhi as well as Indore and Agra bringing loads of vegetables everyday. Uncertainty prevails among the vendors as to how to price their vegetables following the information circulated amongst them saying the markets would be shut from March 19.

Manuel Jeyaraj, president of the Paravai Vegetable Market association said there was no direction from the government yet on closure of markets. ``We get our potatoes from Indore, Delhi and Agra, onions from Maharashtra, and vegetables such as cauliflower, beans and carrots from Karnataka in tonnes. These are perishable items that are essentials too, so they cannot close the markets,’’ he said. Thangaraj, a vendor in the market, said they were told that lorries from outstation would not be permitted into Tamil Nadu from March 21, ``This will definitely cause a crisis, at least as far as potatoes and onions are concerned,’’ he said. R Gowri, a housewife, said she was concerned that tomatoes and onions would not be available if markets closed. President of Mattuthavani Vegetable Market Association P S Murugan said they had informed the government that they were an essential service and that closing market was out of question. ``We know that people have to build their immunity to withstand the virus. What will they do if they cannot buy vegetables? After all, not all people can afford to buy and hoard and vegetables cannot be hoarded,’’ he said.

Title: Swab testing lab to be set up at GMC Miraj: Rajendra Patil-Yadravkar
Content: KOLHAPUR: A laboratory will soon be opened at the Government Medical College (GMC) at Miraj in the neighbouring Sangli district for testing swab samples of coronavirus suspects.Minister of state for health Rajendra Patil-Yadravkar visited the quarantine wards and checked the preparations of the health administration to fight against the spread of coronavirus. As of now, no confirmed case of coronavirus has been reported in the district.Currently, the facility to collect swab samples from the suspects is being operated at the GMC. The samples are then sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune. As of now, samples of only 10 suspects of the total 265 screened have been sent for testing.Of the 10, four have tested negative while six were rejected stating the people do not have symptoms or travel history to the countries affected by Covid-19. The health officials, too, are of the view that the number of tests done so far are much less than expected.“The next phase of coronavirus spread is critical. We have decided to set up the testing labs at several places in the state. One of which will be opened at Miraj which will be helpful to increase the number of tests carried out. Private doctors have assured us to assist in all possible ways to stop the spread of coronavirus.”District collector Daulat Desai has appealed to the people with travel history to the affected countries to home quarantine for 14 days. The health staff is visiting the home quarantined suspects.Desai has also ordered the civic bodies and rural administration to reach out to people arriving from the other cities as well where cases if coronavirus have been reported.The number of home quarantined suspects is currently at 223, up from 170 reported on Tuesday. The number of suspects completed 14-day home quarantine area 42 while number of people with a travel history traced on Wednesday was 56.

Title: Covid-19: Railways cancels trains due to poor patronage
Content: MADURAI: Railways has announced the cancellation of a few regular and special trains in view of poor patronage due to coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak.Train no. 07117 Hyderabad – Ernakulam Junction weekly special on March 25 and train no. 07118 Ernakulam Junction – Hyderabad weekly special on March 26.Train no. 06048 Thiruvananthapuram – MGR Chennai Central weekly special on April 1 and train no. 06047 MGR Chennai Central – Thiruvananthapuram weekly special on April 2.Train no. 06045 Ernakulam Junction – Rameswaram weekly special on April 2 and train no. 06046 Rameswaram – Ernakulam Junction weekly special on April 3.Train no. 22205 MGR Chennai Central – Madurai AC Duronto Express is cancelled on March 23, 25 and 30. Train no. 22206 Madurai – MGR Chennai Central AC Duronto is cancelled on March 24, 26 and 31.Train no. 06015 Ernakulam Junction – Velankanni Weekly Special is cancelled on March 21 and train no. 06016 Velankanni – Ernakulam Junction special is cancelled on March 22.Train no. 01704 Jabalpur – Tirunelveli weekly special is cancelled on March 26 and train no. 01703 Tirunelveli – Jabalpur weekly special is cancelled on March 28.Train nos. 56737/56738 Sengottai – Kollam – Sengottai passengers, train nos. 56740/56739/56744/56743 Kollam – Punalur – Kollam passengers, train nos 56333/56334 Punalur – Kollam – Punalur passengers are fully cancelled from March 19 to 31.Train nos. 56365/56366 Guruvayur – Punalur – Guruvayur passenger is partially cancelled between Kollam – Punalur. TNN

Title: Madurai: Fireworks industries told not to allow over 50 workers at a time
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: Even as collectors of the southern districts conducted awareness sessions with various stakeholders on Wednesday, the Virudhunagar collector asked fireworks industries to allow only 50 workers to work at a time.

A Covid-19 preventive meeting with various stakeholders such as lodge owners, car rental owners, omni bus operators and marriage hall owners was held in Virudhunagar district . Speaking at the meeting, Collector R Kannan said Covid-19 infection spreads 20% by coming in contact with the air that an infected person coughed or sneezed into and 80% through surfaces touched by the person. Hence, all people should wash their hands at least seven to eight times a day and avoid touching their faces.

All organisations employing more than 50 people were asked to ensure that only 50 worked at a time. People can call the numbers 011-2397804 ,044-29510400 and 044-29510500 and 9444340496 and 87544487 throughout the day for information, he said. A similar awareness session was conducted by health and revenue officials in Theni district at Kumili and Cumbum bordering Kerala. All people coming into Tamil Nadu were screened and vehicles sprayed with disinfectant. The screening would be conducted throughout the day, Theni district collector Pallavi M Baldev said.

Ramanathapuram collector K Veera Raghava Rao has asked people to refrain from crowding at places, and wash their hand regularly. Awareness is being created at all levels by officials. Many district collectors announced cancellation of grievance meets.tnn

Title: ZP polls: Velim, Nuvem set for high-stakes battle
Content:
Margao: The stakes are high for both Congress and BJP in Nuvem and Velim constituencies for the March 22 zilla panchayat polls.

While Congress is keen on “teaching a lesson or two” to the defectors who switched over from the grand old party to the saffron camp, BJP, which has failed to field candidates on party tickets, is determined to gain a foothold in these two Catholic-dominated constituencies. The BJP has strategically supported independent candidates in the two constituencies, realising fully well that it could fare miserably if it nominated candidates on party lines.

Chief minister Pramod Sawant was forthright when he admitted that the party needed more time to convince Salcete voters about BJP’s principles. “It will require some more time for the people (of Salcete) to accept the principles of the BJP and its ideas of development, though the MLAs believe in them. The eight months (since the Congress MLAs defected to the BJP) may have been too short a period for this,” Sawant said, interacting with reporters on the sidelines of a corner meeting at Davorlim recently.

BJP has fielded candidates in only two constituencies — Davorlim and Guirdolim — of Salcete, which has nine zilla panchayat constituencies, while extending support to independents affiliated to BJP MLAs in the rest.

In Nuvem, BJP MLA Wilfred D’Sa has extended support to independent candidate Breezy Fernande,s while Congress has fielded Assuciana Rodrigies as its candidate. Political observers say that both candidates are equally poised and the contest could be heading for an exciting finish. What has lent some advantage to Congress is the support it has received from former MLAs Francisco Pacheco and Aleixo Sequiera.

In Velim, though it is a six-cornered contest, political observers feel it is going to be a straight fight between independent candidate Anthony Rodrigues, or Babush, as he is popularly known, and Congress candidate Julio Fernandes. Rodrigues, who had won the 2010 ZP polls, is now seeking a second term, while Fernandes is a greenhorn in grassroot politics.

While Rodrigues, political observers say, could be enjoying covert support from Velim MLA Filipe Neri Rodrigues, Fernandes has been extended support by Velim sarpanch Savio D’Silva. Rodrigues, however, denies in public that he is supported by the BJP MLA, stressing that he enjoys support from across the political spectrum.

Congress, however, has made its anti-CAA(Citizenship (Amendment) Act stand the poll issue and has also been asking voters to reject the candidate “sponsored by the Congress-turned-BJP MLA.”

Title: Assam, Bengal & Odisha men flee Kerala quarantine
Content: GUWAHATI: An Assam native who had been quarantined in a Kerala hotel after he showed Covid-19 symptoms fled along with two others — one from Odisha and the other from West Bengal — on March 16 and is suspected to be travelling to the state by train.“We were informed by Kerala Police today that three people fled a quarantine facility there. One of them happens to be from Lahorighat in Morigaon district,” Morigaon SP Swapnaneel Deka told TOI on Wednesday. “We are tracking his mobile phone, based on which we believe he is on a train to Assam.” When the police last traced his mobile tower location, he was “somewhere in West Bengal”. All railway stations along the route to Assam have been alerted to keep an eye out for anyone matching the person’s description. “We have alerted Government Railway Police and hope to isolate him soon,” Deka said.It isn’t known if the Assam native who fled Kerala is employed there or has a history of travel to any of the countries affected by the pandemic. “As of now, we only know where his home is,” a police official said. “We don’t have any information about his test result either.”Assam is among the states that have so far not reported any confirmed case of novel coronavirus . A man with Covid-19 symptoms was on Wednesday shifted from a hospital at Mirza in Kamrup district to Gauhati Medical College and Hospital In Dhemaji district , a South Korean visiting the state since March 11 on a business trip has been quarantined in a hotel since Wednesday.

Title: Police rescue abducted youth in Aurangabad
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: The Pundaliknagar police on Tuesday rescued a 20-year-old youth who had been kidnapped by alleged private moneylenders from Partur in Jalna district .

The youth was reportedly kidnapped as his father had failed to pay the exorbitant interest rate charged on a loan he had taken.

Pundaliknagar police station’s assistant inspector Ghanshyam Sonawne said around 2 pm on Tuesday, they received a call informing that some suspects had kidnapped a youth from near the Hotel Shalimar, forced him into a car (with registration number MH-44-B-2867) and were heading towards Gajanan Maharaj temple.

Acting on the information, the detection branch team from the police station rushed towards the High Court signal and went towards Baba petrol pump. A few metres away, the police spotted the car and stopped it. The suspects managed to get out of the car and flee — leaving their vehicle and the youth, identified as Atul Satish Hajare , behind.

In his statement to the police, Atul, who hails from Partur but has been residing in Pundaliknagar area, said that his father is a tour operator. About a year ago, due to financial crisis, he had taken a loan of Rs 1.70 lakh on 5% interest. As a surety, his father had given two blank cheques and had signed a blank bond paper.

Atul said the suspects started collecting money from his father with an interest rate of 30% from the following month. Despite repaying an amount of Rs 17 lakh, the suspects refused to return the cheques and bond paper.

A month back, the suspects allegedly snatched their jeep (MH-21-BH-0686) and forcefully took possession of their house in Partur. Fed up with the harassment, the family then shifted to Aurangabad . On Tuesday afternoon, Atul was kidnapped when he stepped out of the house to meet his friend, The four suspects, allegedly using a firearm and a sharp-edged weapon, kidnapped him and were trying to take him to Partur.

Title: Covid 19 in Maharashtra: School closure stops midday meals for kids, SC sends notice
Content: MUMBAI: Maharashtra minister for school education Varsha Gaikwad has scheduled a meeting with officials following the Supreme Court ’s suo motu notice to all states over non-availability of mid-day meals to children due to closure of schools. Experts said there is a need to continue mid-day meals for vulnerable children from poor families.There are around 86,000 primary schools in the state where 1.1 crore-odd children get mid-day meals. The state education department has asked schools to remain shut till March-end as a preventive step to curb Covid-19.An official said the government may consider providing mid-day meals only to children in rural areas, saying they may be affected more than those in urban areas. At the village level, it may be possible to provide mid-day meals at the children’s homes due to the short distance of travel required.On Wednesday, the SC took cognisance of the non-availability of mid-day meals.A faculty of a reputed institute in Mumbai associated with disaster management said mid-day meals must continue even during vacations, droughts and outbreak of an epidemic. “Anganwadi workers normally serve nutritious food to children, lactating and pregnant women so they do not get infected with the virus,” he said, adding government should try to curb the virus while applying other methods to control vulnerability. Incidentally, in Kerala, the administration has made arrangements to home-deliver the meals to the children.

Title: Madurai man who arrived from Dubai admitted to GRH
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: A 24-year-old man from Thirumangalam who arrived at the Madurai International Airport from Dubai on Wednesday, has been admitted to the isolation ward of the Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) on suspicion of Covid-19 virus symptoms.

Health department sources said that man arrived by a SpiceJet flight at around 4pm. During mandatory screening at the airport, his was found to have high temperature. He was immediately sent in a 108 ambulance to the GRH. Officials said that he would be under observation at the isolation ward, and would be tested for the infection on Thursday. He is the only person in the isolation ward at the GRH on Wednesday. Screening has been intensified in the Madurai airport and passengers are being screened for their body temperature with thermal detectors and also provided hand sanitizers before leaving the airport.

Meanwhile, in Tuticorin district , a youth from Assam and another youth from Odisha were admitted in isolation ward of Thoothukudi Medical College Hospital with fever, cough and cold. A Central Industrial Security Force (CISF) personnel who was admitted in the port hospital in Tuticorin with symptoms was discharged after he tested negative. Four suspects were admitted to the Tirunelveli government medical college hospital.

Title: Mercury spikes as warm Easterlies blow hard
Content:
Panaji: The significant rise in mercury during the morning hours has been causing some discomfort, as the minimum temperature rose from 20.2 degrees Celsius on Saturday to 25.4 degrees Celsius on Wednesday morning.

While the winter season this year has been uncharacteristically warm, the temperature on Saturday, as the summer season progresses, was three degrees below normal. And then on Wednesday, it was nearly two degrees above normal.

The pleasant weather has given way to warmer nights due to a change in wind direction and a cyclonic circulation over central Maharashtra. While the mercury had remained somewhat low during the first fortnight of March due to western disturbances and northeasterly winds blowing towards Goa, the change in wind direction seems to have upset the regime. “The easterly component of wind has become stronger, and cloudy weather is trapping the heat from escaping,” Rahul M, scientist, India meteorological department (IMD), Panaji said.

But the circulation over the neighbouring state’s mid-region is expected to weaken by Thursday morning, and night temperatures may again decrease gradually over the next three days.

“At the most, the minimum temperature may hover around 22 to 23 degrees C,” the scientist said. The maximum temperatures have been within the normal range throughout March, though the mercury crossed 35 degrees on at least seven days in February, at the fag end of winter.

On Wednesday, IMD recorded a maximum temperature of 33.6 degrees C, just 1.6 degrees above normal.

Title: Aurangabad: Colleges evade Bamu’s academic audit
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: A section of colleges affiliated to Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University (Bamu) has not registered for the mandatory academic audit even after being warned by the varsity of stern action.

The university has now given another extension to the institutes for necessary enrolment till March 21. A senior Bamu official said the deadline for colleges to carry out the registration would not be extended.

“The deadline has been extended twice owing to requests from some colleges. However, colleges must note that no more extension will be given,” he added.

“Name of colleges not registered for the audit would be shared after the deadline expires. We want all affiliated institutions to carry out the audit and avoid action. The process of disaffiliation could cause huge inconvenience to the students and, therefore, it is the duty of the college to follow the order,” he added. In January, Bamu had asked its affiliated colleges to carry out the academic audit. The institutes failing to show compliance could lose the affiliation from upcoming academic year.

Title: Four nabbed while planning to burgle house in Madurai
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: The Silaiman police on Tuesday arrested four people including two juveniles in conflict with law, for conspiring to commit burglary.

A police team led by sub-inspector Karthick, found the four people gathered at a private farm located between Silaiman and Panaiyur at Ramanathapuram Road Junction. As the cops approached the gang upon suspicion, they tried to flee the spot.

They were chased down and taken to the station, where an inquiry was conducted. The suspects told police that they were planning to burgle a house. Weapons including knives and machetes were seized from them. Based on a complaint from the sub-inspector, a case was registered.

Two of the accused were identified as S Sivasri from Karuppupillaiyendal near Andarkottaram and R Kanjivaram from Vandiyur. tnn

Title: Student puts IAS officer & doc at risk, draws Didi’s ire
Content:
KOLKATA: Bengal’s additional chief secretary (home) Alapan Bandyopadhyay quarantined himself on Wednesday after it emerged that he had briefly met the lady bureaucrat whose 18-year-old London-returned son on Tuesday became the state’s first confirmed Covid-19 case.

Bandyopadhyay’s wife, Calcutta University vice-chancellor Sonali Chakravarti Banerjee , also did not venture out of their home, while the doctor who had first examined the teenaged patient was placed under home quarantine.

As the search for secondary contacts of the patient continued, there was some reassuring news from the Beleghata Infectious Diseases Hospital as the boy’s parents and the family’s two drivers tested negative for Covid-19.

Officials said the patient himself was doing fine, but there was concern over how the family’s alleged carelessness between Sunday and Tuesday left many others potentially exposed to the virus.

Apart from Bandyopadhyay, the list of those at risk includes several home department staffers and a Kolkata Municipal Corporation official who met the patient’s mother at the state secretariat on Monday. Several residents of Nadia who were treated by the Covid-19 patient’s paediatrician father on Monday and Tuesday may have also been put at risk.

CM Mamata Banerjee did not hide her anguish at the slip-up. “We welcome citizens who are returning from abroad. But we do not welcome the virus. Those coming from abroad should undergo medical tests. It applies to everyone, whether the person is a VIP or an LIP (less important person),” she said.

“I do not support those who do not go to a doctor and roam about, enter shopping malls and visit parks. One cannot skip the mandatory check-up just because someone in the family is an ‘influential’ person,” she said. Mamata advised "extra caution" for the next two weeks.

Title: Bankrupt travel agents seek govt help
Content:
Visakhapatnam: The global coronavirus outbreak has brought the travel and tourism industry to a standstill. A majority of travel agents in the city and state have started to cut down costs by asking their staff to go on unpaid leave for the next two months or altogether terminating their contracts. Small and mid-sized travel agents have already shut down operations.

Tour operators TOI spoke to said they had initially hoped to make do with business from domestic tour packages this summer given as there were restrictions on travelling abroad, but that plan too seems unviable in the face of the worsening health situation in the country. Summer tour packages accounts for 50 per cent of the revenue of tour operators each year.

Andhra Pradesh has about 400 agents, of which 100 focus on outbound tours and 300 agents on domestic travel. As per statistics from tours and travel associations, losses for agents in AP will be about 15 crore per month. The estimated loss to the industry in January is Rs 8 crore; February, Rs 12 crore; March, Rs 15 crore; April, Rs 15 crore; May, Rs 15 crores; and June, Rs 15 crore.

K Vijay Mohan, president of Tours and Travels Association of Andhra (TTAA) said, “We were all hoping that we could survive on business from domestic travel, but now with a shut down in Gangtok, Mumbai, Delhi, Chennai, Bangalore, Kerala and Andaman, the hope is lost.” Adding that the usual business pattern of travel agents in terms of revenue in January, February, March, April-June, July-September, October-December is 10%, 5%, 5%, 50%, 10% , 20%, Vijay Mohan added, “This year, the corresponding figures are 5%, 1%, 0%, 0%. From January to June, we usually get 70% of the year’s revenue, but the expected revenues of around 6% will kill the travel industry.” The tours and travel agents, in a letter, requested the government to extend some help to them. Stating that tourism contributes 9.3% of the country’s GDP, they said the state and central government should help travel agents by offering special concessions on income tax rebate, waiver of GST for six months and a moratorium on loans for six months to one year. Dheeraj of DC holidays who is the vice president of TTAA, said, “The operations of travel industry has come to a complete halt and most of the travel agents will go bankrupt. We request the government to provide support for the next few months as the panic might continue throug the year.”

Chitturi Srinivas, manager of Akbar travels, said, “People are not willing to travel now. They want to cancel their trips and want the money to be refunded. However, the airline operators say that the flights are running, hence refund will not be given. As a travel agent were we get Rs 50-100 as service charge, it has become difficult to convince our clients and the airlines.”

Title: Mother of twins stranded in Kuala Lumpur, kids in city
Content:
Visakhapatnam: Although 185 Indians from Kuala Lumpur landed at Visakhapatnam International Airport on Wednesday by an Air Asia flight, there are others stranded in the Malaysian capital.

V S S Sindhusha from Visakhapatnam who has been living in Kulala Lumpur for the past four years was in the city with her parents for eleven months after delivering twins last May. However, she had to go back to Kuala Lumpur to renew her visa which expired on March 7, 2020. She left her babies with her parents as she planned to come back within three weeks after the process was completed.

However, Sindhusha’s mother on Tuesday informed her that the babies were crying and not eating properly. Sindhusha who had booked her tickets for this week went to the airport to prepone her travel, but was told that flights to India had been cancelled. She, along with others stranded in Kuala Lumpur approached the Indian High Commission. “On Wednesday, we approached the Indian embassy and spoke to the officials. They said they were helpless and nothing could be done as the government had passed order to cancel all flights till March 31.”

“I tried my best to look for other options to reach Visakhapatnam via Singapore or Thailand. However, I was scared that if I would get stranded in other airports. At least here I am with my husband. But we are desperately waiting to see our babies. We are facing a lot of problems as there is no food available here,” added Sindhusha speaking to TOI from Malaysia.

Sindhusha’s father, Nagesh, who is a CID DSP said, “We appreciate the efforts by the Indian government to contain the spread of coronavirus. However, flights from Malaysia have been cancelled without prior notice. We are worried about her as Malaysia is under lock down. We hope there is some intervention from the government to bring back stranded people.”

“I wanted to get my visa renewed as I planned to be with my babies and celebrate their first birthday in Visakhapatnam along with my family. I put in a lot of effort to figure out some way to come back, but there is no support in any way. I hope the government helps us so that I can be with my children,” Sindhusha said.

Sindhusha, who has been living in Kuala Lumpur for four years, came to Vizag after the birth of her twins 11 months back. She returned to Malaysia to renew her visa. She is unable to return as flights to India have been cancelled

Title: Coronavirus in Mysuru: Poultry farmers in distress as no takers for chicken, egg
Content:
Representative image

MYSURU: Poultry farmers, who were already reeling under a slump due to coronavirus scare, are now staring at a bleak future as chicken sales have nosedived after the outbreak of bird flu in the district.

The prices of chicken and eggs have crashed following a complete ban on movement of poultry products from Karnataka to Kerala. It further fell in the domestic market after people desisted from consuming chicken at hotels, roadside eateries and at their homes due to bird flu outbreak.

The roadside eateries and kebab stalls that sell non veg-food are also on a sticky wicket as consumers are keeping a distance due to coronavirus and bird flu scare.

The price of chicken, which was Rs 150 per kg some 15 days ago, is now available for Rs 40 and 60 per kg. The price of egg has also come down to Rs 2.9 from Rs 5. Over 20 lakh eggs and tonnes of chicken produced by over 100 big and small producers in the district remain unsold resulting in a huge loss to the poultry layer farmers, said sources in the animal husbandry department.

The district has over 100 poultry units, both broiler and layer farms. These are concentrated on roads connecting Gaddige, Bogadhi, Hunsur, Nanjangud and H D Kote, Bannur and T Narasipur. Major egg suppliers like Mangaluru Coastal Broiler Supplies, Suguna, Venkateshwara and others have suffered huge losses due to the bird flu scare.

“Last year, the poultry farmers suffered losses due to the rise in prices of poultry feeds. However, this year, the coronavirus scare and bird flu have forced them to shut down their business after suffering heavy loss. The cost of production per egg is nearly Rs 3.7. Now, the poultry producers are forced to sell them at a throwaway price of Rs 2.9, and that too with hardly any buyers. What is worrying the layer farmers is that the price of egg is likely to come down further once eggs from Tamil Nadu’s Namakkal district arrives in city market,” said Lakshmikanth, one of the layer poultry producer on Nanjangud Road.

Another poultry producer from Chowdenahalli village in Periyapatna taluk, Lokesh, said both small and big poultry have suffered an unprecedented blow due to the virus and bird flu scare. The price of one kilo broiler chicken has come down to Rs 8. “Even if we are ready to sell chicken at throwaway prices, people are not coming forward to buy as most of the chicken and egg stalls have been issued closure order by municipal bodies both in neighbouring Kerala and several districts of Karnataka,” he said.

Mysuru district poultry producers, who used to supply tonnes of chicken, are now worried about their future. The poultry producers, including both small and big ones, rear nearly 20 lakh chickens in the district.

“The cost of production of broiler chicken comes to nearly Rs 100 per kilo including Rs 19 to buy a chick, poultry shed, power, vaccination and other costs but there are no takers due to the outbreak even if we are ready to sell in distress,” said Lokesh.

Title: Spl team to speed up land acquisition for service road
Content:
Trichy: After public outcry over the delay in commencing the construction work for a service road on Trichy-Thanjavur National Highways (NH83), the district administration has appointed a special team to expedite the land acquisition process. So far, in-charge revenue department officials had been overseeing the land acquisition process.

On October 2019, the Madras high court asked the state government and NHAI to lay a service road for the 14.5-km stretch between Thuvakudi and Palpannai within six months, but the stakeholders have been delaying the work. Angered residents staged a protest a week ago as road accidents have become frequent on the stretch of the NH83, which was commissioned during 2011-12.

Meanwhile, as a significant development, the district administration has appointed a team of 11 revenue department officials. The team will undertake land acquisition for the pending service road. So far, revenue officials deployed for Trichy-Chidambaram NH were additionally overseeing the work on service road.

The 11-member team has a tahsildar, a revenue inspector, a surveyor and other officials to be supervised by a district revenue officer (DRO) cadre officer. The team said that they are awaiting a revised land plan schedule (LPS), which will mention the extent of land required for the service road to come up in three widths namely 45 metres, 50 metres and 60 metres. “NHAI is finalising the LPS, they have assured us to hand it over for initiating land acquisition before the end of March. The special team exclusively appointed for the project will quicken the land acquisition,” a senior official with the district administration said. Once the LPS is submitted to the revenue department, 3D notification as per NHAI Act will be released by disclosing the extent of land to be acquired for the service road, officials said.

Title: Roll back increased platform ticket price, demands Madurai MP
Content:
MADURAI: Madurai MP Su Venkatesan has demanded that Southern Railway withdraw its decision to increase the price of platform ticket by five times, from Rs 10 to Rs 50, as a preventive measure against Covid-19, instead of creating awareness on the disease.

In a communication to the SR general manager, he said that as a Parliamentary Railway Advisory Committee member, the recent actions of the railways are unacceptable. Railways could ask the people to refrain from coming in crowds to send passengers. People can also be politely denied entry by security personnel at the gates. He said the decision not to provide blankets to passengers on AC coaches was implemented in a single day which was irresponsible. Instead, railways should have taken the responsibility to provide hygienically safe blankets.

The government was asking people to avoid unnecessary travel, but the railways continued to collect cancellation fees. Brealthyzer tests for its employees by the Southern Railway should also be dropped as the aviation ministry had stopped it as a precaution. A lot needs to be done in terms of creating awareness among the public by the railways, he said.

Meanwhile, commuters are now trying to bypass the increased platform ticket fare by buying passenger tickets to nearby destinations that cost only about Rs 10 one way. A commuter said that the platform ticket fare at Rs 50 is more than the fare of Rs 35 to Rameswaram, which is more than 160 kms away. We also have other means to check those misusing passenger tickets,” a railway official said.

Title: Elcot IT park in Trichy yet to adopt preventive steps, say staff
Content: TRICHY: While the government insists that private information technology (IT) and information technology enabled services (ITES) firms take precautionary measures against Covid-19, its own IT park here has come under the scanner for not taking up quarantine measures. Employees of the Elcot IT park at Navalpattu said there is no thermal scanning to detect those with fever or provision to sanitize hands with alcohol-based sanitizer at the entrance of the park.Spread over 60,000 square feet, the Elcot IT park accommodates six IT and ITES companies with a collective employee strength of 1,500. As part of preventing Covid-19 outbreak at workplace, the IT department had in a circular instructed IT office spaces to provide hand sanitiser to staff. “Many of the employees stay in hostels along with inmates from various states. To prevent infection, the entrance of IT park should have had hand sanitiser and thermal scanner. But both are missing,” an employee who did not want to be identified said. Employees at the IT park said they feel insecure at the workplace equipped with a common washroom which has only one handwash, that too non-alcohol-based. While the IT department circular insisted on thermal scanning for all employees attending office, the IT park employees said this is not done. Trichy city has about 68 companies in the IT and ITES sector, a majority of them functioning outside the IT park. But several firms have not officially facilitated the work-from-home option for their employees. Companies say that the infrastructure required to work, such as high-speed internet to make international calls, is available only at the workplace. “Employees feel a little uncomfortable to work at the office. Though precautionary measures such as banning food from outside were taken up in our office, we feel vulnerable while travelling to the office,” an employee of an IT firm in the city said. When contacted, an official with Elcot turned down the allegations stating that precautionary measures were in place. However, the official did not divulge the safety measures taken. “We have instructed the IT companies to permit employees to work from home,” official added.

Title: Students want to join door-to-door survey by GVMC
Content:
Visakhapatnam: Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation ( GVMC ) is now conducting door-to-door survey to sensitize the public about coronavirus and also identify persons who returned from abroad recently. The survey which began four days ago will conclude by Monday.

After Chest Hospital reported several suspected cases, GVMC’s medical wing formed teams with volunteers, ANM, Asha workers and sanitary workers at Sachivalyas. The survey teams identified around 195 persons in the city who have come from abroad.

“All of them are kept in quarantine in their houses. Local ANM and Asha workers were asked to keep a watch on them. We also asked their family members not to take them to conferences or weddings,” GVMC chief medical officer Dr Sastry told TOI.

Vizag city has more than five lakh households and now volunteers along with other team members are busy with the survey. The survey is going on in all the eight zones in the GVMC.

GVMC medical staff asked AU students to identify persons who had gone to coronavirus-affected states recently. “AU students are spreading awareness on campus and some of the students approached us and requested to be allowed to join the survey. We have already set up 10 corona help desk centres to create awareness,” Dr Sastry said.

Title: Inheriting a state dogged with issues, Pramod Sawant emerges unscathed, a year on
Content:
PANAJI: A week is a long time in politics, so a year should be a good time to judge what chief minister Pramod Sawant has done since assuming office on this day at 2am, last year.

The ayurvedic doctor-turned-politician had exceptionally big boots to fill. He was trying to fill the void left by Manohar Parrikar, Goa’s tallest politician, so it’s not really a surprise that Sawant chose to walk a different path. Knowing that the previous system was well entrenched under Parrikar, Sawant started his innings with a new set of bureaucrats, all handpicked by him. He reshuffled the bureaucracy, unsettling those close to his mentor, and for a while, there were allegations of de-Parrikarisation.

At every step, Sawant knew that his actions – or even the lack of them – would be compared to Parrikar. The former chief minister would micromanage almost everything, so Sawant had to be different. He’s been trying to do just that.

In politics, public perception matters more than anything else. Perhaps, the BJP managers have consciously tried to carve an independent image for Sawant; that he is simple, approachable, accessible, and one who is willing to take suggestions.

Sawant has tried to directly connect with the people, assuring them that major issues plaguing the state cannot be resolved in one year. That he needs time, and he would deliver as promised.

His well-cultivated image of a Bahujan samaj CM from a weaker economic section, is there for all to see, and seems to have struck a chord with the OBCs and tribals.

Politically, there’s little to complain. The start was challenging. He had to face bypolls and parliamentary elections within two months of taking over. Losing the bypolls would have invited criticism. He ensured his critics had nothing to complain about, winning four seats, although he lost the most prestigious seat of Panaji, which Parrikar had represented for the quarter of a century.

The bypoll results enhanced BJP’s strength in the house to 17, but he was still dependent on the allies – three members each from GFP, MGP and two independents. Realising that he would not have it easy as BJP didn’t have the numbers, he tried to increase the party’s strength in the assembly soon after taking over.

Sawant first clipped the wings of his deputy Ramkrishna Dhavalikar , got two of the three MGP MLAs – Manohar Ajgaonkar and Deepak Pauskar – in a midnight coup and then topped it all by convincing a 10-member Congress group to join BJP. From 13 MLAs in 2017, BJP had jumped to an astonishing 27.

He showed considerable guts too, quite unlike someone who was considered a ‘soft’ CM. He dropped two deputy CMs –Dhavalikar and Vijai Sardesai – besides two ministers from GFP to make room for new faces. In a new realignment of forces, Michael Lobo was inducted into the cabinet, along with four others.

With an unprecedented strength of 27 MLAs, it was expected that the Sawant government would take big strides. But it has not been easy, largely because he inherited several problems dogging the state - poor finances, the Mhadei water dispute, mining closure, opposition to the casinos, degrading environment and garbage management.

The Mhadei issue has hit him the most— that the Centre kept him in the dark while deciding on diversion of waters or writing a letter to the Karnataka CM, reflected his lack of clout, a political analyst said.

Financial management has been another concern; besides, there seems to be no sign of the jobs that unemployed youth were promised more than two years ago.

Sawant had to also face a lot of flak for issues like the potholed roads, perpetual traffic congestion along the Agasaim-Cortalim route, floods in several parts of the state and breakdown of main pipeline at Curti which led to an unprecedented water shortage in the state capital and surrounding areas for several days. The CM, though, stood tall and refused to budge during the taxi strike, even though some of his party colleagues lobbied hard for the taximen.

There is no doubt that Sawant is putting in long hours of work, at times, traversing from one end of the state to the other, but he would need to up his game and make some smart moves to show that he is making a difference.

Sawant’s elevation was welcomed by many during the first two months of his innings. Living up to that image, and those expectations, has been tough.

Title: Trichy: Additional BDO held by DVAC for taking bribe
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: Additional block development officer in Karur district was arrested on Wednesday for demanding bribe of Rs 30000 to give building plan approval.

DVAC police led by its deputy superintendent of police B Manikandan arrested Jayanthi, additional block development officer and carrying further investigation with her.

According to DVAC police, Ramesh from Pavitharam village near Paramathi of Karur district, had approached panchayat office to get building plan approval a few days ago. While Jayanthi had demanded Rs 30000 as bribe to give building plan approval, he approached the DVAC Karur and lodged a complaint.

DVAC team set a trap on Wednesday and asked Ramesh to offer the money lased with chemical. As soon as she received the money, DVAC team hiding in the office, caught her red-handed. Further investigation is on.

Title: Culling ends in Kumbara Koppal, mopping-up operation from today
Content:
Mysuru: The veterinary department has completed culling of birds on the second day of its operation at Kumbara Koppal on Wednesday. A total of 989 birds were killed and scientifically disposed to prevent the spread of avian influenza during the day.

On the first day of culling, five rapid response teams (RRT) killed 4,100 birds which were within one kilometre radius of Kumbara Koppal. As per the survey conducted by the animal husbandry department, there were 144 households where they had reared 6,436 birds out of which 1,252 were domestic birds, 5,100 commercial birds, 254 pet birds, 12 quails and 18 turkeys.

After the first day of culling, nearly 2,336 birds had remained. On Wednesday, 13 RRTs conducted the drive at Metagalli, BM Sri Nagar, Ambedkar Jnana Loka, Kumbara Koppal and Hebbal and culled 981 birds. Out of the total birds, 304 were broiler chickens, 160 egg-laying chickens, 173 country chicken (Naati Koli) and 326 adult Naati Koli , 20 pet birds and six turkeys.

Deputy commissioner Abhiram G Sankar told TOI that the RRT teams will conduct mopping up operation from Thursday to find whether any birds are left out during the drive. “We will conduct a mopping operation and if more birds are found, they will be scientifically disposed,” he said

According to vet department sources, there are still nearly 1,355 birds remaining in the localities.

“On Wednesday, the staff had a tough time convincing the house owners to hand over their pet birds like parrots for culling. In each house, we had to convince the people, which was difficult. So, less birds were culled on Wednesday,” said an official.

Meanwhile, during the combing operation, the vet staff and Mysuru City Corporation health officers found a small factory near Ambedkar Jnanloka, run by a man called Akram, where buffalo horns weighing more than 3,000 kg were stored in large numbers. The horns were used to make buttons and show-pieces.

The health officers found that Akram had not procured trade license from MCC or clearances from Karnataka State Pollution Control Board (KSPCB).

MCC health officer M S Jayanth told TOI that Akram has no trade licence. “So a fine has been levied for the violation. The factory has been sealed. The veterinary department will issue a notice on Thursday and action will initiated,” he said. MCC has levied Rs 10,000 fine for the violation.

Mandya bans sale of chicken

Close on the heels of avian influenza being detected in Mysuru, deputy commissioner, Mandya, M V Venkatesh ordered a ban on production, sale and transportation of chickens in 13 villages in Srirangapatna taluk on Wednesday.

In his order dated March 18, the DC has directed the authorities to take necessary steps in the 13 villages namely Palahalli, Belagola, Karekura, Mogarahalli, Chakkanakuppe, Hosa Alanduru, Majjigepura, Hosahalli, Hulikere, Naguvanahalli, Bramhapura, Belavadi and Bechanakuppe under Srirangapatna taluk to prevent the spread of avian influenza.

As per the order, areas in one kilometre radius from these villages will be declared as avian influenza infected and 10 kilometres from these villages has been declared as sensitive zone.

The production, sale and transportation of chicken has been banned upto 10 kilometre radius from the villages.

Title: IRCTC feels virus pinch, pantry car sales drop by 60%
Content:
Vizag station on Wednesday

Visakhapatnam: Following the outbreak of coronavirus, Indian Railway Catering and Tourism Corporation (IRCTC) officials are in a Catch 22 situation. The sale of meals on trains handled by IRCTC Visakhapatnam area officials is down by 60 per cent in the past 14 days.

Officials said, initially there was a drop in demand for non-vegetarian meals including chicken and eggs. Officials tried hard to provide substitute vegetarian meals such as idli, dosa and veg cutlet for breakfast and paneer or any veg curry for lunch and dinner. However, they could not improve the situation as gradually the number of passengers onboard started dropping. “First the passengers were reluctant to take chicken and eggs. Now passenger occupancy onboard has decreased considerably. With this, the sale of food, especially on pantry cars, has dropped by more than 60 per cent,” Chandra Mohan Bisa, the area official (Visakhapatnam) of IRCTC told TOI.

Sale on long distance trains has also been affected considerably. One of the nine trains originates from Sambalpur and ends at Nanded in Maharashtra.

An official confirmed that on Hirakund Express (Visakhapatnam – Amritsar) that departed on May 15 they could sell meals worth Rs 22,359. Whereas the average sale figure on that train is around Rs 50,000 to Rs 60,000. “Despite giving our best effort to maintain cleanliness and hygiene on board, sale is not picking up. Rather, I would say it is deteriorating almost every day. People are actually apprehensive to buy outside food and our problem is worsening as passenger occupancy onboard is decreasing,” said an onboard supervisor of IRCTC. Although IRCTC hires an outsourced agency to run the pantry car, it also appoints a BSc Hotel Management graduate on board to supervise the production onboard every train.
